DOC.HEAD: Donor-Search Leukemia Patient Ready for Transplant Thursday
DOC.TEXT: A leukemia patient whose plight prompted 50,000 people to step forward as possible bone-marrow donors will undergo a transplant of bone marrow from her mother Thursday, a hospital spokeswoman said Wednesday. The operation on Allison Atlas, 20, is expected to take at least four hours and could last six hours or more, said Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center spokeswoman Alice Burgess. Doctors are scheduled to extract the marrow from Miss Atlas' mother at 9 a.m., the spokeswoman said. The marrow from her mother matches only four of six antigens, or cell identifiers. But the New York University student from Bethesda, Md., decided to undergo the operation while she is still strong enough. She began chemotherapy July 31, and has responded well, Burgess said. Doctors said a patient with Miss Atlas' type of leukemia can expect a 60 percent chance of recovery if the transplant marrow is perfectly matched. Without a transplant, they say the disease is 100 percent fatal. In leukemia, a form of cancer, white blood cells multiply uncontrollably. Bone marrow produces blood, and doctors can combat the cancer by replacing the diseased marrow with healthy tissue. Miss Atlas' condition prompted a campaign by her family last fall to find a perfectly matched donor. They were unsuccessful, but the effort raised $3 million to process blood samples from the 50,000 people in the United States and Israel who volunteered. Ten patients found perfect donors.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, France Send Troops to Gulf
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Australia to send ships; pickup graf 3 `French President....' INSERTS 4 grafs after graf 10 ```France will...' with details of Australian force; pickup graf 11 `President Saddam...'
DOC.TEXT: Britain, France and Australia announced Thursday they are sending ships and planes to the Persian Gulf in response to U.S. appeals for help with a multinational force to defend Saudi Arabia against Iraq. U.S. officials were busy Thursday trying to muster global support for the force, sent in to defend against any Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, which neighbors Iraq and Kuwait. However, only Britain and Australia announced they would send hardware and troops as part of the force. French President Francois Mitterrand announced Thursday evening that his nation was increasing its naval and air forces in the Gulf ``as needed to intervene'' if necessary. He said they would coordinate with the international force but remain under French command. British officials said they would immediately send two fighter aircraft squadrons, anti-aircraft missiles and other air and sea forces totaling more than 1,000 men to the Persian Gulf. Defense Secretary Tom King told a news conference that Britain will send a squadron of Tornado F3 fighter jets from Cyprus and a squadron of Jaguar ground-attack fighters from England, as well as a number of Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft. The Ministry of Defense said each squadron includes 12 planes. Two British frigates will arrive in the gulf this weekend to join the destroyer, HMS York, and three minesweepers will be deployed, initially to the eastern Mediterranean, King said. A squadron of Rapier ground-to-air missiles is also being sent, he said. Mitterrand said his country will send an aircraft carrier to the gulf region, bolstering French naval and air forces already there to counter any new aggression by Iraq. After a two-hour emergency Cabinet meeting, Mitterrand also promised France will send war materials and technicians to the gulf as requested by Saudi Arabia and other states. ``France will, there as elsewhere, continue to exist in solidarity and coordination with countries like the United States, but only under French officers,'' Mitterrand told reporters. In Canberra, Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke said his country will send two frigates and a supply ship as part of the international force. He said they will be used ``to enforce the blockade on Iraq and Kuwait and protect the exports from other oil-producing countries,'' he said. Western leaders have talked of a blockade if a U.N.-organized global embargo against Iraq fails. ``I believe the gravity of the situation warranted this action,'' Hawke told a news conference. He said the ships will be able to leave Australia within five days and arrive within 22 days. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, whose forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, has denied any intention of attacking Saudi Arabia. However, Western reports say his troops have massed on the Saudi border. U.S. soldiers were steaming into Saudi Arabia on Thursday. The Pentagon declined to detail the size of the U.S. deployment, but Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said all F-15 fighters sent to Saudi Arabia had arrived, as have five AWACs reconnaissance planes. Six U.S. warships stand by in the Mediterranean and two aircraft carrier groups are positioned in the Red and Arabian seas, he said. Mideastern diplomatic sources said the U.S. buildup would total at least 40,000 troops backed by more than 100 jet fighters. Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti on Thursday told British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that Italy has not been asked to join the multinational force in Saudi Arabia, according to the Italian news agencies ANSA and AGI. They cited unidentified sources in the premier's office. His spokesman could not be reached to comment. Several nations, including Canada and The Netherlands, have said they will decide whether to participate in the U.S.-led force following separate meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and European Community foreign ministers in Brussels, Belgium, on Friday. Portugal, West Germany, Italy and Spain have offered use of bases. Greece on Wednesday allowed nine U.S. support planes to pass through its airspace on their way to the gulf. Egypt and Morocco, mentioned by U.S. Defense Department sources as the likeliest Arab participants, refused to join. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt proposed that an Arab force act as a buffer between Kuwait and Iraq. That proposal was expected to be on the agenda at an Arab summit meeting in Cairo, which was postponed to Friday. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who arrived in Ankara on Thursday, indicated he may ask Turkish President Turgut Ozal to permit the United States to use that country's military bases as staging areas in the event of strikes against Iraq. ``It goes without saying that Turkey is strategically very important,'' Baker said on his flight from Washington. Turkey borders Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Acquitted, Races Off to Join Unit Shipping Out to Saudi Arabia
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A young soldier offered to plead guilty to a burglary he said he didn't commit so he could ship out for Saudi Arabia with his unit. But a jury quickly found him innocent Thursday, and he was on his way. Pfc. Joseph Cufferi, 20, was accused of breaking into a neighbor's house in October 1989 while home on leave. Cufferi said he got together with friends, drank ``approximately 10 beers'' and had some trouble getting into what he thought was his parents' home. He was actually two doors down at the home of Robert Anthony Keller. ``I remember ringing the doorbell and going around and saying, `Let me in.' I thought that was my house,'' Cufferi said. But when Keller heard the backyard gate open and saw the dark-clothed man trying the French doors, he thought Cufferi intended to hurt his family, Assistant State Attorney Thomas Lawson told the Palm Beach County Circuit Court jury on Wednesday. ``He spent about 15 minutes knocking,'' said Assistant Public Defender Karen Ehrlich. ``Burglars don't knock.'' Keller said he told Cufferi to leave, but the soldier kept banging doors and windows. So Keller grabbed a shotgun, pointed it through the window at Cufferi and threatened to shoot, Keller said. Cufferi ran but was later caught by police and charged with attempted burglary. ``I'm sorry I went to the wrong house, but it was a mistake,'' Cufferi said Wednesday. ``But now I need to go do my job. I defend the United States of America.'' Some members of his unit, the 24th Infantry based at Fort Stewart, Ga., were due to leave Thursday. Prosecutors agreed earlier in the week to allow Cufferi to plead guilty to the lesser charge of trespassing, but he rejected the deal. However, he changed his mind after learning his unit was shipping out, apparently believing he'd be allowed to go after pleading guilty. But the Kellers refused to go along with the deal, and Cufferi went on trial. On Thursday, a hopeful Cufferi parked his packed car near the courthouse. The jury took only 15 minutes to decide his fate. ``The first thing we did was take a vote and it was unanimous _ not guilty,'' said juror Tim Kelly. Thursday night, Cufferi's father said his son called from Fort Stewart to say he'd arrived in time to catch up with his buddies. ``I'm glad that at least through all of this he was able to be where he wants to be,'' said Jospeh Cufferi Sr.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Ready for Battle, While Families Settle in to Wait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf, `On Wednesday ...,' to UPDATE with planes leaving Fort Bragg on Wednesday night; picks up 7th graf, `Early in ...' Minor tightening elsewhere.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp
LaserPhoto XGDN01
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers packed and shipped out to the Middle East on Wednesday, leaving behind frightened civilians and tearful wives and fiancees. Others rode the rumor mill wondering if they would be the next to be mobilized. ``They're going. They are definitely going. There is no doubt in my mind that this is another war,'' said Effie Parsons, 23, a clerk at a convenience store near Fort Bragg, N.C., home of the 82nd Airborne Division. President Bush ordered U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia to help it repel a potential attack by Iraq, which invaded neighboring Kuwait last week. Bush specifically mentioned the 82nd. Pentagon sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they also expected deployment of the 24th Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. Elements of those three units would be deployed with the 18th Airborne Corps, a control unit at Fort Bragg that directs the combat divisions, the sources said. A soldier at Fort Bragg, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said about 2,000 soldiers from there were to go to Saudi Arabia and that some of that force had left Tuesday night. On Wednesday, truckloads of soldiers and supplies were seen driving toward Pope Air Force Base, which adjoins Fort Bragg. At least two large civilian jetliners that could be used to haul soldiers landed at Pope. Around 8:50 p.m., a steady stream of C-141s began leaving the air base, and continued leaving for at least 30 minutes at intervals of a few minutes. About two hours later, at least four planes were heard leaving or landing. Early in the week, convenience store clerks said sales of chewing tobacco, batteries and insect repellent were brisk as soldiers hurriedly stocked up. ``A lot of fathers are coming in with their kids, holding them real tight'' and many wives are in tears as they make their purchases, said Ms. Parsons. Assistant store manager Wade Felman, comparing this deployment with the Panamanian deployment of December 1989, said the atmosphere now is much more tense and wives coming in are more nervous. ``The Panamanian thing, I guess, seemed so small to them,'' he said. ``I think this thing is a little more worrisome.'' One of the 82nd's soldiers, Pfc. Mark Ohmer, was to marry Angela Nelson, 19, in suburban Detroit this Saturday. The $6,000 wedding was postponed when he was called back to base. ``It happened so fast. I'm so upset,'' Nelson said. ``Iraq does a lot of chemical warfare, and Mark's job is to deactivate chemical weapons and deactivate contamination of soldiers. He also was taught to dismantle bombs.'' While the Pentagon sources said the 101st Airborne also was going, spokesmen for the 14,000-soldier division at Fort Cambpell continued to deny that Wednesday. That didn't convince people just outside the post gates in Clarksville, Tenn., and Fort Campbell, Ky. ``Everybody's a little nervous; you never know what can happen,'' said Tammy Bradford, whose husband Mike is a 101st infantryman. Mrs. Bradford, at work at a restaurant, said she tried not to think about the possibility that he could be ordered to the Middle East. ``I think we should be out there to stop Iraq,'' she said. ``But I don't want my husband to go.'' ``I feel something's going on on the base at Fort Campbell that we're not aware of and we shouldn't be aware of,'' said Morrell Boyd, owner of a cleaning shop in Clarksville. Boyd said the number of soldiers bringing in uniforms to be cleaned or mended had not increased over the past two days. ``But those that are coming in are needing it in a rush,'' he said. At Fort Stewart, Army officials tightened security Wednesday night as members of the 24th Infantry loaded their gear into desert-tan trucks and Bradley fighting vehicles. Army officials refused to say whether the division would deploy to Saudi Arabia to help protect the oil kingdom from an Iraqi invasion, but relatives braced for their departure and expressed concern for their safety. Maj. Ron Keeling, a Fort Stewart spokesman, said the division was conducting a routine emergency deployment exercise. Some soldiers had been called back from leave. Helmeted soldiers armed with M-16 rifles could be seen trudging through motor pools with rucksacks and duffel bags. Wives and girlfriends huddled with soldiers in parking lots. A telephone operator said long-distance circuits were jammed with calls from Fort Stewart soldiers. Military Police set up checkpoints at some entrances to the post. Spec. 4 Norman Aimes, 24, part of the infantry division, said earlier that he was called back from leave in Utah. ``They called and said there is a 99 percent chance that we are going,'' Aimes said Tuesday. ``I'm worried,'' said Surshander Armstrong, wife of an Army specialist at Stewart. ``If you knew exactly what they were going to do, then the waiting wouldn't be so bad. Then you could prepare yourself.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Racketeering Rampant at Fulton Fish Market
DOC.TEXT: A federal administrator appointed two years ago to help drive organized crime out of the Fulton Fish Market said in a court report filed Wednesday that racketeering remains rampant at the huge market. In the report filed in U.S. District Court, Frank H. Wohl said the market was controlled by a few people who set rules for delivering seafood and practiced extortion. He told The New York Times in an interview published in Thursday editions that strong-arm tactics by some companies discouraged suppliers from sending fish to New York, driving up retail prices for local consumers. He told the Times that city officials worsened the problem by abdicating their responsibility to regulate and police the market. He said he would soon impose rules to help suppliers and businesses operate at the market without intimidation. About 90 million pounds of seafood with a retail value of $2 billion are sold each year at the market in lower Manhattan. Wohl said in the report that city officials told him they feared for the safety of city employees involved in the market and also feared attempts to corrupt police officers if the city enforced regulations more strictly. He said that although the city had the authority to license and regulate deliveries, arriving truckers are ``assigned by some unknown authority to unload their trucks.'' Under this system, his report said, it costs as much to transport a pound of fish 50 feet at the market as it does to transport it from New England to New York City. The unloaders charge the wholesalers $1.35 per 100-pound box. If truckers unloaded supplies themselves, Wohl said, they would be ``subject to physical abuse.'' Drivers must pay extra to have their fish unloaded promptly, he said. Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for the city Office of Business Development, told the Times Wohl's report was ``old news'' and reflected his ``inability to correct the problem'' despite a budget of $750,000 and a staff of a dozen investigators and researchers.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Religious Group to Distribute Correction to Pamphlet
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday ordered a conservative religious organization to distribute a correction to a pamphlet used to press its case that the National Endowment for the Arts is supporting pornography. The ruling by U.S. District Judge William C. Conner came in a lawsuit by artist David A. Wojnarowicz against the American Family Association of Tulepo, Miss., and its executive director, David E. Wildmon. The judge said the pamphlet used cropped images of Wojnarowicz' work to suggest he created sexually explicit images. Its distribution had likely harmed the artist's professional and personal reputation, he said. Conner made permanent an earlier injunction that barred any further publication of the pamphlet, titled ``Your Tax Dollars Helped Pay for These Works of Arts.'' The judge also awarded $1 in damages to Wojnarowicz, who had sought up to $1 million. He said Wojnarowicz had not proven financial damage because no galleries or museums had canceled exhibits of his work. Conner said Wildmon must send a court-approved ``corrective communication'' to all who received the pamphlet. The association sent the pamphlet to 4,000 churches, members of Congress and other individuals as part of its campaign against the endowment. Wildmon had objected to several of Wojnarowicz' works exhibited earlier this year at the Illinois State University Galleries. A catalog of reproductions of 60 of his paintings, collages and photographs was partly financed by the NEA. Tim Wildmon, the executive director's son, said the association had not made a decision on whether to appeal the order to distribute a correction. He praised the judge's decision to award $1 in damages, saying the action showed ``the lack of validity of his lawsuit.'' Paul Weiss, one of Wojnarowicz' attorneys, said he believed his client should have received more money because the controversy could affect his ability to show and sell his work in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Political Exiles Begin To Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Lindiwe Phillip, an anti-apartheid activist, fled into exile and expected to return triumphantly in a few months. That was 14 years ago. She came home in June, when the government granted temporary amnesty to dozens of African National Congress leaders so they could return and prepare for talks on ending apartheid, the racial policy that gives 5 million whites supremacy over the nation's 28 million blacks. Ms. Phillip, now 32, was among thousands of young blacks who left after the the 1976 student uprisings. Hundreds of people were killed in 1976 and the uprising helped shape a generation of militant activists. ``I thought (exile) would be very temporary, about three months,'' she said. ``As time went on, I had to grapple with the fact that I am in exile and that I can no longer go home.'' The ANC, South Africa's leading black opposition movement, has an estimated 20,000 members in exile. The ANC and the government agreed Monday to clear the way for their return, starting in September. While Ms. Phillip was in exile in Zambia, her parents died. After she was in touch with her brother about the deaths, he was killed, and then her younger brother was found stabbed to death. She still does not know who killed either of them. ``I was just heartbroken,'' she said. ``I was almost on the verge of going nuts, crazy.'' During her exile, Ms. Phillip received military training and studied in Cuba and Tanzania. She also worked in the ANC Women's Section and the Department of Information and Publicity in Lusaka, Zambia, the ANC's exile headquarters. Her feelings were mixed when she returned in June with a group sent to recruit members for the ANC Women's League. ``We had so longed to be back home, but at the same time we were not sure it was the correct time,'' she said. African National Congress members began trickling out of South Africa when the organization was banned in 1960. President F.W. de Klerk lifted the 30-year ban in February. A law passed at that time empowers de Klerk to grant immunity, but so far he has given only temporary amnesty to a few dozen ANC leaders and officials. Officials say that, under Monday's agreement, the cases of all exiles will be reviewed and disputed cases will be handled by a special commission. Mathews Phosa, a lawyer on the ANC negotiating team, fled South Africa five years ago when he was told his life was in danger, but had to leave his wife and 3-year-old daughter behind. ``It is one of the most traumatic decisions one could take in one's life, a very very painful experience _ shattering, terrible,'' he said. What sustained exiles, Phosa said, was unshakeable belief in the struggle to end apartheid. ``You don't know where you are going to exactly,'' he said. ``You are being uprooted from your loved ones. ... You know you are going to comrades, but that's not enough. You still have to make new friends.'' After the initial shock, life in exile becomes normal, the lawyer said: ``People get married, they fall in love, they work, and home is not something that haunts you every day.'' Finding a place to live is a major problem for returning exiles. There is a severe shortage of housing for blacks. Many will want to catch up on education they missed while fighting for Spear of the Nation, the ANC military wing, but black schools are overcrowded, qualified teachers are rare and violence has disrupted classes for years. Recent right-wing violence against blacks and against whites opposed to apartheid is a source of fear for returning exiles, Phosa said, ``but that can't be a reason for us not to come home.'' With ``the political space being there to organize and build our organization, it would be irresponsible for us not to deploy our cadres inside the country,'' he said. ``I think I am optimistic that we will get over the stumbling blocks. There is a willingness on the part of the government. They are very slow ... hesitant, but I think they are moving forward and they should be credited for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Isolate Marijuana Target in Brain
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today said they have cloned a ``button'' marijuana presses in the brain, a step that may lead to medications that mimic the drug's therapeutic effects without affecting mood or thinking. New treatments for pain, high blood pressure, epileptic convulsions, nausea, asthma and the eye disease glaucoma may result, other scientists said. The new work revealed the chemical makeup of a protein structure on the surface of brain cells. Marijuana's main ingredient, called a cannabinoid, binds to this structure to exert its effects. The study is presented in today's issue of the British journal Nature by scientists from the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. Their paper describes the brain-cell structure as it appears in rats, but further study showed the human structure is virtually identical, said study co-author Tom Bonner. Marijuana is best known for producing a calm, mildly euphoric state. Time seems to slow down and users become more sensitive to sights, sounds and touch. Ideas may flow rapidly through the mind while short-term memory is suppressed. The new work opens the door to developing derivatives that produce medicinal effects without marijuana's undesired ones, said Dr. Solomon Snyder, director of the neuroscience department at Johns Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore. The newly cloned structure is called a receptor. Many drugs and natural substances bind to particular receptors to exert their effects on the body. Previous studies suggest that cannabinoids exert a variety of effects because they bind to a variety of receptor variants, called subtypes, Snyder said. ``So if you could get a derivative that works on the therapeutic subtype but not the subtype that makes you high, then you would have an effective drug without the possibility of being a drug of abuse,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Drug companies have been working on this for years, but have been unsuccessful because they didn't have any way to look at these receptor subtypes that we think exist.'' Researchers should now be able to use the cloned cannabinoid receptor to search for related subtypes, he said. ``Then a drug company can synthesize lots of chemicals and check them out on receptor A and receptor B, and then gradually sculpt a molecule that fits receptor A and not receptor B, and then you have a super drug,'' he said. Bonner said the existence of the receptor suggests that the brain naturally contains some sort of cannabinoid-like substance. ``The receptor's not there just so that people can go out and smoke pot and get high,'' he said. Finding the brain chemical would shed light on the workings of the central nervous system and might give clues to developing new medications, he said. In the Nature paper, scientists said they found genetic material that tells brain cells how to make the receptor. When they inserted the genetic material into hamster ovary cells, the cells produced receptors that behaved as expected when exposed to cannabinoids.

DOC.HEAD: L-Tryptophan Outbreak Linked to Manufacturing Process
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of a sometimes fatal blood disease among users of L-tryptophan was blamed by scientists today on impurities introduced during manufacture of the diet supplement in Japan. U.S. researchers believe the contamination resulted from changes in the way L-tryptophan was made by Showa Denko K.K., one of six companies worldwide that manufacture the over-the-counter supplement in bulk. ``We believe that some of the agent has been getting into L-tryptophan for years,'' said Dr. Michael T. Osterholm. ``But there was a series of circumstances that may have increased the agent in the product in late 1988 and at the same time resulted in lowering the amount removed in the finished product.'' Osterholm, the Minnesota state epidemiologist, said researchers are trying to pinpoint the contaminant. Showa Denko spokesman Alan Wachter acknowledged that statistical evidence pointed to the company's product as the cause of the outbreak. But he said it is uncertain whether the fault lies in changes in its manufacturing process. L-tryptophan was ordered off the market in the United States in March after it was linked with an outbreak of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome that has struck more than 1,500 people, killing 27. The painful disorder can cause high fever, rash, weakness and shortness of breath, among other symptoms. L-tryptophan is an amino acid. It has been sold as a treatment for insomnia, depression and other disorders. Osterholm is senior author of the report in today's New England Journal of Medicine. He worked with other researchers from the Minnesota Health Department and scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and the Mayo Clinic. While most of the cases of the blood disease associated with L-tryptophan were spotted in 1988 and 1989, Osterholm said others occurred in the early 1980s. L-tryptophan is made in fermentation vats by the bacteria Bacillus amyloliquefaciens. The researchers believe that the tainted product may have resulted from two changes in Showa Denko's manufacturing process. They found that the problems began after the company began using a new strain of the microbe and cut in half the amount of carbon used to filter out impurities. ``What we were able to demonstrate without a doubt was that there were changes that occurred that let more of it be in there,'' said Osterholm.

DOC.HEAD: Typewriter Repairman to Generations at Yale Closing Up Shop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: He's been fixing typewriters for students, secretaries and the literati for more than half a century in his dusty shop near Yale University. But time and technology have overrun Manson H. Whitlock. ``The typewriter is going the same way as the horse and buggy. I guess it just isn't meant to be any more,'' said Whitlock, 73, who will close his doors at the end of the month. Whitlock has worked on the typewriters of some of the country's best known writers: Pulitzer Prize-winners Robert Penn Warren, Archibald MacLeish and John Hersey; biographer and historian William Manchester; and ``Love Story'' author Erich Segal. Before word processors and personal computers, Whitlock was part of a spring ritual at Yale. At the end of each school year, hundreds of students would drop off their typewriters for storage and servicing over the summer. ``We used to sweat it out when September got close. That doesn't happen any more. This past summer I didn't have a single request,'' Whitlock said. ``I'm just so darn worn and weary with it now,'' he said. But closing wasn't so easy. Longtime customers have been rushing to get their machines in for repairs before he shuts his doors. He's got a backlog of at least two dozen repair orders. Manchester, a fan of manual typewriters, has been coming to Whitlock's since the 1950s. ``I've never known anyone who works on typewriters that can match him in any way. He's in a class by himself,'' said Manchester, writer in residence at Wesleyan University in nearby Middletown. Whitlock started his repair business in 1934 at the age of 17, working out of his father's book store, itself a New Haven institution for years. ``I've always liked mechanical challenges, and with typewriters every one has its own personality and characteristics,'' he said. Whitlock has never worked on electronic typewriters, which have computer chips. He hired an assistant to take care of those new-fangled machines. The work has taken its toll. He can no longer fully extend his right hand, which has spent thousands of hours clutching a screwdriver. His dark cluttered store, with shelves of vintage, jet-black manual typewriters, has become an anachronism on its block, now a fashionable home of several eateries, a nightclub, a copying center, an art shop and Mory's, the storied Yale dining club. Reluctantly, Whitlock has begun getting rid of his stock. He recently threw away over 200 cannibalized machines that had served as sources of hard-to-get parts and has sold most of his antiques. Dozens have also gone home with him. But there are still some oldies in the store, like the midget collapsible typewriter weighing less than 7 pounds used by news correspondents during World War I, and the blue-and-white typewriter that his father had Smith-Corona make for Yale students in the 1920s. Whitlock refused to entertain any offers to buy the business. ``I don't want someone else to have the chance to spoil what I've done,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Leaders Take Unprecedented Stand in Accepting U.S. Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Long wary of Saddam Hussein, Saudi Arabia has for the first time turned to the United States for protection because of the threat posed by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Not since the early 1960s, when Saudi Arabia responded to the Egyptian presence in North Yemen, has it made such a major military commitment to a perceived threat. Knowledgeable Saudi officials and Arab diplomats based in the Persian Gulf said the Saudi leadership has been fearful of Saddam since he wrested power from Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr in 1979. Most of Saddam's neighbors have appeased him to ensure their own preservation, they said, noting Saddam's decision to wage war on Iran in 1980. ``The Saudis tried to placate Saddam, accepted his promises about non-aggression and exerted themselves to arrange an understanding between him and the Kuwaiti government,'' said one Arab diplomat, speaking on condition his name not be used. ``Saddam did the same thing with (Egyptian President Hosni) Mubarak, who felt insulted when he realized the Iraqi leader was lying. The Saudis felt not merely insulted but also threatened.'' Apart from fighting for their own survival, the Saudis feel indebted to the invaded Kuwaitis for harboring them in the latter part of the 19th century. The Arabian Peninsula was then part of the Ottoman Empire, whose leaders had denied the house of Saud their throne in Riyadh. But on Jan. 15, 1902, a young warrior prince called Abdel-Aziz Ibn Abdel-Rahman Al Saud led 40 desert fighters by camel from Kuwait to retake Riyadh. Aided and encouraged by the benevolent Kuwaitis of the al-Sabah family, Abdel-Aziz retook Riyadh and instituted the monarchy that in subsequent decades spread across a vast area covering hidden treasures. The advent of oil transformed both Kuwait and Saudi Arabia almost simultaneously into rich countries. The two ruling families began vying for political distinction. Jealousies and political rivalries often overshadowed their kinship. ``But the shock of invasion and the flight of the ruling family pushed to the fore the question of survival,'' said one Arab diplomat. ``The Saudis had to choose one of two bitter options _ either to back down and wait for their turn to go down under the heavy boots of some neighboring dictator, or to resort to the Americans and defy the Iraqis.'' The Saudis won a denunciation of Iraq's invasion from its allies on the Gulf Cooperation Council. The council said exiled Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah was the only legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Born in the summer of 1981, the GCC groups join Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman in a military and economic pact. State-run radio and television stations, along with government-guided newspapers in all GCC countries condemned Saddam. As U.S. troops headed to Saudi Arabia, the GCC foreign ministers met in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, denounced the invasion and called for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. During the 1962-67 Yemen war, the Saudis poured massive weapons stocks and vast sums of money into Yemen and recruited mercenaries to evict the Egyptian armies of the late President Gamal Abdel-Nasser. The net gain for the Saudis was the ouster of the forces of revolutionary regimes from North Yemen. At one stage during the Yemeni war the Egyptians sent their warplanes raiding the southern Saudi border regions of Najran and Jaizan with poison gas. Iraq is known to possess vast quantities of chemical weapons, which Saddam has said he would use if attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Debilitating Sand, Heat, Threat of Chemical Attack Face U.S. Troops
DOC.TEXT: Few areas of the planet are more forbidding for the American warrior than Saudi Arabia, home of the world's largest sand desert, where the summer heat often tops 120 degrees and can sap even the native tribesmen. Drinkable water is scarce. Sand and dust can debilitate not only armies on the march but also aircraft, supply vehicles and gun sightings on tanks and rifles. Add to that the threat of being attacked with poison gases you can neither see nor smell, and you have a picture of the peculiarities of mobilizing on the Arabian Peninsula to defend the world's largest oil reserves from the Iraqi army. President Bush told the nation Wednesday that American forces were landing in Saudi Arabia to protect the desert kingdom from a menacing million-man Iraqi army. The president said U.S. troops would not initiate a conflict but would respond if attacked. Government sources said at least 5,000 paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne Division and other highly mobile units were en route or already taking positions on Saudi soil _ backed by a swelling armada of naval air and seapower. Diplomatic sources in Saudi Arabia said 4,000 Marines already had been moved to a oil-terminal Saudi town close to the Kuwaiti border. Those sources said the total U.S. troop strength could reach 30,000, while The Washington Post and The New York Times quoted estimates of 50,000. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has vowed to crush any resistance to his occupation of Kuwait. The Saudi desert itself is a formidable foe for the Americans. The name alone _ the Empty Quarter _ speaks volumes about the inhospitable conditions. The heat can be defeating. Temperatures in August often top 120 degrees; on Tuesday, as the first U.S. air and ground units readied for their mission, it was 110 degrees in Riyadh, the Saudi capital. Even without the physical strain of combat, U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia would have to drink at least six gallons of water a day while their bodies adjusted to the climate, said an Army planner who spoke on condition of anonymity. Deliveries of drinking water become nearly as important as armaments. Also on the equipment list for this deployment: plenty of sunscreen lotion and sunglasses. The desert environment presents these other challenges to the Americans there: _Distortion of all optical systems, including binoculars and sighting optics on tanks, by surface heat waves. _Damage to weapons, other vehicles and aircraft from the effects of blowing sand and dust. The sand can grind down helicopter rotor blades much like the effects of sandpaper on light metal. Sand also can clog engines and air filters. _Transport of troops and supplies is more risky, particularly over the great distances in the Saudi desert, because of a lack of ground cover. That gives added importance to air power, and in turn puts a greater onus on air defenses. Besides the dangers of exhaustion and dehydration, the heat also hurts the U.S. troops' ability to cope with the threat of a chemical attack by Iraq, according to military officers. The use of chemical weapons is outlawed by the 1925 Geneva Protocol, but Iraq has admitted to using poison gas during its eight-year war with Iran. Hundreds of civilians in an Iraqi village that fell into Iranian hands were burned to death in an Iraqi gas attack in 1988. The Washington Post reported Wednesday that Iraqi forces appeared to have loaded gas munitions aboard combat aircraft. U.S. officials would not confirm the report. ``It's a threat we're concerned with,'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters Wednesday. ``The intelligence is somewhat ambiguous'' on whether the Iraqis are preparing to use chemical weapons, he said. Maj. Joe Padilla, an Army spokesman at the Pentagon, said the soldiers heading to Saudi Arabia are equipped with gear to defend against a chemical attack. This includes protective clothing, such as boots, gloves, masks and special trousers and jackets, as well as equipment for decontaminating clothing and gear. They also are carrying special sensing devices, including battery-operated devices that sample the air for indications of poisonous gas, as well as medicines to counteract the effects of exposure to chemical agents, officials said. Padilla said all soldiers routinely are trained in chemical protective measures, but most are exposed only to a simulated chemical attack, not the real thing. ``It's something we train for on a regular basis,'' he said. The harsh climate combined with the vast, nearly featureless open spaces of the Saudi desert presents extraordinary problems for soldiers' ability to hide from the enemy. ``There's less area to camouflage yourself,'' said Maj. John Wagstaffe of the Army's National Training Center at Fort Irwin, Calif., in the Mojave Desert.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait Crisis: Questions and Answers
DOC.TEXT: Here are some questions and answers about issues involved in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:

Q. Why did Iraq invade Kuwait? A. Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along its disputed border with Iraq and of seeking to wreck Iraq's economy by overproducing oil and thus pushing down prices.

Q. What has been world reaction? A. The U.N. Security Council on Monday ordered a worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq. The 12-member European Economic Community has imposed an embargo against imports of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. It also banned exports of weapons to Iraq, suspended that country's preferential trade status and froze Iraqi assets. The United States has frozen both Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets.

Q. What has been the reaction of the Arab states? The Gulf Cooperation Council foreign ministers met in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, denounced the invasion and called for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. The GCC consists of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar and Oman in a military and economic pact. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was joined by King Hussein of Jordan in proposing an Arab summit, set for Thursday in Cairo. Countries expected to attend include: Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Algeria, Djibouti, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Libya, Tunis, Morocco, Jordan, and Oman.

Q. Have other nations supported the United States? A. Yes. Britain will send unspecified naval and air force units to join the multinational force. West Germany, Spain and Italy agreed to let the United States use bases on their territory to help transport U.S. troops and equipment sent to the Persian Gulf. Turkey has shut down the Iraqi pipeline that runs through its territory to the Mediterranean.

Q. How will the consumer in the United States be affected? A. It means higher gasoline prices, lines at gas pumps, higher fuel oil prices, higher airline ticket prices. It can mean higher utility bills, and it can also mean lost jobs.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Says Train Explosion That Killed 5 was Caused by Embezzler's Bomb
DOC.TEXT: The KGB has determined that a bomb that killed five people on a Moscow-bound passenger train last month was made by a debt-ridden embezzler who may have wanted to fake his own death, a newspaper reported. The KGB secret police identified the bomb-maker as Asker Askerov, 34, who investigators believe was killed when the device went off in his hands while he was drunk, the newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna reported Wednesday. The story said not much was left of the corpse but forensic tests led investigators to conclude that the body was Askerov's. A youth aged 10-12 who was traveling with Askerov was among the five killed in the July 20 explosion, which also injured 12 people, the newspaper said. The explosion occurred shortly after midnight between the second and third cars of a train traveling on the Donetsk railway line in southern Russia, just south of the Ukrainian border near the Sea of Azov. The train had departed the day before from Tshkaltubo in the republic of Georgia. Askerov, who had worked in a cooperative or private venture, embezzled more than $636,000 and ran up huge debts, the newspaper quoted two KGB investigators as saying. Askerov, of Naberezhniye Chelny, about 550 miles east of Moscow, made the bomb himself in a hotel in the Russian town of Bataisk in the northern Caucasus, according to the KGB investigators. As for motive, the newspaper quoted the investigators as saying Askerov may have wanted to fake his own death to foil his creditors, or he might have been planning to threaten them with the bomb. Before the blast, passengers on the train recalled seeing a man fitting Askerov's description walking through the cars, obviously drunk and muttering that there would be an explosion, the newspaper said. ``The bomb exploded in Askerov's hands when he was drunk,'' the newspaper quoted the investigators as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Producer Cancels Broadway Musical Over Union Ban on Actor
DOC.TEXT: The producer of ``Miss Saigon'' has canceled the Broadway musical rather than bow to an Actors' Equity demand that he dump a white actor cast in the role of a Eurasian brothel owner. ``The debate is no longer about the casting of `Miss Saigon' but the art of acting itself,'' producer Cameron Mackintosh said Wednesday in announcing the London hit will not open in New York next March. Equity, acting on a complaint from an Asian playwright and an Asian actor, on Tuesday barred Englishman Jonathan Pryce from re-creating in New York the role he originated in the show's London version. The actors' union, which has veto power over foreign actors for roles in the United States, said it turned down Pryce because ``the casting of a Caucasian actor made up to appear Asian is an affront to the Asian community.'' Pryce said from London that he supports Mackintosh. ``What is appropriate is that the best person for the job play the role and I think it's completely valid that I play the role,'' he said. ``If the character is half Asian and half European, you've got to drop down on one side of the fence or the other, and I'm choosing to drop down on the European side.'' Mackintosh canceled despite $25 million in advance sales, the largest in Broadway history. About $600,000 had already been spent on the production, he said. ``The entire creative team and I do indeed feel totally defeated artistically by this turn of events and in no way do we wish to practice our art in the horrible atmosphere which has now been created by Equity,'' Mackintosh said. ``Racial prejudice does seem to have triumphed over creative freedom.'' The controversy arose after Actors' Equity received complaints from playwright David Henry Hwang and actor B.D. Wong about the casting of Pryce. ``It has certainly never been my intention to see a show canceled. I simply felt that an important point had to be made, and this has clearly been achieved,'' Hwang, author of the Broadway hit ``M. Butterfly,'' said Wednesday. The economic fallout on Broadway from the cancellation could be enormous. George Wachtel of the League of American Theaters and Producers said a show the size and caliber of ``Miss Saigon'' could have ticket sales in its first year of $30 million to $35 million. Salaries alone would be $200,000 a week, Wachtel said. The show would have employed about 182 people, including 34 performers of Asian descent. The musical is a love story set during the closing days of the Vietnam War. Mackintosh declined to take the union ban to arbitration. ``I think Actors' Equity misjudged Cameron Mackintosh,'' said Richard Maltby Jr., co-lyricist of the musical. ``They didn't understand that if the show wasn't done to Cameron's standards, he'd just as soon not have it done.''

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Steps Up Antismoking Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The government, which has already banned smoking in most public areas, is moving its campaign to the airways. The Health Ministry said Wednesday that smoking will be prohibited on domestic airline flights of two hours or less. The ban affects flights between Brazil's major cities such as Rio, Sao Paulo and Brasilia, the capital. The new rule will take effect after a public education campaign by the airlines and the Department of Civilian Aviation, the ministry said. It said it also was considering creating special shuttle flights for smokers. Three months ago, the government approved a plan to cut down on smoking in this country of 150 million people. The measures included a ban on cigarette sales to minors, prohibition of cigarette ads on television between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m. and required health warnings on TV, newspaper and billboard ads for cigarettes. About 55 million Brazilians are smokers. A law prohibiting smoking in elevators, buses and public areas is routinely flouted.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says It Will Send War Powers Notice to Congress
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House says it will give Congress a formal notification of the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia under the War Powers Act, which limits American involvement in foreign conflicts. A spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Frank Sieverts, said Wednesday that the panel was notified by the White House that ``we will be given information that we will regard as notification under the War Powers Act.'' Administrations traditionally do not formally acknowledge the act, which they regard as an unconstitutional infringement by Congress on the president's powers as commander-in-chief of the armed forces. Rather than tackle the issue head-on, however, notification usually is given in a way that Congress regards as compliance with the law. The act requires that the president consult with Congress formally when U.S. forces are introduced ``into hostilities or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated by the circumstances.'' Notification also is required when combat-equipped troops are sent to the territory of any foreign nation. The notification must include the president's explanation of why the move is necessary and the estimated scope and duration of the deployment. The law requires that the president terminate the military deployment within 60 days unless Congress has specifically authorized its continuation. The 60-day period can be extended to 90 days if the president certifies that such a move is ``an unavoidable military necessity.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said while the deployment might not meet the ``imminent hostilities'' test of the law, at least ``the spirit'' of the act should be observed.

DOC.HEAD: Spacecraft Hurtles Toward Friday Rendezvous With Venus
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft accelerated toward Venus today on a mission to make the most detailed pictures yet of the cloud-shrouded planet's rugged surface. If all goes as planned, a computer program will order the 3.7-ton spaceship to fire its rocket Friday, slowing Magellan so it will go into orbit around the second planet from the sun, NASA said. The $413 million Magellan, centerpiece of a $744 million mission, was released from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, then launched by a booster rocket. Once Magellan is in orbit, engineers will test its radar and, if necessary, fire the spacecraft's thrusters to adjust its path. During the week of Aug. 26, Magellan will begin using its radar to peer through thick Venusian clouds to make pictures and maps of the planet. The first pictures probably won't be released until September, NASA said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has a Busy Week _ But Still Finds Time for Tennis
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From the moment that word flashed back to the White House that Iraqi tanks were storming across the Kuwait border, President Bush kept up a frenetic schedule orchestrating the response of America and its allies. Aides say the president made the decision to send U.S. forces to the Persian Gulf on Saturday, and orders were cut for the military Sunday night. Bush got little sleep last Wednesday night as the invasion unfolded in Kuwait. He met with his top generals and civilian advisers Thursday morning in the Cabinet Room, denouncing Iraq's ``naked aggression'' and calling for its immediate withdrawal. Then he flew to Aspen, Colo., to confer with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and give a speech to the Aspen Institute outlining plans to shrink the military by 25 percent _ 500,000 soldiers _ over the next five years. In a concession to the crisis, Bush canceled plans to spend the night on the Rocky Mountain ranch of Henry Catto, the U.S. ambassador to Britain, and instead flew back to Washington, getting home after 2 a.m. Friday. He spent the weekend at Camp David, Md., meeting with national security advisers Saturday to map his response to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. On Sunday morning, Bush was occupied with the evacuation of Americans from the civil strife in Liberia. When he arrived back from Camp David in mid-afternoon, he told reporters about his telephone conversations with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and others. But he was testy, and one reporter who felt Bush's bite received a handwritten note of apology from the president the next day. Bush met Sunday evening with his national security advisers, and was on the phone repeatedly with foreign leaders _ at least 20 times to a dozen different presidents and prime ministers. He dispatched Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to the Middle East to talk with Fahd, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Morocco's King Hassan II. Bush himself spoke several times to Fahd and Turkish President Turgut Ozal, through whose countries ran the pipelines that carry 90 percent of Iraq's oil to market. On Monday, as the United Nations Security Council voted 13-0 to impose stiff sanctions on Iraq, Bush was in the Oval Office with Mrs. Thatcher and later with NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner. Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney flew in for dinner. On Tuesday, Bush briefed his Cabinet and headed off for two hours to visit Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in nearby Langley, Va. At one point he ducked out of the CIA briefings to call Mulroney in Toronto to follow up their conversation from the night before. Bush resolutely fended off reporters' questions as word filtered out that American soldiers and warplanes were on their way to Saudi Arabia. With his wife in Kennebunkport, Maine, with their grandchildren, Bush invited national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and other senior aides to dinner Tuesday night. It was a quiet, relaxed affair, and the guests left Bush on his own by 9 p.m. He headed into the Oval Office by 6:40 a.m. Wednesday, tieless and relaxed when a reporter encountered him as technicians readied the cameras for his 9 a.m. address to the nation. If the president appeared somewhat tired and tongue-tied at his subsequent news conference, it was not from working late Tuesday but ``just the accumulation of things'' over the past week, an aide said. By Wednesday afternoon, however, things had calmed down enough for Bush to quit work early and head for the White House tennis courts.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman's Son's Unit Sent to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: When Rep. Jerry Costello's son wanted a break from college, his parents never imagined he would join the Army. But nine months after he enlisted, Jerry F. Costello II is now a paratrooper in the Middle East, his father says. ``I'm concerned for his safety and well-being,'' Costello, D-Ill., said Wednesday. ``By the same token I'm very proud that he chose to go in and defend his country.'' Last November, after two years at Lincoln College, the younger Costello, 21, joined the Army. He was assigned to the 82nd Airborne, whose members were ordered to the Middle East to stop Iraq. Costello and his wife, Georgia, called Fort Bragg, N.C., but no information was released because of security concerns. ``Given the fact that there have been 5,000 soldiers from the 82nd Airborne deployed from Fort Bragg, there's no question in our minds that he is either in Saudi Arabia or on the way there,'' Costello said. The parents saw their son over the weekend. ``He fully expected that if the aggression by the Iraqis continued, and if there was a threat to Saudi Arabia, he would go. Whenever we send ground troops in, normally the 82nd Airborne will go in, either to secure airports or rescue hostages,'' Costello said. He said his son's Army stint is rooted in a desire for public service. ``One of the things he's always said since he was a little boy was that everyone should have to serve their country in one form or another. ... He believes there ought to be a draft,'' Costello said. Although his son is at risk, the father believes President Bush made the right decision. ``It's in the interest of the American people,'' Costello said. ``I'm glad we have made a major commitment and not just sent a few troops.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter to Try to Fashion Farm Bill to Administration Wishes
DOC.TEXT: When Congress goes back to work next month, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says he'll be ready to work with lawmakers on a final version of the 1990 farm bill. The House and Senate have each passed a version of the five-year bill, but a conference committee will have to iron out differences. And those will have to be acceptable to the Bush administration, Yeutter said Wednesday. Probably the biggest obstacle will be adjusting farm program benefits to fit within federal budget rules, which are still being negotiated. There are other hurdles, too. Yeutter told reporters he wished that Congress had ironed out many of the problems while the bills were still in committees or when they came up for floor debate. Yeutter said he was hopeful Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, and Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, head of the House Agriculture Committee, would do some streamlining when the bills go to conference. He said he hoped the two chairmen would be ``willing to jettison undesirable provisions that may have been added for political purposes'' during development of the House and Senate bills. Yeutter labeled as ``pure bunk, absolute political year nonsense'' charges that he had shied away from the farm bill to spend more time on Uruguay Round negotiations under the international General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``If there's anything that reflects demagoguery, those kind of comments do,'' he said. ``We've been fully involved in that (farm bill) process from the very first day.'' Yeutter said the Agriculture Department sent Congress a ``green book'' of more than 70 major recommendations on the farm bill and had mailed 20,000 copies all over the country to promote the administration's plan. Further, he said, two senior USDA officials were assigned fulltime to the House and Senate as the farm bills developed. ``Some members of Congress wanted to have the secretary of agriculture on site so that they could use him as a whipping boy in the congressional debate,'' he said. ``We had sufficient perspicacity to avoid that temptation.'' Yeutter said he probably will spend much time on Capitol Hill during the conference negotiations. ``This is crunch time in the farm bill, and I will certainly make my personal views known to all the conferees as we proceed the rest of the way,'' he said. Yeutter said the administration ``will obviously seek a number of changes'' in the farm bill versions as they now stand. But he declined to spell out what those would be. However, Yeutter said his earlier threats of a veto recommendation to President Bush still stand if the 1990 farm bill doesn't meet budget and market requirements. He did not elaborate further. Yeutter's remarks were at a telephone news conference with farm broadcasters and with reporters afterward. He was joined at the USDA news conference by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Both officials decried recent moves by the European Economic Community, or EEC, to step up export subsidies of agricultural products. ``What the (EEC) has done recently is a good indication of what they'll do if we don't get some disciplines negotiated in the Uruguay Round'' of talks, Yeutter said. The negotiations, due to conclude at the end of this year, include U.S. proposals for ending or phasing out trade-distorting practices such as export subsidies. Yeutter said recent EEC subsidies on wheat shipments, for example, are ``appalling'' and ``are higher than the value of the underlying product.'' ``We've again reached a situation where they can undersell us in the world markets if we price our wheat at zero,'' he said. The EEC also has sharply boosted its export subsidies for some other agricultural products, including dairy and beef, he said. Mrs. Hills said the EEC policies of high domestic farm supports, which encourage surplus production, and huge export subsidies to unload that surplus cannot continue. ``At some point that's going to cause the system to crash,'' she said. Asked during the news conference what might happen if the current round of GATT talks fail to gain the global trade liberalization sought by the United States, Mrs. Hills said she was ``not prepared to speculate on failure.'' Yeutter was leaving today for two weeks of meetings in the Far East to talk about trade negotiations, the 1990 farm bill and other agricultural matters of mutual interest. In Japan, Yeutter said he plans to give away packets of industry-donated U.S. rice as a gesture to encourage relaxation of Tokyo's ban on rice imports. He said this should be done if Japan wants to have credibility as an advocate of world trade liberalization.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Trying to Put Best Face on Bailout Progress
DOC.TEXT: One year after President Bush signed landmark savings and loan bailout legislation, the administration is trying to accentuate the positive about its handling of the still-worsening mess. Anticipating a chorus of criticism around today's anniversary of the bill, Bush's Cabinet officers are emphasizing the bailout's benefits to depositors, minimizing the rising cost to taxpayers and denouncing what they call the ``blame game'' played by congressional Democrats. ``The staggering size of the cost estimates understandably alarms taxpayers and frightens politicians into finger-pointing and blame-avoiding. The line in the political world goes, `Since I don't make mistakes, someone else must be making them,''' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Wednesday. Overlooked in the furor, he said, is the fact that the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, as it is formally known, has so far protected 6.4 million deposit accounts averaging around $10,000 each. ``Our job is to conduct the massive cleanup operation effectively and responsibly, to rise above the political blame game, and to work steadily and professionally to get the job done,'' Brady said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and chief White House economic adviser Michael Boskin also are defending the administration at other events this week. But the record over the last year and the outlook for the next is decidedly mixed. The Resolution Trust Corp., created to handle the bailout, has closed or sold 211 insolvent thrifts and plans to deal with 126 more this year. But that would leave it still running 135 collapsed thrifts and looking ahead to an additional 230 to 550 failures among the remaining 2,430 privately-run S&Ls. Solvent S&Ls lost $271 million in the first three months of 1990 even though they are under less pressure from insolvent institutions desperately seeking deposits with high interest rates. The Justice Department established financial institution fraud task forces in 27 cities and hired 118 assistant U.S. attorneys and 153 FBI agents. But complex fraud cases take years to prosecute and it is too soon to tell if the added staff will make significant headway against a backlog of 21,147 criminal referrals. The S&L cleanup is far wider and its cost far deeper than envisioned on Aug. 9, 1989, when Bush signed the law in a sunny Rose Garden ceremony. ``If someone would have told me the day of the bill signing that S&Ls would be the No. 1 issue and the crisis would look even worse than it did a year ago, I would have said, `You're crazy,''' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the House Banking Committee. ``Yet, that's exactly where we are.'' The cost of the bailout contributed to Bush's decision to abandon his ``no new taxes'' pledge and led to the first serious congressional push since Watergate to reform campaign finance laws. The bailout also threatens to spill into the general economy as a credit crunch. Real estate developers and small businesses already are complaining that they can't get loans. The Federal Reserve Board has been forced to cut interest rates. Savings and loans, barely mentioned in the 1988 presidential race, have become a prime issue in this year's congressional races. Challengers view the issue as their best chance to defeat incumbents, especially those who received political contributions from the industry. Behind the firestorm is the need for more tax money to finance the cleanup. The year-old act provided $50 billion to cover S&L losses and allowed regulators to raise additional cash by borrowing against the sour loans, distressed real estate and other assets inherited from the bankrupt thrifts. Now, regulators say they will need up to $100 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1. That includes $30 billion to $40 billion from taxpayers, with the rest to be borrowed and repaid when assets of failed S&Ls are sold. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House task force monitoring the bailout, says taxpayers' liability won't be contained until the Resolution Trust Corp. makes headway in selling failed institutions' assets. The bailout agency last week announced its ``great fall inventory clearance sale,'' which will use an international satellite auction and other techniques to reduce its $165 billion asset portfolio by $50 billion by Dec. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Take My Flight, Please: Comedy in the Skies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Aprill cq in 7th graf, `Comedian Al ...'
DOC.TEXT: Did you hear the one about the stand-up comic who got booked on a commuter flight? Had to sit down. Too much turbulence. Passengers are getting comedy with their cabin service on Continental Express flights from Detroit to Cleveland this week. ``If you don't like my act, where are you going to go?'' comic Don Tersigni told his audience Wednesday aboard the 30-passenger Flight 4454. Tersigni, who did Elvis Presley and Sylvester Stallone impressions after lemonade and peanuts were passed out, said afterward that it wasn't like entertaining the average nightclub crowd. ``I couldn't hear myself, really, especially doing impressions,'' he said, alighting from the noisy twin-turboprop. ``I was just sort of winging it,'' he added, starting to smile. ``I hope it will help my career, sort of, take off.'' Comedian Al Aprill did a sit-down act when Flight 4454 ran into turbulence Monday night. ``I was told our comedian does a real good job. I'm sorry I can't let him stand up,'' Capt. Bill Daly said. Continental Express scheduled business briefings on morning flights and comedy in the evening this week to pump up publicity for its new Cleveland-Detroit route. The 50-minute flights are too short for movies. Johnny Carson mentioned the gimmick on his ``Tonight Show,'' saying that anyone traveling to Detroit or Cleveland could use a little comedy. ``It's different,'' said one passenger, William Stadler, a Boston businessman. ``It wasn't boring, anyway.'' Earlier Wednesday, most of the 17 passengers on a 7 a.m. flight stayed awake to hear Detroit Free Press assistant business editor Nunzio Lupo discuss labor negotiations between the Big Three automakers and the United Auto Workers. Lupo stood, braced against the closed cockpit door, glanced at a few note cards and delivered a 20-minute summation into a hand microphone. Passengers applauded. Perhaps more important, they listened to the airline's emergency instructions. ``In the morning it's really hard. They'll sleep, or read their paper. They don't listen to my demo,'' said flight attendant Lisa Lyons. Spokeswoman Peggy Mahoney said Continental Express hadn't decided whether to try such promotions on its other commuter flights from Continental Airlines' hubs in Cleveland, Newark, Houston and Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Fantastic Concert: `Ellington Express'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: ``Ellington Express'' carried the audience at Lincoln Center through an evening of three extended pieces by Duke Ellington and six of the songs he wrote about trains _ all brilliantly performed. Each of the train songs was from a different decade. Classical Jazz at Lincoln Center, knowing the Wednesday night concert was special, will offer a rerun Thursday at Alice Tully Hall. The high point of the first piece, the 1959, four-movement ``Toot Suite,'' was a long solo by tenor saxophonist Todd Williams in ``Ready Go!'', the last movement. Williams, who is in Wynton Marsalis' band, brought the audience to its feet in last year's Ellington concert with ``Diminuendo and Crescendo in Blue.'' He stands calmly, no grimacing, and escalates listeners' blood pressure just with his steady, persistent playing. Marsalis played in the band and he was a revelation. As good as one expects him to be, one doesn't expect so many styles to be done to perfection. He went from sounding primitive and earthy in ``Red Carpet'' from ``Toot Suite'' to a deep growl, contrasting with Alvin Batiste's clarinet, in ``Bluebird of Delhi'' from the 1966 ``Far East Suite,'' to a high, bright use of a metal hat mute in ``Happy-Go-Lucky Local.'' Alto saxophonist Norris Turney's romantic ``Isfahan,'' with the other instruments orchestrated to swirl around him, was another of many special movements in the exotically beautiful ``Far East Suite.'' Act 2 started with the six train songs, from ``Choo Choo'' of 1924, when Ellington was 25, to ``Loco Madi,'' written at the University of Wisconsin in Madison in 1972. David Berger, who transcribed the evening's music from recordings by the Ellington Band, conducted. For him, ``Day Break Express'' from 1933 is ``the most dazzling of all Ellington's train pieces.'' He said, ``It comes out of the night into the morning at 100 miles an hour.'' The band, which was wonderfully rehearsed, fresh, full-bodied but never heavy, rushed ``Day Break Express'' past all depots. That was followed by ``Happy-Go-Lucky Local'' from 1946, from which Jimmy Forrest ``appropriated'' the main melody for ``Night Train.'' Final piece on the program was ``Harlem,'' an evocative piece with many mini-portraits and moods, obviously about a place that Ellington loved. ``Harlem,'' a tone poem from 1950, has a triumphal ending with high-note trumpets. The audience wouldn't let the band go so they played two encores, ``Rockin' in Rhythm'' and ``Things Ain't What They Used To Be.'' Ellington music sounds as good as it used to.

DOC.HEAD: Fear and Terror Surround Saddam Hussein
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: During a meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein two months ago, a group of U.S. senators were startled to see the official interpreter rush into the room late, quivering in fear. The translator had been held up briefly in an elevator, and the meeting had been delayed by a few moments. ``The poor guy was terrified. He looked like he was afraid he was going to die,'' said one of those present. Fear and terror surround the 53-year-old Iraqi president, and U.S. intelligence officials and other analysts believe that climate could be his undoing. ``Everybody around him tells him what he wants to hear,'' said one congressional source, who has concluded that Saddam's invasion of Kuwait was a severe miscalculation based on poor information and a failure to foresee the international fallout that would result. But the U.S. intelligence profile of Saddam also is of a risk-taker who is not afraid to gamble against long odds. Concern is heightened by the Arab leader's profile as one without respect for common human values or the normal rules of diplomacy. Use of chemical weapons, terrorism and hostage-taking all are possibilities, they say. The picture of Saddam shows a man with a strange duality: tough, yet fearful; inspiring fear in his own people, yet also basking in a kind of populist veneration from many of the region's Arabs. The portrait is one of a poor orphan who rose to power through opportunism and brutality, whose anti-Western views were shaped in childhood, and who now _ commanding the world's fourth-largest army _ is trying to deliver on his nationalist dreams. Saddam, say intelligence sources and Americans who have met with him, is a ruler without finesse, but with keen political instincts and well-defined goals. Foremost among those goals, the sources say, is to become the ``Nasser of the '90s,'' the dominant figure in the Arab world and the chief controller of OPEC oil. Driving Saddam is a devotion to Arab political and cultural supremacy and a deep-seated hatred for Israel and for any Western infringement of his independence _ particularly from the United States and Great Britain, the two countries that have publicly committed troops to Saudi Arabia's defense. But while jealously guarding Arab independence, Saddam also covets Western technology and education and has sought to modernize his country. He has been able to work well with the French, who have supplied many of the weapons that are the basis of Iraq's military might. The son of peasants who was orphaned at an early age, Saddam grew up with an uncle in the Iraqi town of Takrit, which was known as a hotbed of ferment against the British rule of Iraq. His uncle was arrested for participating in an uprising against the government. He later joined the Arab Baath socialist party and became devoted to the cause of ridding his country of foreign influences. His rise to power has been facilitated by execution of his opponents, and he has used chemical weapons against Iran and against his own Kurdish minority. There is strong evidence that Saddam personally shot to death one of his cabinet ministers in 1982 after the official said aloud at a cabinet meeting that the invasion of Iran had been a mistake. Unlike leaders of other Moslem countries, Saddam appears to be a purely secular head of state. ``He doesn't seem to value human life, or to have any moral standards,'' said one congressional source who has met with Saddam. ``He has got certain views that don't appear much amenable to a lot of negotiation. You didn't come out thinking, `we can probably work out a deal,''' the source said. Saddam frequently states his conviction that there is a conspiracy among Israel, the United States and Britain to topple him, and visitors are left with the impression of someone who is insecure. Saddam, who has been the target of assassination attempts, surrounds himself with military bodyguards. He wore a gun during a meeting with Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., in January, an aide to the senator said. He relies on terror to maintain his power. He is often compared to Adolf Hitler, and Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman David Boren, D-Okla., called the Iraqi security apparatus ``the most effective internal police state in the world.'' Iraqi citizens are afraid to speak their ruler's name, said Boren, for fear it will be misunderstood as criticism, an offense that is punishable by execution. ``His sense of face and dignity is extremely important,'' said another U.S. analyst. ``He governs by ruthlessness and fear and awe. If he is thought to lose face, that's losing a good half of his capacity.'' Intelligence sources said Saddam saw in the conquest of Kuwait a chance to meet several needs and tried to calculate the risks before moving ahead. He wanted to gain greater access to the Persian Gulf, to gain new wealth to offset his country's debt from its eight-year war with Iran, and to punish what many Arabs see as Kuwaiti arrogance. But analysts said he probably had no idea that his invasion of Kuwait would bring the broad condemnation, trade sanctions and military response that have resulted. Saddam is limited in his ambitions only by threats to his own power at home, say U.S. analysts. ``He goes for the jugular on power,'' said one government analyst. ``He understands how to get it, how to wield it and how to keep it.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico To Send Additional Oil To US for Two Months
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In a gesture to a ``friendly and important customer,'' Mexico will send an additional 100,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States to help ease shortages caused by the embargo imposed against Iraq and Kuwait. The Mexican commitment, scheduled to last two months, is expected to restore about 15 percent of the more than 700,000 barrels a day the United States is no longer receiving as a result of the embargo. The Mexican decision was announced Wednesday by Foreign Secretary Fernando Solana, who headed his country's delegation to a daylong meeting of Mexican and American officials convened to discuss cross-border issues. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela also announced plans Wednesday to increase oil production. While the Mexican move could ease concerns about domestic supplies in this country, it also will provide added cash to Mexico, with a bonus resulting from the higher prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady praised the Mexican action, saying it ``exemplifies the spirit of relations between the two countries.'' ``This aid by Mexico is much appreciated at this time,'' Brady said. Solana said he felt it was necessary to meet the needs of ``an important and friendly customer.'' Total U.S. oil imports average an estimated 4 million barrels a day. Solana indicated that the Mexican increase would have been higher but that oil production in Mexico is running virtually at capacity. Mexico exports about half of its 2.5 million barrel daily production of oil. More than 70 Mexican officials accompanied Solana for Wednesday's meeting, which was held under the auspices of the U.S.-Mexico Binational Commission. All told, more than 150 delegates from the two countries took part in the discussions, which are held annually and touch on a broad range of cross-border issues. The meetings took place against a background of unusual harmony in Mexican-American relations. At the ceremonial opening session, Secretary of State James A. Baker III joined with Solana in denouncing the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait and in calling from the withdrawal of Iraqi forces. Baker had been scheduled to devote a full day to the commission deliberations but left in late morning for Turkey to deal with the Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Completing Latin Trip
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle concludes his Latin American journey today, insisting that the United States has ``zero'' intention of involving its military forces in operations against the cocaine trade. ``Let no one say ... that there are military operations by the United States of America in this effort,'' Quayle told a news conference Wednesday night. ``The United States has no intention of ... (undertaking) military operations. Zero.'' Latin American sensitivity on that point drew the question of military involvement repeatedly as Quayle visited Bogota, Colombia; Lima, Peru, then La Paz. He got a public welcome there, his first after the rigorous security that surrounded him in the other two Andean capitals, both plagued by violence. Crowds lined the La Paz streets to see him, and applauded him as he stepped from his limousine for conferences with President Jaime Paz Zamora and other Bolivian officials. Quayle was flying on to Santa Cruz, Bolivia's second city, for a refueling stop and a conference with Gen. Hugo Banzer, a former military dictator who now shares power with Paz Zamora, himself a former Marxist once jailed for attempting to overthrow Banzer. After a final drug conference, with U.S. drug enforcement and aid officials working in Bolivia, Quayle was flying to Haiti later today to urge support for the fledgling electoral process that is supposed to produce that nation's first free elections on Nov. 4. He returns to Washington tonight.

DOC.HEAD: Bar Association Drops Pro-Choice Stand on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Abortion rights advocates are not giving up their fight to put the American Bar Association back on record in favor of a pro-choice stand on abortion despite a setback from the nation's largest lawyers' organization. ``Time is on our side,'' said Estelle Rogers of Washington, D.C., a leader of the defeated abortion rights forces. She said that as more women become lawyers and join the ABA, they may persuade the organization to reinstate a pro-choice policy. The lawyers, deeply split over the issue, headed home from their annual summer convention after the ABA's policy-making House of Delegates on Wednesday reversed a 6-month-old policy in support of abortion rights.
