The delegates adopted the policy in February by a margin of more than two-to-one but repealed it on Wednesday by a vote of 200-188. A resolution favoring neutrality on abortion was approved by a coalition of attorneys either opposed to abortion or who believed the association tarnished its reputation by going on record in support of such a controversial position. Abortion rights supporters said they are not discouraged, noting that about 90 percent of the delegates were men. They said male dominance is bound to erode as more women join the ABA. ``Nobody here has the illusion we're going to put our tails between our legs and go home,'' Ms. Rogers told reporters. During nearly two hours of debate, Sally Determan of Washington, D.C., said the repeal measure sends a message that the ABA is abandoning its support of ``women's right to choose, to control our own bodies.'' But Barbara Howard of Cincinnati, Ohio, said she supported repeal because views on abortion are deeply held individual religious and moral convictions. ``Abortion is not a legal issue. It's a political issue, a moral issue,'' she said. The House of Delegates repealed its abortion rights stand at the urging of a larger group of lawyers, the ABA Assembly, who voted 885-836 on Monday in favor of neutrality. It is uncertain when the next fight over the issue may occur, but the 360,000-member organization holds conventions every six months and some officials said sooner or later there is bound to be another clash. The ABA's new president, John J. Curtin Jr. of Boston, held a joint news conference after Wednesday's vote with his designated successor, Sandy D'Alemberte of Tallahassee, Fla., to stress the need for healing wounds. The two men are on opposite sides of the issue. Curtin urged repeal of the abortion rights stand. D'Alemberte pleaded with his colleagues to stand fast behind the pro-choice policy, calling it an endorsement of ``the principle of liberty.'' Both men said ABA members should stay in the organization and hash out their differences on the issue. More than 1,500 quit in protest after the pro-choice policy was adopted in February.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Oil Shock as Endangering Economy, But Brady Disagrees
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady says soaring oil prices need not topple the United States into a recession, but private analysts warn that the shock endangers an already weak economy. ``We are not contemplating recession,'' Brady said Wednesday at the National Press Club. ``Certainly the events of last week, where the price of oil has gone up, are going to impose additional hardships on the country,'' he said. ``But I don't think we should come to judgment quickly.'' The price of crude oil soared from $20 a barrel last week, before Iraq invaded Kuwait, to $25.96 on Wednesday. Brady said increasing production outside the region will eventually help offset a break in oil supplies from the Persian Gulf. ``Before we wring our hands and hang our heads about the price of oil, we should remember the system adjusts,'' he said. However, the chief economist of the influential U.S. Chamber of Commerce declared that the nation will be unable to avoid a recession later this year even if the explosive situation in the Persian Gulf eases soon. ``We anticipate that the economy will grind to a virtual standstill during the third quarter of this year and actually contract by 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter,'' Richard W. Rahn told a news conference. ``Our forecast shows the economy continuing to experience negative real growth in the first quarter of 1991 and practically no growth in the second quarter,'' he said. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve reported Wednesday that economic growth was slackening even before Iraq invaded Kuwait. In a July 27 survey of the Fed's 12 district banks, ``most noted that the pace was slow or had slackened recently,'' the central bank said in a report known as the Beige Book. Rahn blamed the softness on what he views as the Fed's misguided tight-money policy, aimed at controlling inflation. Brady said he and President Bush want the Federal Reserve to give economic growth a boost by lowering interest rates. The Treasury secretary said strong growth was particularly important now, as the United States responds to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``Everybody wants lower interest rates. ... At this point in time in the United States, economic growth is very important,'' he said. Brady expressed confidence that Federal Reserve policy-makers, who meet on Aug. 21, would lower rates in response to sluggish growth. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at an anemic 1.5 percent annual rate in the first half of 1990. ``The fact that the country is faced with slower growth will almost certainly produce lower interest rates,'' Brady said. Reducing the federal budget deficit also becomes more important as the United States tries to exert its influence in the Persian Gulf, he said. Private economists, however, contend that large spending cuts or tax increases would threaten a shaky economy and Brady conceded that deficit negotiations with Congress may produce a reduction other than the stated $50 billion goal. Brady also said he did not know if oil companies were taking advantage of consumers by raising gasoline prices so quickly after the invasion of Kuwait, But, he said, ``If people are gouging ... those that are doing the gouging will hear from the president.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Has Mightiest Armory in Arab Mideast
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's battle-hardened, 1 million-man army, powerful air force, and store of missiles and chemical weapons are the mightiest in the Arab world. Although Iraq is outgunned by the air and sea power of U.S. forces now being ranged against it, President Saddam Hussein can count on disciplined phalanxes fresh from the 8-year war with Iran and held in rein by fear. Saddam has repeatedly purged the officer corps since he rose to power in the mid-1970s, subordinating the armed forces to the ruling Baath party. If they were lucky, officers that didn't fall in line were simply retired. But many were executed, sometimes on trumped-up charges as an example to the others, Iraqi exiles have said. Iraqi author Samir al-Khalil wrote that in once instance Saddam drew his pistol and, before several other officers, shot a commander who made a ``tactical retreat'' because he didn't have the heart to order his forces to mow down an Iranian human-wave attack. There were constant reports during the war with Iran that morale in the ranks was flagging, not surprising in view of the battlefield standstill that set in after Iraq's initial victories early in the fighting. But none of them translated into mass desertions or major challenges to Saddam's rule, and the army remains its most powerful bastion along with the ruling party. By Middle East standards, Iraq's forces have an awesome armory, comparable only with Israel's. Before the latest crisis he had an army of 955,000, with another 45,000 in the navy and air force. Since invading Kuwait on Thursday, Saddam has announced the creation of new army divisions that could add at least 100,000 troops. Iraq's army has 5,500 battle tanks, 7,100 armored personnel carriers and 3,000 towed artillery pieces, according to the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. Iraq's 40,000-man air force flies 513 combat aircraft, mainly Soviet-made MiGs and French Mirages, including some armed with anti-ship Exocet missiles. In the Iran-Iraq war, Saddam's air force devastated Iran's oil production facilities and shipping. It was a French-made Exocet that crippled the U.S. frigate USS Stark, killing 37 American sailors in an attack Iraq said was a mistake. American officers who observed skirmishes during the Iran-Iraq war judged Iraqi pilots to be skillful but so wary of anti-aircraft defenses around Iran's big Kharg Island oil terminal that they often launched their missiles from maximum range of about 40 miles. This, the officers said, burned most of the missiles' fuel and effectively reduced their explosive power on impact. Saddam's arsenal has been bolstered by a recent buildup of sophisticated missiles, some capable of carrying chemical weapons, which Iraq used against Iran and also against its own rebellious Kurdish minority, killing thousands. In attacks on Iranian cities, Iraq used its Al Hussein missile, which has a 400-mile range. Iraq says it has now developed missiles with a 750-mile range. Iraq announced in December that it had launched a 48-ton, three-stage rocket capable of putting a satellite into space and had test-fired two surface-to-surface missiles with a range of 2,140 miles. Western intelligence sources confirmed the rocket launch, but said it was less successful than at first believed. They said the rocket only flew for two minutes, reaching an altitude of 12{ miles before plunging to earth. Nonetheless, some analysts believe it put Iraq on the threshold of ballistic missile capability. More fears about Saddam's military buildup were aroused earlier this year when British authorities intercepted a shipment to Iraq of what Western experts said were nuclear-bomb triggers. British customs officers also stopped shipments to Iraq of huge steel pipes that were described as parts of a giant ``super gun'' capable of firing chemical or nuclear shells several hundred miles. But analysts say Iraq is still years away from a nuclear capability. Amid growing concern in Israel and the West over his growing arsenal, Saddam in May threatened to destroy half of Israel with chemical weapons in the event of any Israeli attack. He proudly announced that Iraq had manufactured advanced binary chemical weapons _ the type that the United States has recently been destroying as it reduces its forces in the post-Cold War era. After last week's invasion, Iraq threatened to ``turn Kuwait into a graveyard'' if any outside force were to intervene. By comparison with the rest of his arsenal, Saddam's navy is puny. Most of it was sunk by Iranian warplanes and artillery early in the war, clogging up the Shatt-al-Arab waterway. The Shatt-al-Arab was Iraq's only outlet to the Persian Gulf _ until its conquest of Kuwait. The Iraqis have five frigates and 38 patrol ships, no match against the fleet of U.S. warships _ including three aircraft carriers _ being deployed in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Brigitte Bardot is demanding that Japan return a chimpanzee that a French zoo traded to a Japanese research institute for 10 monkeys. The former film star said during a meeting with Japanese Ambassador Akitani Kiuchi that the 10-year-old chimpanzee named Chloe was living ``worse than badly, in a frozen universe'' at the University of Kyoto's Primate Research Institute. Chloe was traded along with an orangutan by the Zoo de Vincennes in Paris for 10 macaque monkeys in 1984. The orangutan died earlier this year in a concrete cage, Ms. Bardot's Society for the Protection of Animals claimed. ``Chloe is in a basement, lacking sunlight, space, contact and especially lacks affection, like all laboratory subjects,'' it said in a statement. The type of research was not specified. The Japanese government will investigate Ms. Bardot's claims, a spokesman said. But he noted that the animal trade was made between private institutions. Ms. Bardot, 55, who rose to world fame in the 1956 movie ``And God Created Women,'' gave up her film career in 1973 and has since worked to protect animals.

Jessica Tandy had a chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Getting a driver in real life may be a little harder for the actress. Miss Tandy, 81, and her husband, actor Hume Cronyn, 79, wanted to build an apartment above their detached, three-car garage in case they find it necessary to hire domestic help, Cronyn said in a zoning application. But town zoning regulations require accessory apartments to be built in an existing house or adjacent to it, and the application was rejected. ``We can't afford to await an immediate crisis before making arrangements for the inevitable day when we must have someone on the premises who can drive a car and give us a hand in the house,'' Cronyn said in the application. Cronyn said his wife has heart trouble. He said he lost one eye to cancer and has a cataract in the other eye. Miss Tandy won a best actress Oscar earlier this year for her portrayal of an elderly widow in ``Driving Miss Daisy.''

A spokesman for Geraldo Rivera says a TV station caved in to a Fort Worth mother of two in dropping his afternoon talk show. ``It's certainly not a surprise, because the station has made several announcements over the past few months that it intended to drop the show because of pressure being brought to bear by one viewer,'' said Jeff Erdel. But Joe Bell, program manager for KDFW-TV, said a drop in ratings was the main reason ``Geraldo'' was not renewed. Lynda Beams has campaigned for nearly three years to have the syndicated show moved from its after-school time slot, complaining the program was unsuitable for children because it sometimes dealt with sex and violence. Her petition drive forced some sponsors to withdraw support for the show. Erdel on Wednesday said ``Geraldo'' has changed since December to become ``the cleanest, most wholesome talk show on television.'' ``The `Geraldo' shows have focused on such issues as education, child welfare, gun control and very relevant social issues, leaving the subjects of necrophilia and other sexual perversions to the other talk shows,'' he said.

Sheriff's deputies went to W. Axl Rose's apartment when neighbors complained that the Gun n' Roses lead singer was playing his stereo too loudly at night. That much is clear, but what happened next is in contention. Deputy George Ducoulombier, a Sheriff's Department spokesman, said several officers turned up at Rose's door shortly after midnight on Aug. 1, asked him to turn down the music and left. But Rose said about 13 officers with nightsticks tried to get in. The officers tried to provoke him and threatened to bring him down to the station, he said in a complaint filed with the department. ``As there was no cause or warrant to enter his home, Axl is left with the conclusion that this was an act of heavy-handed intimidation and a substantial violation of his civil rights,'' he said in a statement.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Lakers star Magic Johnson has withdrawn his name from consideration as a candidate for the board of trustees at his alma mater, Michigan State University. Members of Democratic Gov. James Blanchard's administration had pushed for his candidacy. Johnson spokesman Darwin Payton said the basketball star was excited to be considered but ``wants to wait until the end of his NBA career.'' Candidates for the Michigan State board are selected at the political conventions of the major parties. The nominees appear on the ballot in November. Johnson played for Michigan State's 1979 NCAA championship team. He left the university before earning a degree.

DOC.HEAD: Rich Kingdom Vulnerable to Social, Military Forces from Outside
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years ago, Saudi Arabia depended on the annual Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca for a significant portion of its revenue. The unprecedented oil wealth accumulated since then has helped it build a modern state and army. But balancing traditional Islamic political and social laws with the dizzying speed of development has always made the royal family feel vulnerable. The name ``Saudi Arabia'' is almost synonymous with oil. The estimated 255 billion barrels of oil lying beneath its deserts represent a quarter of known world reserves. The jump in prices in the 1970s from a few dollars to more than $40 per barrel brought staggering wealth. Saudi citizens are believed to have $200 billion in Western banks. The government has about $70 billion in financial reserves, down from $130 billion a decade ago due to low oil prices in the late 1980s. Spending has been prolific, with the annual budgets at about $35 billion. Defense spending in the projected 1990 budget was $13.8 billion, about 40 percent of the total. The Al-Saud rulers spent just $100 million on defense in 1971, fearful of spawning a competing power. The vast growth in the neighboring armed forces of Iraq, Iran and Israel, as well as the value of the oil reserves, changed that attitude. ``We are a very appealing piece of cake,'' former oil minister Ahmed Zaki Yamani once said. Geographically, Saudi Arabia is a massive desert except for the mountainous areas near the Red Sea. At roughly 873,000 square miles, it is about one-third the size of the United States. No formal census statistics exist. But the population is estimated at about 14 million, with more than 4.5 million foreigners. The local populaton is overwhelming Sunni Moslem. There is a Shiite minority in the eastern oil-producing province, often suspected of harboring sympathies for the Islamic revolution in largely Shiite Iran. Islam pervades the social, political, legal and cultural system of Saudi Arabia. It was shaped by Wahhabism, named after an 18th-century puritan. He sought to maintain Islam as it existed when the Prophet Mohammed founded the faith in Mecca in the 7th century. Women and men are strictly separated in public. Women are veiled, have a separate education system and are not allowed to drive. The modern state dates only to 1932, when the king known in the West as Ibn Saud unified a collection of tribal provinces. The tribe numbers about 4,000 princes. The few hundred directly involved in running the country control all significant posts. King Fahd is head of state, commander of chief of the armed forces and prime minister. His crown prince is his half-brother Prince Abdullah, head of the national guard. Next in line is Defense Minister Prince Sultan, a full brother of Fahd. Interior Minister Prince Naif is a full brother as is the governor of Riyadh, Prince Salman. All nine provincial governors are royals. Other prominent family members include Foreign Minister Prince Saud Al-Feisal, a son of the late King Feisal and nephew to Fahd. The ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar ibn Sultan, is son of the defense minister. Differences rarely spill into public, unless on the scale of the early 1960s fight to get the incompetent King Saud off the throne. Decision-making is done by consulting the princes and other powerful tribes. Each leader confers with the people through a majlis, or audiences that any Saudi male has the right to attend. The system builds consensus but is painfully slow. Thus the Saudi government has long relied on the United States to provide backup to its 60,000-man army in times of crisis. Thousands of U.S. military advisers live in Saudi Arabia to help with training. Saudi Arabia helped insulate the world economy from major oil supply interruptions by increasing production at crisis periods such as the 1979 revolution in Iran. But U.S.-Saudi relations have been rocky due to strong Israeli-American ties. The Saudi Arabian king's most prestigious title is ``Guardian of the Two Holy Cities,'' Mecca and Medina. The treasury once depended totally on what Moslem pilgrims spent on their annual visit. As long as the third holiest city, Jerusalem, remains under Israeli control, detractors like Iran can challenge the Al-Saud role as guardians of the faith. Saudi Arabia has always avoided allowing U.S. forces openly into the country out of fear their presence would help an internal opposition jell. An air base near Dhahran was closed in 1962. The United States has been sensitive to the need for Saudi Arabia to keep its distance. ``We must continue to recognize that preserving Saudi Arabia's own stability requires the government to maintain a posture of independence,'' Secretary of State Alexander Haig said during one of the bruising congressional battles Saudi Arabia went through to acquire sophisticated U.S. weapons. The Israeli lobby in Congress always sought to block the sales.

DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian Lets Town Use Bequest for Library
DOC.TEXT: The Smithsonian Institution has agreed not to interfere with this seaside town's plan to use a $1 million bequest to convert an old school into a public library. The dispute was over the will of Franz Denghausen, a sculptor and poet who lived in Rockport for 36 years. He died childless in 1987 and left $1 million to the town to replace the turn-of-the-century Carnegie Library. The Smithsonian gets at least $3 million more from Denghausen's estate. Ambiguous wording of one phrase in the will had led the Smithsonian to argue that the town had to spend its own money for the renovations and use the bequest only for operating and maintaining the new library. The Smithsonian on Friday agreed to drop its challenge. ``This is really a terrific resolution to what was a thorny and complex problem,'' said Attorney General James Shannon, whose office supported Rockport's position and tried to settle the dispute. Because Rockport cannot afford the renovations without the bequest, the $1 million would have gone to the Smithsonian if the museum had prevailed, Shannon said. Smithsonian spokeswoman Madeleine Jacobs said the museum simply wanted good relations with the town. ``It was just getting to be a very, very unhappy story,'' she said. Jacobs said the Smithsonian had received about 40 letters criticizing its position. ``We were greatly distressed that our motives were misinterpreted,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 27,615.73, down 893.41 points, or 3.13 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bovine Boot Salesman Says Shoe's on the Other Hoof
LaserPhoto SUC2 of Aug. 8
DOC.TEXT: Jim Wells is used to snickers over his boots for bovines, but he doesn't care so long as dairy farmers keep snatching them up. ``That's everybody's first reaction. It's comical to see a cow wearing a boot,'' said Wells. ``They come over, make a joke about it, then ask what the boot is for. Then I've got them.'' The clothing store owner introduced his Shoes for Moos a year ago in eight countries, including Canada, the Soviet Union and Japan. Since then, he has sold more than 15,000 of the boots at $50 apiece to help the hooves of dairy cows heal from corns, ulcers, hoof rot and other infections. Paul Larkin, a dairy farmer from Hamilton, grinned as he looked over the boot recently at a farm trade show in Seneca Falls. He walked away with one under his arm. ``It's bad news when you have a cow with hoof rot or some other kind of foot infection. I'm always looking for the better way and this looked like one,'' Larkin said. The boot is a shorter version of a firefighter's boot. It's made of fabric-backed rubber with two bright yellow straps and buckles. It has a pebble-textured bottom for traction. Usually, when a cow develops hoof trouble, the animal is given antibiotics and the foot is bandaged and wrapped in plastic bags to keep the dressing dry. ``Plastic bags, as you can imagine, aren't the best fit. Cows will rub them, chew at them or whatever until they come off,'' Wells said. ``They can't do that with the boot.'' Some farmers use old galoshes, but they wear out easily. Others use disposable diapers. There are 2{ million dairy cows in Canada and 11 million in the United States. Capturing just 1 percent of the market would mean sales of $6.5 million. ``Three years ago, I didn't know a thing about cows. But a couple of Mennonite farmers came into my store and bought rubber boots for their cows,'' he said. ``After talking to them, I realized there was an untapped niche there.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Religious Group to Distribute Correction to Pamphlet
DOC.TEXT: A conservative religious group that cropped pictures of an artist's work to suggest that it was sexually explicit has been ordered by a federal judge to distribute a correction to the pamphlet. The American Family Association of Tupelo, Miss., had reprinted fragments of images by David A. Wojnarowicz to promote the organization's contention that the National Endowment for the Arts supports pornography. The ruling Wednesday by U.S. District Judge William C. Conner came in a lawsuit by Wojnarowicz. The judge said the pamphlet had probably harmed the artist's professional and personal reputation. Conner barred further publication of the pamphlet, ``Your Tax Dollars Helped Pay for These Works of Arts.'' He also awarded $1 in damages to Wojnarowicz, who had sought up to $1 million. He said Wojnarowicz had not proved financial damage because no galleries or museums had canceled exhibits of his work. Conner said the Amercan Family Association must send a court-approved correction to the 4,000 churches, members of Congress and other individuals who received the pamphlet. The association and its executive director, the Rev. Donald Wildmon, have for years led campaigns against films, music, TV shows, magazines and art that they deem obscene. Wildmon had objected to several of Wojnarowicz's works exhibited this year at the Illinois State University Galleries. A catalog of reproductions of 60 of his paintings, collages and photographs was partly financed by the NEA. Wildmon's son, Tim, said the association had not decided whether to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bush Aide Testifies Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A national security aide to George Bush when he was vice president has testified before a federal grand jury conducting a criminal investigation of the Iran-Contra affair. G. Philip Hughes, who has been nominated by President Bush to be U.S. ambassador to Barbados, declined to discuss his testimony Wednesday after being questioned by Iran-Contra prosecutors in front of the grand jury empaneled at the U.S. Courthouse. Hughes until recently was the National Security Council's executive secretary. He was deputy assistant for national security affairs to Bush from 1981 to 1985. In 1985 and 1986, Hughes met periodically with North when Hughes was the National Security Council's director for Latin American affairs. At the time, North was running a secret network to resupply the Nicaraguan Contras. The network operated during a two-year congressional ban on U.S. military to the rebel force. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office, declined to make any comment on Hughes' grand jury appearance.

DOC.HEAD: Air Rifles Being Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Crosman Products is recalling nearly 53,000 air rifles that may have a defective trigger mechanism. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday the company is recalling its Model 3100 air rifle, which has been sold nationally since July 1986 and may contain an improperly hardened sear in its trigger. If the sear is not properly hardened, it may wear prematurely and the consumer may not be able to cock the airgun, the commission said. If the gun is cocked with a defective sear, it could discharge without the trigger being pulled _ even if the safety mechanism is engaged. Consumers who own Crosman Model 3100 air rifles should discontinue use and call the company toll free at 1-800-836-3100 for instructions. The line is open from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. EDT, Monday through Friday. The East Bloomfield, N.Y., company will inspect all returned rifles, replace defective sears and return the airguns at no charge.
DOC.HEAD: Study: Many Americans Can't Afford Necessities After Housing Costs
DOC.TEXT: A third of Americans spend so much for housing they can't afford other necessities of life, according to a new study. The report issued Wednesday by the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal economic research organization, said 27 million households ``are unable to meet their non-shelter needs at even a minimum level of adequacy'' because of high housing costs. Those households contain 78 million people, or 32 percent of the population, the organization said. The study said 42 percent of all who rent their homes were ``shelter poor'' in 1987, the last year of the study. Twenty-two percent of homeowners were in that category, it said. The study's author, Michael E. Stone, professor of community planning at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, used an index that assumes a family pays its rent or mortgage first, then uses what income is left to pay for basic needs such as food, clothing, transportation and medical care. He concludes that people are ``shelter poor'' if their household has too little left after paying the housing costs to afford the minimum basic necessities, as defined by the federal government's bureau of labor statistics low budget standards. His report contends that growth in one and two-person households since 1970 has concealed an increase in housing affordability problems experienced by families with children. The ``shelter poverty'' rate for one and two-person households declined from 32 percent to 26 percent during the period, while the rate for households with three or more people rose from 29 percent to 34 percent. The problem is worst among the poorest one-third of households, but also affects some middle-income households, particularly renters, the study said. The study said the average ``shelter poor'' household faced a gap of $290 a month between what they were paying and could afford for housing.
DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit by Former Chicago-Philadelphia Agent Against FBI Settled
DOC.TEXT: The FBI says it has settled a lawsuit filed against it by a black agent who complained he had been a victim of racial discrimination. The FBI statement announcing the agreement Wednesday did not give details, including whether any payment was made to Donald Rochon, a special agent who sued over alleged discrimination against him in the bureau's Chicago office. In January the FBI settled racial discrimination complaints by two other employees, Leadell Lee, a Chicago agent, and Gertie Armstrong, a clerk in Omaha. Rochon's suit in U.S. District Court in Washington alleged he was the butt of racial jokes and death threats in the Chicago office. Rochon also had worked in Omaha and complained of racial harassment there. That complaint was upheld in administrative proceedings and was not part of the lawsuit. Rochon had been assigned to the Philadelphia office, but the FBI statement said part of the settlement provided that he ``will not return to active duty with the FBI.''

DOC.HEAD: Electronics Company Accused of Defense Fraud
DOC.TEXT: An electronics company and two executives have been indicted on charges of falsely certifying the quality of parts for the space shuttle and numerous weapons. Impala Electronics Inc. was charged by a federal grand jury Wednesday along with Joseph A. Pistone, owner and president, and James Wilson, sales manager. Both live in Tampa. Government officials said there is no indication of safety problems caused by the alleged scheme. Impala parts are in the shuttle's main engines, MX missiles, B1-B bombers, Tomahawk and Harpoon missiles and components of the ``Star Wars'' anti-missile program. According to the indictment, low-quality resistors were falsely marked as superior in reliability and other qualities. In addition, the resistors allegedly were designated as newer than they actually were. Resistors are small components that control current in an electrical circuit. Impala was charged with operating a criminal enterprise, filing false statements with government agencies and conspiring since 1971 to defraud the government. If convicted, the company could be fined $4 million. Impala's telephones have been disconnected and officials could not be reached for comment. Pistone, 47, could get up to 110 years in prison and $4.75 million in fines. Wilson, 46, faces up to 75 years in prison. The indictment stemmed from a yearlong investigation prompted by a tip to the Pentagon.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Believe Tiny Skull Oldest Mammal on Record
DOC.TEXT: Scientists claim to have found a tiny skull of a shrew-like mammal that lived 10 million years before the oldest mammal on record. A team of paleontologists from the New Mexico Museum of Natural History found the fossil near Lubbock, Texas. ``What we've done is pushed back the record of mammals worldwide by 10 million years,'' said Spencer Lucas, curator of paleontology at the Albuquerque museum and head of the team. Scientists hope the fossil, which is smaller than a dime, will be an important link in the evolutionary chain between reptiles and mammals. The skull apparently belonged to a shrew-like animal with some features common to reptiles and mammals and is 220 million years old, Lucas said. That's 10 million years older than the Morganucodon, a British fossil believed to be that of the oldest mammal in the world, and 25 million years older than the previously oldest mammal fossil found in North America. ``Ten years from now, this mammal will be included in man's understanding of the origin of mammals ... and the history of life,'' Lucas said. University of Chicago professor James Hopson, considered an authority on the link between reptiles and mammals, saw the fossil at the American Museum of Natural History in New York and said it probably belongs to the oldest known mammal. ``The area it comes from is older than beds in other parts of the world where early mammals came from, such as in China, England, South Africa and Arizona,'' Hopson said Wednesday. Openings in the brain casing indicate the mammal had a more complex inner ear and circulatory system than reptiles, Lucas said.

DOC.HEAD: Kitty Dukakis Says the White House Would Have Sent Her Over the Edge
DOC.TEXT: Kitty Dukakis says if her husband had become president, the pressure of life in the White House would have sent her over the edge. ``I am certain the first crisis would have sent me out of control,'' the wife of Gov. Michael Dukakis said in her book, ``Now You Know,'' excerpted in the current issue of Good Housekeeping and reported in today's Boston Globe. ``I am equally certain that, thrust into the smothering, protective confines of the White House, I would not have been able to seek proper help.'' Mrs. Dukakis acknowledged her drug and alcohol addiction and blamed many of her problems on her mother, Jane Goldberg Dickson, and on her discovery that her mother was an adopted child of illegitimate birth. Mrs. Dickson died in 1977. Mrs. Dukakis said she panicked before the New Hampshire primary in 1988 when she realized her husband might win. ``Michael was good enough to be president, for sure, but was I worthy to be his partner? In my despair, I turned to alcohol,'' she said. Mrs. Dukakis wrote of periods of heavy drinking during the campaign and after her husband's loss to George Bush as well. She said she began a typical day at 9 a.m. by canceling her appointments and downing three or four ounces of straight liquor. ``Then I'd go upstairs, shut the blinds, unplug the phone, and read till I passed out _ a process that usually took no more than 10 minutes. Two and a half hours later, I would wake up and repeat the process,'' she said. The book, written with Jane Scovell, is due out in the fall. Mrs. Dukakis said she was 18 when cousin revealed that her mother had been adopted. She said she was ``thunderstruck'' when she learned that the couple she knew as her grandparents were her mother's adoptive parents, and that the woman who lived with the couple as a nanny was actually Mrs. Dukakis' grandmother. ``As far as I was concerned, there had been an enormous breach of trust. That traumatic moment haunted me for years,'' Mrs. Dukakis wrote. Within a year, Mrs. Dukakis said, she started using amphetamines, or diet pills, discovered in her mother's room. She said her mother ``took a lot of pills, including mood-altering ones,'' and also was fond of alcohol. ``My mother was an extraordinary cook. But she never cooked a meal without a glass of vermouth sitting on the counter next to her. It was continuously filled,'' Mrs. Dukakis said. In the book, Mrs. Dukakis wondered if her 20-year addiction to pills may have been responsible for four miscarriages she had during her two marriages. She said her moods changed quickly whenever she stopped using pills, causing her to fight with her husband and children. Mrs. Dukakis, who is taking lithium for manic depression, wrote that when she was hospitalized for drinking rubbing alcohol last year, she was not suicidal.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia Patient Allison Atlas Comfortable Before Bone Marrow Transplant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Transplant begins 4 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Leukemia patient Allison Atlas, whose nationwide plea for a perfectly matched bone-marrow donor drew 50,000 people to no avail, rested today in a hospital before transplant surgery to receive her mother's marrow. The operation was scheduled for noon at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center. The procedure could last as long as six hours. Miss Atlas, 20, of Bethesda, Md., decided to accept bone marrow from her mother, even though it does not perfectly match her own, while she was still strong enough to undergo the operation. Arline Atlas' marrow matches four of six antigens, or cell identifers, in her daughter's marrow. The Atlas family mounted a search last fall for a perfect donor. About 50,000 people in the United States and Israel took blood tests to determine their chances, but none was suitable for Ms. Atlas. Ten other people with leukemia found perfectly matched donors as a result of the flood of new listings with the National Marrow Donor Program. A support group, Friends of Allison, raised $3 million for processing the samples. Actor Dustin Hoffman donated a six-figure sum and made public appeals for help. Miss Atlas, who was a student at New York Unversity until she became ill last year, was admitted to Fred Hutchinson on July 26. She began chemotherapy July 31 to destroy her diseased marrow and has responded well, center spokeswoman Alice Burgess said. Blood-producing marrow is a key element in the body's immune system, and transplant recipients are extremely vulnerable to infection immediately after the procedure, before the new marrow begins functioning.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's New Government Announces Harsh Austerity Program
DOC.TEXT: The new government of President Alberto Fujimori has announced a harsh austerity plan aimed at ending hyperinflation and rebuilding a collapsed economy. Troops were deployed to head off any food riots. Subsidy cuts and a lifting of price controls mean Peruvians will pay a lot more for food, gasoline and basic services, Economy and Prime Minister Juan Hurtado Miller said in a nationally televised speech Wednesday night. Hurtado said a gallon of gasoline would cost 30 times more today. The price of milk and bread were to triple, while noodles were to cost five times what they did Wednesday, he said. ``This is the price we must pay,'' said Hurtado. ``This is the period for cleaning up and detoxifying.'' The tough policy is a switch from the campaign platform of gradual reform that helped catapult Fujimori from a virtual unknown at the beginning of the year to the victor in the June election. His opponent, acclaimed novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, had backed speedy market-oriented reform. But Fujimori, who took office July 28, has been told by international creditors that he must control inflation before they'll lend him more money. Soldiers and police took up positions throughout the capital before Hurtado's speech. On Tuesday, the government declared a state of emergency in Lima and 10 large cities, fearing food riots would break out after the austerity measures were announced. Mobs on Tuesday looted the central markets of both Lima and the nearby port of Callao before being controlled by police and soldiers. Bread, noodles, beans, sugar, cooking oil and milk have all disappeared from store shelves in recent days. This was due to both panic-buying by consumers and hoarding by merchants, who were awaiting higher prices. Most stores and market stalls remained closed in the hours before Hurtado spoke. In his speech, Hurtado vowed to cut inflation to ``less than the Latin American average'' by the end of the year. He said the government will increase its income and spend only what it earns. All price controls and subsidies will end, he said. The austerity measures also include emergency taxes on the wealthy and a restructuring of import duties, Hurtado said. Press reports have said the government plans to devalue Peru's inti by at least 50 percent, though Hurtado made no mention of such a move Wednesday. To soften the effects of the measures on Peru's millions of poor people, the government will set up soup kitchens and directly subsidize water and bus services, Hurtado said. Fujimori has said that harsh measures are needed to stop Peru's fall into economic chaos. Annual inflation tops 3,000 percent, four of five people lack steady work and the economy has shrunk 20 percent in two years. Fujimori has taken office with Peru in the midst of its worst drought this century, with up to 70 percent of the yearly production of many basic crops destroyed. He must also deal with a worsening guerrilla war that in the past 10 years has claimed 20,000 victims. Tension in the capital increased in the days leading up to Hurtado Miller's announcement. The dollar doubled in value in the first three days of the week, with its price jumping from 200,000 intis to 400,000. Many stores doubled their prices even before Hurtado spoke Wednesday, getting a jump on the expected end of price controls. Other stores remained closed for fear that looting would break out. Most market stalls were shuttered and those were open displayed vastly reduced stocks. Drivers formed lines dozens of cars long to fill up before gasoline prices jumped. The state of emergency declared in Lima and 10 other large cities means that most of Peru is now under special law. A state of emergency is already in effect in half the country due to guerrilla activity. It suspends constitutional guarantees of freedom of travel and assembly and allows authorities to detain people without hearing and search houses without warrant.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Dollar Drop
DOC.TEXT: Growing pessimism over the Middle East set stock prices nose-diving in Tokyo today, and the dollar fell moderately against the Japanese yen, traders said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 893.41 points, or 3.13 percent, ending the day at 27,615.73, its lowest level since Oct. 25, 1987, when the key index closed at 27,421.49. Traders said the Nikkei's fall quickened toward the end of afternoon trading, when major securities houses such as Nomura Securities Co. filed large sell orders in an attempt to take profits between spot and the futures markets before today's expiration of August options. ``The market was extremely weak, and almost no one was interested in buying stocks,'' said Yoshio Ogawa, chief trader at Nikko Securities Co. He said investors had become increasingly pessimistic about the Middle East conflict, which they believe will be prolonged. The Tokyo stock market, already vulnerable due to higher interest rates, has lost 4,348.01 points since July 20. ``It is rather natural for the index to plunge,'' said Masahiro Yagi, deputy director of the capital trading department at Sanwa Bank. ``The Japanese stock market has been suffering from increasing interest rates, and that's the fundamental problem.'' Yagi said the Bank of Japan will have to raise its discount rate, now 5.25 percent, at some point. He said the Nikkei's 856.07-point surge on Wednesday was ``too much considering the Middle East situation and rising interest rates here.'' The market has not bottomed out, he added. Trading was thin today, with volume on the market's first section estimated at 380 million shares, down from Wednesday's 580 million. About 5 percent of the issues remained unpriced with no buy orders during the day. In contrast, the yen rose against the dollar as optimistic currency investors sold the U.S. currency to take profits from its surge following last Thursday's invasion by Iraq of Kuwait, dealers said. The U.S. currency has gained 3.03 yen since last Thursday. The dollar closed at 149.68 yen, down 0.32 yen from Wednesday's 150.00-yen finish. It opened at 149.50 yen and ranged between 149.50 yen and 149.90 yen. ``Currency investors think the Middle East situation will not get much worse, because many countries are jointly putting pressure on Iraq,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The U.N. Security Council voted Monday for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq. The major industrial nations have already begun sanctions, including an oil boycott. As higher prices and other negative effects of the Iraqi-Kuwaiti conflict have been gradually factored into the market, investors began selling the dollar, which they had overbought as a safe haven in the wake of the Iraqi invasion last week, Ms. Takeuchi said. She said a declining trend in oil prices, which had surged to about $28 a barrel earlier this week, also encouraged the yen's strength against the dollar. Traders said the slide in oil prices resulted from prospects for higher oil production by Saudi Arabia and other producers. At about 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at about $23.60-$23.70 a barrel, down from $26.00-$26.20 Wednesday. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 7.985 percent, up from Wednesday's close of 7.915 percent. Their price ended at 83.52 points, down from 83.80 points.

DOC.HEAD: Union Auto Worker Turns Down Prize Car
DOC.TEXT: Pamela Richards became a hero at the auto parts plant where she works when she refused on a game show to accept a new car made at a non-union factory. But when the show aired a night after it was recorded, censors deleted her explanation for rejecting the $17,500 Honda Accord. ``I was disappointed when they bleeped out my comment. I didn't slam Honda. I just wanted to get across that I'm proud to be a union member,'' Mrs. Richards, a member of United Auto Workers, said Wednesday. Mrs. Richards has worked 23 years at Toledo Precision Machining, a Chrysler Corp. subsidiary in Risingsun, a town of 700 about 30 miles from Toledo. The UAW has been trying for years without success to organize employees at Honda's U.S. plants in Marysville, 100 miles from of Risingsun. Mrs. Richards was one of four contestants competing for cash and Ohio-made prizes on an Ohio Lottery TV show videotaped Friday and broadcast Saturday. When her turn came to choose from 24 boxes containing cash and prizes, she picked one that revealed she had won an Accord made in Marysville. She had the choice of accepting the car and ending her participation or taking the cash prize in the same box and continuing. ``I don't want that Honda. I am union,'' she said, accepting instead the cash prize of $1,000. Ultimately, she won $6,400. At Toledo Precision Machining, workers hung a banner commending her loyalty. ``It make me feel good. But I'm sure others at the plant would have done the same thing,'' Mrs. Richards said. ``The union has given me a lot through the years. A lot of benefits, wage increases, security when I retire. I feel if they could give me this all these years, I can buy union-made products.'' Marcus Advertising, which produces the TV program, made the decision to edit her criticism of Honda. James Reed, a Marcus account supervisor, defended the editing, saying companies often provide the prizes at deep discounts. Bob Kowalcyzk, marketing director for the Ohio Lottery Commission, said the censors may have overreacted. ``It is not necessarily a forum for free speech. But what are we messing with when we make these kind of decisions?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Israel And Iraq Trade Threats
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Iraq would be inviting a ``heavy tragedy'' if it attacked Israel over allegations the Jewish state was sending forces to assist the U.S. defense of Saudi Arabia. The concern was triggered by Iraq's claim on Wednesday that camouflaged Israeli planes were participating in the U.S. military build-up in the Persian Gulf. The Israeli army vehemently denied the allegations. Media reports suggested preparations were in full gear to defend against a possible strike by Iraq, which invaded Kuwait a week ago and is reported to have massed 100,000 troops on the Saudi border. ``Whoever plots to attack Israel must know that Israel has the capability, will and readiness to defend its security absolutely, and whoever tries to hurt it is liable to bring on himself a heavy tragedy,'' Shamir said on Israel radio. He assured Arab nations ``Israel has no intentions whatsoever to attack any of its neighbors.'' But he added, ``Israel's defense and security forces are aware and alert and devoting their efforts to prevent any danger to the people and state.'' Defense Minister Moshe Arens and other leaders also said they took the Iraqi threat seriously. Newspaper editorials called for distribution of gas masks to defend against a possible assault by chemical weapons. Shamir also ordered Cabinet ministers traveling abroad to prepare to return, officials in his office said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, Israelis have remained glued to their radios, hoping that their ally the United States would rein in Saddam's aggression. Jerusalem and Baghdad traded threats in April, when Saddam said he would torch half of Israel with chemical weapons if attacked by the Jewish state. The Iraqi statement Wednesday was widely seen as a possible pretext for such an attack. ``Israeli warplanes were painted with American colors and Israeli pilots were provided with American identity papers in order to avoid Iraq's reaction against Israel,'' said a statement broadcast on Baghdad radio. ``We hereby warn ... that we will answer back to any aggressive act by Israel, as we would to any such act by the United States,'' the Iraqi statement added. Israel today was faced with the delicate dilemma of warding off Iraq's threats while trying to refrain from involvement in the Persian Gulf conflict. Analysts said there was concern that any Israeli intervention could also run the risk of Israel getting into a war with Iraq's Arab allies. On Wednesday, Shamir expressed support for the U.S. move into Saudi Arabia as a show of force against Iraq, whose 1-million-man army poses the most dangerous Arab threat to Israel. But officials also said the United States had not asked Israel to commit troops to the Persian Gulf, and that such a request was not expected. The army has decided in principle to distribute gas masks to the entire population over the next six months, army officials said. Israelis, increasingly anxious over Iraq's military expansion had already begun stockpiling canned goods in their attics and looking for gas masks to purchase. Israeli generals held an emergency meeting last weekend and decided to step up the distribution of gas masks nationwide, but some Israelis are too jittery to wait for the army-issued equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``There are some indications that he's already beginning to feel the pinch. Nobody can stand up forever to total economic deprivation.'' _ President Bush on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein.

``If someone would have told me the day of the bill signing that S&Ls would be the No. 1 issue and the crisis would look even worse than it did a year ago, I would have said, `You're crazy.''' _ Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the House Banking Committee, one year after President Bush signed landmark savings and loan bailout legislation.

``I believe the United States shares our desire to bring peace to Liberia and halt the daily carnage there, especially around Monrovia, urgently and we are hoping that this operation will get the support of America.'' _ Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida, as a five-nation West African peacekeeping force prepared to move into war-ravaged Liberia.

DOC.HEAD: Showers over Middle Atlantic States, Heat Wave Lingers in West
DOC.TEXT: Showers were scattered over the Middle Atlantic states today, and a heat wave lingered in most the nation's interior. Today's forecast said thunderstorms were likely to develop over the Carolinas, Virginia, Florida, Georgia, Wisconsin and northeastern California. Rain also was likely in Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Temperatures were expected to soar above 90 degrees over much of the Plains and the West, and exceed 100 west of the Rockies and in the desert Southwest. On Wednesday, temperatures pushed above 100 across much of the West as far north as Washington and Idaho. Pasco, Wash., reached 103 and Ontario, Ore., hit 105. In Georgia, thunderstorms produced large hail near Roswell, toppled trees at Stathams Landing and near Veazey, and downed power lines and trees near Rockledge, Lothar and Soperton. Thunderstorms produced winds gusting to 55 mph in Atlanta and hail as large as golf balls in Marion County, Fla. The high temperature for the nation was 121 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Dart Man OK to Stand Trial, Charges Lowered
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of being the ``Dart Man'' who shot pins into women's buttocks was found mentally competent to stand trial. But the charges were downgraded from felonies to misdemeanors and he was freed on bail. Criminal Court Judge John Walsh released Jerome Wright, 33, on $1,000 bail Wednesday. The reduced charges mean Wright would face only a year in jail if convicted on a weapons possession charge, said Colleen Roche, spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. She would not explain why the charges were reduced. Wright, who made a rambling statement to police after his arrest, was examined by psychiatrists and ruled fit to stand trial. Police believe Wright used a blowgun to fire homemade darts fashioned from pins and paper at 55 women, all wearing skirts. The attacks, mostly in midtown Manhattan, took place between June 13 and his arrest on July 13. Wright was charged in only two attacks. Assistant District Attorney John Sullivan requested permission Wednesday for another two victims to see Wright in a lineup. Defense attorney Robert Wolf said he has evidence Wright was at work when the attacks occurred. In addition to the weapons charge, Wright faces two misdemeanor counts of reckless endangerment and two misdemeanor counts of harassment.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Back at Hangar; Columbia Heading Out
DOC.TEXT: In an unprecedented shuttle shuffle, NASA returned Atlantis to the hangar today for repair of a hydrogen leak and sent a newly fixed Columbia out to the launch pad to await a September liftoff. Columbia had been rolled back to the hangar in June because of a hydrogen leak. It was the first time two shuttles had passed one another in upright launch positions. ``It's interesting both are passing, but it's unfortunate one's having to be brought back off the pad,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. Atlantis began the 3{-mile trip to the hangar Wednesday night and arrived around 4 a.m., nearly six hours later. NASA parked Atlantis outside the doors of the crowded hangar, and around daybreak rolled Columbia out past Atlantis toward the vacated pad. Atlantis was expected to be inside the hangar by mid-afternoon, after Columbia was secured at the pad. Until June, NASA had moved a shuttle from the launch pad back to the hangar on only three occasions, the most recent in 1985. During its two months in the hangar, Columbia's leaky fuel lines were replaced with components from the new shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. NASA is working toward a Sept. 4 or 5 liftoff of Columbia with the $150 million Astro observatory. Atlantis' secret military mission, originally scheduled for July, is off until November. Columbia's leak was detected during fueling for a May 30 launch attempt. The leak on Atlantis was discovered during a test June 29. Atlantis' leak prompted NASA to ground the three-shuttle fleet temporarily. Agency officials have since determined the leaks on the two spaceships are different.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Lower In Cautious Trading, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was slightly lower in cautious European trading late this morning as dealers awaited fresh developments in the Persian Gulf. Gold prices rose more than $3.50 an ounce in London but were fractionally lower in Zurich. Currency dealers ascribed the dollar's relative steadiness to the absence of major news from the Middle East overnight. ``The whole market has calmed down,'' said a trader at Commerzbank AG in Frankfurt. ``I think the market is consolidating.'' Another trader at a major West German bank in Frankfurt said the market remained nervous about a possible outbreak of Mideast fighting. He said the dollar could jump several pfennigs if hostilities are reported. In Milan, one trader said: ``The dollar has completely lost its role as a `safe haven' currency.'' He added that the U.S. currency is poised to move lower in the near term because of soft U.S. interest rates. But in the longer term, he said, there ``will be physical demand for dollars to pay for higher oil prices'' and this will push the dollar back up. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.32 yen to a closing 149.68 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 149.60 yen. Japanese dealers said a bout of profit-taking followed dollar's surge following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait a week ago. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.5917 West German marks, down from 1.5940 _1.3397 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435 _5.3358 French francs, down from 5.3445 _1.7915 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7955 _1,165.00 Italian lire, down from 1,166.37 _1.1475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1485 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.8720, compared with $1.8660 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $382.80 a troy ounce, up from $382.25 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a higher recommended price of $385.85. London dealers said trading was volatile amid nervousness over the direction of oil prices and developments in the Persian Gulf. In Zurich, the bid price was $384.25, down from $384.35 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.52 to close at a bid $384.17. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.89 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.87.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Cosmonauts Return After Problem-Plagued Mission
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet cosmonauts returned safely to Earth today, ending a six-month mission during which they grew million-dollar crystals for industry and survived a near-fatal space walk trying to repair damage on their capsule. The Soyuz TM-9 capsule carrying cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin landed near the town on Arkalyk on the Central Asian steppes, the official Tass news agency reported. The landing, one minute ahead of schedule, was not shown live on Soviet television, but at the midday news showed pictures of the cosmonauts waving goodbye to their replacement crew aboard the orbiting Mir space station. Solovyev and Balandin were launched into space Feb. 11 in what was billed as the first manned mission in the 33-year history of the Soviet space program to turn a multimillion-dollar profit. Their hundreds of experiments included photographing 8.4 million square miles of the Earth's surface and growing 23 pure crystals for use in semiconductors and computer chips. Each crystal is worth about $1 million, Tass said. The cosmonauts also made two space walks last month, the first to repair damage caused to the spacecraft on takeoff. On July 17, they spent seven hours repairing torn thermal insulation surrounding the Soyuz capsule which would bring them back to Earth. The repairs took longer than expected and Soviet media reported the two cosmonauts could have died because their oxygen was running so low. Their spacesuits soaked with perspiration from the exertion, they were forced to leave the capsule's re-entry hatch slightly ajar and return to the space station through an emergency porthole. They left behind handrails attached to the exterior of the capsule. A second, shorter, space walk on July 26 was needed to close the hatch and retrieve the handrails. Tass quoted ground control officials as saying Solovyev and Balandin had opened the hatch before the airlock was completely depressurized and it swung outward with such force that a key joint was damaged. It was the latest in a series of problems for the Soviet manned space program, which for decades had been a source of intense national pride. For the past two years, the program has been plagued by docking equipment malfunctions, human error and budget cuts. The replacement crew of Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov docked with the Mir on Friday, two days after blasting off from the Baikanor Space Center in Kazakhstan. They will remain in space until Dec. 10, conducting an estimated 250 experiments, including the production of more crystals. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pressure has grown on the space program to prove its worth in a shortage-plagued society. Some Soviet lawmakers have raised the once taboo topic of cutting the space budget since many Soviet people don't have decent housing or enough to eat. Manakov and Strekalov will return to Earth with a paying customer, a Japanese cosmonaut who will have been brought to Mir on Dec. 2 by their replacement crew. Two employees of the Tokyo Broadcasting System are vying for the seat: television camerawoman Ryoko Kikuchi and former Washington bureau chief Toyhiro Akiyama. Future flights in 1992 will carry British, Austrian, West German, French and Spanish passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Hostage Freed, But Colleague Still Held in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese kidnappers early today released a Swiss Red Cross worker from 10 months of captivity, but one of his colleagues remained a hostage. It was the first release of a Western hostage since two Americans were freed in April. Officials denied any deal was made for today's release. Emanuel Christen, 33, was set free just after midnight Wednesday by a group calling itself The Palestinian Revolutionary Squads. The group had said in a statement Tuesday that his colleague _ 24-year-old Elio Erriquez _ would also be released. There was no immediate explanation for why only Christen was freed. A total of 15 Westerners, including Erriquez, remain hostage in Lebanon. They include six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Christen was handed over to Swiss Charge d'Affaires Fritz Kuehni at the Syrian Foreign Ministry in Damascus, witnesses said. They said Kuehni and Christen were then driven to the Swiss Embassy. A member of the Swiss embassy in Damascus, Claudine Zbinden, said Christen had lost about 30 pounds. ``But he is in relative good shape, if one may say so,'' Ms. Zbinden said today in a telephone interview. Red Cross officials said Christen was expected to return to Switzerland by special flight due to arrive in Zurich this afternoon. Christen and Erriquez were kidnapped Oct. 6. Both were orthopedic technicians helping to manufacture artificial limbs for Lebanon's war wounded in the southern city of Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. In Beirut, his kidnappers issued a statement Wednesday night, but it did not explain why only one captive went free. ``After we have promised last night to release the two delegates of the International Red Cross in Lebanon within 24 hours, one of them, Emanuel Christen, has been set free and handed over to a representative of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan at 6 p.m. this evening,'' said the text in full. It was handwritten in Arabic. The statement, signed by The Palestinian Revolutionary Squads, was delivered to the Beirut office of a Western news agency. It was accompanied by an instant photograph of Christen. Kenaan is the chief of Syrian army intelligence in Lebanon, whose headquarters are in the east Lebanon village of Anjar in the Bekaa valley. The statement said the decision to free the Red Cross captives came in response to the wishes of Syrian President Hafez Assad, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi and Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid. Both the Swiss Foreign Ministry and the Geneva-headquartered International Committee of the Red Cross denied that any deal had been made with the kidnappers. In their statement Tuesday, the Palestine Revolutionary Squads said they had decided to free the two Swiss ``after we acquired guarantees that our demands will be met.'' But Foreign Ministry spokesman Michel Pache said Swiss authorities never had any contact with the kidnappers. ``We never knew who they were and what they wanted.'' The longest held foreign hostage in Lebanon is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The two most recently freed hostages were Americans Frank Herbert Reed, 57, and Robert Polhill, 55. Both were freed in April.

DOC.HEAD: Air Raid Sirens Wail in Amman
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with state news agency saying sirens were unannounced test. Picks up 5th pvs, `Despite the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Air raid sirens wailed in Amman today. A government security official said Israeli jets had violated Jordanian air space but the official news agency said it was an unannounced test. The official, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said he had no immediate additional information. The siren warning came at 1:15 p.m. as the streets of the capital were jammed with traffic during the lunchtime break. The Petra news agency report said the sirens also sounded in the cities of Irbid and Zurka. In the capital, people rushed to balconies and into the streets to scan the skies for a few minutes. They returned to whatever they were doing when they saw nothing. Despite the sirens there was no apparent move by citizens to rush to air raid shelters. Amman is only 30 miles from the Israeli border, only a few seconds flying time for a warplane. The warning added to the tension created by the weeklong crisis that began when Iraq invaded and annexed Kuwait. There is fear that any clash between U.S. troops now being deployed in Saudi Arabia and Iraqi troops just across the border in Kuwait could spark a full blown Middle East war. Israeli forces were on alert today. Israel has said previously that it would move into Jordan if Iraqi forces crossed the Iraqi-Jordanian frontier. Concern markedly following King Hussein's warning late Wednesday that an Arab summit scheduled to start in Cairo later today was ``the last chance'' to avert the outbreak of war.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Edouard Near Mid-Atlantic Azores
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Edouard, packing top sustained winds of nearly 45 mph, buffeted part of the Azores early today and passed fewer than 100 miles from the Mid-Atlantic Portuguese archipelago. Edouard's winds and rain blanketed the islands of Terceira and Horta and tropical storm conditions were expected to continue throughout the day. At 6 a.m. EDT, Edouard's center was located near 38.3 north latitude, 28.9 west longitude, or about 80 miles west southwest of Terceira, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``Edouard is certainly over the Azores right now, and they're feeling it,'' said Miles Lawrence, hurricane specialist at the center. The storm was heading east northeast at about 12 mph and was expected to hold the same course and speed for the next 24 hours. Lawrence said little change in strength was likely today for Edouard. ``It's heading towards northern Europe, but it doesn't appear to be doing anything dramatic,'' Lawrence said.

DOC.HEAD: Salvage Crews Sop up Sludge as Cleanup Nears End
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Coast Guard began to cut back crews today as the cleanup of a 700,000-gallon oil spill in Galveston Bay nears an end. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Rich Muller said salvage crews were sopping up remaining pockets of sludge near Houston Point in the bay's northernmost part, but Coast Guard officials believe the $3 million cleanup should be complete by Friday. ``We still have some people up there,'' Muller said of the Houston Point area. ``That operation will be shutting down, just because there isn't that much left to do.'' Other crews, meanwhile, continue to take apart a battered barge that remained outside the Houston Ship Channel. Crews began cutting the barge, one of two ruptured in a July 28 collision with a Greek tanker, with blow torches on Wednesday so that the pieces can be moved to a Galveston scrap yard. Once the barge is severed, the Coast Guard plans to reopen the ship channel to two-way deep draft ship traffic for the first time since the accident. The Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two of three barges being towed by the tugboat, Chandy N, through the ship channel in the bay. The tanker, although damaged, lost none of its cargo of jet fuel because of a double hull, but the two barges spewed 700,000 gallons of a heavy catfeed oil used in petroleum refining. The accident, near Redfish Island, created a slick that at one time measured 17 miles in length and threatened most of the sensitive wildlife areas of the bay. The Texas Department of Health is maintaining a ban on shellfishing in most areas of the bay because of the spill.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Alleges Anti-depressant Drug Causes Suicidal Behavior
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Aron in 10th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A salesman says he developed suicidal impulses while taking the anti-depression drug Prozac, and he once intentionally smashed his car into a truck. In a lawsuit filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, Ralph Langer of suburban Chicago is seeking more than $1 million in damages from the drug manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co. of Indianapolis, and its subsidiary, Dista Products Co. Langer contends in the lawsuit that Eli Lilly has failed to warn doctors about what the suit said is a link between Prozac and suicidal or aggressive behavior. An Eli Lilly spokeswoman refused to comment on the lawsuit, but defended the drug as safe. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has no evidence of the drug being linked to specific deaths and still considers the drug safe, spokeswoman Eva Kemper said in a telephone interview from Maryland. Langer contends he began experiencing suicidal and self-destructive impulses after his therapist prescribed Prozac in September 1987 to treat his depression. Other lawsuits also have been filed involving the drug. A New York woman sued Lilly last month. In addition, the widows of three victims of a Kentucky man who murdered eight people before shooting himself are each suing the pharmaceuticals company for $50 million, saying the aggression was linked to Prozac. Langer's lawsuit says that at one point while on the drug, he intentionally drove his car at high speed into the rear of a truck. He suffered broken bones and bruises in the crash. His attorney, Aron D. Robinson of Chicago, said his client had never had suicidal impulses before being prescribed Prozac. He said this was the pattern in other Prozac cases studied by his law firm. The aggressive or suicidal behavior ``began when the person first began taking the drug and ended when the person was taken off the drug,'' he said. Lilly spokeswoman Mari Abbott said the drug was tested on more than 11,000 people before it was marketed. It has been prescribed for more than 2 million patients without evidence that it was linked to suicidal impulses, Ms. Abbott said. ``All of the data we have does not show a cause-and-effect relationship between our product and suicidal thoughts and acts,'' she said. ``The safety and effectiveness of this product has been tested.''

DOC.HEAD: Cook County School Funds Reported in Non-Interest Bearing Accounts
DOC.TEXT: The superintendent of Cook County schools continued to deposit millions of dollars in state and federal funds into accounts that pay no interest after promising to stop, a newpaper reported today. Superintendent Richard Martwick had made the pledge after a lawsuit in 1985 and criticism from prior state audits, according to today's Chicago Tribune. But a partially complete audit for 1989 shows Martwick continued putting the money into the non-interest accounts, said spokesman Lee Milner of the state Board of Education. More than $1.35 billion went into the accounts, costing taxpayers as much as $400,000 a year in lost interest, the Tribune said. The Tribune said Martwick could not be reached for comment. The bank's general counsel, William Dunn, declined to comment on the deposits. State officials say the average daily balance in the account Martwick keeps at Amalgamated Trust and Savings Bank is $6.5 million to $7 million. State audits in 1987 and 1988 revealed the practice. After the 1988 audit, Martwick's office said the money would be invested in an interest-bearing account. In the 1985 lawsuit, four school districts filed a class-action suit in U.S. District Court charging the non-interest deposits violated state and federal laws and deprived school districts access to money to which they were entitled. The suit is still pending. Last year, Cook County Clerk Stanley Kusper deposited $6.8 million in a non-interest account at Amalgamated. Amalgamated has been the depository of state government funds and has made loans to prominent politicians, including Gov. James Thompson, the Tribune said.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives Await Word on Relatives in Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs. `He estimated ...' with five grafs to ADD comments of 79-year-old woman awaiting word on her son. Picks up 9th graf pvs. `Edwin and ...
DOC.TEXT: A State Department task force has taken more than 11,000 calls from people wanting information about Americans stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, but word from the Middle East is reaching loved ones only in dribs and drabs. Kevin York of Mount Prospect, Ill., has not talked to his wife, Faye, who was in Iraq to visit friends and family, since before the Aug. 2 invasion. ``She called (her sister) Amy at 1 a.m. last Thursday, bawling her eyes out, saying that she was at the airport (in Baghdad) but couldn't get on the plane because the airline wouldn't accept her ticket. Then they closed the airport,'' he said. Mrs. York, a 31-year-old naturalized American of Iraqi descent, is two months pregnant with their first child, York said. President Bush on Wednesday said U.S. troops were sent to Saudi Arabia to deter an attack from Iraq. Also Wednesday, Iraq annexed Kuwait. Poor telephone connections and confusion in Baghdad have made contact difficult if not impossible since the invasion. Some Americans said they heard about relatives through employers or the State Department. Thirty-eight Americans remain in a Baghdad hotel from which they are not allowed to leave, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday. The hotel is under guard, but the Americans are safe, he said. He estimated there are 400 Americans in Iraq and 3,000 in Kuwait. The task force is tracking 1,468 people in Kuwait and Iraq it has identified or been in contact with, Boucher said. Emily Abramson of Southbury, Conn., said the decision to send U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia has increased her fears for the safety of her son and his family trapped in Kuwait. ``I'm dreadfully upset today, more so than I was up to now,'' she said Wednesday. She said the State Department has told her that her son, Paul Pawlowski, his wife, Ingrid, and their 6-year-old daughter, Tess, are safe. But Mrs. Abramson, a 79-year-old widow who lives alone, said she has only left her house to go to the mailbox. ``I don't dare,'' she said. ``I'd rather be here in case a call comes through.'' Edwin and Irene Davis of Koran, La., last heard from their daughter in a 4 a.m. telephone call a week ago: ``Daddy, don't worry; we're under attack.'' ``I know what warfare in the cities is like _ trigger-happy and nervous. I advised them to stay in the house. I hope that's what they did,'' said Davis, a retired Baptist minister. Their daughter, Martha; her Kuwaiti-born husband, Mahmoud Al-Ghareeb, and their children, Millie, 18, and Michael, 14, were visiting Al-Ghareeb's parents. Boucher said U.S. officials have met with the Americans at the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad. ``What we are doing is trying to obtain Iraqi government consent to open the borders, to open the airports, and to allow people to leave the country,'' Boucher said. ``We are certainly working to see that all Americans, including these people at the Rashid Hotel, are free to go and are able to leave the country.'' A 39th American at the hotel, 10-year-old Penelope Nabokov of Albany, Calif., was taken to the U.S. Embassy by agreement with Iraq, the State Department said Wednesday. One official said he did not know where she would go next or when. The girl's family said she was among 367 passengers taken from a British Airways jet in Kuwait while the invasion was under way. She was traveling alone to India, where her mother was doing research.

DOC.HEAD: A Fishy Problem Recurs in Maine
LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The smell ...' to DELETE phrase, `speaking on condition of anonymity.'
DOC.TEXT: Residents keep their windows shut and an inn has closed as the stench from thousands of rotting fish fills the air. In the waters of Quahog Bay, Maine's latest menhaden kill has suffocated thousands of lobsters, crabs, snails and other sea life. ``The eels are even dead and they're hard to kill,'' said Linda Webber, who owns Webber and Sons Lobster Co. with her husband in this seacoast town of 2,500 about 15 miles from Portland. Webber said the company has lost about $10,000 worth of lobsters. Robert Waddle, owner of Quahog Lobster Inc., the other lobster dealer at Quahog Bay, said he has lost at least that much. Lobsters generally sell for less than $4 a pound in Maine this time of year; wholesalers commonly keep the crustaceans in holding pens in bays or harbors. ``The overall loss is tremendous. Not just my loss, but everyone's loss because everything in the bay's been killed,'' Waddle said. Vast schools of menhaden, or pogies, first were chased into Quahog Bay by feeding bluefish about a month ago, Waddle said Wednesday. The schools severely depleted the oxygen in the water, killing lobsters and other aquatic life. Dead pogies can be seen floating in clumps throughout the cove and are caked onto rocks along the shore. ``It's been like this for almost a month, but the past few days have been unbearable,'' said Marianne Lavine, who has kept a summer home at Quahog Bay for 20 years. ``We've had the doors and windows closed for three days now. It irritates your throat and nose. It's disgusting.'' The smell is so bad that a bed-and-breakfast on the bay closed. One of the inn's owners said he and his wife will not reopen until the odor is gone. Fish kills have happened along Maine's coast several times in recent years, but ``this is certainly a large die-off,'' said Marshall Murphy, spokesman for the state Department of Marine Resources. Pogies are oily fish that can weigh up to two pounds and are used for lobster bait, fertilizer and cat food. An estimated 3,000 pounds of pogies, or 50 bushels, washed ashore in Belfast Bay in September 1987.
