In August 1985, about 8,000 bushels of pogies washed into a cove in Southport, and officials brought in a huge vacuum cleaner to suck the rotting fish out of the water. In 1984 about 25,000 menhaden and 500 bluefish died in the Kennebec River, also from oxygen deprivation. Murphy said the state won't attempt a cleanup in Quahog Bay. He said past cleanups have proved to be ``very expensive and less than totally successful.'' ``At this point, our decision is to allow nature to continue the decomposition process of the menhaden,'' he said. It takes about 10 days for the fish to decompose. There is no river is at the head of the bay to flush the cove, so only winds and tides may help. A northerly wind last week carried some of the pogies away, but a southwesterly wind this week carried the dead fish back into the bay, Murphy said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed as Two Freight Trains Collide ^Eds: UPDATES thruout with details of collision, injuries. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two freight trains collided in northwest Georgia early today, killing three people and injuring four. Authorities said a northbound freight train ran head-on into another train that was traveling onto the main Norfolk Southern track from a side track shortly before 3:30 a.m. in a rural area west of Resaca, about 60 miles north of Atlanta. The engineer and conductor of the train on the main track and the conductor of the other train were killed, said Norfolk Southern spokesman Bob Auman. Four other railroad employees were taken to Gordon County Hospital in Calhoun with bruises. Hospital officials said three would be treated and released and one admitted. Auman said both engines on one of the trains and one of the engines of the other train derailed and caught fire. In addition, at least 14 cars derailed, but none carried hazardous materials.

DOC.HEAD: King Fahd Says U.S. Force For Defensive Purposes Only
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more details from King's speech. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd said today that foreign nations were not establishing a permanent military presence in his kingdom. ``These forces from friendly powers are here temporarily,'' the king said in the nationally televised address, his first public statement since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed it on Wednesday. He spoke as at least 5,000 U.S. troops were pouring into Saudi Arabia, backed by an armada of U.S. air and seapower in the region. Another 4,000 U.S. Marines were moving close to the Saudi-Kuwait border, diplomatic sources said. The king said the forces ``are to help defend the kingdom, participate in joint exercises, and will leave here as soon as the kingdom so demands.'' He stressed that inviting Western and Arab forces to the kingdom was ``not directed against anyone, but a purely defensive measure.'' He said American, British and other unspecified forces were invited into the country due to the the Iraqi troop buildup on the Saudi-Kuwaiti border and to help Saudi Arabia in its duty to defend its territory. The Iraqis ``massed large numbers of troops on the border of the kingdom,'' the king said. ``Faced with this bitter reality, and out of keenness to safeguard its territory and economy ... The kingdom expresses a desire to Arab and friendly forces to participate'' in the multinational force. Fahd called Iraq's move ``the most horrible aggression the Arab nation has known in its modern history,'' and demanded a withdrawal of Iraqi troops. ``Saudia Arabia calls for a return of things as they were before the Iraqi invasion and that the ruling family be allowed to be reinstated,'' he said in reference to the exiled Al-Sabah family. ``The invasion has caused Kuwaitis to become refugees, to suffer. The kingdom of Saudia Arabia is very upset at this attack, this invasion from Iraq,'' Fahd added. Fahd said he supported all attempts to resolve the crisis, adding: ``We are supportive of the decision of the Islamic summit, the Arab League, the Council of Gulf States and the international community.'' ``We are hoping that the emergency Arab summit called by Hosni Mubarak, president of brotherly Egypt, that this summit will bring the results that will (lead to) unity and solidarity among the Arab world.'' Egypt and Morocco have refused to join the U.S. and other Western forces. Arab leaders were meeting in Cairo in a last-ditch effort to resolve the crisis caused by the invasion and the troop buildup on the Kuwaiti-Saudi border.

DOC.HEAD: Good Samaritan Ends Standoff Between Illegal Parker and Tow-Truck Operator
DOC.TEXT: For nine hours, the illegally parked motorist went eyeball to eyeball with a highly determined tow truck driver. Neither blinked. Finally, early today, a knight in a white Lincoln Continental came to the rescue. The standoff began Wednesday afternoon when Ann Miser parked in a private lot without paying. In 10 minutes, Wilbey Mullen was hooking Miser's car to his tow truck. Miser, apparently aware that it is illegal here to tow a car carrying a passenger, jumped in the front seat and refused to budge. Mullen, 26, an employee of Maryland Impounding Inc., demanded a $110 towing fee to unhook Miser's car. Miser said she would pay, but only had a check. Mullen refused. ``Company policy. You can't stop payment on cash,'' he explained. Miser got a passer-by to call a co-worker, who telephoned area television stations and a member of the City Council. An unidentified woman also came to Miser's aid by bringing dinner _ a turkey sandwich, boiled egg, pickles, raisins and a jug of water. Watching the local 11 p.m. newscasts, which featured live reports on the impasse, was Norman McCarthy. McCarthy, who described himself as a celebrity bodyguard, was naturally sympathetic since his car had been towed last fall. He drove right down to the parking lot. In the meantime, Mullen had kept his meter running and was demanding $400 by the time McCarthy arrived. He was willing to settle for $200, which the good Samaritan paid off in nickels, dimes and quarters he kept in a plastic water bottle in his car. ``I just don't want her to sit in the car, and I want to get rid of my change,'' said McCarthy. Mullen was grateful: ``Thanks a lot, man. Now I can go home.'' All Miser could say was: ``I just can't believe it.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Claims MTV's `Remote Control' Was His Idea
DOC.TEXT: I want my MTV royalties, says a 39-year-old man who claims in a federal lawsuit that the music television network stole his copyrighted idea for a rock 'n' roll game show. Mark Winik, who runs a printing supply company, is suing MTV and its parent company, Viacom Inc., over the network's 3-year-old game show ``Remote Control'' and a 1990 show called ``Turn It Up.'' The lawsuit, filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court, contends Winik developed an idea in 1985 for a game show called ``Rockout.'' He copyrighted the concept and tried to sell it to MTV in 1986, but the music network rejected his proposal, the suit said. ``Come to find out, sometime down the road, that the idea he proposed he saw on TV,'' said Winik's lawyer, Henry B. Henrici. Hilary Condit, a spokeswoman for Viacom, said Wednesday the company does not comment on pending litigation. Winik's lawsuit claims that ``key creative and distinct elements'' of the game shows were stolen from him. His suit asks for $100,000 for every instance of copyright infringement. Winik said his concept was to combine a traditional television game show with trivia questions about rock music and a segment in which contestants would try to identify artists or songs by watching small parts of videos or listening to the first few bars of a song. He said he went to New York in 1986 to discuss the idea with MTV officials. ``They told me the idea was too commercial and wouldn't fit into their programming, and then two years later they premiered `Remote Control,''' Winik said.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Suggests Iraq Prepared To Use Chemical Weapons If Attacked
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is prepared to use chemical weapons if attacked, Baghdad's envoy to Greece suggested today. ``If we are attacked by a foreign power we will retaliate with all sorts of defensive weapons that we have,'' the ambassador, Abdel Fetah al-Khazreji, said in a telephone interview. Earlier, he was asked by reporters if Iraq had been preparing for chemical warfare since its invasion of Kuwait last week. Khazreji said that no special preparations had been made, but acknowledged that Baghdad has chemical arms. President Bush has promised severe retaliation if President Saddam Hussein used chemical weapons against American soldiers. Thousands of American troops have arrived in Saudi Arabi to defend the desert kingdom against possible attack in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait one week ago. Saddam used chemical weapons against Iran during the countries' eight-year war, and also against Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority. Saddam also threatened in April to attack Israel with chemical weapons in the event of an Israeli attack. ``As we have declared for the last couple of months we have said that we will retaliate if Israel attacks any of our installations. But we will only act defensively,'' Khazreji said. The Iraqi envoy denied reports that Iraqi forces have been increased on the border with Turkey, and he also reiterated the Iraqi claim that there are no plans to attack Saudi Arabia. ``There is no deployment against Saudi Arabia. We will only strike at any country that attacks us,'' he said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Central Park Jogger, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0512,0475
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Asks Jurors To Imagine Victim's Terror
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `Justice Thomas ...' to UPDATE with jurors deliberating today. ^By SAMUEL MAULL
DOC.TEXT: The case of the Central Park jogger was sent to a jury after the prosecutor reminded jurors of the brutal gang rape and beating endured by the victim. ``Imagine what went through the mind of (the jogger) as the attackers surrounded her and started ripping off her clothes,'' Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer said in her four-hour summation Wednesday. ``Antron McCray, Yusef Salaam and Raymond Santana had their fun in Central Park on April 19, 1989,'' she said, referring to the teen-age defendants. ``Today they have no one to blame for their predicament but themselves. They showed no sympathy or mercy. ... The only fair and just verdict is guilty.'' Justice Thomas Galligan instructed the jurors, who began deliberating this morning. Salaam, 16, Santana, 15, and McCray, 16, are charged in Manhattan's state Supreme Court with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery in attacks on the woman and on two male joggers during a gang rampage. About 10 minutes into Lederer's summation, a row of family and supporters of the defendants walked out of the courtroom together without speaking. ``The defendants dragged her into the cover of darkness,'' about 78 feet into the woods from the area where she took her nightly run, and there beat and raped her, Lederer said. ``These defendants wanted her to die,'' the prosecutor said, ``and they took the steps to make that happen. These defendants had every reason for not wanting her to survive.'' The woman lost three-fourths of her blood in the ordeal. The jogger is back at work as a vice president at Salomon Brothers investment bankers, but she testified that she still suffers from impaired sight, balance and smell as a result of the attack. ``The fact that she could even come to this courtroom is a miracle,'' Lederer said. Defense lawyers summed up Tuesday, with one attorney suggesting the victim was not gang-raped and another accusing detectives of lying about how incriminating statements were obtained from the three defendants. Those statements are the prosecution's chief evidence. Referring to Salaam's contention that he was tricked into confessing the crime, Lederer noted Salaam's confidence when he testified. ``This is not a person who is manipulated. This not a person who has words put in his mouth,'' Lederer said. She called Salaam's claim that he entered the park with a gang of youths but spent his time there wandering around by himself ``absolutely incredible.'' Lederer reminded the jury that in McCray's videotaped statement, the youth freely offered information and corrected details the police were trying to pin down.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 28 Dead In Widespread Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Heavily armed police in armored vehicles today tried to restore order in the southeastern city of Port Elizabeth after 23 people were reported killed in a night of rioting and looting. Police said today at least five other people had been killed Wednesday in different parts of the country. Hundreds of rioters stormed through Port Elizabeth on Wednesday night, looting and attacking bystanders, police said. ``Criminal mobs ran amok ... looting and burning shops at random and causing damage ... A baby was shot dead in its mother's lap,'' said local journalist Cliff Foster. Police spokesman Major Bill Dennis said 18 people were killed by gunfire, but he did not have figures on how many of them were killed by police. Police repeatedly opened fire with shotguns and pistols to disperse the mob. Overall, police said 23 people were killed in Port Elizabeth. The rioters, who surged through parts of Port Elizabeth and surrounding townships, destroyed and burned 23 shops, six houses, two factories, one church and three schools, Dennis said. Police in armored vehicles patrolled the city's streets today to try to restore order. In other unrest reported today, police said three people were killed and 18 injured Wednesday night when workers attacked other staff at President Steyn gold mine at Welkom in the Transvaal. Police arrested 35 men. Anglo American Corp., which owns the mine, gave no reason for the fighting, but it appeared to be black faction fighting. In Natal Province, police reported today two men had been killed in black faction fighting on Wednesday. Police and residents in Port Elizabeth said they feared new unrest could occur. Police reinforcements were being rushed to the town to help exhausted local officers, police said. The rioting began Monday over a political dispute, but police said criminals had taken advantage of the confusion to start looting. One shopkeeper, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he and his family hid in a garage for several hours to escape the mob. ``We heard windows breaking. We then watched the mob. They charged across the road looting the shops. It was then we began to panic,'' the shopkeeper said. The man and his family escaped when a police armored vehicle scattered the looters. They were able to follow it to safety.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Warns It Will Not Tolerate Kuwait's Annexation
With PM-Kuwait-Iraq-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran, which fought a brutal eight-year war with Iraq, today said that Tehran will not tolerate Baghdad's annexation of Kuwait, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. A Foreign Ministry statement on IRNA condemned the Iraqi takeover of its small, oil-rich neighbor and said the incursion ``has made the Persian Gulf region, the Middle East and the Islamic world face an increasing crisis, making the future prospects for this sensitive part of the world more ambiguous.'' The IRNA report, monitored in Nicosia, said the statement added that ``as the major power of the Persian Gulf region, Iran will not tolerate any alteration of the political geography of the region.'' Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, annexed it on Wednesday. The statement called for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, and said ``the situation must come to an end as soon as possible,'' the news agency said. IRNA quoted an Iranian newspaper as saying today that Washington had failed by sending troops to defend Saudi Arabia to adopt a ``clear-cut'' stand on Baghdad's aggression, which amounted to a ``tacit approval of the Iraqi invasion, or at last acceptance of the invasion as a tolerable act.'' The radical Farsi-language Jomhuri Islami added that the United States was looking to use President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as a ``scarecrow'' in the region to scare off anti-American Islamic movements in the region. The newspaper was skeptical that international embargoes aimed at strangling the Iraqi economy and forcing Saddam to retreat from Kuwait would work. Therefore, ``regional regimes and sheiks of the southern Persian Gulf in particular, must seriously contemplate their future,'' the paper said. The more moderate English-language Tehran Times called the international response to the invasion ``acceptable,'' but added that ``only drastic action can adequately respond to the actions of Baghdad's adventurism.'' The newspaper, close to the Foreign Ministry which is known to favor better relations with the United States, said such ``drastic action should necessarily come from the United States.'' The Times editorial was the first to encourage American military action against Iraq. The Iranians had up until now urged a regional solution to the problem, and vehemently condemned any foreign intervention. Washington has disclosed it is seeking help from Iran and Syria, two countries the United States has previously denounced for encouraging terrorism, in forcing an Iraqi withdrawal. The Tehran Times did stress, however, that ``after the end of the crisis such a force should leave the region and leave the responsibility of peace and security of the region to the regional countries.'' But President Hashemi Rafsanjani's pro-Western inclinations contrast sharply with those of his hard-line, vehemently anti-American opponents. Rafsanjani's pragmatic government has been locked in an increasing power struggle with radicals led by former interior minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. Rafsanjani's efforts at improving ties with the West have been repeatedly frustrated by the hard-liners.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Test Launches Arrow Missile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with description of missile, launch had been expected soon, detail on Iraqi rockets, reaction from Rabin. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel today launched the first test of a new U.S.-financed missile developed to combat short-range ballistic missiles, and state radio called it a direct response to an Iraqi threat a day earlier. The radio report said the missile was launched at 3:40 p.m. (8:40 a.m. EDT) at an undisclosed location. It left a short trail of fire and underneath a small ring of smoke, said one of the radio's reporters. Israel radio said the launch was a direct response to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threat on Wednesday to launch a missile attack on Israel. Saddam made the threat after alleging that Israeli warplanes had been painted with American colors in preparation for an attack on Iraq. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today said Saddam invited a ``heavy tragedy'' if he launched such a strike. Citing foreign reports, Israel radio said the missile is 12 yards long, has a range of 42 miles and can fly up to 18 miles overhead. Today's missile launching was attended by officials from Israel Aircraft Industries, which is developing the Arrow, and by American representatives, the report said. Industry and D13. (Egg yolks and organ meat are the foods highest in cholesterol.) 9. False. While consuming only 20 percent of calories as fat is perfectly healthful (the Japanese do it and suffer less heart disease than Americans), it is a hard change to implement. For that reason, you are advised to aim for a diet that contains 30 percent calories as fat. Presently, the fat intake of the average American is closer to 40 percent of total calories. 10. False. A few years ago the theory that low cholesterol level may predispose the body to developing cancer gained momentum in a few scientific and lay circles. It now appears that the interpretation of the data was complicated by the fact that low blood cholesterol often results from, rather than predicts, cancer _ probably due to weight loss and other outcomes of cancer.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Aug. 13

DOC.HEAD: Woman: False Witch Rumors at Heart of Alleged Murder Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `Mercer County ...' to CORRECT name to Dupplier, sted Duppler.
DOC.TEXT: Two men were charged with conspiring to murder a neighbor they thought was a witch, authorities say. Karina Singer, 61, said she had no idea some of her neighbors wrongly suspected she was a witch until two armed men were arrested on her farm last week. ``I'm stunned my neighbors could believe these things when we've lived here 21 years,'' Mrs. Singer said. ``And that instead of calling me to find out if they were true, circulating them around until they became like an atomic blast mushrooming out of the prairie.'' Jim Reppen, who works for a tire service company, and farmer Dean Unterseher were charged with conspiracy to commit murder. The charge carries a possible life term. Both were freed on $5,000 bond after their arrests by police officers acting on a tip. Mercer County State's Attorney Alan Dupplier said rumors about Mrs. Singer have circulated in the county for years. This summer, they also included two visiting friends, he said. ``There have been rumors flying around Mercer County that these three ladies are witches and they're sacrificing animals and doing general cult-type of things,'' Dupplier said. The two arrested men, he said, apparently ``decided they were going to go down and eliminate the problem.'' A search of the Singer farm uncovered nothing witch-like, Dupplier said. Mrs. Singer said she did not know the two men, who authorities said hatched the alleged murder plot at a bar in nearby Hazen. Since the arrests, neighbors have told Mrs. Singer of hearing stories of firelight rites at the farm. What really has been going on, Mrs. Singer said, was a plan she developed with her late husband, John, to turn the farm into ``a place of beauty and peace'' that friends could visit for extended vacations. Her husband died of cancer in April. Last fall, the couple laid down two Indian ``medicine wheels,'' or rock configurations ``for the healing of the land.'' During the spring and summer, several old frame buildings were torn down, a pit was burned in the yard and a guest house was erected. But rumors circulated that the guest house was a church and that visitors were seen dancing around a pit fire. The ``dancers,'' Mrs. Singer said, actually were workers from a Hazen construction company that tore down the buildings and put out grass fires started by sparks from the pit. All in all, she said, ``it was probably too fast a change'' for the neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Wouild Restore Unemployment Benefits for Census Workers
DOC.TEXT: A bill awaiting President Bush's signature would reverse a recent law denying unemployment benefits to temporary census workers when their jobs end. Congress approved the provision providing the benefits to census workers when it passed an unrelated trade bill last week in its rush toward August recess. The House approved the bill early Saturday, following Senate approval. The provision had been added by House and Senate conferees on the trade bill as a way to reverse the exemption from jobless benefits that Congress adopted as a cost-cutting move when it passed an appropriations bill in May. It was intended to save an estimated $70 million set aside for unemployment claims once the census workers lose their jobs. The law had set an April 20 cutoff for temporary census workers to receive job credit toward later unemployment compensation. Work after that date would not count when they eventually apply for unemployment benefits. Repeal of the provision had been sought by Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y., who said the census workers were being unfairly singled out as a way to save money.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Bank Robbers Arrested After Shopping Spree
DOC.TEXT: A couple who celebrated a bank robbery with an expensive dinner and a shopping spree were arrested after a limousine chauffeur drove them to Connecticut on their ``honeymoon,'' authorities said. Marvin Birdsong, 41, and Lilckets to Miami on a 6:30 a.m. flight under aliases. The FBI said the couple had more than $23,000 in their possession, and two revolvers. Early Wednesday, detectives asked Gay to turn over the $450 the couple had given him for driving them. But the chauffeur could at least take pride in his job performance. ``They were really happy with me,'' Gay said. ``They told me they were going to call my boss today and insist that they give me a raise.''

DOC.HEAD: Dozens of Fires Rage in Oregon, Idaho and Utah
DOC.TEXT: Lightning, strong winds and scorching temperatures fueled dozens of fires in parched Oregon, Idaho and Utah, but scattered rain was expected to cool off some areas next week. Four major forest fires in eastern Oregon _ including one that scorched 80,000 acres and forced evacuations _ continued to grow today and lightning sparked new blazes in the southwestern corner of the state. In central Idaho, crews reined in a forest fire at Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness Area on Wednesday evening. But a fire in southern Idaho advanced into the Sawtooth National Forest, another was fanned by strong winds through sagebrush north of Shoshone and timberland further north was hit by new lightning-caused fires. The most dangerous fire in Oregon was the Pine Springs combination of fires, including a blaze, which grew to about 80,000 acres overnight, fueled by winds up to 60 mph. It was within three miles today of the towns of Burns and Hines in southeast Oregon and about 20 people were evacuated overnight from Riley and nearby ranches after flames crept to the edge of town, said Greg Thayer, a spokesman for the U.S. Forest Service. They returned after the fire reversed course and no buildings were damaged, he said. The fire was spreading through sage and juniper range land today, he said. A fire 40 miles northwest of Burns on the Malheur National Forest was at 7,600 acres, and another blaze 15 miles north of Burns was reported at 3,500 acres, forcing the evacuation of a campground. A fire 15 miles of Prairie City on the Malheur National Forest was reported at 4,240 acres, while another burned 2,600 acres off the Strawberry Mountain Wilderness Area southeast of John Day. ``All available (fire) crews are committed,'' said spokesman Don Ferguson of the Oregon Multiple Agency Center in Salem. ``Air support is in real short supply.'' Ferguson said eight new fires were reported outside Medford in the wake of a lightning storm Tuesday night that left 42 new fires in the Klamath Basin. In the rest of the state, 19 small fires were burning, but officials were hopeful they would be contained quickly. Terry Marsha, a National Weather Service meteorologist, said all of Oregon is still vulnerable to lightning, but cool, wet weather would help by early next week. In Idaho, Payette National Forest spokesman Dave Olson said lightning sparked more than than 30 fires in the eastern part of the forest Wednesday evening. ``Virtually every strike started a fire,'' he said. Meanwhile, in Utah, firefighters shored up the perimeter and battled hot spots today on the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation. The 5,350-acre fire is 80 percent contained. It has burned for ten days through rugged wildlife habitat in the eastern Utah reservation.

DOC.HEAD: US Troop Move Hinged on `Significant Moment'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Some diplomatic ...' to CLARIFY that diplomatic sources referred to are from the Mideast
DOC.TEXT: The movement of tens of thousands of U.S. soldiers, sailors and airmen to Saudi Arabia will take days to accomplish and may last for months, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says. Cheney described the deployment as ``a major commitment of U.S. forces'' that included elements of the 82nd Airborne Division and F-15 fighter jets. The breakthrough that paved the way for their deployment came during a crucial, two-hour session between King Fahd and Cheney in Jiddah on Monday night. ``The discussion ... was a significant moment,'' Cheney recalled to reporters Wednesday. At President Bush's behest, Cheney had flown to Saudi Arabia, armed with graphic descriptions provided by U.S. intelligence agencies of Iraq's ``blitzkrieg'' drive through Kuwait and its buildup of troops, tanks, artillery and surface-to-surface missiles. The Saudis had rejected many U.S. requests to base American forces in the strategic country, the source for much of the world's oil. However, this time ``it had become abundantly clear that the Iraqis had, in fact, committed an act of infamy ... in their aggression against Kuwait. Having told the Saudis they had no intention to invade, they did in fact invade,'' Cheney said. ``The message was that preparation was the best way to deter further aggression, and that if U.S. military assistance was requested, we would stay only as long as the Saudis wanted us to,'' said a senior Pentagon official familiar with the talks. The king reminisced about his family's long ties with the United States. But it was the realization of Iraq's ``naked aggression,'' coupled with Bush's personal diplomacy and Saudi Arabia's historic ties to the United States, that convinced the royal ruler to request U.S. military assistance, Cheney said. Military officials said Wednesday that U.S. warplanes and combat troops, backed by an armada of Navy ships, had taken up defensive positions in and near Saudi Arabia. Some Air National Guard members in New York, New Jersey, Tennessee, West Virginia and Wisconsin were called up for active duty. Cheney declined to provide a specific number of the troops involved, citing security concerns. A senior military official in the Pentagon said the deployment was ``open-ended'' and the numbers of troops, airmen and sailors deployed would depend on Saddam's reaction. Some Mideast diplomatic sources put the troop level at about 30,000 and several other estimates ranged even higher. On the first day of deployment, at least 5,000 ground troops were being dispatched, officials said, backed by an armada of air and seapower. Another 4,000 Marines were moved close to the Saudi-Kuwait border, diplomatic sources said. Nearly 40 warships and escort vessels _ some armed with sophisticated cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific Iraqi targets _ will be in Mideast waters by next week, the sources said. Squadrons of F-15 jet fighters from Langley Air Force Base in Virginia were flown to the region, as were the 82nd Airborne's Ready Brigade aboard huge transport planes. FB-111 fighter-bombers were in position at NATO bases in Turkey, and B-52 bombersthat had arrived for long-planned exercises on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia were held in position. Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C., said A-10 air-to-ground attack jets from Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C., had left for Saudi Arabia. Unlike the F-15, an ``air superiority'' fighter designed to tangle with other planes, the A-10 was designed to attack ground targets. The aircraft carriers Independence and Eisenhower were being moved into position to do serious damage to Iraq's strategic sites. Pentagon sources said it would take several days for the troops to converge on Saudi Arabia, but that the initial units would be in place by early today. The length of their stay remains a question, Cheney said. ``The situation is uncertain. We don't know how long it will last. We don't know when it will end,'' he said. ``We do not know how events will unfold over the next few months, but obviously, the president had made it very clear that ... this is a part of the world that's of absolute strategic significance to the United States and we are prepared to use U.S. military forces, if necessary, to protect our interests and those of our friends in the area,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-War Activists Dusting Off Peace Signs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to change cycle designator to PM.
DOC.TEXT: About 30 people gathered at the federal courthouse to protest the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, contending that the move constitutes an unnecessary defense of rich oil barons. Leaders of Wednesday's rally said it was the first in the nation to question the most recent U.S. military moves. More were are scheduled today in Washington, D.C., New York, San Francisco and other cities Sponsored by a group calling itself Women Against Military Madness, protesters chanted ``Oil, Schmoil _ Ride your bike.'' ``This seems kind of scary. It's not just protecting Saudi Arabia, it seems bigger than that,'' said one protester, Jackie Heine. The protesters say it's a conflict centered less on ideology than crude oil. ``There's a moral question about defending rich Kuwaitis,'' said Heine. ``It's important to have someone protesting so that people realize something can happen because of this. A lot of people are sleepers.'' Protesters reject the U.S. government's assertions that the troops are intended only to deter an Iraqi move on Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kohl Scraps Plans to Move Up All-German Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Kohl scrapping plans to move up elections.
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has scrapped plans to move up all-German elections from Dec. 2 to Oct. 14, officials said today. The decision followed a day-long parliamentary debate in which the opposition Social Democrats made clear they would not let Kohl have the two-thirds majority needed for a necessary constitutional change. Kohl had originally planned elections for an all-German parliament on Dec. 2. But last week East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, after consultations with Kohl, said the date of the elections and of formal German unity would be moved up to Oct. 14. It was not immediately clear what date Kohl has decided on for formal German unity. The opposition Social Democrats want it to occur on Sept. 15, with elections on Dec. 2. During a stormy Bundestag debate, lawmakers from Kohl's governing coalition and his rivals charged each other with slowing up the unity process and sowing uncertainty among the beleaguered East German populace. Otto Lambsdorff, head of the Free Democrats, junior partner in Kohl's coalition government, accused the Social Democrats of ``sinning against the people of the DDR (East Germany).'' He maintained that holding elections in October rather than December would ``improve the psychological situation (in East Germany) and thereby create better frameworks for the (East German) economy.'' Herta Daeubler-Gmelin, a high-ranking Social Democrat, accused Kohl's Christian Democrats of sowing ``uncertainty'' among East Germans. During the West German parliamentary session today, lawmakers postponed a key vote regulating the all-German election treaty. The treaty lays the groundwork for the first pan-German elections since 1933. On Wednesday evening, East German lawmakers called for all-German elections and unification on Oct. 14. But that vote does little good without approval of a new election treaty. East Germany is suffering from fast-rising unemployment while it shifts from 40 years of communism. Inefficient businesses exposed to the free market have begun to fail or lay off excess workers. Economic unification began last month, with East Germany trading in its currency for West German marks. But lower East German wages have not kept up with the cost of living, and East Germans have suffered from a loss of communist subsidies.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Assures Turkey of NATO Support in Iraqi Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; restores cycle designator; edits throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III assured Turkey today that it would receive full support from NATO if it suffers for taking a ``forthright stand'' against Iraq. Baker and Turkish officials discussed ways in which the two countries could cooperate ``to deter Iraqi agression.'' However, he steered around the issue of whether the United States would be able to use Turkish military bases as staging areas for any operations in the Gulf. ``I don't plan to get into the specifics of any discussions we might or might not have had on matters of defense cooperation,'' Baker told reporters before departing for Brussels, Belgium. He said they also discussed the economic hardships Turkey will face in the loss of oil revenue by cutting off pipelines from Iraq. The ousted Kuwaiti leaders have offered ``to do what they can to minimize those financial loses,'' Baker said. ``It goes without saying that Turkey is strategically very important,'' Baker said earlier. He assured the Turks they would have the support of the NATO alliance, of which Turkey is a member. Earlier, Baker disclosed that he dispatched John H. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for the Near East, to Damascus, Syria, ``to see if we can coordinate with the Syrians on collective efforts regarding Iraqi aggression.'' Kelly also will go to Saudi Arabia, where thousands of American troops are being deployed to protect the oilfields, for talks with Saudi officials and with Kuwaiti leaders who took sanctuary there after Iraq overran their small country. Baker said before his meetings with Turkish officials that he had received new assurances of Soviet support in enforcing the economic boycott of Iraq ordered by the U.N. Security Council. Baker spoke for about a half hour by telephone from his U.S. Air Force jetliner with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze _ their third conversation in two days _ and then told reporters: ``They continue to support enforcement of the U.N. resolution. We can look toward continued Soviet cooperation to carry out the resolution.'' Specifically, Baker said Moscow had dispatched naval forces to the Persian Gulf for use in any international blockade to enforce the sanctions approved unanimously Monday by the Security Council. ``The Soviets view this aggression in the same way that we do,'' Baker said. On Friday, he will meet in Brussels with Nikolai Afanasyevsky, the Soviet ambassador to Belgium and to NATO. Baker's main purpose for going to NATO headquarters is to plot with the 15 allied foreign ministers their ``possible participation in military deployments'' to enforce the economic boycott of Iraq voted unanimously Monday by the U.N. Security Council. Despite some reservations expressed privately by Moscow about the economic boycott of Iraq and public disquiet about mounting a military blockade, the cooperation between Washington and Moscow is unprecedented in recent history. It is especially striking since Iraq has received a sizable portion of its weapons from Moscow. Officials said the Kremlin agreed to suspend further deliveries without hesitation. Baker's nine-hour visit to Ankara underscored both U.S. gratitude for the actions Turkey has taken against Iraq, and the additional demands that may be placed on NATO's only predominantly Moslem member. Risking commerce with Iraq valued at $3 billion a year, Turkey effectively ordered a shutdown Tuesday of Iraqi oil pipelines by banning ships from loading Iraqi crude at offshore terminals in the eastern Mediterranean. The pipelines carried more half of Iraq's total exports from its northern fields. Turkey also banned trade with Iraq and froze $25 million in Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets. Baker has stressed Turkey's strategic situation. Besides sharing a border with Iraq, there is concern in Ankara for an estimated 60,000 Turkish construction workers in Iraq. ``It is important that we make clear to them that they will continue to enjoy the collective defense support that is afforded to each and every member of the NATO alliance,'' he said. Probably the most dramatic step taken by the Bush administration, however, was its willingness to solicit Syrian participation in undercutting Iraq's Hussein. The enmity between the Syrian and Iraqi governments is intense. Syrian President Hafez Assad and Saddam Hussein are longtime rivals within the Arab world. The two countries are ruled by rival Baathist parties, each considering the other outcasts. Baker declined to say what ``collective efforts'' Syria and the United States might undertake against Iraq. ``I really don't want to get into the specifics of that,'' he said. At the same time, Baker verified reports the United States also has been in touch with Iran through ``third party contacts.'' Iran and Iraq fought a bloody war in the Persian Gulf for a decade. Iranian antipathy of Iraq may actually surpass Syria's and is of much longer standing. A senior U.S. official, demanding anonymity, said it was up to Saudi Arabia to decide whether Syria and Iran would participate in defense of the country against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Pledges Armed Backing; Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal Offer Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details of British involvement, U.N. vote, Soviets saying they'll only consider joining after U.N. vote. Pickup 10th pvs, `France, one...' Minor editing to CONFORM
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain today pledged to send jet fighters, a detachment of ground-to-air missiles and warships to back U.S. forces dispatched to Saudi Arabia to deter Iraqi aggression. But as of today, Britain was the only other nation apart from Saudi Arabia to pledge forces to the multinational force envisioned by President Bush. The Soviet Union dispatched two warships to the Persian Gulf ``to protect Soviet maritime traffic,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri D. Gremitskikh said today. But Gremitskikh said the Soviet Union would only consider participating in a multinational force or naval blockade against Iraq if it were approved by the U.N. Security Council. The U.N. Security Council today unanimously declared Iraq's annexation of Kuwait to be ``null and void'' and called on all nations to shun the government Baghdad installed in Kuwait. But there was no indication that a vote on the multinational force would be taken by the world body. Canada will decide whether to participate in a multinational military blockade of Iraq following a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Brussels on Friday, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Wednesday. Portugal, West Germany, Italy and Spain have offered the use of bases. Egypt and Morocco _ considered the likeliest Arab participants in a U.S.-led multinational force _ refused to join. A senior Turkish government official said Wednesday that Turkey is unlikely to join a multinational force or commit itself to allowing the United States to use the strategic NATO air base at Incirlik for any military intervention in the Persian Gulf. Britain said it would send two squadrons of warplanes and a number of ground-to-air missiles and to defend Saudi Arabia and other gulf states, Defense Secretary Tom King said today. The Defense Ministry said each squadron consisted of about 12 planes. King said Britain's contribution to the multinational effort also included three mine sweepers, to be deployed initially to the Eastern Mediterranean. The British destroyer HMS York is already in the gulf, and two frigates are expected to arrive there this weekend. Britain decided Wednesday to join the multinational force following a formal request for British assistance from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. France, one of the few members of the 16-nation NATO alliance with an appropriate military capability, said Wednesday that it had not been asked by Saudi Arabia to send forces. France, which has two ships just outside the Persian Gulf and a frigate with Exocet missiles en route, said French participation was not envisaged at this stage in a multinational force. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said Wednesday that his country had not sent troops but advocatged an Arab multinational force. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose forces invaded neighboring Kuwait one week ago to touch off the crisis, has denied he intends to invade Saudi Arabia. But Iraqi forces are reported massing on the borders with Saudi Arabia and Turkey. The Portuguese Foreign Minister said late Wednesday that Portugal has granted the United States use of the air base at Lajes in the Azores islands in the mid-Atlantic in the build-up operation of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia that began Wednesday. Portuguese news reports said six U.S. Air Force midair refueling planes landed at the Lajes base on Wednesday. The base is shared by Portuguese and U.S. forces. Italy has agreed to let bases be used to help facilitate transport of troops and equipment and for logistical support, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti's office announced Wednesday. Spain, whose Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez opposes outside intervention in the Persian Gulf, nonetheless agreed Wednesday to allow the United States to use four jointly operated military bases to support U.S. troops. Bonn signaled readiness Wednesday to allow the U.S. military to use American facilities in West Germany as a ``basis for operations'' for soldiers headed to Saudi Arabia. West Germany said Tuesday its constitution bars use of German troops outside the country. Greece said Wednesday that nine U.S. support planes were granted permission to pass through Greek airspace on their way to the Persian Gulf. The Chinese Foreign Ministry said in a statement today that the crisis in the Persian Gulf should be solved by gulf states and Arab countries: ``The outside forces, especially the superpowers, should not be involved in this matter. Otherwise, it will intensify the crisis.'' Japan has expressed support for the U.S. decision to send troops into Saudi Arabia as a defensive measure.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Community Mobilizes to Fight Strictures on Federal Grants
DOC.TEXT: An ``art ambulance'' carrying coffins containing once-banned books and paintings tours Boston neighborhoods. A reproduction of Rodin's famous sculpture, ``The Thinker,'' is covered daily with a shroud in San Francisco. A jazz funeral is held at the New Orleans Museum of Art. Curtain speeches are given at New York Shakespeare Festival performances in Central Park. Brochures mailed by the Virginia Symphony depict Michelangelo's statue of David with the slogan ``Banned in the U.S.A.?'' pasted over his genitals. Across the country this summer, the arts community is belatedly mobilizing public support for the National Endowment for the Arts in the escalating brouhaha over federal financing of controversial art. Characteristically slow to anger, arts supporters have begun striking back at conservative members of Congress and religious fundamentalists who accuse the NEA of subsidizing obscene and blasphemous art with taxpayers' funds. Concert audiences, theatergoers and visitors to museums and art galleries are being recruited as foot soldiers in the arts advocates' battle to protect the NEA from serious damage this fall when Congress debates extending the life of the $171 million federal arts agency. Pamphlets labeled ``Be Quiet and the Arts Will Just Go Away'' are being handed to theater patrons in Chicago, courtesy of the Illinois Arts Alliance. Inside are cutout post cards urging senators and House members to support the NEA, and this warning: ``A small faction of politicians and extreme right-wingers want to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts, which provides government support for artists and arts institutions in the United States. This minority is well organized and vocal. Their side is winning.'' In Baltimore, patrons of Baltimore Symphony Orchestra concerts, Center Stage plays and Maryland Art Place exhibition openings are asked to write members of Congress, sign petitions and dial a special 900 telephone number appealing for a five-year extension of the NEA, without any anti-obscenity restrictions on the grants it awards. ``It's now time for us to stand up,'' said Philip Arnoult, director of the Theater Project in Baltimore. The League of American Theaters and Producers in New York published a pro-NEA editorial in Playbills that have reached an estimated 1 million theatergoers. The Metropolitan Arts Commission in Portland, Ore., working with Mayor Bud Clark, won the endorsement of the U.S. Conference of Mayors for a letter to Congress urging no-strings support for the endowment. Besides the ``art ambulance'' and a multimedia ``Caravan for Freedom of Expression'' van that has toured Boston neighborhoods, arts supporters there have circulated a ``Declaration of Cultural Rights'' that opposes what they view as threatened government censorship of the arts. A full-page advertisement in the Boston Globe last month, featuring a once-controversial John Singer Sargent portrait of a woman with a plunging neckline, resulted in 1,000 calls urging members of Congress to support the NEA, the ad's sponsors said. An estimated 5,000 patrons of San Francisco Bay Area bookstores signed letters petitioning Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., to vote against anti-obscenity curbs on the endowment. Rodin's ``The Thinker'' was shrouded for an hour every day during a 12-day ``Festival for Freedom of Expression'' in San Francisco that was backed by more than 200 arts organizations. Bob Lynch, director of the non-profit National Association of Local Arts Agencies, said his organization's 900-number campaign has yielded an estimated 100,000 mailgrams and perhaps a half-million personal calls and letters to Capitol Hill in support of the endowment. Although the NEA's conservative critics are heavily financed, Lynch said, ``we will ultimately win because it is becoming clear that Americans recognize the value of the arts and the endowment, and are not people who respond blindly to the other side's appeals to `stop sin'.'' The House has agreed to begin debate on the arts endowment's fate in September, when it will consider Republican-led proposals to restrict the agency's grant-making authority, shift the bulk of its grant money to state control or abolish the NEA altogether. ``Time is of the essence,'' said Anne Murphy, executive director of the non-profit American Arts Alliance, a national arts advocacy coalition. ``Every individual who calls, writes or meets personally with a member of Congress really does help.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Turkey Denies Report That Iraq Sending Forces to Turkish Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE defense minister denying border buildup but saying military leaves have been canceled. Pickup 6th, `Iraq, which...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has started beefing up its forces along the border with Turkey, a news agency reported today, two days after Turkey effectively shut down pipelines carrying Iraqi oil through its territory. However, Turkey's defense minister, Safa Giray, denied the report, telling The Associated Press: ``We have received no intelligence indicating Iraq has added to troops already deployed in the area.'' Giray also denied Turkish news reports that Turkey has increased its military readiness by moving some air force fighter planes to bases close to the border with Iraq. But he said the government has canceled the leaves of all high level-military officials and the vacations of civilian officials. The semi-official Anatolia news agency, which quoted villagers on the Iraqi side of the border, said the Iraqi reinforcements included armored units. Anatolia, which did not say how large the Iraqi force was, said about 1,500 Turkish sentries had been sent to border guard stations that had been unmanned since last year when a cease-fire took effect in the Iran-Iraq war. Iraq's ambassador to Greece, Abdel Fetah al-Khazreji, also told reporters in Athens today there was no buildup of Iraqi forces on the border with Turkey. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed it on Wednesday, has reportedly massed tens of thousands of troops along Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia, prompting fears that Baghdad will invade Saudi Arabia. The United States has sent thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia to defend it against a possible attack, and nation's around the world have imposed economic sanctions on Iraq in an effort to force it to pullout of Kuwait. As part of that effort, Turkey effectively ordered a shutdown Tuesday of pipelines carrying Iraqi oil through its territory by banning ships from loading Iraqi crude at offshore terminals in the eastern Mediterranean. The pipelines carried more half of Iraq's total exports from its northern fields. Turkey also banned trade with Iraq and froze $25 million in Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who is visiting Ankara, today assured Turkey it would receive full support from NATO if it becomes a target of Iraqi intimidation for taking a ``forthright stand'' against Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: The Bible in Mongolian _ An 18-Year Task
DOC.TEXT: The New Testament of the Christian Bible has been translated into Mongolian for the first time, and 5,000 copies are printed and awaiting distribution, the United Bible Societies said. The translator is a 45-year-old Englishman, John Gibbens, who became interested in the project when he visited the communist Mongolian People's Republic in 1972. He spent 18 years on his self-appointed task. Gibbens was helped by his Mongolian wife, Altaa, whom he met on his second visit in 1978. He is now working on a Mongolian translation of the Old Testament, Steven Downey, information officer for the United Bible Societies, said Wednesday. The societies coordinate worldwide Bible translation, publishing and distribution. Mongolia is officially atheist, and Downey said it is believed to have fewer than a dozen Christians. But with growing political freedom there has been a resurgence of interest in the traditional Buddhist religion inside the country.

DOC.HEAD: Lorenzo Selling Most of Continental Airlines Stake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Lorenzo and why he decided to resign; picks up 3rd graf, `His departure ...' SUBS grafs 9-10, `The Wall ...,' with 1 graf to CORRECT total compensation to $29.8 million, sted $15 million, DELETE outdated material; picks up 11th graf, `SAS, which ...'
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo, a central figure during a tumultuous period in the airline industry and the bane of organized labor, announced today he was getting out of the business. Lorenzo's Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. said he was selling most of his stake in the company, formerly known as Texas Air Corp., to Scandinavian Airlines System. He also will quit as chairman and chief executive but will walk away with nearly $30 million in severance payments and sale proceeds. Lorenzo told reporters at a New York news briefing that he decided to resign partly because the barrage of negative publicity about his management practices was hurting the company's overall performance. ``It's been obvious to me that I've become a lightning rod for many of the attacks the company's taken,'' Lorenzo said. ``This transaction allows me to step aside.'' His departure marks the end of an era in the U.S. airline industry, which has undergone sweeping changes since deregulation more than a decade ago. Using billions of dollars in borrowed money, cheap fares and bankruptcy laws to restructure high-cost airlines Continental and Eastern, Lorenzo expanded his company to the nation's biggest airline operator with about 20 percent of the domestic market. But Lorenzo has been bitterly criticized by airline unions, which were driven from Continental and waged a bitter strike at Eastern. Both airlines are under extreme financial pressure, and doubts are widespread about Eastern's ability to survive. Lorenzo, 50, said he will be replaced as chief executive by Hollis L. Harris, president of rival Delta Airlines. He called Harris ``one of the industry's most experienced and highly regarded executives.'' Delta confirmed today that Harris, 58, left the company, effective Wednesday, to assume a position with Continental. Delta said Ronald W. Allen, its chairman, would take on Harris' duties. Lorenzo will immediately get about $17.13 million in cash. He also will get $2.7 million over three years and $10 million from SAS for his stake in Continental. But the $29.8 million total is still only a franction of what he was worth a few years ago when his airlines were in better shape. SAS, which first bought a stake in Lorenzo's business a few years ago, said it was spending $50 million on the transaction, which already was approved by Continental Holdings' board of directors. Lorenzo became one of the most despised figures among union groups in the 1980s because of what they called his brutal treatment of organized labor. The most dramatic result: a strike at Eastern Airlines in March 1989 that prompted the carrier to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors while it reorganized. Lorenzo lost control of Eastern in April when federal bankruptcy judge Judge Burton Lifland placed the airline in the hands of a trustee, Martin Shugrue. Following that move, Lorenzo's company changed its name from Texas Air to Continental Airlines Holdings, borrowing the name of the airline that Lorenzo acquired in 1982 and continues to run. The sale of Lorenzo's stake would boost SAS's interest in Continental Holdings to 16.8 percent in terms of equity and 18.4 percent in terms of voting control. SAS already holds 9.8 percent of Continental Holdings and has a seat on the board. The transaction will require approval of the U.S. Department of Transportation. It does not appear to violate laws limiting foreign carriers to no more than a 25 percent stake in a U.S. airline.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Truck Collision
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline tanker truck collided with another truck Thursday, veered off a highway and burst into flames, killing eight people and injuring 12, police and radio reports said. The truck smashed through a line of people waiting for a bus before crashing next to a residential building, Spanish National Radio reported. Most of the victims were waiting in the line, said a police official. He said 12 people were injured, seven of them seriously. The police officer said the truck apparently lost its brakes and went out of control on Highway 301 heading south out of Murcia. The accident killed the driver of the tanker truck. A fire that broke out after the accident destroyed about 10 cars and damaged several apartment buildings lining the highway, according to the radio.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian President Says Soviet Troops Won't Disarm Militants
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin has agreed to let Armenian authorities try to disarm thousands of militants in the republic and will not resort to sending in troops, the new president of Armenia said Thursday. Levon Ter-Petrosyan also said it is time to ``expand state sovereignty'' of his republic, and he said he is ready to negotiate with neighboring Azerbaijan over the bitter dispute involving control of the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Speaking at a news conference in Moscow, Ter-Petrosyan said he had ``positive'' talks with Soviet KGB and Interior Ministry chiefs Wednesday about thousands of Armenian National Army volunteers defying President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order to turn in their weapons and disband. Gorbachev had threatened to send in Soviet Army and Interior Ministry troops to forcibly disarm militants if they did not turn in their weapons by Thursday. Soviet Interior Minister Vadim A. Bakatin had suggested the deadline be extended. Neither Ter-Petrosyan nor Bakatin, who spoke in a Tass interview, defined the new deadline. Ter-Petrosyan also dismissed Kremlin estimates of up to 160,000 members in the Armenian National Army as ``grossly exaggerated,'' saying there are ``not more than 5,000.'' The 45-year-old nationalist, once jailed by the Soviets for organizing demonstrations over Nagorno-Karabakh, was elected Armenian president on Saturday. He said he agreed with Moscow that Armenian authorities will carry out Gorbachev's order to disarm militants. ``As regards the deadlines, we talked about the fact that I am a new leader of the republic and I cannot be held responsible for the sins of the previous leadership,'' Ter-Petrosyan told reporters, speaking in a pink marble hall at the Armenian government mission in Moscow. ``But there was quite clear agreement it (the decree) will be implemented by our own means, without any interference from the Soviet Army or the Interior (Ministry) troops,'' he said. Bakatin told Tass that Armenia's new leaders agreed on ``the need to strengthen law and order, protect citizens and rule out the unlawful bearing of arms.'' Gorbachev, trying to quell violence in this ethnically diverse nation, on July 26 gave militants across the Soviet Union 15 days to turn in their weapons. Many militants, especially those in Armenia, have refused to comply. Armenia's parliament, which this week is considering a declaration of independence, rejected Gorbachev's decree as interference. Although no specific republic was mentioned in the decree, it clearly was aimed chiefly at Armenia. Ter-Petrosyan said he had a ``warm conversation'' with the vacationing Gorbachev by telephone this week. ``He expressed his readiness to cooperate with the new leadership ... hence, my visit to Moscow,'' said Ter-Petrosyan, who also met with KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov and Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Ter-Petrosyan told reporters the main goal for Armenia is ``to expand state sovereignty and radically democratize social life.'' He also said it is possible for Armenia to have good-neighborly relations with its traditional enemies _ the Moslem Azerbaijanis, Turks, and Iran. Ter-Petrosyan said he is ready to open talks with Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian enclave that is part of Azerbaijan. He said ``there is a basis for compromise.'' ``The first step to be taken, which will satisfy both sides, is to restore Soviet power and operation of Soviet laws in Karabakh,'' he said. ``That is the only territory in the Soviet Union where there is no Soviet power. It is an occupied land, ruled by the army.'' Ter-Petrosyan also said he and Bakatin agreed that the state of emergency in Nagorno-Karabakh will be eased. Ethnic battles between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over who should control the mountainous region have killed more than 200 people in the past two years. He said his administration's priorities are settling the Nagorno-Karabakh crisis, restoring the area devastated by the Dec. 7, 1988, Armenian earthquake, and easing the plight of the thousands of Armenian refugees fleeing ethnic unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Challenges State's Runoff System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs `Georgia's majority ...' with 1 graf to DELETE Dunne's reference to governor's race being the exception
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department filed suit under the Voting Rights Act today challenging Georgia's runoff election system that requires candidates to receive a majority of the vote to win an election. The law, similar to legislation in eight other Southern states, gives ``white candidates an extraordinary power,'' said John R. Dunne, assistant U.S. attorney general for civil rights. The law has stymied black candidates who may win the most votes in a three-way race with two white candidates but can't gain a majority in the ensuing two-way runoff. Dunne said the law has had ``a demonstratively chilling effect on the intent and willingness of blacks to become candidates for office'' across the South. The other states with similar runoff systems are: Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Texas. Georgia's majority vote law requires a runoff election in every state, local and federal election in which a candidate does not receive a majority of the vote. The suit, filed in Atlanta, is the first challenge of a majority vote runoff system brought by the Justice Department under the 1965 Voting Rights Act. Perry Michael, assistant state attorney general, said Georgia officials only learned of the suit today and would not comment until they have reviewed it. Dunne said the lawsuit was similar to one filed earlier in Georgia by state Rep. Tyrone Brooks. But unlike the Brooks suit, he said, the Justice Department action does not seek to invalidate the entire runoff law. Dunne said the Justice suit would challenge only those elections in which the majority vote requirement has been used to dilute the voting strength of minorities. That would include all statewide elections and many local elections where blacks comprise a majority of the voting population but have been unable to elect black candidates. Although 24 percent of Georgia's voting age population is black, Dunne said blacks hold fewer than 10 percent of elected offices in the state, and most of those are at the local level. ``The higher the office and the broader the constituency, the smaller the number of black elected officials,'' he said. Dunne said the department waited until after Georgia's Tuesday runoff election in the Democratic primary for governor to file the suit so the action could not be interpreted as a challenge to those results.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Envoys at Arab Summit; Security Council Rejects Annexation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Iraqi envoys arriving for Arab summit, U.N. vote, Iraq borders sealed, details on Britain's contribution to multinational force. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6,7,8,MYB1,FTSX1,FAYX1
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders gathered today for a high-stakes summit that brought together envoys from conquering Iraq and the ruler of vanquished Kuwait. The U.N. Security Council rejected Baghdad's annexation of the emirate. The fate of thousands of foreigners trapped by Iraq's lightning invasion of Kuwait one week ago became even more uncertain today, as Iraq sealed its borders to all foreigners except diplomats. Thousands of American troops poured into Saudi Arabia today and reportedly took up positions within seven miles from the Iraqi border, and Iraq's envoy to the Cairo summit denounced ``overt U.S. threats to the Arab nation.'' The troops were sent to protect Saudi Arabia. Iraq has promised not to invade it _ but it had said the same thing about Kuwait, which it annexed Wednesday, six days after the invasion. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, in his first public comment on the invasion, today called it ``the most horrible aggression'' in the Arab world's modern history. Secretary of State James A. Baker III today visited another of Iraq's neighbors, Turkey, and assured officials of full support from NATO if Turkey, too, becomes a target of Iraqi intimidation. Turkey's semi-official Anatolia news agency today quoted villagers on the Iraqi side of the border with Turkey as saying Iraq has started beefing up its forces along the frontier. Turkey's defense minister denied the report, which comes two days after Turkey effectively shut down pipelines carrying Iraqi oil. On the economic front, delegates from industrialized nations gathered in Paris today to assess the impact of the international boycott against Iraq, imposed to punish Baghdad for the invasion. Iraq is the world's second-largest crude exporter after Saudi Arabia. In other developments today: _To solidify what it called its merger with Kuwait, Iraq today appointed the head of Kuwait's Iraq-installed government a deputy prime minister of Iraq, and canceled Baghdad's multibillion-dollar debt to Kuwait. _Israel today launched the first test of a new missile developed to combat short-range ballistic missiles. Israel radio said it was a direct response to an Iraqi threat a day earlier. _Iran, which fought a bloody eight-year war with Iraq, today warned that Tehran ``will not tolerate'' Baghdad's annexation of Kuwait. A Foreign Ministry statement quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency said the Iraqi takeover brought on a ``crisis'' in the region. _Stock prices tumbled in Tokyo today amid pessimism about how the Middle East crisis will affect the economy of Japan, which relies on imports for virtually all its oil needs. But stock prices rolled forward in London in a recovery triggered in part by Wall Street's strength a day earlier. Two top Iraqi officials were in Cairo for the emergency Arab summit: Taha Yassin Ramadan, Iraq's first deputy premier and a member of the ruling military junta, and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Ramadan said he was attending the summit ``to confront the overt U.S. threats to the Arab nation.'' ``U.S. land, naval and air forces have taken up positions on Arab territories and waters to attack Iraq,'' he told reporters in Baghdad before leaving for Cairo. His comments were distributed by the Iraqi News Agency. Arab diplomatic sources had said the absence of Saddam or key aides from the summit would dim the chances of effective action by the Arab heads of state. Kuwait's deposed emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, also arrived today to take Kuwait's seat at the summit. Egypt and most Arab states recognize the ousted government as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Arab nations were initially slow to denounce the invasion, and have been reluctant to join in the U.S.-led multinational military effort. Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, instead suggested an all-Arab deterrent force. But the lone Arab member on the U.N. Security Council _ Yemen _ joined in the 15-0 vote declaring Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' The resolution calls upon all states and international organizations not to recognize the annexation and not to take any action that might be interpreted as inderect recognition of the annexation. The Saudis and other oil producers including Venezuela, Mexico, Iran and Nigeria have indicated they will pump more crude to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti production, which experts say totaled 4 million barrels daily before the crisis. Oil prices, which had shot up at the onset of the crisis, began dropping. In Paris, delegates from industrialized nations said there was no immediate danger to world oil supplies. ``Presently there is not a significant shortfall of crude oil in the market,'' said U.S. Assistant Energy Secretary John Easton as the 21-nation International Energy Agency opened an emergency meeting today. President Bush is deploying thousands of troops and scores of warplanes in the Saudi desert and has send three aircraft carrier groups to the region. Iraq has an estimated 100,000 troops just across the border in Kuwait _ but the Americans have superior air and sea power. Diplomatic sources in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, said U.S. Marines arrived early today near Khafji, a coastal city seven miles south of the Kuwaiti border that includes an oil terminal. Bush declined to discuss the size of the U.S. military force. But government sources said Wednesday at least 5,000 ground troops were en route or already taking up positions on Saudi soil, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers. Diplomatic sources said the U.S. force buildup would total at least 40,000 troops. Several other estimates ranged up to 50,000. In addition, a formidable U.S. naval fleet is gathering in and around the Gulf and the Mediterranean. Travellers from the Khafji border point said Saudi troops in the area confronting the Iraqi-occupied Kuwait were buttressing their own positions continuously with missiles, tanks and armor. So far, Britain is the only nation to commit troops to the U.S.-led effort, though other countries have offered support such as use of bases. Britain said today it would send two squadrons of warplanes and a number of ground-to-air missiles, along with three mine sweepers, to be deployed initially to the Eastern Mediterranean. The British destroyer HMS York is already in the Persian Gulf, and two frigates are expected to arrive there this weekend. Bush promised severe retaliation if Saddam used chemical weapons against American soldiers. Saddam used the arms against Iran during the countries' 8-year war and also against Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority. Iraq's envoy to Greece suggested today that Iraq is prepared to use chemical weapons if attacked. ``If we are attacked by a foreign power we will retaliate with all sorts of defensive weapons that we have,'' the ambassador, Abdel Fetah al-Khazreji, said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts End Six-Month Mission With Rich Payload
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts whose mission was plagued by technical problems and a perilous spacewalk returned to Earth on Thursday with a multimillion-ruble payload of space-grown crystals. The Soyuz TM-9 capsule carrying Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin landed on the Central Asian steppes at 11:34 a.m., one minute ahead of schedule. The landing was not broadcast live on Soviet television. But the midday ``Vremya'' TV news program showed the cosmonauts waving goodbye to their replacement crew before leaving the orbiting space station Mir. ``Back in the landing spaceship, we felt the slightly bitter smell of absinthe in the Kazakh steppe,'' Solovyev told reporters after landing and ending his six-month stay in space. ``I also dreamed that my wife would bring me fresh delicious apples when I was back on Earth,'' he said in remarks carried by the Tass news agency. Solovyev and Balandin were launched into space Feb. 11 in what was trumpeted as the first manned mission in the 33-year history of the Soviet space program to turn a multimillion-dollar profit. They conducted hundreds of experiments, photographed 8.4 million square miles of the Earth's surface and grew 23 pure crystals for semiconductors and computer chips, Tass said. Tass said they also studied the influence of space flight on the development and behavior of birds, and that this would help develop life-support systems for future manned spacecraft. Crystals grown in the zero-gravity environment of space tend to have far fewer imperfections, such as ripples or other impurites, than those produced on Earth. The crystals are sliced into thin sheets and etched to create tiny circuits, or semiconductors, with optimum conductivity. Tass said each of the 23 crystals grown on the Mir station was worth $1 million, but the news agency did not say how big the crystals were or what material they were grown from. A $23 million profit from the space venture likely would help the cash-hungry Soviet government fend off criticism about the cost of its space program. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pressure has grown on the costly, but once sacrosanct, space program to prove its worth in a society where many people do not have decent housing or enough quality food to eat. Future expeditions to Mir will carry paying passengers. The first will be an employee of the Tokyo Broadcasting System, who will have a seat on an eight-day mission beginning Dec. 2. The Japanese passenger will return to Earth with the two cosmonauts currently aboard Mir, Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov. Manakov and Strekalov, who replaced Solovyev and Balandin, docked with the space station Aug. 3, two days after blasting off from the Baikonur Space Center in Kazakhstan. They will conduct an estimated 250 experiments over the next six months, including growing more crystals and making two spacewalks. Solovyev and Balandin made a life-threatening spacewalk July 17 to repair their capsule's thermal insulation, which was torn on takeoff. The repairs took seven hours, longer than anticipated, and their life-support supplies nearly ran out. Having damaged the exit-and-entry hatch at the beginning of the spacewalk, the cosmonauts were forced to return through an emergency porthole. In their haste, they left behind handrails attached to the exterior of the capsule. A second spacewalk was required July 26 to retrieve the handrails and fix the hatch.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Saudi King's Television Address
DOC.TEXT: The following is the text of King Fahd's television address as translated by the The Associated Press:

In the name of God the beneficent, the merciful. Brother citizens, God's peace, mercy and blessings be upon you. No doubt you know, by following the sudden and regrettable events in the Arabian Gulf region during the past few days, the extent of the dangerous situation confronted by the Arab nation under the present circumstances. No doubt you know that the kingdom of Saudi Arabia has exerted all it could in efforts and attempts with each of the governments of the Republic of Iraq and the State of Kuwait to contain the dispute that developed between the two countries, and I undertook in this connection a number of telephone contacts and brotherly talks. As a result, a bilateral meeting of Iraqi and Kuwaiti delegations was hosted by the kingdom in the attempts to heal the rift and prevent an escalation of matters. Some of the brothers, kings and heads of state of the Arab states, contributed vastly and commendably to this end, impelled by faith in the unity of the Arab nation and bolster its march toward solidarity and cooperation in a way that achieves complete success in these matters of destiny. But, most regrettably, matters took a course contrary to what we, the Islamic and Arab nations and the entire peace-loving world, were seeking. The painful and regrettable events developed as of the dawn of Aug. 2 in a manner that took the entire world by surprise _ when the Iraqi forces overran sister Kuwait in the most horrible aggression the Arab nation has known in its modern history. This rendered the people of Kuwait homeless and afflicted them with insufferable pains. The kingdom of Saudi Arabia expresses its deep denunciation of the the aggression on sister state Kuwait and declares its categoric rejection of all the measures and announcements that followed the assault. Likewise, statements from Arab leaderships, the Arab League, the Organization of Islamic Conference and the Gulf Cooperation Council, and all Arab and international organizations and authorities rejected them. The kingdom of Saudi Arabia affirms its demand that the situation in the sister state of Kuwait be restored to what it was before the Iraqi invasion and the return of the ruling family led by His Highness Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the emir and his government. We hope that the emergency Arab summit called by President Hosni Mubarak of sister Egypt will achieve the aspirations of the Arab nation and bolster its march toward solidarity and unity. Following that regrettable event, Iraq ventured to amass large numbers of troops on the border of the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Faced with this bitter reality and out of the kingdom's keenness to safeguard its territory and protect its vital and economic potential, and desirous of bolstering its defensive potential and enhance the level of training for its armed forces, and out of its interest in peace and non-resort to arms in settling differences, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia expressed its desire for the participation of sister Arab forces and other friends. The governments of the United States of America and Britain and other states hastened by virtue of the bonds of friendship between the kingdom of Saudi Arabia and these states to send air and land troops to help the Saudi armed forces perform their duty in defense of the homeland and the nation against any aggression, while affirming that this measure is not directed against any one but is a purely defensive measure dictated by the circumstances that the kingdom of Saudi Arabia is confronting. It is worth noting that these forces will participate in joint exercises with the Saudi armed forces and their presence on Saudi territory will be temporary. They will leave here as soon as the kingdom so demands. We ask God to guide our steps for the good of our faith, and the safety of our lands. God's peace, mercy and blessing be upon you.
