DOC.HEAD: Arab League-at-a-Glance
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts on the Arab League and its members' positions on the Iraq-Kuwait controversy.

HISTORY _ The Arab League was founded in 1945. Summit conferences as an instrument of policy began in 1964. Because of frequent inter-Arab bickering, there have been more emergency summits than regular ones.

MEMBERSHIP _ The league had 22 members until May, when the merger of North Yemen and South Yemen lowered membership to 21. They are Algeria, Bahrain, Djibouti, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, Tunisia, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization, now officially listed as Palestine.

POSITION ON IRAQ-KUWAIT CRISIS _ Member foreign ministers, meeting as the Arab League Council, gathered in Cairo on Aug. 3 to consider Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Fourteen members voted for a resolution condemning the invasion and urging immediate Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of the overthrown Kuwait government. By Egyptian government count, the 14 were: Algeria, Bahrain, Djibouti, Egypt, Lebanon, Mauritania, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Syria, Tunisia and the UAE. Against were Jordan, the PLO, Sudan and Yemen. Iraq and Kuwait had no right to vote on the issue. Libya was absent. Those who opposed the resolution argued that condemnation of Iraq would undermine Arab efforts to achieve a peaceful solution. Despite their dissent, the league accepted Egypt's call for an emergency summit. Libya also accepted.

DOC.HEAD: White House Calls Anew For Multinational Force
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs, SUBS 11th graf pvs, By air... to UPDATE with Pentagon saying no Marines involved; editing thruout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The White House issued a fresh call today for other nations to join the United States in a military buildup to defend Saudi Arabia from possible attack by Iraq. More U.S. forces arrived in the Persian Gulf, and the Pentagon said Iraq was beefing up its forces in Kuwait. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said an estimated 120,000 Iraqi troops are now in Kuwait and that Iraq also had improved air defenses in Kuwait as part of what appeared to be defensive measures. ``They're holding on to what they have acquired,'' Williams said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush ``is very satisfied with the course of events in the last 24 hours.'' He declined to criticize Egypt or other Arab nations for failing to join the United States and Britain in the defense of Saudi Arabia. `The United States acted in the interest of our country and other Western nations,'' Fitzwater said. ``We would always like to see others participate but the organization of that is up to the Saudis.'' Fitzwater said the Gulf Cooperation Council countries _ Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates as well as Saudi Arabia _ have a 3,000-member force in Saudi Arabia. The Pentagon declined to detail the size of the U.S. deployment, but Williams did say all F-15 fighters sent to Saudi Arabia had arrived, as have five AWACs planes. Six U.S. ships are in the Mediterranean and two aircraft carrier groups are positioned in the Red and Arabian seas, he said. Fitzwater told a White House briefing that Bush would exempt the military operation from mandatory spending cuts that could be triggered if the president and Congress do not reach agreement on cutting the federal deficit. The Middle East crisis notwithstanding, Bush planned to leave Washington on Friday for a 25-day vacation at his oceanfront home in Maine. Bush likely will return to the White House for a day or so next week for military briefings, Fitzwater said. The Bush administration has urged Americans to leave Iraq and Kuwait, but Fitzwater said Iraq's borders remain closed and only diplomats are being allowed to leave. The State Department said Iraq turned over a 10-year-old girl, Penelope Nabokov of Albany, Calif., to U.S. diplomats in Baghdad but kept 38 other Americans confined to a hotel under armed guard. By air and sea, additional U.S. troops and equipment headed for the Saudi kingdom and elsewhere in the gulf region. Diplomatic sources in Saudi Arabia said U.S. troops arrived today near Khafji, a coastal oil city seven miles south of the Kuwaiti border. The Saudi sources had identified the troops as U.S. Marines but the Pentagon today said no Marines are among the forces deployed in Saudi Arabia. Even more troops still on U.S. soil were placed on alert for possible Mideast duty and Air National Guard members in a handful of states were activated. At the United Nations, the Security Council voted 15-0 to declare Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' The U.S. ambassador to the forum, Thomas Pickering, said ``the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the large military presence on the Saudi frontier creates grave risk of further aggression in the area.'' Fitzwater characterized the vote as ``one more block to the growing international foundation of condemnation.'' The president's actions are winning broad support in Congress, but concerns were raised today about the lack of clear support from other Arab nations. ``If it appears that it's the United States and Saudi Arabia versus the rest of the Arab world, then that is not going to be in our longterm interest or Saudi Arabia's interest,'' Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn said. While expressing support for the deployment, Nunn cautioned that ``a longterm, protracted presence of 50,000 to 100,000 people is in my view not desirable either militarily or certainly psychologically or politically in that part of the world.'' Hopes of a diplomatic resolution to the crisis rested largely on a gathering of Arab leaders in Egypt. But a summit meeting planned for today was postponed until Friday. The effort to win regional support for its campaign against Iraq's Saddam Hussein has the United States sounding out unlikely partners _ including Iran, Syria and the Soviet Union. Also, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Turkey today for consultations with its leaders, and told them the deposed Kuwaiti leadership had promised to help Turkey make up for revenues it expects to lose because it shut down two pipelines that carry Iraqi oil. Bush himself was out of the public eye this morning. On Wednesday, he expressed optimism that the worldwide economic pressure would force Saddam to abandon his conquest of Kuwait and his threatening military position on the Saudi border. ``There are some indications that he's already beginning to feel the pinch,'' Bush said at a news conference. ``Nobody can stand up forever to total economic deprivation.'' The stakes are high. Saudi Arabia provided 7 percent of U.S. oil last year. Bush is counting on increased production from the Saudis and other oil producers to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies. ``A line has been drawn in the sand,'' Bush declared as U.S. warplanes and ground forces arrived in Saudi Arabia. However, he said, ``We're not in a war.'' Top U.S. military officials refused to reveal the size of the president's commitment to Saudi defense, but some Middle East diplomatic sources put the troop level at about 30,000. Other estimates ranged up to 50,000. Those totals would include ground and air forces as well as sailors aboard ships in the region. On the first day of deployment, at least 5,000 ground troops were being dispatched, officials said, backed by an armada of air and seapower. No one was guessing how long they would be away from home. ``The situation's uncertain. We don't know how long it will last. We don't know when it will end,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said. Baker told reporters the Soviet Union sent naval forces to the Persian Gulf for use in any international blockade to enforce a United Nations trade embargo following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. Baker also dispatched an aide to Syria ``to see if we can coordinate'' and added the United States has been in touch with Iran ``through third party contacts.'' Both nations are bitter foes of Iraq. But Syria is on the official State Department list of states supporting terrorism, and Iran has long been accused of pulling the strings behind the holders of American hostages in Lebanon. Bush said U.S. forces would safeguard the Saudi oilfields but would not attempt to drive Iraqi troops from tiny Kuwait. Bush warned Saddam not to use his arsenal of chemical weapons, saying that ``would be dealt with very, very severely.'' U.S. troops were equipped with medical supplies and protective clothing to counter a chemical weapon attack. Bush explained why he ordered the largest military deployment since the Vietnam war, saying America imports half its oil and ``could face a major threat to its economic independence'' if Saddam took over the oilfields of the Persian Gulf. Military sources said the U.S. contingent included 140 jet fighters and bombers as well as battleships that carried 32 Tomahawk Cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific targets in Iraq. ``You can be sure that for the mission we have been given we will put in adequate forces,'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Pentagon briefing. He expressed confidence that American forces were prepared for battle in the hostile, desert environment if called upon. ``We've trained for it, we've exercised in it,'' Powell said. He said the battle-hardened Iraqis ``are not invincible. They are not 10 feet tall.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Refuse to Join US Force in Saudi Arabia
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union refused Thursday to join a U.S.-led multinational force to stem Iraqi aggression but said it might go along if the United Nations organized a similar operation. ``At this stage we do not consider the possibility of participating in either the international force or naval blockade,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri D. Gremitskikh told reporters. He coupled the Soviet restraint with a fresh demand that Iraq restore the ``sovereignty, national independence and territorial integrity of the state of Kuwait.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The Soviet determination to refrain from military involvement showed how stringently the Kremlin was sticking to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of ``new thinking'' in foreign affairs. That policy, which calls for non-violent means of settling conflicts and respect for other nations' positions, has been most evident in the Soviet decisions to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan and to refrain from force to keep communist regimes in place in Eastern Europe. In another development, the Soviet Union's point man in diplomatic contacts over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov, met Thursday in Moscow with representatives of Warsaw Pact nations, Tass reported. The news agency said Belonogov and Yuri Kvitsinsky, another deputy foreign minister, told the representatives about Soviet efforts to resolve the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The Soviet people began speaking out publicly, as well, and state television aired a panel discussion by political commentators about the situation. ``We Warn: The Danger of Neo-Nazism. Hitler Began the Same Way,'' read posters bearing a picture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and displayed at a demonstration outside Iraq's embassy in Moscow. About 100 people took part in the protest and burned the posters. Stanislav Kondrashov, an analyst for the government newspaper Izvestia, said in the TV discussion that the Soviet Union is joining a worldwide boycott of Iraqi oil. The Soviet Union, a major oil producer, received Iraqi oil as payment for goods, then passed the crude on to Bulgaria and India, Kondrashov said. Alexei Vassilev, deputy director of the Soviet Institute of Africa, said on the TV program the Soviet Union would benefit financially overall because the Iraqi crisis had driven up oil prices, including those of Soviet crude. Gremitskikh told a news briefing that Gorbachev had contacted Saddam by telegram, hoping to persuade the Iraqi leader to adhere to the U.N. Security Council resolution to withdraw from Kuwait, Gremitskikh said. ``Unfortunately our hopes were not fulfilled,'' he said. He signaled the Soviets have no intention of sending troops into Saudi Arabia, as the United States has done. ``The Soviet position is that the settlement in connection with the Iraqi invasion into Kuwait must be coordinated within the (U.N.) Security Council,'' Gremitskikh said. If the United Nations approved a multinational force or naval blockade ``then we would think about it and would take our own sovereign decision about what to do,'' he said. The Soviet Union has taken some protective military action, however. The spokesman said two Soviet warships, a destroyer and an anti-submarine vessel, were dispatched from the Indian Ocean to the Persian Gulf ``to protect Soviet maritime traffic.'' Gremitskikh said Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze spoke to Secretary of State James A. Baker III by telephone twice Wednesday and received assurance the American-led troops massing in Saudi Arabia would leave as soon as tensions eased. Baker told reporters traveling with him to Turkey that he spoke to Shevardnadze again Thursday. He quoted the Soviet minister as saying Moscow had dispatched its warships to the gulf for use in any international blockade. Gremitskikh would not elaborate on their conversation. He read a Foreign Ministry statement that shied away from direct criticism of the U.S.-led multinational force but appeared to be referring to the operation when it called for prevention of ``actions that may pour oil on the flames.'' ``The experience of many years shows that the most correct and sensible way of acting in conflict situations is through collective efforts and the utmost use of U.N. mechanisms,'' the statement said. Gremitskikh said the Soviet Union, which had been Iraq's main arms supplier, has a special responsibility for ending the crisis. Moscow suspended all arms sales to Baghdad shortly after the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Security Council Declares Iraqi Annexation Null and Void
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi and Soviet comment to the Sekcurity Council. Pickup 3rd, `The resolution...
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council today unanimously declared Iraq's annexation of Kuwait to be ``null and void'' and called on all nations to shun the government Baghdad installed in Kuwait. The vote was 15-0 on the council, which met for the third time in one week to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and to support the ousted government. The majority included the council's only Arab member, Yemen. Iraq's ambassador, Amir al-Anbari, rejected the resolution, telling the council: ``My government reaffirms the unity between Iraq and Kuwait is an indestructible one. It is eternal and irreversible.'' Al-Anbari denounced the U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia, saying it is responsible for instability. He said his government ``respects the territorial integrity of all neighboring Arab states, including the brotherly country of Saudi Arabia.'' The Soviet delegate, Ambassador Valentin V. Lozinskiy, told the council his government opposes use of force and unilateral decisions and favors U.N. solutions to resolve such conflicts. The resolution says, ``Annexation of Kuwait by Iraq under any form and whatever pretext has no legal validity, and is considered null and void.'' It calls upon all states and international organizations not to recognize the annexation and not to take any action that might be interpreted as inderect recognition of the annexation. It ``demands that Iraq rescind its actions purporting to annex Kuwait.'' The resolution repeats its demand that Iraq withdraw immediately and unconditionally. It also says it is determined to bring the occupaion of Kuwait to an end and restore the nation's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity. The resolution says the council is determined to restore the authority of the legitimate government of Kuwait. On Monday, the Security Council voted 13-0 with two abstentions to order a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq. Hours after Iraq invaded Kuwait last week, the Security Council unanimously condemned Iraq and demanded that it withdraw. Yemen abstained from both earlier resolutions. Cuba abstained from the call for an economic boycott. The council includes the five permanent members: The United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union and 10 other members: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire. The Security Council handles issues relating to international peace and security. Its resolutions are legally binding on all U.N. members, although past council resolutions have often been ignored or flouted. The United Nations has no enforcement mechanism.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Launches Test Missile, Shamir Warns Iraq Not To Attack
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In a dramatic response to an Iraqi threat, Israel on Thursday launched the first test of a new anti-ballistic missile. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned of ``heavy tragedy'' for any nation attacking Israel. The launch of the U.S.-financed Arrow missile came a day after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to start a missile attack on Israel. Saddam made the threat after alleging that Israeli warplanes had been painted with American colors in preparation for an attack on Iraq. Observers said the timing of the launch was a clear signal to Saddam _ who in April threatened to burn half of Israel with chemical weapons if attacked _ that Israel is a power to reckon with. The Arrow left a trail of fire and smoke and shot many miles up and westward in less than a minute, then fell in an arc into the Mediterranean, witnesses said. The Arrow was developed to combat the short-range ballistic missiles of the kind possessed by Iran. Washington provided 80 percent of the $158 million cost of the first phase of the project. Defense Minister Moshe Arens praised the Arrow as an important technological achievement but noted it was only a ``developing program at this stage.'' It is not expected to be operational until at least 1992. Shamir assured Arab countries Israel had no aggressive plans, but added: ``Whoever plots to attack Israel must know that Israel has the capability, will and readiness to defend its security absolutely, and whoever tries to hurt it is liable to bring on himself a heavy tragedy.'' ``Israel's defense and security forces are aware and alert and devoting their efforts to prevent any danger to the people and state,'' Shamir told Israel radio. Several Israeli analysts said Saddam may attack Israel in a frustrated response to a U.S. military move. ``What he is actually saying to the Americans is ... `I'm going to consider any military confrontation between Iraq and America as an Iraqi-American-Israeli confrontation,''' said Amatzia Baram, an Iraq expert at Haifa University. ```I cannot reach America, I don't have missiles that reach that far, but I can reach Israel. So you ought to know that if you launch an attack against me I'm going to press the button.''' The atmosphere of anxiety was reflected in newspaper editorials that called for distribution of gas masks to defend the population against a possible assault by chemical weapons. ``We don't have to panic, but is this not the time to calmly and quietly open our anti-chemical warfare arsenals that are intended for distribution to the people?'' Yediot Ahronot wrote. The army has decided in principle to distribute the masks to the entire population over the next six months, army officials said. In two locations, the army carried out test distribution 18 months ago. ``The government can give us means of defense. We don't have to be afraid,'' said 11-year-old Roi Samuel of Ramat Hasharon. He told Israel radio he keeps a government-supplied gas mask in his closet.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Weary Mel Gibson, squeezing his last ounce of energy for interviews promoting his new film ``Air America,'' is taking a year off. After his fourth movie without a break, the warrior has tired of the road. ``It gets to a point where your work suffers. I've got to go away and learn some new tricks. I've got to replenish my creative energy because I'm out of it,'' he said in an interview this week. Gibson said he reached the burnout stage near the end of filming the fourth movie, ``Hamlet,'' in which he co-stars with Glenn Close. ``Frankly, I didn't think I'd make it to the end of the movie. I simply ran out of gas, and when that happens it's a good idea to just go away for awhile,'' said the star, who gained fame in ``Road Warrior.'' Gibson's other recent films include ``Lethal Weapon 2'' and ``Bird on a Wire.'' He doesn't think the vacation will hurt his career. ``I don't pay much attention to that movie star stuff. And I don't pay much attention to that king of the hill stuff, either,'' Gibson said.

Ronald Reagan says even he was taken aback by the $2 million the Japanese paid him to make two speeches, but he doesn't consider it improper. ``I didn't have a fee; it was their offer,'' the former president said in the Aug. 12 issue of Parade Magazine. ``But I have to say this: Yes, it sounds a little out of line, even to me, that that much money was offered. ``But it wasn't cashing in on the presidency. If I'd been of a nature to cash in, I would have returned to the industry that I left,'' he said. ``I'm quite sure that there would have been some healthy fees offered me if I agreed to play a part in the movies.'' The 79-year-old Reagan said he plays golf once a week with actor friend Tom Selleck and has added four inches to his chest since leaving the White House. He's also started going to church, saying he has ``great faith in the man upstairs.'' ``What really ended church for me was when the Secret Service said that, with all the terrorism existing at the time, it wouldn't be just another assassination attempt against me, but that I could be responsible for a lot of deaths from a terrorist bomb. ... ``I missed it very much. But now I'm going to church again.''

The Duchess of York and her daughters arrived in London Thursday after a 12-day visit to Argentina. The wife of Prince Andrew was the first member of Britain's Royal Family to travel to Argentina since the two countries battled over the Falkland Islands. The 30-year-old former Sarah Ferguson was visiting her mother's husband, Hector Barrantes, who is seriously ill with cancer. It was Barrantes first visit with the Duchess of York's four-month-old daughter, Eugenie. Her older daughter, Beatrice, also made the trip.
DOC.HEAD: Ed: Also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: British ice skating champion Christopher Dean announced his engagement Thursday to French Canadian skater Isabelle Duchesnay. Dean, 32, met his 26-year-old fiancee nine years ago and has helped choreograph some of her skating routines. He proposed to her last week in Germany, where she is training for the 1992 Olympics. No wedding date has been set. ``There's a bit of a bug at the minute with everyone getting married -- we've all joined the same club,'' Dean said. Dean's skating partner, Jayne Torvill last month disclosed her engagement to Phil Christensen, a 35-year-old American sound engineer. They met when he worked on the Torvill and Dean tour of the United States last year. Torvill and Dean won a gold medal in the 1984 Olympics for Britain.

Irish singer Sinead O'Connor is suffering from an undiagnosed illness that may cause her to cancel dates on her U.S. tour, a publicist said Thursday. Concert-goers booed Tuesday after O'Connor cut short her performance by one song at the Star Lake Amphitheater in Washington County west of Pittsburgh. ``She's got to take it easy,'' publicist Elaine Schock said in a telephone interview from Pelham, N.Y. ``She wasn't feeling well, but went through the set anyway and cut the encore. That's not all that uncommon.'' About 6,100 people attended the show, paying $20.25 for tickets. O'Connor's recent single ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' and album ``I Do Not Want What I Haven't Got'' topped Billboard magazine's charts in both those categories.

DOC.HEAD: Seeing the Other Side of Watts: A Bank Manger's Perspective
With AM-Watts Anniversary Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Charlotte Burnett acknowledges her transfer three years ago to head a bank in Watts was not exactly the career move she had in mind. After all, for many Watts is the definition of urban blight and racial unrest, the community after which the Watts riot of 25 years ago was named. California Federal's Watts branch is on 103rd Street, once known as Charcoal Alley. But running the only bank in the Los Angeles community of Watts proved a rewarding experience and greatly changed Burnett's view of the community and its potential for the future. ``What I have found is that what I see on television and in the newspaper about the community is basically not very true or the whole picture,'' she said. ``I see a difference. I always see the negative (in the media). I see the positive here.'' Burnett is among a dedicated core of business people and community activists working to turn Watts around. From her vantage point as a bank vice president, Burnett sees the other side of Watts, the working people, the families, and retirees who overwhelmingly outnumber the drug dealers and school dropouts who always seem to make the news. Many of the people in Watts have lived there for 40 or more years in homes from the 1940s with neat lawns and freshly painted fences on tree-lined streets, many blocks away from the housing projects and vacant lots. The CalFed branch, which opened in 1970, symbolizes for many residents Watt's rebound from the riot of 1965 and offers an example of where the community can go. The branch employs 13 people, 10 of them from Watts, and handles a wide variety of services, from checking to mutual funds. As a local business person, Burnett often has duties outside the office, from giving investment seminars to working on community advisory programs. ``I see people who have pride in their community, (an attitude of) we're going to make this work. It's going to be as good a community as any other community,'' she said. ``But most important thing is I see families, the pictures they (media) never show of the mother, the father and the children. I see it every day.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi King Says Military Help Only Temporary
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd, in his first address to the nation since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, said Thursday his decision to seek foreign military help was a defensive move forced by the Iraqi aggression. It was the first time the Saudi government had explained to its people the arrival of tens of thousands of American troops. Fahd called the takeover of neighboring Kuwait ``the most horrible aggression the Arab nation has known in its modern history'' and said his request for foreign military help was aimed at restoring peace to the region. Fahd demanded that in addition to an Iraqi troop pullout, the al-Sabah royal family return to power in Kuwait. Following the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Iraqis ``massed large numbers of troops on the border of the kingdom,'' Fahd said. ``Faced with this bitter reality, and out of keenness to safeguard its territory and economy ... the kingdom expressed a desire to Arab and friendly forces to participate'' in the defense task, he said. The king spoke as U.S. airborne rapid deployment forces and fighter jets poured into Saudi Arabia. An official statement later distributed by the Saudi Press Agency said the troop buildup was to be completed Friday. It expressed the kingdom's ``deep appreciation'' to all states that were sending troops. Their involvement reflected ``keenness to see security and stability prevail in the Arabian Gulf region until normal conditions are restored as well as the legitimate authority in the sister state of Kuwait, and all consequences of the Iraqi invasion, are eliminated.'' Diplomatic sources noted this would coincide with the emergency Arab summit being held in Cairo. The summit was expected to take up Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's proposal to line up a pan-Arab force, which would replace the Iraqi occupation troops inside Kuwait until the differences over land, oil and money that sparked the invasion could be settled. Referring to the foreign troops in Saudi territory, the king said: ``These forces from friendly powers are here temporarily.'' ``They are to help defend the kingdom, participate in joint exercises, and will leave here as soon as the kingdom so demands,'' he said. Fahd stressed that inviting Western and Arab forces to the kingdom was ``not directed against anyone, but a purely defensive measure.'' The landing of the thousands of foreign troops has been cloaked from ordinary Saudis, since they were being deployed at the northeastern desert edge of the kingdom. The area is known as Hafr al-Baten, where one of the world's biggest military cities was completed in 1985. The city can accommodate up to 70,000 officers and soldiers, aside from dependents. A 10,000-strong fledgling rapid deployment force from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other four partners in the Gulf Copperation Council alliance _ Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates _ is also based at Hafr al-Baten. ``We feel them but we don't see them,'' said a resident reached by telephone in the vital oil center of the Eastern Province, where the troops were headed. Aside from a run on newspapers and portable radios, residents went about their lives, remaining mainly indoors as usual as the summer temperatures soared to about 100 degrees. There has been no panic or mass evacuation of the estimated 4.5 million foreign workers and their dependents in the kingdom. But some foreigners, especially dependents, were leaving if their stay was not necessary. Many workers from the Indian subcontinent were lined up seeking visas. Regional shipping executives and the London-based Lloyd's shipping intelligence unit, which monitors the maritime navigations of the Persian Gulf, said that Saudi Gulf ports of Dammam, Ras Tanura, Juaymah and Jubail were operating normally.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Army May Be Less Of a Threat Than Numbers Indicate
With AM-US-Military, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's massive war machine is largely a ground force whose true military capabilities are less than its size and armament would suggest, according to U.S. analysts. While President Saddam Hussein's 5,500 tanks and million-man army are the Arab world's largest force, and the world's fourth-largest military, the United States believes they can be kept at bay and eventually starved by a much smaller contingent that relies on air and sea power. It is true that an eight-year war with Iran that ended in 1988, and a $34 billion military buildup over that period, left Iraq with hardened, battle-tested forces. But a conflict over Saudi Arabia would be of a far different character, and much of that experience might be less relevant, according to U.S. officials. ``We treat them and view them as a capable military force,'' said Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``But they are not invincible and they're not 10 feet tall.'' Against Iran, Iraqi troops became adept at building massive earthworks, constructing tank traps and flooding land as a defense against the human waves sent by the Ayatollah Khomeini. They learned to move elite units quickly to hot spots along the border and developed an extensive fleet of armored troop transports. Iraq also acquired SCUD missiles, a relatively clumsy ground-to-ground weapon, from the Soviet Union, and improved their range with help from private engineers in the West. And Saddam has developed an independent capacity to make mustard gas and nerve gas, and deliver them in artillery shells and on missiles. On paper, Iraq also has a substantial air force and formidable defenses against possible sorties by U.S. fighters and bombers. But the numbers lie, said one congressional military expert. ``Except for about 50 of them, Iraqi pilots are third-rate,'' said the source, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. The fifty pilots went through a three-year training course in France as part of Iraq's purchase of French Mirage fighter planes. Some of those planes are equipped with French Exocet missiles, one of which hit the USS Stark and killed 37 sailors. It was those four fighter squadrons which carried out the most effective raids during Iraq's eight-year war with Iran, attacking oil-loading facilities at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf, said the source. While the air force includes 450 other combat planes, some of them Soviet MiGs, they have not been a threat. ``The pilots are chicken and not very imaginative,'' said the source. Bombing runs on Tehran during the war were carried out from 30,000 feet because of fear of antiaircraft fire and did little damage, the analyst said. The Iraqis have more than 300 surface-to-air missiles, which could be used against American pilots, but are said to be unprepared to use them. There was little need for air defense in the war with Iran, so skilled personnel were not committed to those areas. The Iraqi navy is almost non-existent, which is why military strategists see a naval blockade to starve Saddam into submission as a leading option. The Iraqi leader can deploy only five ships of any size, and his primary waterway to the Persian Gulf remains choked with the wreckage of ships sunk during the war with Iran. Even Saddam's million-man ground force is not as formidable as it appears. Fully half of those troops are reserves, less well equipped and minimally trained. Some forces must be kept to watch the country's borders with Iran and Turkey. The elite Republican Guard, seven divisions numbering about 120,000 men, are the most experienced and are all positioned in Kuwait. Any reinforcements would have to come from what one expert called ``second-rate troops.'' And even the elite units are not experienced in sustained combat, the analyst said. The Iran-Iraq war was made up of a series of short skirmishes, with only two or three major battles a year. The longest conflict was less than two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Summit Postponed; Security Council Rejects Annexation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Mubarak spokesman confirming summit postponed, Kuwait's emir weeping upon arrival in Cairo, France willing to send military equipment to Saudi Arabia. Pickup 14th, ``_To solidify...' Recasts grafs 21 and 22, `Kuwait's deposed...deterrent force.' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6,7,8,MYB1,FTSX1,FAYX1
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders gathered in Cairo today for a high-stakes summit on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait but put off formal talks for one day, and the United Nations Security Council refused to recognize Baghdad's annexation of the emirate. The Arab summit had been scheduled to start today, but the leaders instead held preparatory talks while waiting for more participants to arrive, President Hosni Mubarak's press secretary, Mohamed Abdel-Moneim, said. Those on hand included top-level envoys from Iraq and the deposed emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who wept upon arrival when an Egyptian military band played the Kuwait national anthem in his honor. Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, who set the crisis in motion, was not attending the Cairo gathering. The fate of thousands of foreigners trapped by Iraq's lightning invasion of Kuwait one week ago became even more uncertain today, as Iraq sealed its borders to all foreigners except diplomats. Britain's Foreign Office announced the move by Baghdad and said it assumed Iraqi frontiers now included annexed Kuwait. Thousands of American troops poured into Saudi Arabia today and reportedly took up positions within seven miles from the Iraqi border. Iraq's envoy to the Cairo summit denounced the deployment as ``overt U.S. threats to the Arab nation.'' The troops were sent to protect Saudi Arabia. Iraq has promised not to invade it _ but it had said the same thing about Kuwait, which it annexed Wednesday, six days after the invasion. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, in his first public comment on the invasion, today called it ``the most horrible aggression'' in the Arab world's modern history. Secretary of State James A. Baker III today visited another of Iraq's neighbors, Turkey, and assured officials of full support from NATO if Turkey, too, becomes a target of Iraqi intimidation. Turkey's semi-official Anatolia news agency today quoted villagers on the Iraqi side of the border with Turkey as saying Iraq has started beefing up its forces along the frontier. Turkey's defense minister denied the report, which comes two days after Turkey effectively shut down pipelines carrying Iraqi oil. On the economic front, delegates from industrialized nations gathered in Paris today to assess the impact of the international boycott against Iraq, imposed to punish Baghdad for the invasion. Iraq is the world's second-largest crude exporter after Saudi Arabia. In other developments today: _The Pentagon said an estimated 120,000 Iraqi troops are now in Kuwait and that Iraq also had improved air defenses in the emirate. ``They're holding on to what they have acquired,'' spokesman Pete Williams said. _The White House made a new call for other nations to join the multinational military effort, but refused to criticize Arab nations for failing to join in. _President Francois Mitterrand said today that France will beef up its naval and air forces in the Persian Gulf and send war materials and technicians to the gulf as requested by Saudi Arabia and other states. _To solidify what it called its merger with Kuwait, Iraq appointed the head of Kuwait's Iraq-installed government a deputy prime minister of Iraq, and canceled Baghdad's multibillion-dollar debt to Kuwait. _Israel today launched the first test of a new missile developed to combat short-range ballistic missiles. Israel radio said it was a direct response to an Iraqi threat a day earlier. _Iran, which fought a bloody eight-year war with Iraq, today warned that Tehran ``will not tolerate'' Baghdad's annexation of Kuwait. A Foreign Ministry statement quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency said the Iraqi takeover brought on a ``crisis'' in the region. _Stock prices tumbled in Tokyo today amid pessimism about how the Middle East crisis will affect the economy of Japan, which relies on imports for virtually all its oil needs. But stock prices rolled forward in London in a recovery triggered in part by Wall Street's strength a day earlier. Two top Iraqi officials were in Cairo for the emergency Arab summit: Taha Yassin Ramadan, Iraq's first deputy premier and a member of the ruling military junta, and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Ramadan said he was attending the summit ``to confront the overt U.S. threats to the Arab nation.'' ``U.S. land, naval and air forces have taken up positions on Arab territories and waters to attack Iraq,'' he told reporters in Baghdad before leaving for Cairo. His comments were distributed by the Iraqi News Agency. Arab diplomatic sources had said the absence of Saddam or key aides from the summit would dim the chances of effective action by the Arab heads of state. Kuwait's deposed emir also arrived today to take Kuwait's seat at the summit. Egypt and most Arab states recognize the ousted government as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Arab nations were initially slow to denounce the invasion, and have been reluctant to join in the U.S.-led multinational military effort. Mubarak instead suggested an all-Arab deterrent force. But the lone Arab member on the U.N. Security Council _ Yemen _ joined in the 15-0 vote declaring Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' The resolution calls upon all states and international organizations not to recognize the annexation and not to take any action that might be interpreted as indirect recognition of the annexation. Oil prices, which had shot up at the onset of the crisis, began dropping, and in Paris, delegates from industrialized nations said there was no immediate danger to world oil supplies. ``Presently there is not a significant shortfall of crude oil in the market,'' said U.S. Assistant Energy Secretary John Easton as the 21-nation International Energy Agency opened an emergency meeting today. President Bush is deploying thousands of troops and scores of warplanes in the Saudi desert and has send three aircraft carrier groups to the region. Iraq has an estimated 100,000 troops just across the border in Kuwait _ but the Americans have superior air and sea power. Diplomatic sources in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, said U.S. forces arrived early today near Khafji, a coastal city seven miles south of the Kuwaiti border that includes an oil terminal. Government sources said Wednesday at least 5,000 ground troops were en route or already taking up positions on Saudi soil, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers. Diplomatic sources said the U.S. force buildup would total at least 40,000 troops. Several other estimates ranged up to 50,000. In addition, a formidable U.S. naval fleet is gathering in and around the Gulf and the Mediterranean. So far, Britain is the only nation to commit troops to the U.S.-led effort, though other countries have offered support such as use of bases. Britain said today it would send two squadrons of warplanes and a number of ground-to-air missiles, along with three mine sweepers, to be deployed initially to the Eastern Mediterranean. The British destroyer HMS York is already in the Persian Gulf, and two frigates are expected to arrive there this weekend. Bush promised severe retaliation if Saddam used chemical weapons against American soldiers. Saddam used the arms against Iran during the countries' 8-year war and also against Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority. Iraq's envoy to Greece suggested today that Iraq is prepared to use chemical weapons if attacked. ``If we are attacked by a foreign power we will retaliate with all sorts of defensive weapons that we have,'' the ambassador, Abdel Fetah al-Khazreji, said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Summit Postponed Until Friday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPGRADE attribution on postponement of the summit. Pickup 6th graf, `Iraq's presence...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An emergency Arab summit to discuss Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was postponed one day until Friday because some Arab leaders did not arrive in time, President Hosni Mubarak's spokesman said. The spokesman, Mohamed Abdel-Moneim, said Mubarak would host a dinner tonight for Arab presidents and kings who already had arrived and who had expected the summit to begin today. Of the 21 Arab League countries, Tunisia, Mauritania, Yemen and Djibouti had not sent delegations by the scheduled early evening opening time. Egypt hopes the summit will forestall a Western military attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait and along its border with Saudi Arabia. Both Iraq and Kuwait's ousted government have sent representatives to the meeting. ``The emergency Arab summit will start tomorrow, Friday,'' Egypt's Middle Eastern News Agency said. ``Today will be limited to side talks among the kings and presidents participating in the summit. They will meet tonight (at the dinner) until the rest of the delegations arrive...later Thursday.'' Iraq's presence at the meeting could be a breakthrough for moderate Arab leaders who have refused to join a U.S.-led force that was deployed to defend Saudi Arabia following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The moderates hope for a diplomatic solution. The Iraqi delegation chief, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said he was attending the summit ``to confront the overt U.S. threats.'' He said U.S. forces ``have taken up positions on Arab territories and waters to attack Iraq.'' Ramadan, first deputy premier and member of President Saddam Hussein's ruling military junta, warned against an attack on his country by the United States, which is building up forces in neighboring Saudi Arabia. ``Any aggression on Iraq, regardless of its source, will be answered decisively,'' Ramadan said. ``And when Iraq says something, it is capable of following it through.'' He spoke before his departure from Baghdad and his comments were distributed by the Iraqi News Agency. Iraq invaded Kuwait a week ago and annexed it Wednesday. The U.N. Security Council today declared the annexation ``null and void.'' Kuwait's deposed emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, also arrived today to take Kuwait's seat at the summit. Egypt and most Arab states recognize the ousted government as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. ``I find myself obliged to warn of the extreme danger,'' Mubarak, the summit host, said Wednesday. He called for a joint Arab force that would keep the Iraqis from taking more territory, specifically Saudi Arabia. Such a force would be unlikely to be used to try to push Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Finding an Arab solution ``would be better than having a solution forced on us by foreign powers,'' Mubarak said in a nationally televised speech. ``I appeal to President Saddam and the Iraqi leadership to respond to the idea of an Arab umbrella, withdraw its forces from Kuwait, restore legitimacy, then there would be no objection to a joint Arab force serving as a buffer between the two sides. Then negotiations can follow,'' Mubarak said. U.S. officials had said Egypt would join the United States in a multinational force defending the Saudis from Iraqi aggression; but Egypt said it would not participate in an American-led force. Diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said one of the summit's options was to support Mubarak's idea of a joint Arab deterrent force. Their other main alternative would be to join the world in imposing sanctions on Iraq, hoping the seige would force Iraq to withdraw. The very least they will do is reiterate their condemnation of the incursion and urge Western powers not to intervene, the diplomatic sources said. President Bush, seeking to dispel fears of an impending U.S. attack against Iraqi forces, said in Washington on Wednesday that U.S. forces being sent to Saudi Arabia were aimed only at preventing an Iraqi incursion. Jordan's King Hussein was asked at an Amman news conference on Wednesday if the summit was the last opportunity to avoid fighting. He responded without hesitation: ``Yes, I see it as a last chance.'' Libyan leader Moammar Ghadafi was the first Arab leader to arrive for the summit. He was greeted Wednesday at Cairo International Airport by Mubarak, who later welcomed Lebanese President Elias Hrawi. Those arriving today included leaders of Algeria, Bahrain, Jordan, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates as well as Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat. Senior officials attended from Morocco and Oman.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Navy Fleet Maintenance Costs Higher Than Projected
DOC.TEXT: The cost of maintaining and overhauling the nation's naval fleet exceeded original estimates by about 30 percent with expenses rising to $3.7 billion over a three-year period, congressional investigators say. The General Accounting Office, the watchdog agency of Congress, found cost growth and schedule overruns at the eight public shipyards and 44 private shipyards across the United States between fiscal 1985 and fiscal 1988. Public shipyards generally work on more sophisticated ships, including submarines, carriers and nuclear-powered surface ships. Private shipyards usually handle auxiliary and amphibious ships. The GAO blamed the problems at private shipyards on an inability to determine beforehand what repair work must be done, unplanned work added after the government contract has been awarded and difficulty in obtaining materials. In the study, released the end of July, the GAO also found that the market for ship maintenance and modernization is highly competitive, forcing contractors to submit low bids to obtain Navy work. Similar problems also existed at public shipyards, where the GAO found that in some cases the companies did not have enough labor to do the work properly. At the private shipyards, the GAO said that over a three-year period, contract costs increased from $2.8 billion to $3.7 billion with the final prices exceeding the contract award prices on 357 of 402 projects. The cost increase at public shipyards was about 3 percent as estimates rose from $8.4 billion to $8.7 billion over the same three-year period. Completion dates for the projects at the private shipyards overran the original schedules by an average of 43 days, while at the public shipyards, completion dates overran the original schedules by an average of 81 days. ``The Navy is aware of the problems, but past efforts to correct them have not been fully successful, as evidenced by the continued cost growth and schedule overruns,'' the GAO said. ``A new plan to correct depot maintenance problems was recently approved by the Secretary of the Navy (Lawrence Garrett III). This plan is a step in the right direction, but more corrective actions are needed.'' In comments included in the GAO report, the Defense Department largely concurs with the GAO findings, but cites a number of unusual reasons for the cost increases. ``Schedule overruns at public shipyards for the last four years are directly attributable to an unusually high number of submarine overhaul starts, beginning in the fiscal 1985 to fiscal 1998 time frame, which created a serious imbalance between workload and shipyard trade and management skills,'' the department said. Both the GAO and the department note that since the early 1970s, the Navy has changed its strategy for maintaining and modernizing ships by scheduling fewer regular overhauls and opting for ``shorter, more frequent,'' repairs. The GAO report was requested by Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Real Estate Woes Spreading, Fed Member Says
DOC.TEXT: Weak commercial real estate markets have spread from the Northeast and Southwest to the Midwest and even the booming West Coast, a Federal Reserve Board member said Thursday. Real estate problems have been most pronounced in New England, John P. LaWare told the House Banking Committee, but weakness now exists along much of the East Coast. ``Market conditions in some Midwestern cities have also begun to show a marked loss of strength, and even the western states of California, Oregon and Washington, long the beneficiaries of strong real estate markets, have begun to report increased office vacancy rates in at least some areas,'' he said. As a result, the number of delinquent real estate loans at commercial banks are mounting, up 37 percent in 1989 and 8 percent to $32 billion in the first three months of 1990, he said. However, LaWare and Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke, whose office oversees nationally chartered banks, said regulators were on top of the trend and insisting on sound lending standards. The comptroller's office ``has been sounding the alarm on real estate lending for the past three years,'' Clarke said. Members of the committee reacted skeptically, likening the deterioration in bank profits and the regulators' reactions to the early phases of the savings and loan mess. ``During the '60s, '70s and '80s, the regulators said pretty much what you're saying today,'' said Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the panel. ``I'm worried,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. ``Some of the very same fundamentals that caused problems in the S&L industry are going to continue to cause problems in the banking industry until we examine it and change the way ... banks operate.'' However, private analysts appearing before the panel said that banks' position, while serious, cannot be compared with that of savings institutions. ``U.S. commercial banks are in varying degrees under considerable strain,'' said James J. McDermott Jr. of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. ``Nevertheless ... banks in the aggregate should avoid the plight of the savings and loan industry and manage their way through the current stresses.'' Gonzalez also rebuked the regulators for refusing to answer questions about $2 billion in bank loans to Donald Trump, who is struggling to preserve his real estate empire. ``The savings and loan scandals grew in the dark basements of official government secrecy and the facts did not reach the American public until the problems became massive and unmanageable,'' Gonzalez said, asking how depositors were to know where to put their money. Clarke replied that there was a longstanding regulatory tradition to keep information about bank customers confidential. ``I think it would be a terrible mistake for bank supervisors to come up here and present financial information about individual bank borrowers in a public forum,'' he said. Trump and representatives of Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Bank, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. and Bankers Trust New York Corp. all declined invitations to address the committee. Trump, in a letter to Gonzalez, said he did not want to reveal proprietary business information and the bankers said they were obligated to preserve customer confidentiality.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Station Owner Drops Prices, Despite Invasion
With AM-Iraq-US Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A businessman who drops his gasoline prices every Aug. 8 to mark his daughter's anniversary stuck to his promise this year, even while others jacked up prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Leland Morgan said Thursday his goodwill gesture cost him dearly. ``We lost a considerable amount, I'm sure,'' he said. ``It ran into a couple of thousand. In retrospect, I'm not too happy I guess. But we'll do it again next year.'' Morgan announced last week that gas prices would drop to 98.8 cents a gallon for regular unleaded gasoline and $1.08.8 for super unleaded for one day only _ Aug. 8, his daughter Marta's second wedding anniversary. A few days later, Iraq invaded Kuwait, driving up oil and gasoline prices. On Tuesday, Morgan paid his supplier more than $1.20 for regular unleaded and more than $1.30 for super unleaded. Customers began arriving at Marta's Mini Mart in central Connecticut at 5 a.m. Wednesday, and lines were steady all day long. Morgan said he sold all but 300 of the 8,000 gallons of gas in his underground tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Council Declares Kuwait Annex `Null and Void,' Again Demands Iraqi Pullout
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council on Thursday unanimously expressed outrage over Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, declaring it ``null and void'' and called on all nations to repudiate the puppet Kuwaiti regime. Iraq repudiated the council. The vote was 15-0 on the 15-member council, which met for the third time since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. It demanded immediate and unconditional Iraqi troop withdrawal from Kuwait. It has already called for a worldwide economic embargo against Iraq. The move was considered one of the strongest Security Council actions. Combined with the two earlier resolutions of condemnation and sanctions, it indicated that after years of division and ineffectiveness, the body was performing its original peacemaking role. Yemen, the council's sole Arab member, voted with the rest of the council. It abstained in previous votes that condemned the invasion and ordered global economic sanctions. Iraq scorned the resolution, which is considered legally binding on all U.N. members. ``My government reaffirms that the unity between Iraq and Kuwait is an indestructible one. It is eternal and irreversible,'' Iraqi Ambassador Ameri al-Anbari said after the vote. Al-Anbari blamed the U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia and in the region for causing instability and said it had delayed the promised Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He said his government has no intention of invading Saudi Arabia. The resolution, introduced by Kuwait and sponsored by non-aligned nations, says: ``Annexation of Kuwait by Iraq under any form and whatever pretext has no legal validity, and is considered null and void.'' It demands Iraq rescind its annexation and urges all states not to give even indirect recognition to the Kuwaiti government installed by Iraq. ``We cannot allow sovereign state members of the United Nations to be swallowed up,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told the council. Pickering said Iraq repeatedly had lied about its intentions and demonstrated its ``scorn'' for the international community and disdain for international law. Pickering emphasized that the U.S. presence in the area is strictly defensive, under provisions of the U.N. Charter, and intended to help protect Saudi Arabia. Pickering and other speakers likened Iraq's behavior to that of dictators in the 1930s, referring indirectly to Hitler. At that time, Pickering said, ``The result was global conflagraiton.'' ``We here will not and cannot let this happen again,'' he said. British Ambassador Crispen Tickell said: ``This is an important day in the history of this (U.N.) institution.'' He said it set a precedent for the kind of Security Council envisioned when the United Nations was formed in 1945. As the council met, the Soviet Foreign Ministry said Soviet participation in an international force in the crisis was contingent upon U.N. auspices. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he respected the Soviet position, that it deserved consideration, and that the Security Council would have to decide whether to call for a U.N. presence in the region. The council includes the five permanent members: The United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union; and 10 other members: Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Donor-Search Leukemia Patient Undergoes Transplant
DOC.TEXT: A leukemia patient received her mother's bone marrow Thursday, after doctors failed to find a perfect match among 50,000 people who volunteered as donors. Allison Atlas, 20, had the transplant at Fred Hutchison Cancer Research Center in Seattle. Her mother, Arline, 54, was the donor. The plight of Miss Atlas, a New York University student from Bethesda, Md., prompted 50,000 people to volunteer for bone marrow tests. There was no perfect match for Miss Atlas, but 10 other leukemia patients got donors. Mrs. Atlas' marrow matched four of six antigens, or cell identifiers, from her daughter's marrow. Doctors said Miss Atlas would have had a 60 percent chance of recovery if the donated marrow was a perfect match. Her chances are reduced ``somewhat'' but other patients with the same degree of mismatch have recovered, said hospital spokeswoman Alice Burgess said. Without the transplant, she would live less than a year, Burgess said. Leukemia causes white blood cells to multiply uncontrollably. Bone marrow produces blood, and doctors combat the cancer by replacing the diseased marrow. The Atlas family's public campaign last fall raised $3 million to process blood samples from the 50,000 people in the United States and Israel who registered with the National Marrow Donor Program.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Spokesman Says Marines Attacked Presidential Mansion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. denial. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Earlier today...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

U.S. Marines fired from a helicopter at the fortified mansion of President Samuel Doe today, wounding one of Doe's advisers, a presidential spokesman claimed in a radio interview. The State Department denied that the incident took place. The Liberian spokesman described the attack as an attempt to assassinate Doe. He said in a telephone call to the British Broadcasting Corp. that the unidentified Doe adviser was hit in the chest and neck and had been hospitalized. The spokesman called on the international community to pressure the United States to stop any U.S. attempt to remove Doe. ``We categorically deny that happened,'' said a spokesman for the State Department's Liberian task force. Earlier today, relief workers said rebels who oppose intervention by West African forces in Liberia's civil war ransacked Nigeria's Embassy, pushing out hundreds of people seeking refuge there. The rebels led by Charles Taylor, advancing toward downtown Monrovia, today battled government soldiers around the only hospital still operating, the relief workers said. Taylor's rebels launched the embassy attack Wednesday night as part of their bid to capture the city before the five-nation West African force arrived, according to Western relief workers who sent radio messages from Monrovia to Europe. Diplomatic sources quoted Taylor as declaring he would capture the capital by the weekend. Taylor's men today fought Doe's troops in Congo Town, an eastern suburb in which several embassies are located as well as St. Joseph's Catholic Hospital. ``There is fighting going on all around the hospital and workers there are cut off from an embassy where they were staying,'' said a relief worker. Government soldiers had managed until now to hold Taylor's forces back in Paynesville, on the outskirts of Monrovia. But they reportedly met little resistance in their overnight advance. The five-nation West African force, dominated by Nigerian soldiers, mobilized to move into the war-ravaged nation and impose a cease-fire, using force if necessary. Troops and tanks were reported to be massing across Liberia's northern border in Guinea and to the east on the Sierra Leone border, according to military sources in Ghana and Sierra Leone. The rebel movements raise tensions in the region two days after leaders of the West African Economic Community decided to send troops to impose a cease-fire in the 7-month-old civil war. Rebels fighting for Taylor's National Patriotic Front on Wednesday forced hundreds of Nigerians taking refuge in the embassy compound into the streets of Monrovia, said a spokeswoman for a Western relief group. ``They plundered the embassy and forced the refugees out,'' said the spokeswoman for the group. It was not clear whether anyone was injured. The name of the agency was withheld to protect the safety of its workers. There was no immediate comment from Nigeria's ruling military council. It was meeting today in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, to give the force of law to President Ibrahim Babangida's decision to send troops to Liberia. On Wednesday, the rival rebel forces of Taylor and Prince Johnson waged bruising street battles in Monrovia with each other and with forces loyal to Doe, who remains holed up in his mansion in Monrovia. Johnson on Wednesday freed the last of dozens of foreign hostages, including one American, he had seized earlier in the week. Johnson's threat on Saturday to begin rounding up Americans and other foreigners prompted hundreds of U.S. Marines to enter Liberia from Navy ships offshore to rescue Americans. Taylor had threatened to attack any international force that might intervene, saying it would be trying to prop up Doe's government. But this week his envoys told an African summit in Gambia that he might accept the force. Diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that 2,000 West African troops were being sent to Monrovia by sea from Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. Nations sending soldiers are Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Togo. The seven-month war began when Taylor led an insurgent force across he border from the Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption and mismanagement. The war has since turned into a largely tribal conflict, with both sides accused of killing hundreds of civilians from opposing tribes. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the foreigners freed by Johnson on Wednesday were back at a hotel. He said they include one American, whom he identified only as Chris Mendez. A contingent of Marines was at the walled U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, ready to defend it if necessary. About 2,100 remained stationed in ships off Liberia. They were sent to evacuate Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Swiss Hostage Arrives Home
DOC.TEXT: Red Cross relief worker Emanuel Christen, appearing thin but healthy, had an emotional homecoming Thursday after 10 months in captivity in Lebanon. But joy at his release was tempered by concern for fellow Swiss hostage Elio Erriquez, who was abducted Oct. 6 along with Christen. Christen was the first Western hostage released since two Americans were freed in April. Christen, 33, bounded down the steps of a Red Cross-chartered aircraft that arrived at Zurich's Kloten airport after a four-hour flight from the Syrian capital, Damascus. His parents and four brothers and sisters rushed onto the tarmac to embrace him. Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber and Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, also greeted Christen, who was turned over late Wednesday to Syrian officials. Dressed in white shirt and beige trousers, Christen was clean shaven and showed few signs of his ordeal. He smiled at dozens of waiting reporters and photographers but declined to answer questions. A hitherto unknown group, calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads, announced on Tuesday night that both of the Swiss Red Cross workers would be freed within 24 hours. There was no explanation from the kidnappers for the delay in freeing Erriquez. Before being abducted, both men worked as orthopedic technicians at a Red Cross hospital in the southern Lebanese port of Sidon. The Swiss foreign minister told Swiss TV he was confident Christen's release was a ``signal for the next liberation.'' ``We are happy that Emanuel is free but we are also concerned that Elio is still a captive,'' Christen's mother, Marianne Christen, said in a separate television interview. She said she was shocked earlier when she saw a photo of her son released by the kidnappers shortly before he was freed. She said he seemed thin and ``has such a sad look.'' A Swiss Embassy staff member in Damascus, Claudine Zbinden, said Christen had lost about 30 pounds. ``But he is in relative good shape, if one may say so,'' Ms. Zbinden said Thursday in a telephone interview. Both the Swiss Foreign Ministry and the Geneva-headquartered International Committee of the Red Cross denied any deal was made with the kidnappers to win the hostage's release. In their statement Tuesday, the Palestine Revolutionary Squads said they decided to free the two Swiss captives ``after we acquired guarantees that our demands will be met.'' Erriquez's brother Antoine said he was convinced there had been a deal between the kidnappers and Swiss officials. ``They had to make a concession even if they deny it, '' he said. ``But it is also possible that the terrorists, after releasing one hostage, are now waiting whether all of their demands are being met before also freeing my brother.'' In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said the release may have been a result of France's decision last month to pardon Anis Naccache and four other members of a pro-Iranian assassination team. A ministry spokesman said France was informed immediately after Naccache's release July 27 that Iran would pursue efforts to free hostages held in Lebanon and that two Europeans would be freed soon. Christen's release brought to 15 the number of foreigners held hostage in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Deliberations Begin In Central Park Jogger Case
DOC.TEXT: After six weeks of testimony, the jury in the Central Park jogger case began deliberations Thursday, weighing the charges against three teen-agers in one of the city's most infamous crimes. Yusef Salaam, 16, Raymond Santana, 15, and Antron McCray, 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery in attacks on the woman and on two male joggers during a rampage on April 19, 1989. The woman was dragged into the woods, gang-raped, bashed with a brick and a pipe and left to die in a pool of blood after going into the park for her nightly run. The brutality of the attack and her surprising recovery caught the attention of the city and the nation. Defense lawyers summed up Tuesday, with one attorney suggesting the victim was not gang-raped and another accusing detectives of lying about how incriminating statements were obtained from the three defendants. The three were tried as adults, but if convicted would be sentenced as juveniles, limiting the length of any prison terms. Videotaped statements by McCray and Santana were shown during the trial and again during the closing argument Wednesday. The jury Thursday requested the written statements the three defendants gave police. The defense has charged the statements were coerced from the defendants. The panel also asked the judge about the admissibility of any statement made by a minor without a parent or guardian present. ``The fact that a parent was not present during the questioning of a juvenile does not automatically mean the statement is involuntary,'' Justice Thomas Galligan told the jurors. The 30-year-old jogger is back at work as a vice president at Salomon Brothers investment bankers. In a dramatic appearance at the trial, she testified that she still suffers from impaired sight, balance and smell as a result of the attack. ``The fact that she could even come to this courtroom is a miracle,'' prosecutor Elizabeth Lederer said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Drops Push To Speed Up All-German Elections
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl dropped plans Thursday to advance all-German elections by six weeks, a major political defeat for the leader who until now had set the pace of German unification. Still uncertain, however, was whether formal unity would proceed on Oct. 14 apart from parliamentary elections, now set for Dec. 2. Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere had wanted to hold elections and declare unity the same day. Kohl's decision followed a day-long parliamentary debate in which the opposition Social Democrats insisted they would not give him the two-thirds majority necessary for a constitutional change needed to move up elections. In addition, the East German parliament failed Thursday to approve new electoral rules for an Oct. 14 election. Also Thursday, Kohl said the cost of bailing out beleaguered East Germany is exceeding expectations. Up until Thursday, Kohl had been able to set the pace of unity more or less according to his own plans to ensure continued control for his conservative coalition in the new Germany. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble announced Kohl's change in position during a meeting of the ``German Unity'' committee of government ministers, according to participants who spoke later on condition of anonymity. The West German Social Democrats welcomed abandonment of what they termed Kohl's and de Maiziere's ``nonsensical'' plan for elections and unity Oct. 14. A spokesman for the East German Social Democrats said the party was ``pleased to see Dec. 2 confirmed as the date for all-German elections.'' ``It is not an earlier election date but quick unity that creates the necessary framework ... for secure investments,'' said Social Democrats spokesman Juergen Itzfeldt. The Social Democrats demand unity first, then elections Dec. 2. West Germany has previously said that unity should not occur before the Sept. 12 meeting in Moscow of the four World War II allies and the two Germanys to wrap up the ``two-plus-four'' talks on international aspects of German unity. The two Germanys are finishing work on a unification treaty that paves the way for the legal merger of the two countries. It is expected to be finished by late August or early September. Kohl had also hoped to have a treaty regulating all-German elections ratified by both Parliaments by Thursday evening. But the measure just barely failed to get the needed two-thirds majority in the East German parliament, and West German lawmakers decided to postpone their own vote until Aug. 23. East German lawmakers are to consider the measure again Aug. 22. The treaty in all likelihood will be passed on those dates. But the delays put a time squeeze on the West German chancellor's hopes of making the constitutional change necessary for Oct. 14 elections. The Social Democrats had charged that Kohl wanted to speed up elections out of fear voters will turn against him as East Germany's economy further unravels. But Kohl maintained that earlier elections would be best for helping ensure economic and social stability in East Germany.
President Bush signed legislation Thursday designating Oct. 14 as ``National Children's Day.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Forecasts Slightly Larger Corn Harvest This Year
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are looking at a potential 1990 corn harvest of 7.85 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. At 7.85 billion bushels, this fall's harvest would be the largest since 8.25 billion bushels in 1986. The record was the 1985 crop of nearly 8.9 billion bushels. ``Dry conditions in the southeastern states have reduced yields in most areas from the record levels of 1989,'' said the department's Agricultural Statistics Board. But the report added that ``late plantings in the Corn Belt have been offset by excellent growing conditions in July.'' Farmers harvested 7.53 billion bushels in 1989, and the department a month ago projected this year's output might be 7.85 billion bushels, based on yield trends and normal weather. Thursday's figures were the first of the season by USDA based on yield estimates and surveys, reflecting conditions as of Aug. 1. Corn yields were estimated at 117.7 bushels per acre harvested, compared with 116.2 last year. The record was 119.4 bushels in 1987. As livestock feed, corn is the largest and most important U.S. farm crop. It is an essential ingredient for the production of meat, poultry and dairy products. Consumer food prices, which rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981, are expected to climb 6 percent or more in 1990. Soybean production, a source of high-protein meal and vegetable oil, was estimated at 1.84 billion bushels, down 5 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels. Cotton production was indicated at 14.9 million bales, up 22 percent from last year's output of 12.2 million bales. Total wheat output was estimated at 2.71 billion bushels, up 33 percent from the 1989 harvest and fractionally more than indicated in July. The department's all-crops production index was reported at 111 percent of its 1977 average used for comparison. That is the highest reading since the index averaged 116 percent in 1985. Last year, although crop production rebounded sharply from the 1988 drought, total output averaged only 106 percent. The record was 117 percent in 1981 and 1982. In a related report on supply and demand for major commodities, analysts said total corn use in the 1990-91 marketing year, which begins Sept. 1, is expected to be about 7.975 billion bushels, including domestic and export requirements. With demand exceeding 1990 corn production, that will mean a further drawdown of U.S. stockpiles to about 1.2 billion bushels left over by Sept. 1, 1991, down from inventories estimated at 1.33 billion bushels at the beginning of the marketing year this Sept. 1. But that represents only a slight dip in the U.S. corn stockpile, compared to last season's decline, when it plummeted from 4.26 billion bushels on Sept. 1, 1988 to 1.93 billion bushels on hand last Sept. 1. The report said U.S. corn prices may average in the range of $2.35 to $2.75 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, compared with $2.38 forecast for the current season. Soybean prices at the farm were forecast at $5.50 to $7 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with $5.70 in the last marketing year. The report said farm prices of wheat may average $2.65 to $3.05 per bushel, compared with $3.72 the last two marketing years. Other 1990 crop estimates, based on Aug. 1 indications, compared with 1989 output, included: _Sorghum, 546.8 million bushels and an average yield of 59.1 bushels per acre, compared with 617.9 million and 55.4 in 1989. _Rice, 158.1 million hundredweight and a yield of 5,611 pounds per acre, compared with 154.5 million and 5,749. _Peanuts, 4.18 billion pounds and a yield of 2,449 pounds per acre, compared with 3.99 billion and 2,426. _Tobacco, 1.52 billion pounds and a yield of 2,102 pounds per acre, compared with 1.37 billion and 2,016. _Sugar beets, 28.1 million tons and a yield of 20.4 tons per acre, compared with 25.1 million and 19.4. _Sugar cane, 24.9 million tons and a yield of 35.1 tons per acre, compared with 29.4 million and 34.5.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Security Council.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq announced Thursday its borders were closed to foreigners _ apparently meaning both arriving and departing. Arab evacuees reaching Jordan said Thursday a group of Westerners trying to leave Iraq had been stopped just before the Jordanian border. About 400 Americans are believed stranded in Iraq, and 3,000 in Kuwait. Their plight raised fears the Iraqis might seize them as hostages. The Americans in Baghdad include 38 who were transported from Kuwait to the Iraqi capital after the invasion. In Washington, the White House said the 38 still were not being allowed to leave their hotel, which was ringed by armed guards. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater also said, ``We have been told that diplomats, only, will be allowed to leave.'' Meanwhile, some misgivings began to emerge in Washington about the U.S. role on the front line of the Arab crisis, particularly in the absence of broad Arab backing. ``If it appears that it's the United States and Saudi Arabia versus the rest of the Arab world, then that is not going to be in our long-term interest or Saudi Arabia's interest,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., Armed Services Committee chairman. He expressed support for the deployment but said a large long-term U.S. presence is ``not desirable.''

DOC.HEAD: EPA To Require Reduced Diesel Fuel Sulfur Levels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 5th through 8th grafs to add comment from environmental group; edits for transition; picks up 6th graf pvs, `It requires.'
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday it will require an 80 percent reduction of sulfur in diesel fuel starting Oct. 1, 1993. The new requirement is expected to add from 1.8 to 2.3 cents per gallon to the cost of the fuel, the agency said. Diesel exhaust has been identified as a potential cause of cancer. EPA administrator William K. Reilly said the sulfur reduction requirement and new standards to reduce particulates beginning in 1991 ``will virtually eliminate the black smoke from diesel tailpipes, cutting particulates by 90 percent.'' The most impact will be felt in urban areas, where pollution is heaviest and the most people are exposed, Reilly said in a statement. However, the private Environmental Defense Fund said the EPA plan doesn't go far enough because it does not reduce aromatics _ chemicals the defense fund says are responsible for almost half the particulate emissions in some cities.
