The EPA said it will control aromatics ``at about current levels'' by requiring a performance rating for diesel fuel or an optional maximum aromatics content standard. That plan ``doesn't take advantage of a major strategy to help clean up polluted cities that's relatively cost effective and cleans up emissions from every vehicle on the road that burns diesel,'' said Bob Yuhnke, a senior attorney with the defense fund. He said EPA's steps will result in a 15 to 20 percent reduction in particulate emissions from diesel fuel compared to a 35 to 40 percent reduction in California, which has reduced both sulfur and aromatics. The new EPA sulfur rule is based on a 1988 proposal developed jointly by the diesel-engine manufacturing and petroleum refining industries. It requires refiners to reduce the sulfur content of diesel fuel used on the road from .25 percent by weight to .05 percent. Cost to refiners is expected to range from $380 million to $910 million in 1995 and $540 million to $1.3 billion by 2010. Those costs will be at least partially offset for the consumer by cheaper emission control devices, fuel savings from catalytic devices and possibly less wear on the engine, EPA said. Small refiners have until 1995 to phase in the new standards as they install equipment needed to remove the sulfur. They will have to meet interim standards during that period. From 1993 to 1995, fuel produced under the interim standards will be sold only for pre-1994 engine equipped vehicles or to off-highway markets, the EPA said. That is in order to protect 1994 and later model-year engine designs that will require only low-sulfur fuel. The sulfur reductions are expected to help diesel engine manufacturers meet tighter particulate exhaust standards that will take effect in 1991 and 1994. The EPA said the lower level of sulfur will reduce direct emissions of sulfate particulates and also reduce secondary formation of particulates in the atmosphere. By 1995, particulates are projected to be down by 196,000 tons a year. Sulfur dioxide levels should decrease by 580,000 tons per year, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Wins Pledges of Enhanced Military Cooperation from Turkey
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 16th graf pvs, `Turkey has...; picks up penultimate graf, `The crisis...
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III received pledges Wednesday from Turkey that its air bases could be used as staging areas for U.S. military strikes against Iraq in the event of war. Baker then flew to NATO headquarters in Brussels seeking a reaffirmation the allies would rush to Turkey's defense if Iraq attacked its neighbor. Baker's meetings in Ankara with President Turgut Ozal and other Turkish officials will expand military and intelligence cooperation with the front-line state, which fears Iraqi intimidation for effectively shutting down two oil pipelines and freezing trade with Baghdad. U.S. and Western diplomats said the Turks took those steps reluctantly, and that some 60,000 Turkish workers in Iraq could be vulnerable as the U.S.-organized economic boycott tightens. Turkey, which stands to lose an estimated $3 billion a year in commerce with Iraq, received through Baker an offer of some compensation from the oil-rich Kuwaiti royal family that was overthrown in the Iraqi invasion. For his part, Baker promised the United States would back Turkey in its request for development loans from the World Bank and would provide credits for Turkey to import industrial machinery. Also, an administration official said, Baker wrote a letter to the European Community supporting Turkey's application for membership in the 12-nation European Community. As Baker left Ankara after a nine-hour visit, he was reluctant to discuss his request for permission to use an air base near the southern city of Adana or smaller posts as a staging area in the event of a U.S. attack on Iraq. The United States has a military force of 2,400 at the Turkish-operated training facility and rotates up to two dozen F-111 bombers there, similar to the planes used in a 1986 raid against Libya. Turkey is also strategically located for gathering intelligence on the Soviet Union, Iraq and other Middle Eastern countries. ``The use for which we can utilize those bases is well understood,'' Baker said. ``I'm not going to speculate about possible hypotheticals.'' Later, on the flight to Brussels, an administration official briefing reporters on Baker's meetings said that ``in the event there were to be full-scale hostilities, I am quite confident that we could count upon our allies, the Turks.'' The official, who demanded anonymity, added: `We've long had cooperative military relationships with Turkey. I think the Turks see the threat that (President) Saddam Hussein represents. And I think they see the threat his long-range missile capability and his chemical weapons capability presents to many, many nations.'' Describing Turkey as ``exposed'' to a potential Iraqi attack, the official said ``I think they know that the allies are going to be there and that the United States is going to be there _ and they are going to be there for the United States.'' On the other hand, Baker said Turkey had not committed itself to join the multinational force the United States is organizing to enforce the economic sanctions approved by the U.N. Security Council. ``Turkey has not, and that's a question that the Turkish government will have to consider,'' Baker said. The strategy of the Bush administration is to encircle Iraq with a diverse group of nations, including Turkey, a staunch U.S. ally in NATO, and two bitter adversaries, Syria and Iran. Baker was cheered by the unanimous U.N. Security Council vote condemning Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. ``Our strategy from the very beginning is to try to bring about as much of an international consensus in condemnation of this action and support of an immediate withdrawal as we could,'' an administration official said. Asked if he would like Saddam Hussein to look at a map and see all those countries lining up against him, the official broke into a grin. ``Yeah, you bet,'' he said. In Brussels on Friday, Baker will meet with the 15 NATO foreign ministers to try to organize a military blockade to back up the U.N.'s economic boycott. The crisis over Iraq apparently will benefit Saudi Arabia in at least one way. The official said the Bush administration would revive a plan to sell 20 F-15 jet fighters to Saudi Arabia, hoping the threat Iraq poses to Saudi oil fields would convince Congressional critics not to try to block the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers from Kuwait Report Little Resistance, Shortages, Looting
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The eerie silence is often broken by the sound of gunshots in the deserted streets of Kuwait City, where soldiers of the Iraqi invasion army squat and sleep on the sidewalks, travelers reported Thursday. After reaching Manama, the travelers told of beatings, humiliations and looting they said were committed by Iraqi soldiers. They said the Iraqis often knock on doors and ask frightened Kuwaitis for cold water. Sometimes they ask for food, mainly beef and fruit. Kuwaiti refugee Youssef al-Rashidi, 26, told The Associated Press in an interview at the plush Diplomat Hotel that in the sweltering summer heat, ``profusely sweating Iraqis soldiers look tired and, I would say, ashamed of themselves.'' ``A number of Iraqi soldiers came to us and tried to calm us down, saying ``we will do you no harm ... we have nothing against you ... we only carry out orders,''' he said. ``But my companions here have different things to tell you about. Not all Iraqi soldiers are good. Some of them are sons of disgrace.'' He pointed to four other young Kuwaiti men, who quickly nodded approval. One claimed that Iraqi soldiers were ``not begging for, but forcing local residents to give them bottles of cold water and fruit.'' ``I saw Iraqi soldiers heap in trucks sacks of money and bits of furniture stolen from the Gulf Bank,'' said another. ``My brother, Essa, saw Iraqi soldiers loot the al-Ghanem and al-Babtain car showrooms.'' Another Kuwait refugee, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, claimed he saw from a distance jewelry shops being looted. ``I saw Iraqi soldiers armed with rifles stop uniformed Kuwaiti soldiers, force them to remove the uniforms and then order them to return home in their underwear,'' he said. Kuwaiti businessman Mohsen al-Ajmi, 28, said he took part in garbage removal and maintenance operations to help housewives whose husbands were stranded outside Kuwait when the Iraqis struck. ``We supplied these families with food and gas cylinders (for cooking),'' he said. ``We also took part in minor resistance operations, knocked down two Iraqi soldiers with our speeding car, and distributed anti-Saddam leaflets.'' He was referring to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``There are committees at district and suburb levels to help out Kuwaiti families in many ways. I saw a number of Palestinians take part in street patrols alongside the Iraqis. These must be Palestinians loyal to Arafat. But there are other Palestinians who curse Saddam and Arafat and fight alongside Kuwaiti resistance.'' Many Kuwaitis accuse PLO chairman Yasser Arafat of backing the invasion and denounce him. Al-Ajmi said Iraqi soldiers at an intersection stopped him and others two days ago for questioning. ``They did not search us. In fact, they apologized and cursed Saddam. One said `Why are we here? We have been hurting Kuwaitis and drinking warm water in this heat, when Saddam sits there in his air-conditioned palace,''' he said. Al-Ajmi said the Iraqis spotted two Egyptian workers passing nearby, called them, asked them to show identity cards and then said: ``Egyptians? You don't deserve to live.'' ``They beat the two Egyptians so savagely that we implored them to stop. They let the Egyptians go. They were hurt quite badly .'' Most expatriate workers have left Kuwait, a shipping company executive said. He said he communicated with contacts in Kuwait by radio earlier Thursday. ``I was told that probably more than 70 percent of the kuwaitis have left the country,'' he said. Even before the invasion, Kuwaitis were a minority in their own country _ making up about 27 percent of the total population of 1.9 million. The rest are expatriate workers, mostly Palestinians, Egyptians, Iranians, Indians and Pakistanis. Al-Ajmi said resistance was ``getting weaker.'' ``Resistance is not really organized,'' he said. ``A number of Kuwaiti soldiers and civilians have banded together in resistance nests and occasionally harass the Iraqis. ``But their stocks of weapons and ammunition, not to mention food and other necessities, are steadily getting scarce. Resistance can grow, but not before we ensure adequate and secure supply routes to them from wherever Allah deems fit,'' Travelers said Iraqi soldiers scared away a group of ``stubborn Kuwaiti women'' who demonstrated in the Suleibikhat area. The women were shouting ``Long live Jaber! Kuwait will never die! Down with Saddam!'' Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah is the deposed emir. ``The Iraqis thretened to shoot and scattered the women when they attacked and hit with rifle butts,'' said one Kuwait woman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other Kuwaitis said they saw from behind window shutters Iraqi women shouting ``Down with Jaber! Long live Saddam, hero of Arab unity!'' ``I saw that demonstration,'' said 16-year-old Rasha al-Faraj. ``The women's accent was unmistakably Iraqi. They were guarded and protected by Iraqi soldiers.''

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Returns to Washington After 12 Days Apart From Bush
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush returned to the White House Thursday after 12 days apart from President Bush in Maine. She brought the family's English springer spaniel, Millie, with her. The dog has been recovering from acute lead exposure after ingesting paint remover used in White House restoration work. The first lady planned to head back to the family's oceanfront retreat in Kennebunkport Friday with President Bush, who is planning a 3{-week stay in Maine. The White House said Thursday that Bush still intends to go on vacation, despite the ongoing crisis in Kuwait and his decision to send American troops, ships and warplanes to defend Saudi Arabia. Both Bushes spent the last weekend of July in Kennebunkport. When the president returned to the White House July 29, Mrs. Bush stayed behind with several grandchildren and other family. Sondra Haley, a spokeswoman for the first lady, said Mrs. Bush had no public events planned. ``It's a private day,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Worldwide Oil Production Increase Still Wouldn't Meet Need
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, bgng ```The fourth quarter,' to CORRECT spelling of Sieminski
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Even if other oil-producing nations start pumping to capacity, the world will still have a million barrels a day less oil than before Iraq invaded Kuwait, analysts said Thursday. Prices this fall could double or even triple the June level, they said. The embargo imposed by the United Nations on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait last week has removed 4.5 million barrels of oil from the market _ more than 9 percent of production in the non-communist world. If Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates together increase their production to full capacity _ a big if, analysts say _ together they could replace only 2.5 million barrels daily. The Energy Department said Thursday that Iran also is considering increasing production by as much as 500,000 barrels a day, hoping to replace Iraq as a key supplier to India and Japan. Outside the Middle East _ Venezuela, Nigeria, the United States and possibly Great Britain together could add another 1 million to 1.5 million barrels to daily world production over time, but that would still leave at least a 1 million barrel shortage. ``If this offsetting surge capacity were brought on line, it could reduce the temporary loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil to a net loss of only 1.45 million barrels per day,'' the Energy Department said in a statement. Prices of West Texas Intermediate crude soared from an average $17.70 last week to more than $28 on Tuesday before settling around $25.85 Thursday after President Bush dispatched 5,000 troops to help protect Saudi oil fields. But analysts predict prices will rise to the $30-$35 range in September and October if consuming countries don't fill the gap by tapping their emergency government stockpiles. Some maintain prices could rise above that range until the increased production is flowing. ``Prices will undoubtedly go higher, possibly reaching $40 to $50 per barrel in the absence of action by consuming nations,'' said Philip Verleger, an oil analyst for the Institute of International Economics. The situation will only get worse if the embargo continues into the winter, when cold weather will push the worldwide demand up another 3 million barrels, experts say. ``The fourth quarter is going to be a problem no matter how you slice it,'' said Adam Sieminski, an oil economist for Washington Analysis Corp. ``Everybody seems to be hoping that this production will be coming on real fast, but what if there's a hitch ... and a cold winter?'' he said. ``The system already is going to be stretched everywhere.'' Meanwhile, the International Energy Agency, meeting in Paris, took the first step Thursday to what could result in a draw down of government stockpiles in Europe, the United States and Japan to help fill temporary shortages. Although the agency traditionally has looked upon a 7 percent drop in supplies as the ``trigger point'' for scheduling a coordinated draw down, the government energy officials stopped short of ordering one Thursday doing it in response to the 9 percent supply loss represented by Kuwait and Iraq. Instead, they agreed to begin collecting daily statistics on stocks, usage, supplies and prices in what was described as ``gearing up to be capable to do something.'' The United States has 587 million barrels of crude stored in its Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Texas and Louisiana, enough to replace the 750,000 barrels of the country had been getting daily from Iraq and Kuwait for 800 days. Iraq and Kuwait had supplied by 5 percent of the U.S. daily oil consumption of 17.6 million barrels. Japan, which had relied on Iraq and Kuwait for 14 percent of its oil imports, has 206 million barrels and Germany 189 million barrels in reserve. The Bush administration contends that because of recent cuts in production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, enough producing capacity is available without tapping the emergency reserves as a price control mechanism. Cheating by member nations on quotas imposed by OPEC had contributed to oil prices dropping from $23 a barrel last January to $15.50 in mid-June. In response to an OPEC meeting then when exporting countries agreed to quit cheating on the quotas totaling 22.5 million barrels a day, prices had risen back to $20 by the end of July.

DOC.HEAD: Former Fighter Pilot To Command U.S. Forces In Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng `The three-star general,' to ADD Horner's age.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A highly decorated Vietnam fighter pilot has been put in charge of America's effort to bolster Saudi Arabia's defenses. Air Force Lt.Gen. Charles A. Horner, a native of Davenport, Iowa, is in the region to oversee ``Desert Shield'' _ the U.S. effort to deter any Iraqi move against the oil-rich kingdom, the Pentagon announced on Thursday. ``He's the forward commander. He's the one that's on the ground and out in the boonies directing the show,'' said one Pentagon officer. The 53-year-old three-star general is known as a hard-driving worker, a command pilot with more than 4,500 flying hours who regularly takes to the skies in a variety of modern fighter jets. Ironically, when the general appeared before the Rotary Club in his native Davenport in 1987, he told its members that the United States' interest in the Persian Gulf area was protection of oil sources and shipping. At the time, the U.S. Navy was helping escort Kuwaiti tankers during the Iran-Iraq hostilities. According to an account of the speech in the Quad City Times newspaper, Horner told his listeners that American forces were in the area to protect freedom of navigation, ``not to take sides in Arabian wars.'' Horner is the commander of the 9th Air Force and the U.S. Central Command Air Forces at Shaw Air Force Base in South Carolina. The Central Command is responsible for the Middle East theater, which stretches from Pakistan to Kenya and has at its heart the region that contains 70 percent of the world's oil reserves. During tours of duty in Thailand during the Vietnam War, Horner tallied more than 100 combat missions in F-105 fighter bombers. He served as an F-105 instructor at the Fighter Weapons School in Nellis AFB in Nevada and went on to hold a number of positions in the Tactical Air Command, at Langley, AFB in Virginia. A graduate of the Armed Forces Staff College and the National War College, he commanded the 405th Tactical Training Wing at Luke AFB in Arizona, the 474th Tactical Fighter Wing at Nellis and the 833rd Air Division at Holloman AFB in New Mexico. In May, 1985, he was assigned the deputy chief for plans at the Tactical Air Command Headquarters and assumed his present command in 1987. Horner's military decorations include the Distinguished Service Medal, the Silver Star with one oak leaf cluster, the Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross, Meritorious Service Medal, Air Medal and Air Force Commendation Medal. An Iowa native and a graduate of the University of Iowa with a general science degree, Horner is remembered as being a serious student and a good companion. ``So Charlie is running the show in Saudi Arabia?'' said Phil Lainson, a physician who was Horner's fraternity brother in college. ``I remember him as a man who enjoyed himself but was a hard worker.'' Judy Hendershot, director of placement services at the University of Iowa education department, recalled her childhood friend as ``very pleasant, fun.'' She said his life was touched by tragedy when his parents, his sister, brother-in-law and their two children perished in a car accident in the 1960s. Nona Wilson Warden, who attended high school with Horner, said she received a four-page letter from him about a month ago because he had been unable to attend a school reunion. ``He sounded just like he did when we were in high school,'' she said. ``He was just a fun-loving kid. ... He had a great personality. Everybody liked him and he liked everybody.'' ``What he has accomplished is amazing. But from his letter, you can just see that he has taken everything in stride,'' Ms. Warden said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Debt Limit Increase
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a measure Thursday raising the federal debt limit to almost $3.2 trillion through Oct. 2. The move will keep the government from running out of money in mid-August, raising the permissible amount of federal indebtedness by $72.3 billion to $3,195,000,000,000. The House last week voted to raise the limit by $322 billion to give the Treasury more breathing room. But that bill was faced extended debate and possible amendments on unrelated subjects, so the lawmakers passed the smaller to keep then government running before the leaving last weekend for a one-month vacation. The government is expected to hit its old debt ceiling of $3,122,700,000,000 on Aug. 15. As of the close of business Wednesday, total federal debt was $3,117,914,000,000 _ to the nearest million. The federal government has never defaulted on its loans. In debate last week, lawmakers warned that even a brief default could send interest rates soaring and stagger confidence in the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Sends Police, Soldiers, Helicopters To Violent Suburbs
DOC.TEXT: The government sent more police, soldiers and helicopters Thursday to a southeastern port city where rioting in mixed-race suburbs has killed more than 30 people. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said many more people had been injured in Port Elizabeth, but he gave no figures. Police said 33 people had died since Monday and more than 100 had been arrested. Police and political organizations in the city say that most of the violence was caused by roving mobs of people looting and burning. Criminals are also contributing to the chaos. Another six blacks died elsewhere in the country Wednesday and Thursday, including four in black factional fighting at the President Steyn gold mine in Orange Free State province. The riots in the northern Port Elizabeth suburbs of Bloemendal, Arcadia, Chatty, Windvogel and Hillside began Monday in a clash between members of a political group and police. But neither the local Northern Areas Action Committee nor the affiliated African National Congress has any control over the hundreds of rioters who have stormed through the streets, throwing rocks and gasoline bombs. ``Criminal mobs ran amok ... looting and burning shops at random and causing damage ... A baby was shot dead in its mother's lap,'' said local journalist Cliff Foster. Police repeatedly fired shotguns and pistols to disperse the mobs. Businessmen have also been reported firing at looters before fleeing with their families. Government television showed crowds of people walking out of stores with stolen goods as riot control officers made vain attempts to chase and nab one or two looters. Police removed liquor from many shops Thursday to cut down on the mob behavior. Telephone, trash collection, mail and all other public services were cut off to the riot areas. Municipal employees had been targeted for attack and, along with almost all other residents, stayed home from work to protect their houses. The car manufacturing plants that employ many of Port Elizabeth-area blacks were nearly at a standstill. Burning barricades in the streets blocked ambulances and fire trucks from getting in. Shops, factories, schools, a church, police and private vehicles were burned, said Port Elizabeth police spokesman Maj. Bill Dennis. In other unrest, police said Thursday three people were killed and 18 injured Wednesday night when workers attacked other staff at President Steyn gold mine at Welkom. Police arrested 35 men. On Thursday, the mine owner, Anglo-American Corp., announced that a fourth miner had been found dead underground, but gave no further information. The National Union of Mineworkers denied the police version of the conflict. The union said police fired on miners protesting discrimination at the mine. Police reported Thursday two men had been killed in black faction fighting in Natal Province, including one man ``necklaced'' with a burning car tire. New factional fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and Inkatha, a conservative Zulu group, broke out again Thursday in Kagiso, a black township outside Johannesburg, police said. No new deaths were immediately reported in the fighting, which has claimed 15 lives since Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: After 15-Month Trip, Magellan Ready for Venus Exploration
With AM-Venus Missions
DOC.TEXT: Magellan, the first U.S. planetary spacecraft launched in 12 years, reaches Venus on Friday, raising NASA's hopes for a major success after its woes with the Hubble space telescope and the shuttle fleet. ``We're just thrilled to be here and are rarin' to go. We're just as excited as we can be,'' said John McCarthy, Magellan program manager for Hughes Aircraft Co. Hughes built the science instruments on the 21-foot-long spacecraft. At noon PDT Thursday, Magellan was only 242,009 miles from Venus, speeding toward the cloud-shrouded planet at 10,398 mph. It was 144 million miles from Earth, but had traveled 946.3 million miles since it was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. The $413 million spacecraft, centerpiece of a $744 million mission, was scheduled to zoom over Venus' north pole and then drop into orbit after it fires its braking rocket at 9:32 a.m. PDT Friday. The spacecraft will be behind Venus at the time, so engineers won't know if all went well until about half an hour later. After a few weeks of tests, Magellan will start using its radar by Sept. 1 to penetrate the thick Venusian clouds and make pictures and maps of the planet's surface 10 times more detailed than those returned by the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft, which were launched in 1983. During a news conference Thursday at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, engineers and scientists expressed confidence that Magellan's rocket will fire properly and place the vessel in orbit. ``Magellan is the beginning of a new era of planetary exploration,'' kicking off a decade in which unmanned craft will study Jupiter, Mars, asteroids, comets and Saturn, said Wesley T. Huntress Jr., NASA's director of solar system exploration. ``We're looking forward to the drama.'' Magellan is the first U.S. planetary spacecraft launched since 1978, when NASA sent the Pioneer 12 orbiter and the Pioneer 13 probes to Venus. If Magellan's rocket fails to ignite, the spacecraft would fly past Venus uselessly and wouldn't encounter the planet again for 100 years, said Tony Spear, Magellan project manager at the laboratory. NASA has been plagued by trouble lately, including temporary grounding of the shuttle fleet because of hydrogen fuel leaks and a defective mirror that largely crippled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. ``The major pressure we feel is the pressure to succeed,'' Huntress said. ``I'd prefer not to speculate on what failure might mean.'' If Magellan works as planned, it will return more data than all previous NASA missions combined, said Steve Saunders, NASA's chief scientist for Magellan. Venus is similar to Earth is size, density and position in the solar system. Magellan will study's the planet's geology and geography to learn if its geological processes are similar to those on Earth, which is shaped by volcanoes and large-scale movements of gargantuan plates of the planet's crust. ``Venus really is our sister planet,'' Saunders said. ``We need to know a lot more about that planet to understand more about our own.'' The raw radar echoes collected by Magellan will be returned to NASA Deep Space Network antennas in California, Spain and Australia, then converted into pictures at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. NASA expects to release the first pictures next month, unless a major discovery is made during radar tests this month. Magellan is named for Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan, who circumnavigated the world in the early 1500s.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Head For Vacation At Maine Summer Home
Eds. Leads with 8 grafs with Bush quotes; picks up 6th graf pvs: ``Bush's oceanfront,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying ``life goes on,'' Thursday decided to head for Maine on a 3{-week vacation despite the crisis in the Middle East. ``Gotta keep moving. Can't stay in one place all the time,'' a jocular Bush told reporters after leaving the Oval Office early in the evening. The White House announced earlier that Bush would leave for his summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine, as planned Friday, but will take extra staff with him because of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. Bush, who was on his way out to dinner with wife Barbara, told reporters, ``Life goes on.'' Barbara Bush has been staying at the summer home by herself since July 27. She flew to Washington for the day Thursday and will return to Kennebunkport with the president Friday. ``The president will be conducting the business of the presidency at Kennebunkport just as he does every year and every vacation,'' press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. That goes on ``24 hours a day, every day of the week, wherever he is,'' the spokesman added. But Bush is also expected to make a quick trip back to the capital on Wednesday for a comprehensive briefing from military planners on the status of the U.S. forces sent to Saudi Arabia. Bush's oceanfront home at Walker's Point has its own helipad, sophisticated communications equipment, and is heavily protected on land by the Secret Service and at sea by Coast Guard ships hovering offshore. The president has hosted world leaders during past vacations. Top advisers shuttled back and forth from Washington last August as Bush readied his national drug strategy. While the president has not announced a VIP guest list for this vacation, Fitzwater said Bush will have full access to one of his favorite instruments of diplomacy, the telephone. ``We believe that the communications system is excellent for maintaining liaison with anyone in Washington or around the world that the president should need to get in touch with,'' the spokesman said. He said the White House never seriously considered cancelling the vacation plans. Asked if the president was not concerned about being photographed out boating or on the golf course while American GIs in Saudi Arabia are worried about a possible chemical weapons attack by Iraq, Fitzwater answered, ``No.'' Bush has gone to Kennebunkport every summer of his life except 1944, when he was off in the Pacific flying bomber missions for the Navy against the Japanese in World War II. Either Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, or his deputy, Robert Gates, always accompanies Bush to Kennebunkport and provides daily briefings on the latest U.S. intelligence from hot spots around the world. ``Our forces are in Saudi Arabia on a defensive basis. They're not involved in conflict, and there's not the need for any kind of minute-by-minute or hour-by-hour update that might be necessary if they were actually involved in combat,'' said Fitzwater. He said Bush's budget advisers also may make the trip to Kennebunkport at some point to prepare for the resumption of deficit-reduction talks with congressional Democrats in early September. Fitzwater said Bush ``probably'' will return to Washington next week for a briefing. Bush plans to fly to Baltimore Aug. 20 to address the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention. He also plans to attend fundraising events for several GOP candidates in New England during his vacation. File Stored As: ag512 A31 0595 19:05 08-09 ----- uwbx AM-Bush Vacation, 1st Ld-Writethru, send ag512 dsa

DOC.HEAD: Arab Summit Postponed For Day, Ousted Kuwaiti Emir Weeps on Arrival
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with report of dispute over Kuwaiti representation reason for the delay, new arrivals at summit; EDITS to conform; TRIMS pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CAI1
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders gathered Thursday for an emergency summit seen as a last-ditch diplomatic effort to end the Persian Gulf crisis without outside military intervention. The summit, originally planned Thursday, was postponed a day. The official reason for the postponement was some late arrivals. However, unconfirmed reports said the summit hit a snag because the Iraqi delegation brought its own representative for the new Baghdad-installed Kuwaiti government. Most delegates to the summit reject that government. One of those arriving, the ousted Kuwaiti emir who is still recognized by most Arab governments as the sheikdom's ruler, wept as an Egyptian military band played the Kuwaiti national anthem. Senior Iraqi officials are representing Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who appointed a Kuwaiti Cabinet loyal to him after his troops swept away the royal government. President Hosni Mubarak's press secretary, Mohamed Abdel-Moneim, told reporters that representatives to the summit would be arriving as late as Friday, forcing delay of the meeting. Organizers said that of 21 Arab League countries, only Tunisia and Mauritania were still absent late Thursday. Mubarak organized the summit to discuss last week's invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. He said he hoped the meeting would forestall any Western military attack to punish Saddam. The United States has sent troops and materiel to Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational force to guard against possible threats from Iraq. A source close to the summit told The Associated Press the Arabs want to give Saddam a final chance to resolve the crisis peacefully. ``The Arab leaders want to do their duty by Iraq once and for all, to give her a final chance to reverse what she has done,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``If this effort fails and there is no response from Iraq, then he (Saddam) deserves what he will get. We are almost certain that there will be an external strike against him. The question is when.'' On Wednesday, when he requested the emergency summit, Mubarak warned Iraq would be the target of a ``harsh strike'' by Western powers if it refused to withdraw from Kuwait. He said in the nationally televised speech that the summit ``would be better than having a solution forced on us by foreign powers.'' Answering his call, Arab leaders swarmed in Thursday, their private jetliners lined up at Cairo International Airport like limousines in a parking lot. Included in the Iraqi delegation were Taha Yassin Ramadan, first deputy premier and a member of the ruling junta, and Foreign Minister Tarek Aziz. Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, Kuwait's deposed emir, looked weary and thinner than usual as he stepped in his white robes from a blue-and-white Kuwait Airways jetliner. The playing of the anthem evoked tears from the emir and his entire delegation. It symbolized the refusal of Egypt and most other Arab states to recognize Iraq's appointed government in Kuwait. On Wednesday, Iraq said it had annexed Kuwait. The U.N. Security Council declared the move ``null and void'' on Thursday. The conference source said Egypt would demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and return al-Sabah to the throne held by his family for more than 230 years. Egypt also would propose possible formation of a joint Arab force to serve as a buffer between Iraq and Kuwait after Saddam's troops withdraw, the source said. He said the proposed Arab force would not interfere with the U.S.-led multinational force. The gathering is the first Arab League summit in Egypt since October 1976. Egypt's membership was suspended in 1979 to retaliate for its peace treaty with Israel. Mubarak has attended two Arab summits since Cairo regained its League seat last year.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Seek $40.9 Million from Keating, Associates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT that Columbia is not a failed institution.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators moved Thursday to recover $40.9 million from Charles H. Keating Jr. and five associates for losses the regulators claim the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan suffered from sour business deals. The Office of Thrift Supervision also demanded a complete accounting within five days of Keating's personal assets as it seeks restitution from the Arizona businessman and his associates. OTS Director Timothy Ryan said regulators do not believe Keating's repeated claim that he went broke when his American Continental Corp., the Phoenix-based holding company that owned Lincoln, filed for bankruptcy protection. ``There was just too much money available to him and to short a time for it to disappear,'' Ryan told reporters at a news conference. ``We believe Mr. Keating and his associates profited from the improper use of depositors' funds and we want that money returned to Lincoln.'' The $40.9 million is sought from Keating and the five executives either individually or as a group, Ryan said. It is the largest amount sought in a thrift restitution proceeding. The administrative charges also seek to permanently bar Keating and the five executives of American Continental from the thrift industry and to remove them from the Phoenix-based company. The restitution is being sought to cover losses to the savings and loan from three business deals that OTS attorney Richard Delliveneri said were ``evidence of blatant disregard for the safety and soundness of Lincoln Savings.'' These include the $24.2 million Lincoln lost when a subsidiary invested in a money-losing Detroit hotel and $4.4 million it lost from the purchase and resale of Arizona desert land that regulators say falsely inflated the thrift's profits. OTS also seeks to recover $12.3 million Lincoln lost to finance the purchase of American Continental stock from Keating and others by an employee stock-ownership plan. The business deals allowed Keating and his associates to take tax deductions and enjoy other personal financial benefits, regulators charges. Ryan said OTS was investigating other transactions involving Lincoln and may file charges to seek more restitution from Keating. The Irvine, Calif., thrift made heavy investments in the junk bond market, losing $2 billion before it was taken over by federal regulators on April 14, 1989. American Continental, which Keating chairs, filed for bankruptcy protection a day before Lincoln's seizure. Keating could immediately challenge in federal court the temporary cease-and-desist order, which directs him to account for his assets and bars him from transferring anything worth $5,000 without first informing OTS. The OTS charges will be heard by an administrative law judge in late October, Ryan said. A final OTS decision can be appealed to federal circuit courts. Besides Keating, the OTS charges were also filed against Judy J. Wischer, president and chief executive officer of American Continental; Robert J. Kielty, a director, senior vice president and general counsel of the company; Keating's son, Charles H. Keating III, an executive vice president and director; and two of Keating's sons-in-law who are vice presidents, Robert J. Hubbard and Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. OTS also seeks their removal as American Continental officers. Bradley Boland, Keating's son-in-law and a spokesman for American Continental, said Thursday that the six executives will ``take every legal opportunity that is available'' to fight the charges. Boland scoffed at the allegations, calling them ``the same old wine from the same old bottle'' and accusing OTS of political grandstanding. A $1.1 billion racketeering and fraud suit filed in September against Keating and his associates by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. charges they fraudulently diverted depositors' money for business dealings. Separately, a federal grand jury in Los Angeles is investigating Keating's dealings at Lincoln. The Justice Department is also examining whether Keating improperly donated $1.3 million to five senators who met on his behalf with federal regulators in 1987, law enforcement sources say. The Senate Ethics Committee is reviewing allegations of improper intervention with regulators by the five senators: Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John McCain, R-Ariz.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, An American Continental suit challenging Lincoln's seizure is pending before a federal judge here. The second-largest restitution case is a $24 million suit filed this year against Thomas Spiegel, former owner of the financially troubled Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chicago-Philadelphia FBI Agent Gets Pay-Plus-Pension Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A black FBI agent who charged in civil suits he was racially harassed by white agents will receive full pay and pension benefits, possibly worth more than $1 million, under a settlement of the case, his lawyer said Thursday. Attorneys for Donald Rochon, 40, and the FBI signed an agreement this week that settles the three-year-old legal battle arising from the black agent's charges he was harassed by white colleagues when he worked in the FBI's Chicago office. The settlement is a further admission by the FBI of racial problems in its ranks. Officials earlier this year acknowledged that the FBI had settled three other racial discrimination suits, including one involving 30 employees of the fingerprint identification division. The FBI announced the settlement with Rochon on Wednesday but declined to give details. Rochon, who has been on disability leave since April because of emotional stress, will receive full compensation and full pension benefits under the terms of the settlement, said his attorney, David Kairys of Philadelphia. Rochon will remain on disability leave until he is eligible to retire in 11 years, Kairys said. As a result of the emotional strain, ``he never wants to go back to the FBI,'' the lawyer said. The FBI has also agreed to award Rochon some back pay for a promotion the agent claims he was unfairly denied, Kairys said. It will also pay Rochon's former wife, Susan, a sum of money as compensation, Kairys said. The attorney declined to disclose the amount of that sum. But overall, the lawyer said, the entire settlement could be worth more than a million dollars. The FBI also agreed to conduct a full investigation of Rochon's claims and make public its findings by next April, Rochon said. Under the terms of the settlement Rochon will receive disability payments under a finding by the Labor Department that he is entitled to federal workmen's compensation for his emotional distress, Kairys said. In addition, the FBI will pay the difference between the disability insurance and what Rochon would earn if he remained with the FBI. After a year of further leave, Rochon will be formally separated from the bureau but will continue to receive raises and get a pension when he reaches retirement age in 11 years, Kairys said. Agents become eligible to retire on their 51st birthday. Rochon will be paid the average salary of FBI agents who joined the bureau when he did in 1981, taking into account promotions that some of his colleagues received, Kairys said. This provision of the settlement gives Rochon the so-called ``front pay'' allowed in civil rights law for employees who are forced to leave hostile work environments. Rochon also received as $6,000 award to cover moving expenses that the FBI originally refused to pay when he was transferred at his request from Chicago to Philadelphia. Kairys said week-long negotiations ended with the signing of a settlement agreement on Wednesday. Motions to dismiss the complaints will be filed in federal courts in both Chicago and Washington, where Rochon had suits pending. Kairys expressed surprise that the FBI had agreed to settle the case after refusing to do in the past. Several years ago, the federal judge who presided over the Washington case had urged Justice Department lawyers and attorneys representing individual agents named in the complaint to settle the case, but those talks broke down quickly. Rochon claimed his family received threatening telephone calls and letters, including one that contained a picture of the dismembered body of a black man. Another contained a bull's eye superimposed with a picture of a black man. One white FBI agent, Gary W. Miller, acknowledged in a 1985 affidavit that he forged Rochon's signature on an application for a death and dismemberment insurance policy for the black agent's family. Another Chicago agent, Richard Ganslein, was recently added to the suit in that city after the plaintiffs had discovered he had admitted participating in the harassment, Kairys said.

DOC.HEAD: Kitty Dukakis Describes Alcohol and Drug Dependency, Emotional Problems
DOC.TEXT: Had Michael Dukakis become president two years ago, Kitty Dukakis believes the pressure of life in the White House would have sent her ``out of control.'' In excerpts from her new book, ``Now You Know,'' Mrs. Dukakis blames many of her problems on her mother, who was illegitimate. Learning that fact was the turning point in her life, she said. ``Now You Know'' describes in greater detail the extent of Mrs. Dukakis' already known addiction to drugs and diet pills. Her bouts with depression and her struggles with these problems also are futher revealed. ``I am certain the first crisis would have sent me out of control. I am equally certain that, thrust into the smothering, protective confines of the White House, I would not have been able to seek proper help,'' she writes in excerpts from September's Good Housekeeping magazine. The autobiography written with Jane Scovell will be available early next month. Mrs. Dukakis said there were periods of heavy drinking during the 1988 presidential campaign. She said she panicked before New Hampshire's Democratic primary, because she realized her husband might win. ``Michael was good enough to be president, for sure, but was I worthy to be his partner? In my despair, I turned to alcohol,'' she wrote. At one point after Dukakis lost to George Bush, she said her son, John, found her unconscious in a bedroom, ``lying in my own vomit.'' The book describes her drinking habits after the election: ``On a typical day I would rise, wait till my husband left and, by 9 o'clock in the morning, cancel all my appointments. I would go to the liquor cabinet in the dining room, measure out three or four ounces of straight spirits, and drink it down. Then I'd go upstairs, shut the blinds, unplug the phone, and read till I passed out _ a process that usually took no more than 10 minutes. Two and a half hours later, I would wake up and repeat the process.'' Mrs. Dukakis blames her late mother, Jane Goldberg Dickson, for much of her alcohol and drug addiction and for a long history of low self-esteem. When she was 18, a cousin revealed that her mother had been adopted. Later she learned her mother was illegitimate. Mrs. Dukakis said she was ``thunderstruck'' on learning that the couple she and her younger sister, Jinny, knew as their grandparents were her mother's adoptive parents. Her biological grandmother had given up her daughter on one condition: That she be allowed to live with the adoptive couple as a nanny. ``Why did you keep this from me?'' she demanded of her mother, who replied, ``Well, now you know.'' Mrs. Dukakis said it was ``an enormous breach of trust. That traumatic moment haunted me for years,'' Within a year, Mrs. Dukakis started using amphetamine pills that she discovered in her mother's room, the start of a 26-year addiction. She said her mother took many pills, including mood-altering ones. She also said her mother had a fondness for alcohol. Mrs. Dukakis wonders if her addiction to pills was responsible for four miscarriages she had during her two marriages. Mrs. Dukakis, who is taking lithium to control manic depression, wrote that when she was hospitalized for drinking rubbing alcohol last year, she was not suicidal, but depressed. She also said that last December when she took a handful of Tylenol-with-codeine tablets, she was just trying to get to sleep.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Envoy in Damascus on Iraq Sanctions
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. envoy John Kelly flew to Syria Thursday to try to persuade that country to formally join international sanctions against Iraq, diplomatic sources said. Kelly, the undersecretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs, is the highest ranking U.S. official from the Bush administration to visit Syria publicly. He was met at the aiport by Deputy Foreign Minister Nasser Qaddour and U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerejian. The United States is spearheading diplomatic efforts to make sure all nations isolate Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. Iraq is almost wholly dependent on oil sales for revenue. A dormant Iraqi pipeline runs through Syria to the Mediterranean Sea. Syrian sources in Beirut, Lebanon, said Thursday that Iraq's oil minister, Issam Al-Chalaby, came to Damascus this week to ask Syria to reopen the line, but was refused. Syria and Iraq have a bitter rivalry going back 20 years. Their borders have been sealed since Syria supported Iran in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Most of Iraq's 2.7 million barrels per day in exports flowed through pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia. That slowed to a trickle after the United Nations imposed mandatory sanctions on Iraq Monday. Turkey said it would respect the sanctions. Saudi Arabia has yet to announce its position.

DOC.HEAD: More Heavy Rains and Floods
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains and thunderstorms fell again Thursday in many parts of the nation, threatening to worsen floods in Texas and cause them in the East. Flooding in Texas continued. Flood warnings for Thursday and Friday were in effect along the Rio Grande from Presidio to Langtry. Flood warnings were also posted Thursday for sections of North Carolina. One state road was underwater between Zebulon and Wendell. Flood watches were posted for parts of the Piedmont area of Virginia, as well as central Maryland and the District of Columbia. There was also the threat of flooding in parts of eastern West Virginia, east central and southeast Pennsylvania, the metropolitan part of the Delaware Valley in southern New Jersey and northwestern New Jersey. Rain showers and thunderstorms continued into Thursday afternoon, extending from eastern Pennsylvania and New Jersey to eastern South Carolina, and parts of Georgia and Florida. Showers and storms also reached along the lower Texas coast. There were storms and showers over eastern Tennessee into northern Georgia, and from north central Oklahoma into southeast Kansas. Scattered showers and thunderstorms hit northwest Wisconsin, parts of Michigan, southern Nevada, east central California, western Montana, northern Idaho, southeast Washington, and along the Oregon coast. Heavier rainfall totals included 2.8 inches at Fayetteville, N.C.; 1.69 inches at Richmond, Va.; 1.34 inches at Cherry Point, N.C.; 1.16 inches at Goldsboro, Va.; 1.14 inches at Camp Springs, Md.; and 1.1 inches at Fort Belvoir, Va. Record lows for Thursday were set in Lake Charles, La., where it was 61 degrees; Meridian, Miss., 56, Montgomery, Ala., 63 and Pine Bluff, Ark., 57. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 56 degrees in Crescent City, Calif., to 107 degrees in Gila Bend, Ariz., and Needles, Calif. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 35 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lorenzo, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo announced Thursday he would sell his stake in Continental Airline Holdings Inc., ending a stormy tenure at the helm of what was once the nation's largest airline company. Here is a rundown of highlights in his career: _1963 _ Hired by Trans World Airlines as a financial analyst, his first professional job. _1965 _ Becomes manager of the financial analysis department at Eastern Airlines. _1966 _ Forms an airline consulting firm with Harvard business school classmate Robert Carney to explore business opportunities. _1972 _ Becomes president of Texas International Airlines, after a holding company he forms injects new capital into the ailing airline. _1973-77 _ Rejuvenates Texas International using discounted ``peanut'' fares, more efficient routes and upgraded fleet. _1980 _ Forms New York Air to compete with Eastern shuttle service between New York and Washington. _1981 _ Wins control of Continental Airlines over a rival management-led buyout bid. _1982 _ Merges Texas International and Continental under Texas Air Corp. _1983 _ Lays off 15 percent of work force to bring down labor costs; hires permanent replacements for striking machinists. Files for bankruptcy protection to reorganize, voiding labor contracts. Offers to rehire employees at half pay. _1985 _ Loses a bid for Trans World Airlines to financier Carl Icahn, and a bid for Frontier Airlines to People Express. _1986 _ Acquires Eastern Airlines and People Express to form the nation's biggest airline company. _1987 _ Introduces discount Maxsaver fares and announces plans to cut labor costs. _1988 _ Undertakes a joint marketing operation with Scandinavian Airlines System, a leading European carrier. _1989 _ Rejects Eastern union demands in contract negotiations. Workers strike in March, Lorenzo puts the carrier under federal bankruptcy protection and begins to sell many of Eastern's important assets, including the Northeast shuttle. Parent company loses $885.6 million for the year, an industry record. _January-February 1990 _ Drastically reduces proposal for repaying Eastern creditors and faces increased problems in bankruptcy court. _April 1990 _ Loses control of Eastern to a court-appointed trustee, Martin Shugrue. Renames Texas Air to Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. _Aug. 9, 1990 _ Announces resignation as chairman and chief executive officer.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Kill Three in Rioting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with three rioters killed, announcement that currency will be floated; TRIMS pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Security forces shot and killed three rioters Thursday during unrest over austerity measures that sent the cost of food soaring by 300 percent or more. Soldiers patrolled the capital city of Lima in armored cars, brandishing automatic weapons and wearing ski masks for fear of retribution from rioters. The violence broke out after Prime Minister Juan Hurtado Miller announced economic austerity measures Wednesday night in a bid to ease the worst economic crisis in Peru's history. On Thursday, the government announced a new measure, saying it has decided to float Peru's currency, the inti. The price of gasoline, a government monopoly, jumped from 7 cents a gallon to more than $2. Private bus lines halted runs Thursday, stranding thousands of people. Commuters fought one another for room in the back of pickup trucks. Police reported looting in a dozen small street markets in shantytowns that ring Lima. Police and soldiers opened fire and killed a man and a woman among about 130 protesters who were burning rubber tires to block a highway 10 miles east of Lima. In Ancon, a beach town 25 miles north of Lima, a Peruvian marine shot to death a man involved in a fight with other shoppers at a municipal food market. Tension in the capital had mounted in the days leading up to Hurtado's announcement. Many shops doubled their prices even before his address. Bread, noodles, beans, sugar, cooking oil and milk disappeared from store shelves. The emergency economic package included elimination of subsidies to cut a huge budget deficit, which Hurtado blamed for Peru's 3,000 percent annual inflation. The decision to let the currency float means its value will be determined by supply and demand. The subsidized dollar cost only about one-sixth of the free-market dollar in the final days of the previous government of President Alan Garcia. Peru's inti is expected to quickly fall on the open market, lowering the price of the country's exports on the world market. However, the move will bring much higher prices for imported goods. ``The government must exercise leadership even if it means a loss of its popularity,'' said Hurtado, who also is economy minister in the new centrist government of President Alberto Fujimori. Fujimori's predecessor, Garcia, was a populist who spent the country's last dollar reserves before leaving office July 28. ``What we are suffering today was originated by a government that treated us all like guinea pigs to try out its wonderful theory that a nation can indiscriminately increase its deficit by printing money without affecting prices,'' Hurtado said in a television address. Weighed down by hyperinflation, Peru's economy shrank 20 percent in the last two years. Four of five people are out of work. Starting now, Hurtado said, Peru's new government would not spend more than it receives in tax revenues. He said public services must charge enough to cover their costs. The emergency package also includes special taxes on the rich, reduction of import duties to open up the economy to competition from foreign goods, and a wage bonus for workers equivalent to their July pay. Some observers have suggested Fujimori will have to use the army to keep order in the face of the harsh economic measures. He named two army generals to head the Defense Ministry and the Interior Ministry, which controls the police forces. Most public markets in the capital were closed Thursday. Troops were sent to Huancayo, a major commercial center 120 miles from Lima, to prevent looting. Shops stayed closed in Arequipa, Peru's second-biggest city, 465 miles southeast of the capital. The dollar doubled in value on Lima's parallel street market, jumping from 200,000 intis to 400,000 in three days. On Thursday it fell back to about 350,000 intis. During a brief visit Wednesday, Vice President Dan Quayle said the United States supported Fujimori's austerity measures and expressed confidence the reforms would ``put this country back on the road to economic recovery.'' He said the Bush administration was seeking congressional approval for $160 million in military and economic aid for Peru in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Polls: Americans Back Bush but Fear War with Iraq
With AM-US-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Americans strongly support President Bush's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia, even though most believe the United States is headed toward war with Iraq, according to polls released Thursday. Survey respondents also supported the embargo of Iraqi oil, and many said they would accept higher gasoline prices to make it work. But most blamed last week's jumps in gasoline prices on oil company greed, not the embargo. Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait last week and annexed it Wednesday. Bush dispatched U.S. troops to deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia, explaining his move in a televised address to the nation Wednesday. USA Today, in a survey of 610 people Wednesday, found that 81 percent supported sending troops to Saudi Arabia. CBS News, surveying 773 people Tuesday and Wednesday, found 63 percent approval. And a poll of 769 people Wednesday by ABC News and The Washington Post found 74 percent support. However, the CBS poll indicated military action was not Americans' first choice. Asked the best response to Iraq, 42 percent said ``hold off for the time being'' and 35 percent favored using ``diplomatic and economic weapons.'' Just 13 percent favored military force; the rest favored some combination, or were unsure. ``The bottom line is basically this is a popular action,'' said Kathleen A. Frankovic, pollster for CBS. ``While there may be clouds over the horizon, right now they're still in the distance.'' Polls conducted on breaking news events tend to measure visceral reactions, and the surveys found immediate fears of war were high. Seventy-three percent in the USA Today poll said U.S. forces are likely to end up in combat against Iraqi forces. Similarly, 66 percent in the CBS poll called it likely that the situation in the Middle East will lead to an extended war involving the United States. Twenty-two percent called that ``very likely,'' 44 percent ``somewhat likely.'' In the USA Today and CBS surveys, 49 percent favored using U.S. troops to try to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Support for economic and political sanctions was considerably higher. In the ABC-Post survey, 69 percent favored a naval blockade of Iraq. But strong majorities opposed U.S. military strikes against Iraq. On the oil embargo, 68 percent told CBS it was a good idea even if it meant higher prices, and 50 percent said they would support the embargo even if it made gasoline prices reach $2 per gallon. Forty-nine percent told USA Today they would pay an additional 50 cents or more per gallon to make the embargo work. But most said the embargo was not the culprit in recent price increases: Eighty-seven percent in the ABC-Post poll and 84 percent in the CBS poll said gasoline companies were using the crisis as an excuse to raise prices. The telephone surveys had error margins of plus or minus four percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Buildup Plans Could reach 250,000
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon plans call for sending up to 250,000 ground troops to Saudi Arabia's defense in the face of a continued Iraqi military buildup in Kuwait, Pentagon sources and administration officials said Thursday. The substance of the military's so-called ``detail planning'' came as the White House hinted at a possible naval blockade to choke off Iraq's oil exports in the face of its week-old invasion of Kuwait. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters that the U.S. movement of troops continued on Thursday and would take ``many days'' to complete. Williams declined to specify the force level the United States intends to deploy. However, an administration official, speaking privately, said, ``There's a certain minimum force we have to put over there as a deterrent. For now, we're marching ahead with it.'' A Pentagon source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States was prepared to put ``many divisions'' in Saudi Arabia. ``We have contingency plans that could result in the insertion of up to 200,000 to 250,000 ground forces before it's all done,'' said this source, who spoke on condition that further identification be withheld.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Freed Swiss Hostage Arrives Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with first comments from freed hostage; MINOR EDITING; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Relief worker Emanuel Christen arrived to an emotional homecoming Thursday after his release by kidnappers in Lebanon, but he said his joy was tempered by thoughts of a colleague still in captivity. Appearing thin but healthy, 33-year-old Christen bounded down the steps of a Red Cross-chartered aircraft that arrived at Kloten airport after a flight from the Syrian capital, Damascus. His parents and four brothers and sisters rushed onto the tarmac to embrace him. He was handed over to Syrian officials Wednesday after 10 monthsFellow Swiss hostage Elio Erriquez, who was abducted Oct. 6 with Christen, remains a captive. Before being in captivity. abducted, both men worked as orthopedic technicians at a Red Cross hospital in the southern Lebanese port of Sidon. ``It's very difficult for me to accept that Elio is still in captivity today,'' Christen told a news conference less than 90 minutes after arriving in Switzerland. ``We had hoped to be freed together.'' At his arrival, Christen was greeted by Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber and Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the International Committee of thny who left Kuwait for Saudi Arabia on Aug. 3, one day after the invasion. During the 75-minute drive, Whitaker said, Iraqi soldiers ``were lined up all along the road and they had tanks. They had machine guns and rifles. It was an army.'' The group was stopped twice by Iraqi soldiers. The second time, ``I just acted like I didn't hear him and kept going,'' said Whitaker, who returned Sunday to Abilene. ``There's no order back in Kuwait. Nobody goes to work, there's no police, no services. We don't intend to go back there,'' said Kimberly El-Zahr, 29. She, her husband, Camille, 33, and two young children arrived Wednesday in Los Angeles after escaping Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The family plans to stay with relatives in Oregon for now. The estimated 3,400 Americans still in Kuwait and Iraq left many loved ones in this country ignorant of their whereabouts and condition. Bush received high marks in the latest ``Pulse of America'' survey conducted in Lubbock County, Texas _ the president's adopted sounding board for America. Sixty-four percent of 400 people surveyed Aug. 6-8 said they would support Bush if he opted to use military force to push Iraq out of Kuwait. Twenty-one percent did not support military use, 12 percent were undecided and 3 percent had no answer. The survey, sent to Bush on Thursday, was conducted by Southwest Research Associates and has a 4 percent margin of error. Laureen Utz Aljazireh, who moved to Kuwait from Springfield, Minn., but was visiting American relatives at the time of the invasion, also supports the president. ``I'm glad America is stepping in to stop (Iraqi leader Saddam) Hussein before he continues into Saudi Arabia,'' she said. ``Living in Kuwait, reading the newspapers there, you got more of a sense of how powerful Hussein is.'' Aljazireh's husband, Manhal, is an oil refinery engineer in Kuwait, and she has not heard from him since the invasion. Bobby Parker, 48, is one of 38 Americans being detained in a Baghdad, Iraq, hotel. ``I am very frightened for him and I'm concerned for the troops and their families,'' said his wife, Lynda Parker of Beaumont, Texas. All 38 were reported to be in good condition. Arab-American groups were divided in their reaction to U.S. military action. ``We are U.S. citizens and we share the same concerns and feel the same economic consequences as all citizens living in this country. Furthermore, many U.S. Chaldeans have relatives still living in Iraq. This gives us cause for even greater concern,'' the Detroit-based Chaldean Federation of America said in a statement. Chaldeans are Christian Arabs, mostly from Iraq. ``Our confidence is behind President Bush and the government of the United States of America.'' ``All it takes is a manufactured Bay of Tonkin or an accident and we're in another Vietnam,'' radio and televison personality Casey Kasem, who is of Lebanese heritage and often speaks out on Arab issues. ``Gunboat diplomacy is not what the '90s is all about. Shooting from the hip is not what the 90s is about. It's the age of reason,'' he said. M.T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee and the National Council on Islamic Affairs, and about 30 other Arab leaders held a news conference Thursday in New York City. The metropolitan area has about 200,000 Arab-Americans. He said about 60 percent were anti-Saddam, about 40 percent pro, but they unanimously opposed the American military deployment. ``We feel it will increase Arab and Muslim hostility to the U.S. and only increase Saddam Hussein's prestige in the Arab world,'' Mehdi said. ``We're all convinced the route to a solution is through the U.N., not the U.S.'' Mehdi said most Arab-American leaders in the area favor economic sanctions. Ten members of the American Friends Service Committee held a vigil in Atlanta on Thursday to protest the U.S. military intervention. Members of AFSC, a Quaker pacifist organization, said they want Iraq out Kuwait but oppose American troops being sent to neighboring Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Moved into Hangar After Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Atlantis inside hangar, preliminary check showing no damage, other details; picks up 6th graf, `Columbia was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis was moved inside its hangar Thursday after being trapped outside for several hours by a thunderstorm accompanied by lightning and hail. A preliminary check did not find any damage caused by the storm to the exposed shuttle, but NASA planned to conduct a more thorough examination of the spacecraft Friday, said agency spokeswoman Lisa Malone. The newly repaired Columbia, which took Atlantis' place at the launch pad, was not affected by the high winds and heavy rain. Atlantis' 3{-mile trip back to the hangar for repair of a hydrogen leak took nearly six hours and ended around 4 a.m. Thursday just outside the doors of the crowded Vehicle Assembly Building. Shortly before 6 a.m., Columbia was rolled from the structure and out to the pad. It was the first time two shuttles had passed one another in upright launch positions. NASA intended to roll Atlantis into the hangar Thursday afternoon, after Columbia had been secured at the launch pad. Lightning in the area, however, prevented Atlantis from being moved until Thursday night. Columbia was returned to the hangar in June because of a hydrogen leak that was detected during fueling for a May 30 launch attempt. The faulty fuel lines were replaced with components from the new shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. NASA plans to launch Columbia with the $150 million Astro observatory around Sept. 4 or 5. Atlantis' classified military mission, originally scheduled for mid-July, is now set for November. The space agency had planned nine shuttle missions this year, but now is aiming for seven. So far, only three of them have flown.

DOC.HEAD: US Troops Deploying in Heart of Vast Saudi Oil Region
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 10 grafs new with Pentagon contingency plans for deploying up to 250,000 troops; picks up 6th graf: ``Wiliams added,'' Minor editing
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of American combat troops took up defensive positions Thursday in the heart of Saudi Arabia's vital oil-producing province as U.S. military strategists prepared to fight a ``high intensity war'' on a vast scale. The Bush administration kept its official silence on details of the U.S. troop deployment, code-named ``Desert Shield.'' President Bush ordered the operation Monday, saying he hoped to deter Iraqi President Saddam Hussein from sending his million-man army into the kingdom, the world's largest oil exporter. At least 2,300 American ground troops landed in Saudi Arabia on the first day of the deployments Wednesday, and Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, said ``there's much more to come'' over the next several days and possibly weeks. ``This is an operation that is going to continue for several days _ one might say many days,'' Williams told reporters. As the buildup of Iraqi forces in occupied Kuwait swelled, Pentagon and administration sources revealed that military leaders have prepared long-range plans that could put 200,000 to 250,000 U.S. troops on Saudi soil. ``We have contingency plans that could result in the insertion of up to 200,000 to 250,000 ground forces before it's all done,'' said a Pentagon source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The United States is prepared to put many divisions on the ground.'' The sources said the plan would be evaluated at each step and such a large force might never be necessary. ``Hussein's response will determine exactly how much combat power we put on the ground,'' the source said. ``The idea of deterrence is to place your forces so that they never have to be used.'' ``If deterrence fails and we fight, it will be a high-intensity war with many casualties, many chemical casualties, much equipment destroyed,'' the oficial said. ``It will mean warfare on a scale that we haven't seen since World War II.'' A force of 250,000 ground troops would account for a significant fraction of the fighting power of the 940,000 active-duty troops in the Army and the Amrine Corps. It would also require thousands more in warships and airplanes in the theater of operations and in the supply train stretching back to the United States. Williams said U.S. intelligence reports from the Middle East indicated that Saddam was sending additional troops into Kuwait, the tiny but oil-rich country his forces seized a week ago, prompting international sanctions and the U.S. military response. Williams added, however, that there were no signs of offensive operations by the Iraqis, who numbered about 120,000 in Kuwait. In a late-afternoon update, the Pentagon said if all Iraqi combat units that were moving south in Iraq went as far as Kuwait, they would increase the number of troops there to about 170,000. The statement said there ``seems to be some gathering'' of Iraqi troops on the Turkish border but ``no significant gathering is noted on the Jordanian border.'' The Iraqi troops in Kuwait ``seem to be in a defensive posture,'' he said. ``They're holding on to what they've acquired.'' Williams also said he could not confirm reports that Iraq had readied chemical weapons in the border area. The U.S. forces, though greatly outnumbered by a battle-hardened Iraqi army, have sophisticated air and naval weapons designed to shatter advancing armored columns that would have to cross desert wastelands to reach Saudi oil fields. Diplomatic sources in the Middle East said elements of the U.S. 82nd Airborne Division, after arriving Wednesday at the Saudi air base at Dhahran along the Persian Gulf coastline, headed for a remote military installation near the Iraqi border. Williams said American troops were spending Thursday unloading their equipment, preparing their defensive positions and planning unspecified joint maneuvers with Saudi soldiers. In addition to a nine-ship U.S. navy armada plying the Persian Gulf, two American aircraft carrier battle groups were stationed nearby; the USS Independence, with six accompanying combatant and supply ships, was patrolling the Arabian Sea at the mouth of the gulf, and the USS Eisenhower, with three combatant and two supply ships, was in the Red Sea near the end of a Saudi pipeline that carries Iraqi crude. Not counting supply ships, at least 21 surface warships were in the area or headed toward it. Williams said the three warships accompanying the Eisenhower included one that was added on Thursday. He also said the USS Saratoga aircraft carrier battle group, including nine vessels, was headed for the Mediterranean Sea. The Pentagon spokesman said five U.S. Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft were in place in Saudi Arabia, as well as an unspecified number of F-15 fighter jets from Langley Air Force Base, Va. The F-15 contingent was believed to include two squadrons, or about 46 aircraft. The Middle East diplomatic sources, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said at least portions of the American ground force were settling in at the remote military installation at Hafr al-Baten just south of the Iraqi border. The base is in the al-Hajarah region, a stony plain traversed by the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line, which extends 1,068 miles from the gulf coast to southern Lebanon. The main landing for American aircraft is the Dhahran airfield near the vital oil terminal at Ras Tanura. The main Saudi oil producing area is part of an irregular plain ending in a ragged coastline of tidal flats, sand spits and offshore sandbars. Extending over this plain and along the gulf coast are most of the major oil facilities that process and export oil that is vital to the global economy. Saudi Arabia is the world's third-largest oil producer behind the Soviet Union and the United States. Because of its small domestic oil needs, its export volume of about 5 million barrels a day is the largest in the world. Saudi Arabia provides about 15 percent of American oil imports, making it the largest single foreign supplier.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Close Borders to All Foreigners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18 grafs for 3-14 pvs, `Despite earlier...' to ADD Jordanian report of Americans transferred from Kuwait trying to get out of Iraq; pickup graf 15 pvs `Jordanian officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has virtually sealed its borders, preventing thousands of foreigners from leaving that country and Kuwait, Western European diplomats said Thursday. Some U.S., British and other Western nationals trying to leave Iraq by road were stopped near the Iraqi desert border post of Rutbah, said Arab travelers who reached Jordan. A Jordanian news report said a group of Americans who had been transferred from Kuwait to Iraq were trying Thursday to cross into Jordan. However, there was no independent confirmation of that report. Despite earlier assurances that foreign tourists could leave, reports reaching Rome indicated they were being turned back, said an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman. ``At the moment, the situation isn't very encouraging,'' said the Italian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. British Foreign Office officials in Amman said only foreign diplomats will now be allowed passage across Iraqi borders. In London, a British Foreign Office spokesman said he believes the borders of Kuwait, which was annexed Wednesday by Iraq, are also being closed by the Iraqi order. ``These were Iraqi frontiers, which I assume in Iraqi terms now includes the frontiers of Kuwait,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraqi officials on Thursday notified Italian diplomats of the border closing, Western European diplomats said. Italy holds the current presidency of the European Community. Italy had asked that Iraq observe the Geneva convention providing for the protection of civilians in occupied territory, in this case Kuwait. The request, filed on behalf of Western countries including the United States, also asked Baghdad to assure that any foreigner who wanted to leave could do so. The Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq has trapped thousands of Westerners in both countries. There are about 2,600 citizens of EC countries in Iraq. About 3,700 are in Kuwait, including about 3,000 British, according to the Italian embassy in Baghdad. There are about 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 580 in Iraq. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Thursday that Iraqi officials have refused exit visas to Americans and other foreigners in the two countries. U.S. officials have focused their concern on 38 Americans at the Hotel Rashid in Baghdad. Almost all were bused from Kuwait by Iraqi authorities last week and are confined to the hotel under armed guard. But the State Department is refusing to call them hostages. Jordan's official Petra news agency said earlier Thursday that a small group of U.S. citizens who had been transferred to Baghdad from Kuwait last week were waiting at Rutbah for transport to Jordan. The Petra correspondent allowed to reach Rutbah quoted Michael Sabah, a stranded American, as saying he was rounded up with other U.S. citizens in Kuwait after the occupation and taken to Baghdad. ``We stayed at one of the Baghdad hotels, and we were free to leave any time.
