I am here with other Americans to find a U.S. Embassy official to arrange our transportation to Jordan.'' His home town was not given. There was no report of their situation late Thursday. A State Department spokesman in Washington said he knew of no other group of Americans transferred from Kuwait besides the 38 at the Baghdad hotel. However, he said it was possible another group exists. The Italian official said Iraq initially agreed that foreign tourists and those in transit at the time of the invasion could leave. He said an initial wave of people, including many Japanese, had been allowed to depart. Jordanian officials said thousands of foreigners, mainly Arabs, had fled Kuwait in recent days. They entered Saudi Arabia and then crossed the border into Jordan 60 miles southeast of Amman. The Italian official said, however, that foreign residents and businessmen were considered to be in another category from tourists, requiring special exit permits. He said those permits were not being granted. Arab evacuees arriving in Jordan told The Associated Press Thursday that Westerners trying to leave Iraq were stopped at Traibel, a few miles before the Rutbah border post. Rutbah is 590 miles west of Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. In Turkey, Harry Cole, head of the U.S. Consulate in the southern city of Adana, said he waited at the nearby Habur border post Thursday, but no U.S. nationals arrived there.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Witness in Murder of Colombian Presidential Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen disguised as policemen killed the government's chief witness in the 1989 assassination of presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan, police said Thursday. Jose Orlando Chavez and his brother were shot dead last Sunday in a south Bogota neighborhood, a police spokesman said in a telephone interview. He spoke on condition of anonymity, a standard practice of the national police. Chavez had been questioned about being an accomplice in the death of Galan, the governing Liberal Party's choice for president. Galan's murder on Aug. 18, 1989 led to a crackdown on drug traffickers. Chavez told police he was hired to hold up a large poster at a Galan political rally. Assassins hid behind the placard until they opened fire. Chavez was arrested but gained his freedom by cooperating with authorities in the investigation. His testimony led police to the killers, the Bogota daily El Tiempo said. The daily said information provided by Chavez led authorities to conclude that the assassination was ordered by Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a major drug trafficker who died in a shootut with police last December. According to El Tiempo, Chavez agreed to help in the assassination after the cocaine cartel promised him a house and a car. The newspaper said Sunday's attack was the second attempt on Chavez's life. It said he survived eight bullet wounds from an unknown gunman shortly after being released from jail earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Bound Military Equipment Detained
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Customs agents have impounded aircraft, missile and gun parts and computers, satellite equipment and other hardware bound for Iraq or Kuwait in the New York area and Baltimore, officials said Thursday. Customs officials began impounding the goods on Sunday, the same day FBI agents sealed Iraqi Airline offices in Manhattan, Detroit and Los Angeles, FBI spokesman Joseph Valiquette said. Nearly $1 million worth of goods was held at Kennedy International Airport this week, said Customs inspector Ed Hotchkiss. It included 960 barrels of jet fuel, 23 crates of military aircraft parts, three crates of radar equipment, 26 air conditioning units and 21 boxes of personal computers. A small shipment of radios to Kuwait also was impounded. At Port Elizabeth, N.J., in the New York area, Customs agents seized $2 million in U.S.-made satellite equipment bound for Iraq, said Customs spokeswoman Joan Baran. At the Port of Baltimore, two shipments of military equipment bound for Kuwait in 190 containers was impounded, said Customs spokesman Pat O'Malley. The shipments consisted of spare parts for F-18 warplanes, Hawk and Sidewinder missiles, and guns, O'Malley said. Another shipment of 36 containers was expected and would be held, he said. ``All the documentation was in proper order. However, the licenses have been suspended and there can be no export at this time,'' O'Malley said. The value of the shipments was not immediately available, he said. Anyone deliberately trying to circumvent the embargo declared by President Bush following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 would face criminal prosecution, Hotchkiss said. Most of the shipments were ``already in the pipeline'' before Bush's proclamation, he said. No charges were expected against any of the shippers. The goods will be held until the federal government determines ownership, Hotchkiss said. Goods already paid for by the Iraqis will probably be confiscated, while those still owned by U.S. companies may be returned, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Troops Reportedly Kill Four Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Burmese troops reportedly shot and killed at least two monks and two students demonstrating Wednesday in Mandalay, central Burma, on the anniversary of the 1988 pro-democracy uprising, Western diplomats said. They said the deaths could not be confirmed, but one said as many as seven demonstrators may have been killed. One monk and one student were reportedly wounded. Several people were arrested, a diplomat said. The shootings occurred as thousands of monks, forming a line three miles long, went on their morning rounds to gather food, the Rangoon-based diplomats said. The diplomats were interviewed by telephone from Bangkok and spoke on the condition of anonymity. They quoted sources in Mandalay. One envoy said the demonstration appeared organized and was ``presumably intended to be provocative.'' The 1988 insurrection closed schools and universities throughout Burma. It ended six weeks later when the army shot thousands of demonstrators. The morning alms ceremony is a Buddhist tradition, but one diplomat said the monks usually gather in groups of 20 or 30. Students, including members of the National League for Democracy, the major opposition party, joined the procession and shouted slogans, diplomats said. One envoy gave this account: The shootings occured about 7:30 a.m., after one student raised the red flag of a fighting peacock, the league's symbol. When security forces tried to restrain the student, a captain was hit on the head with a rock. Troops then began firing. The league swept national elections on May 27, but the military government refused to transfer power. Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi is under house arrest and other prominent foes of the government are in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Sailors Win $32 Million Court Judgment
DOC.TEXT: In a ruling described as the largest such award in maritime history, a Japanese shipping company was ordered to pay 21 underpaid Filipino sailors $32 million in back wages and punitive damages. U.S. District Judge Jack Tanner said the Delica Shipping Co., which admitted underpaying the MV Pine Forest's sailors on voyages between Japan and the United States, had acted in a ``flagrant, malicious, indifferent and unconscionable'' manner. In his ruling Monday, Tanner awarded the sailors $150,000 in back pay, $15 million in compensatory and penalty wages and $17 million in punitive damages. It was by far the largest wage award in maritime history, said Jim Lafferty, director of the New York-based Center for Seafarers' Rights. The previous highest award was $2.6 million, he said. The Vanuatu-registered Pine Forest carries Douglas fir logs from Weyerhaeuser Co. docks in Tacoma and Longview to ports in Japan. The seamen were recruited last year with employment contracts that left blank a space indicating their wages, and later signed shipping articles promising them higher wages under a collective agreement with the Worldwide International Transport Workers Federation, Tanner said. The sailors never got the higher pay. U.S. law gives federal courts jurisdiction over wage cases involving foreign vessels and crews whose voyages end in U.S. waters.

Secretary of State James A. Baker III assured Turkey today that it would receive full support from NATO if it becomes a target of Iraqi intimidation for taking a ``forthright stand'' against its aggressive neighbor. Baker also indicated that he may ask President Turgut Ozal to permit the United States to use Turkish military bases as staging areas in the event of military strikes gainst Iraq. ``It goes without saying that Turkey is strategically very important,'' Baker said on his flight from Washington. He also disclosed that in the growing U.S. pressure campaign against Iraq, the Bush administration was turning to Syria as a potential partner in joint action against President Saddam Hussein.

A State Department task force has taken more than 11,000 calls from people wanting information about Americans stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, but word from the Middle East is reaching loved ones only in dribs and drabs. Poor telephone connections and confusion in Baghdad have made contact difficult if not impossible since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Some Americans said they heard about relatives through employers or the State Department. Thirty-eight Americans remain in a Baghdad hotel from which they are not allowed to leave, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday. The hotel is under guard, but the Americans are safe, he said. He estimated there are 400 Americans in Iraq and 3,000 in Kuwait. The task force is tracking 1,468 people in Kuwait and Iraq it has identified or been in contact with, Boucher said.

Few areas of the planet are more forbidding for the American warrior than Saudi Arabia, home of the world's largest sand desert, where the summer heat often tops 120 degrees and can sap even the native tribesmen. Drinkable water is scarce. Sand and dust can debilitate not only armies on the march but also aircraft, supply vehicles and gun sightings on tanks and rifles. Add to that the threat of being attacked with poison gases you can neither see nor smell, and you have a picture of the peculiarities of mobilizing on the Arabian Peninsula to defend the world's largest oil reserves from the Iraqi army. President Bush told the nation Wednesday that American forces were landing in Saudi Arabia to protect the desert kingdom from a menacing million-man Iraqi army. The president said U.S. troops would not initiate a conflict but would respond if attacked.

Did you hear the one about the stand-up comic who got booked on a commuter flight? Had to sit down. Too much turbulence. Passengers are getting comedy with their cabin service on Continental Express flights from Detroit to Cleveland this week. ``If you don't like my act, where are you going to go?'' comic Don Tersigni told his audience Wednesday aboard the 30-passenger Flight 4454. Tersigni, who did Elvis Presley and Sylvester Stallone impressions after lemonade and peanuts were passed out, said afterward that it wasn't like entertaining the average nightclub crowd. Continental Express scheduled business briefings on morning flights and comedy in the evening this week to pump up publicity for its new Cleveland-Detroit route. The 50-minute flights are too short for movies.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans to Punish Drug Users, Not Just Sellers
DOC.TEXT: Not long after a drug pusher was shot outside the nearby grammar school, the woman who runs the newsstand in Dos de Mayo square caught her young son playing with a bloody syringe. ``Thank God the needle was capped, otherwise he would have jabbed himself,'' she said, her eyes on the drug dealers sitting at their regular cafe tables. ``I've seen everything here, but that really scared me.'' Consumption of illegal drugs in Spain has grown to the point that the government is drafting laws to punish users for the first time since democracy returned in 1977. Laws passed three years ago provide tough penalties for traffickers and money launderers. In 1983, soon after gaining power, the Socialist government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez lifted restrictions on the possession of vaguely defined ``small amounts'' of drugs for personal use. By deciding to change the rules, the government is tacitly admitting Spain's drug problem is out of control. It also is a response to pressure from other members of the European Community partners to strengthen drug laws before the 12-nation trading bloc abolishes internal borders in 1993. ``We are heading for a new situation in Europe and we need to bring our laws more in line with those of other EC countries,'' said Santiago de Torres, deputy director of the government anti-narcotics program. Spain is one of the main European entry points for Colombian cocaine, Moroccan hashish and heroin from Turkey. Drugs confiscated by Spanish police in 1989 made up 40 percent of the total in 16 major European countries. So far this year, Spanish police have seized more than 3,800 pounds of cocaine, 480 pounds of heroin and 10 tons of hashish. They describe it as a small portion of the total entering the country. The drug bill, which Parliament is expected to pass in September, imposes fines for consuming narcotics in public, discarding syringes or allowing drug use in public places like bars and discos. Unlike Italy, which passed a new law earlier this year, Spain does not plan to imprison drug users. ``We won't throw addicts in jail and scare them away from treatment centers,'' de Torres said. He predicted Italy also would not send drug users to jail, whatever its new law says, ``because there's no room in the jails and they don't believe it's the definitive solution.'' Some Spaniards want to give police more leeway to clean up drug-infested neighborhoods. They say dealers caught with small quantities of drugs now avoid conviction by claiming it is for their personal use. Half the 20,000 people at a recent protest in Barbate, southern Spain, threatened small-time heroin dealers and painted ``Drugs Sold Here'' on pushers' homes. People who live in towns near Gibraltar, a British colony, demand that heroin dealers and addicts be expelled from the country. They say Gibraltar is the base for drug smugglers who supply Spain's southern Mediterranean coast. Agustin Sahagun, the conservative mayor of Madrid, called for tougher public consumption laws after the owners of Archy, a fashionable disco, claimed police had no grounds to close it for alleged use of cocaine on the premises. Sahagun and other centrist and conservative politicians have criticized the initial permissiveness of the Socialists. Gonzalez and many other Socialist Party leaders came of age in the 1960s, when drug use was considered a protest against the authoritarian rule of Gen. Francisco Franco. Enrique Tierno Galvan, the venerable Socialist mayor of Madrid after Franco's death in 1975, once told a youthful audience to ``turn on and tune in.'' Franco's tight control was enough to dissuade most Spaniards from taking such advice. Now, few dealers in Dos de Mayo bother to leave their tables when a patrol car pulls up at a cafe. ``Somebody would have to be pretty spaced out to do a deal here now, but they can always go to some apartment,'' a woman officer said. ``We can't go in there without a judicial order.''

DOC.HEAD: Crime Novelists Meet for ``Black Week'' by the Sea
DOC.TEXT: David Serafin, a dignified Oxford professor, writes about a dentist who rides the subway with female mannequins dribbling fake blood from their mouths. R.D. Zimmerman, a blond and boyish American, imagines a Russian ax murderer who chops up his girlfriend's ex-lover just so he can take over his victim's luxurious Leningrad apartment. And Susan Moody, a short, white English woman, creates a tall, black female detective who sends aid to Third World countries from the profits of her boyfriend's jewel heists. The unexpected, the macabre and the bizarre abounded at a convention last month of crime writers dubbed ``Black Week'' in this northern Spanish port. Sponsored by the city of Gijon and several businesses, the gathering brought together more than 60 writers from 20 countries. They included ex-cops, journalists and former housewives, some of whom had witnessed or lived through events stranger than the most bizarre mystery story. One claimed to own a bullet-proof raincoat, another said he had been taken for a harrowing ride by members of an Argentine death squad and still another once saw a man throw a baby to its death from the window of a New York apartment. The third annual convention united writers from the East and West, including Americans who talked like Karl Marx and Russians who sounded like Donald Trump. They gave talks, held meetings and exchanged endless war stories over drinks in the sidewalk cafes that ring Gijon harbor. Jan Eik, a writer from East Germany, talked about German unification and what it would mean for his future: more freedom but less money. Under communism, Eik said, East German bookshops offered a small selection of crime novels and his works sold out rapidly. ``People bought everything in three or four days. Now, they can buy any book they want,'' he said. Eik does not expect East Germans to buy a lot of crime novels in the next few years because they will be busy purchasing Western products that were out of reach under communism. ``People want new cars, video recorders and electronic equipment,'' he said. ``These things are much cheaper now.'' Twenty-nine-year-old Soviet author and editor Artem Borovik does not write crime stories, but publishes them in a magazine called Top Secret, which is dedicated to stretching the limits of glasnost. ``We call it `Top Secret' because it sells better,'' said Borovik, who lived in the United States for six years and speaks fluent English. ``Remember, this is the free market we're moving towards.'' Borovik, whose faith in capitalism appears unbounded, said Soviet crime writers now have a new enemy to write about instead of the American Central Intelligence Agency: ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the bureaucrats who do not want to turn power over to the press and parliament.'' Borovik may believe the CIA is no longer the enemy, but Cuban writer Luis Adrian Betancourt is not convinced. His novel, ``Hurricane,'' tells of a Cuban who collaborates with a trio of CIA agents who try to sneak on to the Caribbean island and sow instability. In the end, the CIA loses and the forces of communism triumph. Betancourt said he and a recognized Cuban poet once headed a joint book-signing session in Havana. When Betancourt's books ran out, the crowd left. ``I turned to the poet and said, `We Cubans aren't very cultured. We buy spy novels and throw the real literature in the trash.'' Zimmerman, a 37-year-old who lives in Minneapolis, was shadowed by agents of the KGB while traveling in the Soviet Union in 1978. He was working as a guide for a U.S.-sponsored agricultural exhibit. He has incorporated his experiences in the Soviet Union into several of his novels, which include ``Blood Russian,'' ``The Red Encounter'' and ``The Cross and the Sickle.'' Jesse Slattery, a crime writer who has worked as a New York Post reporter for 17 years, talked about his bulletproof raincoat, the time he got stabbed while reporting in Harlem and his dealings with a woman who is considered one of the world's 10 best mercenaries. Author of ``The Julie Effect,'' he also reminisced about the time he dove into a tank of sharks at the New York Aquarium just so he could write a story about it. The protagonist of Susan Moody's novels is Penny Wanawake, a tall, independent woman who always dresses in white and braids her hair in beaded corn rows. When Penny gets angry, she shakes her head and clacks the beads together. Moody, whose latest addition to the world of crime fiction is called ``Playing With Fire,'' said she prefers not to emphasize gore in her books. Far more important than the crime itself, she said, is the unraveling of the mystery, the moving from clue to clue. ``I'm not afraid of blood,'' she said. ``But I certainly don't go into grisly descriptions of hideous decapitations.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Wed Aug. 15

DOC.HEAD: For Releaase Tues PMs, Aug 14 and Thereafter
Riding High on Seven Octaves
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If Mariah Carey had never been born, some record company executive would have surely invented her. She has a seven-octave voice and looks and ambition well beyond the whisper range. She also can write and arrange songs. The only question is why she had to wait until age 20 to hit it big. ``For ... a year I couldn't pay someone to listen to my tape,'' explained Carey, whose debut single, the 1950s-styled ballad ``Vision of Love,'' quickly topped the charts. ``They think if you don't have a high-powered manager or don't have a record company that's already interested in you, you're no good. I had no connections and I was running with my writing partner (Ben Margulies), who was also new and didn't have any connections, either,'' she said. After working in bars and restaurants around New York, Carey was signed by Columbia Records. She had been singing backup for Brenda Kay Starr, a Columbia artist, and managed to get herself into a party attended by company President Tommy Mottola. ``Someone grabbed him and told him to listen to the tape,'' Carey recalled. ``He got out in his car, played it, and turned around and came back to find me. Everything worked out.'' Dog owners beware, Carey's range is so powerful that the two highest octaves are unintelligible to human ears. This is a voice that can probably shatter glass and then put it back together, that sounds as if she's taking the words and twirling them over her head like a cowboy with a lasso. ``I was using my upper register on `All in Your Mind,''' she said of one song from her self-titled album. ``What happened was at the end of it, I did these vocal flips. When I was doing it, my voice split and went into a harmony. If you hear it, it splits. I was saying, `Get rid of that,' but everyone said, `No way, we're keeping that.''' ``Mariah Carey'' includes 11 songs, most of them co-written by Carey and Margulies. But if her life seems like a Cinderella story, you'll have to listen hard for any Prince Charming here. ``I Don't Wanna Cry,'' ``All in Your Mind,'' ``Alone in Love'' and ``You Need Me'' are all about breaking up. ``So when the morning comes, you know I'll be gone,'' she sings in ``Prisoner.'' In ``Vanishing'' and ``Love Takes Time,'' it's already over. ``A lot of those songs were written when I was kind of struggling, before I had a record deal,'' she said. ``It was a harrowing emotional time in my life. I was doing odd jobs and going towards this goal. They weren't necessarily all about relationships, but they were about things happening in my life.'' Narada Michael Walden, whose credits include Aretha Franklin and Whitney Houston, produces along with Rhett Lawrence and Ric Wake. Carey, who'd just assume look after herself, decided to accept the outside help _ for now. ``They did put me with different producers that they wanted to have me work with and this being the first album, I took a certain amount of direction from the record company,'' she said. ``You know, they are taking a chance. Ideally, though, I'd like to be involved with everything.'' Carey, born and raised in New York, is the daughter of Patricia Carey, a former singer with the New York City Opera and a vocal coach. Her parents divorced when she was young. Childhood was a waiting game for Mariah, a gospel fan who knew she wanted to sing for a living at a time her classmates were dreaming of being doctors or astronauts. ``I'd hang out with my friends and go to parties, and just be stupid and goof off, but when I was at home, I was listening to music and writing songs,'' she said. ``I would go and work with Ben or whoever I was working with. I wasn't like an outcast being a musician. I was like everyone else, but really I wasn't.'' You can find aspiring singers or actors in just about any New York restaurant, but Carey pushed for it just a little bit harder. While her fellow employees were out partying after work Carey was writing songs. Maybe she didn't make a lot of close friends that way, she admits, but there was business to take care of, sweet destiny to achieve. How long can you sit tight when seven octaves are just bursting to get outside? ``I was doing all that because I wanted to get a record deal and make an album,'' she said. ``I can hang out and do things that aren't productive or I can make an album. ``Now, I like to take time out to go to a beach whenever I can, spend time with my friends and family. I just wanted it all to happen before it was too late.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Tues Aug. 14

DOC.HEAD: Photographer's Passion Plays Out in Jazz Pictures
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Herman Leonard's admiration for jazz and his fascination with the people who play it led him to spend many late nights photographing the musicians in dark and smoky clubs. ``I love to photograph interesting people, musicians, artists, writers,'' Leonard said. ``I get to know them and photograph them as I see them. This is my passion.'' The results of that passion are the 45 photos capturing jazz greats such as Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie, Billie Holiday and Charlie Parker now touring the country in Leonard's ``Images of Jazz'' exhibit. The exhibit will be in Chicago at the Catherine Edelman Gallery until Aug. 18, on the fourth stop of a 10-gallery U.S. tour. The photos also will be shown in seven cities in Europe. Leonard's photos capture the 1940s and '50s jazz scene. His back-lighting technique plays light off the skin of many of the musicians, highlighting the sweat on their foreheads, an occasional smile of joy and frequent frowns of concentration. ``I wanted to get images that for me personally were representative of the atmosphere,'' Leonard said in an interview. Leonard took the pictures in clubs around the world from New York to Paris to Los Angeles. But it wasn't until the 1980s, when he was living in Paris and a French publisher approached him about putting together a book of his jazz photos, that he pulled them out after almost 20 years of neglect. ``I'd put them in a cardboard box and stuck them under the bed,'' said Leonard, whose photos were compiled into the 1985 book, ``The Eye of Jazz.'' The 67-year-old photographer said age plays a big part in the reaction people have to his photo exhibit. ``For the gray-haired guys, it kind of revives a memory,'' Leonard said. ``It's different for the teen-agers. They've heard and loved the music, and it gives them a chance to feel what it was like to be there.'' The exhibit has attracted everyone from jazz buffs to parents who try to explain who the musicians are to their small children, said Catherine Edelman, owner of the Chicago gallery. She added that Leonard's photos have such a mass appeal they are bringing a new audience into her gallery. ``Jazz crosses barriers. It's a concept they respect,'' Edelman said. ``But nothing really prepared me for the amount of love coming out of people,'' she said. ``It's not just dealing with fine art. People go up to each other and ask, `Hey, have you ever seen Dizzy play?''' Edelman said she also sees Leonard's photos as a kind of visual history. ``I think they capture a special time, a period we'll never be able to return to,'' Edelman said. ``It's nostalgia. A record of time gone by. ``It's very classic. The smoke, the atmosphere _ you can almost taste these things. All of a sudden you want to put on some jazz.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Mon Aug. 13

DOC.TEXT: Responding to the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, Roman Catholic bishops are sending fact-finding, good-will delegations to that area, renewing ties and checking on ways to help. Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati said three delegations will fan out to various parts of Eastern and Central Europe to ascertain needs and coordinate aid efforts. ``These delegations represent the first major step in what the bishops envision as a substantial program of aid by American Catholics to the long-suffering church in those countries. ``Equally important, the delegations will be a key part of a process of renewing and deepening bonds of solidarity ... bonds that had been broken or severely weakened in the past decades due to government interference.'' One delegation, led by Archbishop Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles, visited Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria in early August. A second, led by Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, N.J., will visit Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia Aug. 18-30. A third, led by Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago and Archbishop John L. May of St. Louis, will visit the Soviet Union Aug. 27 to Sept. 6.

Jews for Jesus, which has conducted monthlong street campaigns in New York each summer for the past 15 years, says its campaign this time got bigger results than ever before. ``The spiritual receptivity quotient has shot way up,'' said Tuvya Zaretsky, campaign leader. He said there were l,2l2 converts and 2,798 others interested, compared to 568 converts last summer and fewer before. He added: ``It's been like knocking your head against the wall and, surprise, the wall begins to crumble.''

A gathering of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America clergywomen marked the 20th anniversary of Lutheranism's 1970 admission of women to ordination. The denomination now has 1,198 women among its 17,253 clergy.

Southern Baptist moderates have called a national meeting Aug 23-25 to consider what to do in the face of a fundamentalist wing gaining full-scale control of the huge denomination. The gathering in Atlanta was called to explore ways to uphold principles that differ with the new fundamentalist directions and to consider alternate means for channelling giving to missions. ``I think we are ripe for God to use us in creating something new and visionary and historic,'' said the Rev. Daniel Vestal of Dunwoody, Ga., the moderates' defeated candidate in June for the denomination's presidency. That victory by fundamentalists for the 12th year in a row completed their gradual control over agencies of the 14.9 million-member denomination. A Houston-based moderate organization, Baptists Committed, and Dunwoody called the Atlanta meeting as a growing number of congregations across the country planned limits on giving to the denomination's cooperative budget. Moderate discontent was intensified by the recent firing of the top editors of the denomination's news agency, Baptist Press. Indicating moderates have given up regaining influence over the denomination, Vestal said they don't plan to enter a presidential candidate in 1991.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Fri PMs Aug. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Officially Churches Don't Condone It, But It Happens
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Once it became a public matter, United Methodist bishops intervened and stopped it. But church blessing of same-sex unions still goes on, some ministers say, but quietly. That is the nebulous aftermath in that denomination, with similar inklings in others, after bishops in Washington, D.C., and Wisconsin blocked plans for sanctioning such unions. ``By and large, it's done very quietly rather than publicly for obvious reasons,'' said the Rev. George McLain of New York, executive secretary of the Methodist Federation for Social Action. Despite such general statements, specific cases are hard to pin down in mainline denominations, but it happens, and a woman pastor in San Francisco says she implements it, in her own way. The Rev. Kim A. Smith, pastor of Bethany United Methodist Church, said she has led several ``celebrations of commitment'' between couples of the same sex, and has talked with many pastors who provided similar services. ``They have to be private about it,'' she said in a telephone interview, declining, like others, to identify them. ``They have to do it in secret. It can be dangerous for the pastor.'' However, she said the particular terminology used was part of the difficulty, with church authorities against phrases seen as equating such ceremonies with ``holy matrimony'' or marriage. ``There are a lot of semantics around the issue,'' she said. ``It's very technical, a very fine line. That's what is being tested. It's a wide-open question.'' Ms. Smith chairs the national board of a ``Reconciling Congregations Program,'' in which 46 United Methodist congregations so far have committed themselves to provide full ministerial services to homosexuals. She said she requires the same standards for homosexual as heterosexual couples seeking church affirmation of their partnership _ whatever it's called _insisting that they go through preliminary counseling. Some homosexuals exchange rings, while others don't, she said. ``They commit themselves to long-term relationships. They're active Christians, work, go to camp, pay their water bill. All they want is what straight people have.'' She noted four couples in her congregation have been together for more than 30 years, two of them homosexual couples. However, she said the ``dominant culture doesn't acknowledge this long-term commitment'' between homosexuals. The issue came to a head last May when Dumbarton United Methodist Church in Washington approved a new congregational policy, affirming same-sex unions and announcing two lesbians would exchange vows in a ``holy union'' ceremony. However, Washington Bishop Joseph H. Yeakel strongly objected, and the planned ceremony was canceled. About the same time, Bishop David J. Lawson of Sun Prairie, Wis., blocked a policy adopted by University Methodist Church at Madison, Wis., for celebrating ``holy union'' of same-sex couples. ``What was happening now was outside the pale of the church,'' he said in a telephone interview. Some services there previously had joined same-sex couples under a 1986 congregational policy recognizing same-sex relationships, but disavowed that the joining of the couples was ``a substitute for marriage,'' Lawson said. He said 1988 changes in the church's Book of Discipline made it definite that the congregation had overstepped church law in a planned liturgy for same-sex ``holy union,'' which was ruled out. Like most major denominations, United Methodism bars self-avowed, practicing homosexuals from the ministry, and specifies that marriage occurs only between men and women. However, the church terms homosexuals ``individuals of sacred worth'' who need the church's ministry, part of which includes validating marriages. But that service was blocked for homosexual couples in the two cases. In Boston last February, the Episcopal parish of St. John the Evangelist blessed ``the covenanting of relationship'' between a lesbian couple, despite the opposition of Bishop David E. Johnson. Remonstrating parish priests for that service, Johnson said it ``was not an act of the Episcopal Church,'' which does not sanction such relationships. Homosexual ties are openly condoned in some smaller denominations, notably the Unitarian Universalist Association and the mainly homosexual Metropolitan Community Church. It coined the term, ``holy union,'' for such services, considering it equivalent to marriage. Similar services with various wordings go on sporadically behind the scenes in congregations of most major denominations, Ms. Smith said, attributing that conclusion to conversations with other ministers. However, as to the number of such congregations, she said she couldn't guess. ``It may be a dozen, it may be a hundred,'' she said. Asked if any United Methodists congregations were doing it, now that the Washington and Wisconsin churches had been stopped from it, Robert Lear, the church's Washington information director, said: ``You can always find (among the denomination's 38,000 congregations) a Methodist preacher that has done everything irregular there is to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Nations Want Growth From Economic Triangle
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name cq for Suharto.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of all three countries have approved the integration of Singapore with parts of Indonesia and Malaysia in a compact economic ``growth triangle'' designed to attract foreign capital. The idea is to present Singapore, the southern tip of peninsular Malaysia and several nearby Indonesian islands as a single investment center, not separate areas competing for capital. No formal treaty or European-style common market is planned, officials said, but cooperation would mean uniform standards of economic management and safeguards for investors in individual projects. Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore proposed the idea in December. His affluent city-state would seem, at first glance, to gain more than its poorer neighbors from such an arrangement. Singapore has only 2.7 million people and no hinterland. Its growth is limited by insufficient labor, water and room to expand. Goh suggested the triangle could boom in the 1990s by combining the land, labor, water and gas of Malaysia's Johor State and Indonesia's Batam Island with the managerial talent available in Singapore. As an added attraction, the area could be promoted as a sort of ``Caribbean tourist playground,'' Goh said, with beach resorts on Johor and Batam and Singapore for shopping. President Suharto of Indonesia and Malaysia's prime minister, Mohamad Mahathir, endorsed the idea in June when Suharto visited Kuala Lumpur. ``We agreed that we should work together,'' Mahathir told reporters. ``It will be beneficial for all three of us. We can benefit from the prosperity and spending power of Singapore and the spillover effect of its tourism industry.' Singapore had 4.8 million tourists last year. Government and private planning groups were set up last year between Johor and Singapore, and earlier this year between Indonesia and Singapore, to expand cooperation and streamline customs procedures. As operating costs in Singapore soared in recent years, many manufacturing firms shifted labor-intensive operations to Johor, which is linked to Singapore by a causeway that carries a highway, railroad and water pipeline. Another bridge is planned. Electronic components and other goods shipped into Johor and later exported are not taxed. With costs increasing in Johor, Singapore manufacturers have set their sights on Batam Island, a duty-free zone only 12 miles to the southeast by ferry. Industrialists estimate the labor cost in Johor is about half that of Singapore, and in Batam only half that of Johor. Two state-owned Singapore companies announced in January they would put $220 million into a joint venture with an Indonesian firm to build an industrial park, mainly for computer assembly plants. The promoters said it would employ 40,000 people when completed in five years. Politically, the triangle could help forge closer ties between Singapore, most of whose people are ethnic Chinese, and its big Malay neighbors, which experienced anti-Chinese bloodshed in the 1960s. Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said the joint planning showed Singapore's neighbors realized they had more to gain by plugging into the city-state's success than by trying to go it alone. Goh is scheduled to replace Lee in November. Not everyone is so confident. Muhyiddin Yassin, head of the Johor government, likes the idea in principle but insists his state be a full partner, not ``a mere supplier of primary resources.'' Tosrin Jarvanthi, a Johor state legislator, questioned Singapore's sincerity: ``We have to examine the proposal very closely to make sure that we will not lose out in future.'' B.J. Habibie, an Indonesian government minister who oversees Batam's industrial development, praised the triangle concept but said Singapore probably stood to gain more than Jakarta. Frans Seda, a former Indonesian finance minister, saw great benefits for Singapore, some gain for Batam and uncertainty for the rest of Indonesia. The Straits Times took note of such sentiments in an editorial: ``The underlying fear, no doubt, is that Singapore would have not have come out so enthusiastically and at such high level, in favor of the idea if it did not stand to benefit disproportionately from it. ``The government may thus have no choice but to maintain a watchful eye over the whole project to ensure that Singaporeans venturing to Johor and Riau (Batam) are good envoys as well as good businessmen.''

DOC.HEAD: The Russian Compound: Two Symbolic Jails in The Holy City
DOC.TEXT: Within what is called the Russian Compound, in the heart of Jerusalem, are two jails that symbolize the struggle for this ancient land. One held Jewish guerrillas who fought British rule in the Palestine of the 1940s. It is a museum now, with a plaque dedicated to ``the heroes who fought against foreign rule.'' The other, 300 yards across the compound, remains a jail, mainly for Palestinians fighting Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It has no plaques, just prisoners' tales of beatings, torture and overcrowding. In the 1860s, the Russian Orthodox Church built the two yellow brick buildings as part of a complex of hostels and a green-domed church for pilgrims to the Holy Land. One day in July, dozens of Palestinian families crowded outside the jail, a block-long, one-story building topped by rolls of barbed wire. The Arabs call it Moskobiyeh, or Muscovite. An officer shouted the names of families who would be allowed to visit prisoners _ four families at a time, 15 minutes per visit. Many waited for hours, some in vain. Any who asked questions were pushed aside by officers. Sayra al Hamoni, a gaunt, 50-year-old woman from the Silwan district of Jerusalem, said she had come to see her 17-year-old son Bader, who was picked up two months ago. Mrs. Hamoni, her hair covered by the white scarf of observant Moslem women, said Bader confessed to throwing stones at police after being beaten for 19 days. His nose was broken and he was often unconscious, said Mrs. Hamoni, who has eight other children. ``I brought him new clothes one day and they gave me the old ones; they were all bloody,'' she said, wiping away tears. ``I get sick each time I see him.'' Betselem, an Israeli human rights group, issued a report recently that said interrogators beat prisoners in the jail to extract confessions. It said the report was based on affidavits from Palestinians aged 18 and younger. ``Almost all the minors ... testified that they had been beaten _ generally very severely: slapping, punching, kicking, hair pulling, beating with clubs or with iron rods, pushing into walls and onto floors,'' according to the report. It said some prisoners who were 16 or older told of interrogations by the Shin Bet security service after being locked in one of three special cells. Prisoners have given each of the cells a name: the ``closet,'' three feet wide and the height of a man; the ``grave,'' a box in the ground covered by an iron door, and the ``lockup,'' a cubicle about less than five feet square with a toilet inside. Najib, a 30-year-old Palestinian from Dheishe, a West Bank refugee camp, told an Associated Press reporter he spent three months in the Moskobiyeh, including several days in the ``lockup.'' ``It was very dark; I was forced to sit in the lockup with my hands tied behind my back,'' said Najib, who is tall and thin. He said he refused to confess to charges that he was recruiting for a radical PLO faction. Police spokesman Uzi Sandori denied the existence of the three solitary-confinement cells. The Shin Bet has no spokesman to question about its role in the jail. When asked about reports of beatings, Sandori cited a police response to the Betselem report that was published with it in June. Superintendent Elinoar Mazuz said in it that all complaints of police brutality were being investigated. She said police had not finished investigating six of the eight alleged beatings of minors Betselem cited and that files of the other two cases had been given to the state prosecutor. Sandori would not let the AP reporter see any of the jail's 22 cells. He said only humanitarian groups were allowed to visit. Philip Veerman, a childrens' rights activist who toured the youth wing in March, said it was seriously overcrowded. Eighty-three younsters were held in four cells with 34 beds, Veerman said, and in one of the cells, 39 minors shared 12 beds and one toilet. Two Israelis were held separately in one cell, he said. ``I almost fainted from the terrible smell,'' said Veerman, who represents Defense for Children International. ``The air is stuffy and it is difficult to breathe. In the night, mattresses are spread out, but there is still not enough room.'' In her response to the Betselem report, Ms. Mazuz acknowledged ``extreme overcrowding'' and blamed it on the increased number of prisoners since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. She said the building was being renovated to create more space. Jews call the former jail across the compound Bevingrad, for Ernest Bevin, Britain's anti-Zionist foreign minister of the late 1940s. As a museum, it is named ``The Shrine to Heroism.'' School children visit it on tours and stare at the pictures of Jews executed by the British before Israel was founded in 1948. Like the Moskobiyeh, the British jail originally was a hostel for Christain pilgrims. Its 10 solitary-confinement cells are still there and the gallows has been preserved, along with a death row cell where two condemned Jewish guerrillas committed suicide. On April 21, 1947, Meir Feinstein and Moshe Barazani embraced and ignited an explosives-filled orange pressed to their hearts. They died two hours before their scheduled hanging. Another famous prisoner was Yisrael Eldad, who was co-leader with Yitzhak Shamir, now the prime minister, of the Stern Gang guerrilla group. Eldad, 80, said in a telephone interview from his home in Jerusalem that he spent six months in Bevingrad in 1944 and was not mistreated. ``Lots of Lehi people were there,'' he said, using the Hebrew name for the Stern Gang. ``I was not even investigated. I was just sitting in the cell with my friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Summer Video: A Chance To Stay Home, For Once
DOC.TEXT: You say it's the long, hot, nasty-grindy part of August and you don't know where to turn for a good movie? You say you've seen ``Die Hard 2,'' ``Total Recall'' is sexist trash, ``Arachnophobia'' isn't scary, you READ ``Presumed Innocent,'' your spouse IS a SEAL and Tom Cruise hasn't done anything decent since ``Taps''? You say your clothes are sticking to you and you can't face the crowds in the Downtown Cinema Hell Octoplex? You say Poogie the Wonder Tot just stunned the cat with a sickening, underhand blow? Cheer up, America! Don't hit the kid! Hit the video store!!! It's not a lack of imagination keeping you away from network television and the movie theaters. Really, it's not. Most of what they're offering you this summer really IS dreadful claptrap! Home video, on the other hand, whether rented or store-bought, is better than ever. You can own a $9.95 pre-owned copy of the Warren Beatty-Dustin Hoffman comedy ``Ishtar,'' or, for about the same price, the equally funny Good Housekeeping video ``Colors and Shapes'' for young viewers like Poogie. Even if you bypassed VHS for an 8mm camcorder, the big video stores are starting to offer new releases and old classics in 8mm, from the Star Trek movies and ``Tucker'' to ``Moscow on the Hudson'' and ``Gigi.'' The 8mm format also offers digital stereo sound, higher resolution than VHS, a smaller cassette and new releases priced to sell at $29.95. Thanks to a glut of product and ``sell-through,'' where a hit movie is released at a bargain price (usually from $14.95 to $24.95), prices for most VHS releases are very reasonable. Most popular movies on VHS are $19.95. For those of us who can't live without our own copies of ``Dr. Strangelove,'' ``Dog Day Afternoon'' or ``The Producers,'' this is good news. If you simply MUST own a copy of ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' it's available at $72.95 in VHS stereo and the superior ``letterbox'' format that maintains the wide-screen viewing aspect. It's a lot cheaper to rent it, though. Two other new VHS releases worth mentioning are ``Blood Alley,'' with John Wayne and Lauren Bacall, and ``A Summer Place'' with Troy Donahue and Sandra Dee; priced to sell at $59.95 and much cheaper to rent. New VHS releases you'll have to nag your rental video dealer for are Pier Paolo Pasolini's ``Accattone,'' at $79.95; Hiroshi Teshigahara's ``Woman in the Dunes'' and Federico Fellini's ``I Vitelloni'' are $59.95. Hold onto your money awhile if it's foreign film you crave. Fellini's ``Satyricon,'' Akira Kurosawa's ``Ran'' and Jacques Tati's ``Mon Oncle'' are selling for $29.95 this summer. Regrettably, the aptly titled ``Stuff Stephanie in the Incinerator'' is holding at $79.95, but ``Slumber Party Massacre (I and II)'' (``You Bring the Pizza, I'll Bring the Drill'') are priced at $19.95. Laser disc releases in the stores this summer are more tempting than ever. If you love movies and haven't bought a disc player, you're missing out on crisp, clear images and crystalline, dynamic ``CD quality'' sound. ``Batman,'' which was too dark and cramped in its hastily dubbed VHS version, sells for $39.95 on a beautifully transferred disc version, in letterboxed format, with a digital stereo soundtrack and Danny Elfman's score. There's also a wide-format ``Star Wars'' out there for $69.95, and ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' in cut-down pan-and-scan LaserDisc is only $29.95. VHS Colorized Classics priced at $19.95 include: ``The Magnificent Ambersons'' (now there's an Orson Welles movie that cries out for colorization even louder than ``Citizen Kane,'' eh?), ``The Maltese Falcon,'' and ``White Heat.'' If you want to see an Arnold Schwarzenegger summer movie, why not rent ``Predator'' or ``The Terminator,'' two excellent, suspenseful action movies that take to the little screen as if they were made for it? If you insist on a Bruce Willis actioner, go rent the original ``Die Hard.'' It sells for $19.95 and is available in wide-format laser disc. If you want a Spike Lee movie, go rent ``Do the Right Thing'' or ``She's Gotta Have It.'' Then rent Poogie the delightful ``Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory,'' in which all sorts of nasty fates await wicked children inside the wonderful chocolate factory. Heh, heh. It's not NICE to slug Mr. Kitty, Poog ...

Elsewhere in television . . . `WE ACCEPT YOU, ONE OF US' _ That haunting refrain will engrave itself into the bad dreams of a whole new generation in September, when MGM-UA home video releases Tod Browning's ``Freaks'' for home video at $19.98. The 1932 horror classic was disowned by MGM because it used real side show folk; it was banned in Great Britain for 30 years. It ranks with George Romero's ``Night of the Living Dead'' for dumb dialogue and scary sequences. It's a fable about the circus, and of how a little man from the side show falls in love with the beautiful trapeze artist who deceives, exploits and abuses him. And it's about payback. It's also, for its 1930s ambience, a remarkably sensitive treatment of the lives and feelings of exceptional people. And the payback will scare the living willies out of you. End Adv PM Fri Aug. 10

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, U.S. Teachers Study Teaching Students to Live in Democracies
DOC.TEXT: Thirty Soviet, American and Polish teachers spent two weeks discussing educational alchemy _ how to turn the leaden classrooms of pre-perestroika Eastern Europe into golden laboratories of democracy. They talked about ways teachers can run their classrooms democratically, and how students could be taught skills and attitudes needed in a democracy. And they basked in the changes brought on by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``Gorbachev himself has said, `We are a people who don't know how to carry on a discussion. We are used to giving orders,''' said Alan Shapiro, director of the Soviet education project of Educators for Social Responsibility which co-sponsored the gathering here. ``What's missing is the culture of democracy. People are not really accustomed to what the democratic process means, how long it takes. Authoritarianism can be much more efficient.'' Schools reflected that authoritarianism. ``Classes have been conducted more like a catechism. The teacher asks the question and the student must give the right answer. You could go through a lot of Soviet classrooms and never hear a student ask a question,'' he said. At one point in the workshop, which ended last weekend, the teachers sat in a circle, trying to name the world's most populous countries. With give and take, they came up with the answers. Such a freewheeling exercise, as common in American classrooms as chalk, was formerly unheard-of in Polish and Soviet classrooms. ``In the 1960s and 1970s I may have had that, but it would have been risky,'' said Valentina Mitina, who taught for 22 years and is now a researcher in comparative education at Moscow's Academy of Pedagogical Sciences. The Flint meeting _ the third sponsored by the academy, Soviet Educators for Peace and Mutual Understanding, and Educators for Social Responsibility based in Cambridge, Mass. _ took place at a time of rapidly increasing contacts between U.S. and Eastern European educators. The Americans want to help U.S. students appreciate the historical significance of changes in Eastern Europe. The Europeans are looking to America for lessons in how to teach democratic concepts and foster an inquiring attitude among students accustomed to accepting lessons unquestioningly. The American Federation of Teachers has been particularly active in fostering such contacts. Through the International Federation of Free Teachers' Unions based in the Netherlands, the union has been working with emerging free teacher unions in Czechoslovakia, Poland, Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary. American universities have also been increasing their East bloc ties. Clemson University announced plans in July to set up an MBA program in Moscow. The University of Michigan announced in June it is establishing a center for social research in Warsaw, Poland. Changes do not come easily. Educators who want to shed dictatorial ways often face opposition from parents and students, said Alexander Bannov, a school principal in the Siberian town of Novosibirsk. They are afraid to have choices and participate in decision-making because they don't want to take responsibility for poor decisions, he said. In the old days, they could blame the leaders. ``People are just not prepared for that. The process of preparing our people to live in a democracy is a very difficult pedagogical problem. ``If we just declare a democracy, nothing happens. It can lead to anarchy. It (democracy) must be in every minute, in every detail. We should not teach about democracy. We should live democracy,'' he said. Gennady Belyaev, a Moscow teacher, is helping students write a peace dictionary in which children develop their own definitions for words such as trust and understanding. The class openly discusses the use of Soviet weapons by the Iraqis on the Kurds, for example, as it shatters the assumption that everything done by the Soviet Union automatically is good. ``We try to call a spade a spade,'' he said. He confessed his main problem is freeing students from the fear of repercussions for expressing their views. ``No one is going to go to the headmaster'' and report them, he said. But Ruth Bowman, executive director of the Cambridge group, said there are unexpected similarities between American and Soviet students, and American teachers also are searching for ways to teach citizenship. ``What I've learned from being with the Soviets is we seem to have very common problems,'' Bowman said. ``This surprised me. They use the word apathy quite a bit. One of the Soviet educators said her students want to be spoonfed. They don't want to work for their learning. We're asking the same kind of questions.'' That made the institute a two-way exchange, rather than a seminar taught by Americans for Soviets, she said. ``One specific thing I have learned is we are not as democratic as we think we are and they are not as undemocratic as we think they are,'' said Arthur Marquardt, an Adrian, Mich., high school teacher.

DOC.HEAD: Money Shortages Choking Reform in Big City Schools
DOC.TEXT: For years, Philadelphia schools have offered students a chance to study Latin as early as fourth grade. But this fall, fewer kids will learn their ``amo, amas, amat's'': a tight budget has forced the layoff of six out of 26 itinerant Latin teachers. ``An awful lot of them won't even finish high school, and the only language they are exposed to is street language. This is the one opportunity they have to get a little something beyond that,''said one laid-off Latin teacher, H. Michael Dunn. Many such cuts, affecting both innovative programs and day-to-day operations, await big-city districts across the country this fall. A check by The Associated Press found that districts from Philadelphia, Boston and New York to Dade County, Fla., and Los Angeles face the worst fiscal problems since the mid-'70s. ``It's going to be tough to innovate when you're trying to survive,'' said James Fleming, associate superintendent of Dade County schools, a district that gained national notice for school reforms but now faces a $108 million deficit that will likely lead to more crowded classes. With a possible recession looming and worsening state finances putting a squeeze on school budgets, big-city school officials everywhere are bracing for teacher hiring freezes, layoffs, and larger classes. ``It's a very bleak fall,'' said Jewell Gould, research director of the American Federation of Teachers. He and others believe next spring could bring even worse news when districts customarily send out layoff notices. One leading reformer called this fall's cutbacks fresh evidence that political leaders give more lip service than resources to school improvement. ``If snow is piling up in city streets, you get a greater sense of emergency than if half the kids drop out of school year after year,'' said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. ``On the one hand, we say education is at the center of what we hope for and dream about, and we almost get maudlin about it. But then if something happens, it gets put off as `kid stuff,''' he said. ``This is easily the worst fiscal crisis I have seen in the last 20 years,'' said Fleming of Dade County. State funding fell $44 million less than expected, said Dade County school spokesman Andy Gollan. It's already meant elimination of a merit schools program where schools devised innovative programs to help students achieve educational goals. Philadelphia, anticipating deficits of $68 million for fiscal year 1991-92, $170 million in 1993, and $275 million in 1994, has put on hold reforms including full-day kindergartens, lengthening the school day and year, and more classroom computers. ``It's come to a period where we have to make hard choices, which are not necessarily popular choices,'' said Leontine D. Scott, associate superintendent. In Boston, a $397 million budget approved last week is $6.4 million lower than last year's. Cuts include 100 fewer non-tenured teachers, fewer school police, reduced extracurricular and after-school programs, less funding for a city-financed parent organization, and reductions in a private industry council that provides jobs for high-school students. The city's schoolchildren are ``treated like second-class citizens because they don't have the political clout that other communities have,'' said Boston School Committee member Peggy Davis Mullen. In Los Angeles, a $220 million budget gap earlier this year forced extensive administrative cuts. The crisis worsened last week when Gov. George Deukmejian announced he was withholding $465 million in school funds statewide, compelling the district to cut $77 million more from the 1990-91 budget. School officials haven't decided yet how to parcel out the cuts. But a number of reform ideas have already been shelved or reduced. A Bilingual Master Plan designed to help non-English speaking students in all major subject areas has been only partially funded. The district is also postponing expansion of its school-based management program in which more than 60 schools participate. ``Devastating would not be too strong a word,'' said school board member Rita Walters. ``It just socks it to us.'' New York City's school board must come up with $26.8 million in instructional cuts this fall after having already eliminated some 350 jobs at the central board. ``How that will be done is the unanswered question,'' said Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers. The district is likely to cut school aides and paraprofessionals, measures that the union fears will put more students in already-overcrowded classes. School officials insist that won't happen. Kindergarten classes currently average 24.8 pupils, and high-school classes of 40 or more are not uncommon. Seattle's $243.6 million school budget has meant eliminating 165 teaching, administrative and other positions, mainly through attrition. ``It's been a difficult time,'' said Seattle schools budget manager George Steinhofer. ``We've taken a number of reductions in central administration and this year we took reductions in special education and bilingual programs. The only place left to look is in basic educational programs.'' New Orleans is closing two of its three centers for problem students, and 60 school employees were laid off to balance the $358 million budget, said superintendent Everett Williams. ``That's been the story of our life in this school district for the past four or five years. I have had no budget that's been an even budget, where I have been able to start off the year with no cuts at all,'' he said. In Houston, Superintendent Joan Raymond is pushing for a record 18 percent tax rate hike to fund a $797.9 million budget. The proposed budget would provide a 10 percent pay raise for teachers, 31 new principals and deans, a dropout prevention program, beefed up security, a principal performance incentive program and funding of a massive construction program. But some taxpayers are resisting: ``By no extent of the imagination is the public going along with this, '' said John Pellicciotti, a board member of the Taxpayers Coalition of Greater Houston. Not all cities are in such dire straits. In Atlanta, public schools comptroller Lawrence Thompson said the district has not had cuts. Next year's budget is $331.3 million, compared with $319.3 million this past school year. ``We've been pretty fortunate,'' Thompson said. Newark, with a $421 million school budget, has an $8.5 million shortfall but has largely avoided layoffs. Some assistant principals and other administrators may be demoted to save money, said spokesman Kirk Smith. Next year, the district will get as much as $50 million in additional funds as part of a state plan to boost the quality of New Jersey city schools. But another state plan to shift teacher pension costs entirely to local districts could cancel out those gains, Smith said. In Detroit, an $889 million budget for the 1990-91 school year includes such reform initiatives as expanded preschools and special schools meant to help troubled ninth-graders avoid disciplinary problems. A 5-mill property tax increase and a bond issue approved by voters last September wiped out the district's $160 million deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Primetime Producers Discover Benefit of Merchandising Their Shows
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There's gold in them thar peaks, and Mark Frost and David Lynch are not above trying to mine it. The richly textured ``Twin Peaks,'' laden with 14 Emmy nominations and unchecked praise from TV critics, is going commercial ... as in books, tapes, records, cherry pie and coffee. Yes, executive producers Frost and Lynch, who have tended to put art above profit, want to make a bigger buck from their surreal nighttime soap opera. The way they figure it, someone is going to cash in on the cult following surrounding their saga of sex and murder (and dancing midgets and a woman who carries around a log all the time), and it might as well be them. Like their show, however, Lynch and Frost's approach is slightly off kilter. This is not your average merchandising campaign of T-shirts, hats and buttons. But, then, there is precious little that is ordinary about television advertising and marketing campaigns these days. With changing federal network regulations and an increasingly fierce battle for viewers, the landscape of TV promotions is being plowed under. CBS and NBC are launching mammoth commercial campaigns in concert with such bastions of the American middle class as K mart and McDonald's. Simon and Schuster will publish ``The Secret Diary of Laura Palmer,'' the high school homecoming queen whose murder propelled ``Twin Peaks.'' The book, written in 1{ months by Lynch's 22-year-old daughter, Jennifer, will hit the stands in time for the Sept. 30 premiere of the second season of her father's show. But that's not all. ``The Twin Peaks Tapes of Agent Cooper,'' chronicling coffee-guzzling FBI agent Dale Cooper's rambling cassette dissertations to his secretary, will hit stores at about the same time. Also in the works: a line of ``Twin Peaks'' coffee and cherry pie. And while networks and individual programs are selling themselves with an unprecedented fervor, it is for entirely different reasons. The networks want to lure viewers. Program producers want to make money. No one involved in primetime television merchandising for shows such as ``Twin Peaks'' or cartoon superstars ``The Simpsons'' would say how much they make from program products. But Playmates Toys Inc. sold $115 million last year in ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle'' items ranging from pizza to underwear. Trade estimates put last year's income from merchandise inspired by television and movies at $3 billion. In the case of ``Twin Peaks,'' ``we had some serious debate over whether we should get into the commercial aspect of merchandising,'' said Ken Scherer, chief operating officer and ``camp counselor'' of Lynch-Frost Productions. ``We figured, look, other people are doing it so we might as well do it.'' The ``other people'' Scherer was referring to are the unlicensed sellers of ``Twin Peaks'' T-shirts cropping up in Los Angeles and New York that read ``I Killed Laura Palmer'' and ``Who Shot Agent Cooper?'' Added Scherer, ``There's an awful lot of money out there for other people'' who are illegally selling ``Twin Peaks'' merchandise. When independent production companies such as his launch merchandising campaigns, Scherer said, profits are used to enhance the quality of programming. ``The money that comes back you can put on the screen,'' Scherer said. ``Independent production companies don't have the money that big networks do.'' Such producers may not have network-sized budgets, but they do, for the most part, own the licensing rights to their shows. ABC, CBS and NBC produce only a limited number of programs broadcast on their networks, thus they have been barred from merchandising specific shows. In November, that will change with the lifting of Federal Communications Commission regulations that ban networks from producing more than five hours of prime-time programming each week. When the FCC ceiling is obliterated, ABC, CBS and NBC can produce as much of primetime's 22 programming hours as they want. Television executives said the FCC rules change is likely to result in networks playing a much larger role in merchandising campaigns. Until then, however, the primary focus of the networks' marketing strategy is getting viewers to watch their programs, not selling them books, toys, key chains or coffee mugs. ``The power of advertising and television will reach thousands and thousands of more people than will ever see a `Twin Peaks' mug,'' said George Schweitzer, senior vice president of communications for CBS Broadcast Group. CBS is repeating its behemoth campaign with K mart's 2,300 stores this fall. Last year, in the biggest television contest of its kind, the eye network gave away 6 million prizes, from cars to VCRs to coffee mugs. Attention, K mart shoppers: This year, CBS has upped the ante. More cars will be given away, along with 10 million two-litre bottles of Pepsi and a grand prize of $250,000 in MasterCard funds. According to Schweitzer, last year's campaign increased fall premiere viewership by 28 percent. Players matched the numbers on game cards obtained at K mart stores with figures broadcast during certain CBS programs. The new campaign, which begins Sept. 26, is part of the network's strategy to lure money-spending baby-boomers. CBS has even signed The Temptations to sing their Motown hit ``Get Ready,'' but with eye network lyrics, in commercials promoting the fall season. Product merchandising, Schweitzer said, is lucrative for only a short time and only with giant hits such as Fox's ``The Simpsons.'' ``These things are interesting as gimmicks,'' Schweitzer said, ``but they pale in comparison to the power of a summer's worth of television commercials.'' And, Schweitzer added, networks don't have to pay for their own air time. ``Each network spends about $40 to $50 million a year'' on advertising in addition to production costs for in-house commercials promoting their shows, Schweitzer said. ``If we had to pay for air time, that would cost about $400 to $500 million.'' Next month, NBC begins a $35 million contest with McDonald's tied to its fall schedule, said John Miller, executive vice president of marketing for the network. ``We've never done anything quite this large before,'' he said. Probably because competition between the four networks, cable and video rentals has never been this intense. Nor has viewership in general ever dropped so much, according to ratings _ vehemently disputed by CBS, NBC and ABC _ from the A.C. Nielsen Co. Still, ABC has hung back from the contest route taken by its competitors. ``Ultimately, it's our philosophy that people watch the show because there's something in the show that intrinsically interests them,'' said Mark Zakarin, vice president of marketing for ABC Entertainment. ``Our fall campaign really focuses on the stars of our shows. No one watches a television show because of a singing group.'' The bottom line for network marketing strategies is that contests and advertisements help get viewers to sample a new show, but new car or no, viewers won't come back unless they like the program. ``People watch TV shows, they don't watch fall campaigns,'' Zakarin said. Meanwhile, independent and studio-produced shows continue to exploit merchandising as a way to make more money. There is a limit, however, to how far Lynch-Frost Productions will go in selling ``Twin Peaks,'' Scherer said. ``We wouldn't sell firewood,'' he said, ``because the Log Lady would never burn her log.''

DOC.HEAD: The Going Looks Tough for Many Incumbent Governors
DOC.TEXT: Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden's near-loss in a three-way Republican primary last week is the latest evidence that 1990 is turning into a mean campaign season for incumbents. Voters have lots of reasons to be dissatisfied with government _ among them the savings and loan crisis, the federal budget deficit and the weakened economy. Their discontent already is shaping some of the 36 governor's races this year. ``There's a loss of confidence in government,'' said Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton, who is having his own difficulties as he seeks a fifth term. ``There's a reserve of cynicism in the electorate for a variety of reasons,'' said Mark Gearan, director of the Democratic Governors' Association. ``There's a concern among incumbents. But every state takes on a different hue and cast.'' Hayden won renomination in Kansas by fewer than 8,000 votes and 3 percentage points, after trailing through most of a long night of vote counting Tuesday. Hayden's political troubles stemmed from changes in the property tax system that had resulted in big tax increases for many Kansans. His predecessor, former Gov. John Carlin, who shared some of the heat for tax changes dating back to his term, lost a comeback bid and the Democratic nomination by fewer than 1,800 votes to Joan Finney, veteran state treasurer. An incumbent's advantage is strong, through the ability to raise money, generate publicity and use the powers of government. Yet Kansas is hardly alone in its unease with incumbents. Next door in Nebraska, Republican Gov. Kay Orr is at the top of the GOP endangered list as she seeks a second term. She's in trouble over tax increases and her belated admission that taxes had indeed been raised. To bolster her campaign, she's hosted visits from President Bush, Barbara Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. Ronald Reagan is expected to show up, too. Another shaky Republican, Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, is considered vulnerable because of his opposition to abortion, his vacillation on taxes and general doubts about his management ability. He's presented the Democrats with an opportunity to capture the governorship of one of the largest states, and one that will be a redistricting battleground next year. Democratic governors are having difficulty, too. Clinton in Arkansas, James Blanchard in Michigan and Rudy Perpich in Minnesota all have been in office for eight years or more and face their most serious challenges yet. Nearly all the New England governors have suffered along with the region's economy. And the three Democrats _ Michael Dukakis in Massachusetts, William O'Neill in Connecticut, and Madeleine Kunin in Vermont _ all decided not to run again. Meanwhile, Republican Govs. John McKernan of Maine and Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island are trailing their Democratic challengers in the polls. DiPrete's troubles stem not only from Rhode Island's flagging economy but also from personal ethics questions. His favorability rating has been as low as 17 percent in polls. While Democrats have yet to select their nominee, DiPrete trails all three Democratic contenders in one-on-one polling tests. Michele Davis, director of the Republican Governors' Association, says she doesn't see a wave of anti-incumbent sentiment washing across the governors races. Each, she says, is a victim of individual or regional difficulties. ``I don't see it as an overarching theme or problem,'' she said. ``Each incumbent is judged by their own merits.'' Clinton, however, says President Bush's break with his read-my-lips pledge against new taxes has contributed to an eroding confidence in government at all levels. ``He said X and now he's doing Y,'' Clinton said. ``It's hurting not just him, it's hurting all of us.'' In Clinton's case and a few others, another factor may be at work: voters are just getting tired of the same names and faces. Clinton has been on the Arkansas political scene since 1974 _ and he's only 43 years old. He's been governor for 10 of the last 12 years, including three two-year terms and one four-year term that ends this year. Now seeking a fifth term, Clinton is facing a strong challenge from Republican Sheffield Nelson, himself the victor in a tough primary. Polls show Clinton ahead, but Republicans say he fails to get more than 50 percent in their polls _ giving them reason to believe he is vulnerable. Blanchard won re-election in Michigan four years ago with 68 percent of the vote, but he faces a tougher test this time. He's leading Republican John Engler, majority leader of the state Senate, but Republicans believe Engler is within striking distance. Blanchard vetoed a restrictive abortion bill this year, and abortion could emerge as a big issue in the race. To top off his problems, his ex-wife Paula Blanchard, whom he divorced while in office, has written a book about their marriage and has embarked on a promotional tour.
