DOC.HEAD: Winning Bidders Get the Applause
With BC-Home Auctions
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It looked like a television game show setup, replete with hundreds of spectators, a gavel-bashing host and a raucous band that exhorted the audience to applaud the best players. But the business at hand in the Newport Marriott Hotel wasn't a contest for winning cash, cars or washer-dryers. The players were homebuyers and investors, and the prizes were prime pieces of New England property, sold at auction by developers under pressure because of a weak real estate market. Auction day was a Saturday afternoon in late July, with about 500 people jammed into the ballroom of the hotel in this quaint waterfront town known for its swank mansions, sailboat racing and summertime jazz. Most prospective buyers already had toured the properties to be auctioned, two fancy-sounding subdivisions named Butterfly Estates and Weekapaug Bluffs in nearby Rhode Island communities. The units for sale ranged from empty lots to townhouse condos. Prospective bidders came to Newport with the plot numbers of their favorite sites in hand, hoping to win one at a fraction of the original asking price. The bar outside the ballroom didn't do much business, just a few beers and glasses of wine. Inside, a three-piece combo played while auction-goers milled about discussing the sites. After company president Steven L. Good outlined the proceedings, auctioneer Gordon Green led the group through a mock-auction as bid-spotters worked the crowd. The practice auction involved Newport mansions, and the phony bids were in the millions. Green managed to keep the crowd, for the most part quiet and reserved, laughing and interested. ``With a name like Weekapaug Bluffs, these lots have got to be good,'' he said. Weekapaug, in the coastal town of Westerly, was built in 1988 when the value of oceanfront property was rising dramatically. The units are within walking distance of two golf courses and have a view of Block Island Sound. Bidding started at $65,000 on the Weekapaug Bluffs condos, originally priced at $285,000 to $325,000. Offers shot up to $140,000 in 25 seconds. Two minutes later, the first auctioned unit sold for $142,000. The next went for $140,000, and after that prices leveled off around $138,000. Forty-five minutes into the auction, the units were being snapped up for about $131,000. To the auctioneer's left, signs representing the auctioned units were moved from the ``Available'' board to the ``Sold'' sign. After each winning bid, the band would strike up a jaunty tune as the buyer moved to the front of the ballroom, like a game-show contestant receiving a prize. The crowd clapped. After the buyer filled out the necessary paperwork and put down deposits, he was escorted to the ``mortgage rooms'' on the other side of the floor to work out details with representatives from Rhode Island's Fleet National Bank, which offered financing. Dennis and Debra Rider, of Enfield, Conn., claimed the seventh unit sold for $137,500. The Newport auction was the first for the Riders, who bought the Weekapaug Bluffs property as an investment and don't plan to move there. ``We got caught up in the excitement of it all,'' Dennis Rider said later. He ended up paying about $2,500 more than he wanted to, ``but we got the style we wanted.'' Why did they do it? ``The price and the willingness of the banks to work with us,'' he said. When the day was over, Sheldon Good & Co. had pulled in $4.6 million in total sales, said company spokesman Terrence Kaye. That included 21 condos sold at the Weekapaug Bluffs site, and 31 of 34 plots of land at Butterfly Estates. The Butterfly lots, in the town of Lincoln, originally were priced at $100,000 to $400,000, but went for $50,000 to $82,000. Some prospective buyers left disappointed they hadn't ventured any bids. ``We considered buying,'' said Cleve Elswick of Warwick, R.I., ``but it was a little bit higher than what we wanted to pay. Of course, the prices went down.'' Nonetheless, Elswick, who works in real estate, and his wife, Ruth, came away with a newfound admiration for property auctions _ mainly because there weren't any pushy real estate agents in bright blazers shoving contracts in their faces. ``Here you have total control of yourself,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Guide to Buying by Auction
With BC-Home Auctions
DOC.TEXT: Here's a general buyer's guide to real estate auctions, based on advice from experts in the field: _ Read the papers, get on a list. The Sunday newspapers are usually jammed with advertisements in real estate sections for property up for auction. Also, auctioneers can put you on their mailing lists and provide a calendar of sales. _ Get a brochure. The auction company will send you material that provides basic information on the property, such as total square footage and the latest asking price. Photos are included. _ Learn the lingo. Auctioneers have a language of their own. For instance, an ``absolute auction'' means the property will be sold to the highest bidder regardless of price, while an auction with ``reserve'' means the owner can reject even the highest bid. A good real estate lawyer or accountant can help. _ Inspect the property. Most auction companies have open houses at least a week before the auction date. If none is planned, ask for permission to see the property beforehand. In cases of multiple units up for auction find out if you'll be seeing more than just models. _ Ask questions. You'll want to know what's included in the property _ such as kitchen appliances or carpeting _ or how long any remaining tenants will be occupying a residence. At the site you'll get even more information like a sales contract, an engineer's report, floor plans or financing details. It's a good idea to have a lawyer or accountant look the deal over. _ Register. To make a bid you must register with the auction company. You should do this only after you or your lawyer have completely evaluated the property. Registered bidders will get a ``bid card'' that entitles them to participate in the auction. In addition, auctioneers require that you bring a cashier's check or money order. _ Arrive early, listen. At the day of the auction, usually held away from the property, try to arrive an hour early to ensure a seat. Listen for any announcements prior to the auction's start, such as changes in the property or terms of the auction. _ Hang on to your seats. Usually there will be a practice round of bidding to give first-time participants a feel for the auctioneer's tempo and the bidding process. When the auctioneer is ready to begin, you'll hear ``Do I have an opening bid?'' _ Be ready to pay. The highest bidders are required to sign a real estate sales contract when the bidding is concluded. Your cashier's check is taken and used as ``earnest'' money. At that time, bidders may have to increase their ``earnest'' money to the required percentage amount, usually 10 percent of the bid.

DOC.HEAD: Modern Pirates Prey on Shipping in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Piracy, the centuries-old scourge of the sea, is making a comeback in Brazil. Brazilian authorities have been unable to stop modern buccaneers who raid cargo ships and terrorize crews in ports along the southeastern coast. ``Piracy is getting worse and more violent,'' said Joao Dilermando Goncalves, chief fleet inspector of Lloyd Brasileiro, the country's largest shipping company. Pirates have attacked three Lloyd ships in Rio this year. The new pirates are different from the sneak thieves who always have plagued merchant ships, Goncalves said. ``These are highly organized gangs of up to a dozen armed men,'' he said. ``They intimidate the crew and break containers open _ real heavy assault.'' Although today's pirates use speedboats, Uzi submachine guns and radio communications, their methods have changed little from the days when buccaneers prowled the South American coast in sailing ships. A typical attack occurs at night, when most crew members are ashore. ``One of the gang tosses a grappling hook and rope over the side or climbs up the anchor chain,'' Goncalves said. ``He overpowers the duty officer and lowers the ship's ladder, just like in the old days.'' While some of the raiders hold the crew at gunpoint, others go for the cargo. They take cables, binoculars, bearings, chronometers, electronic appliances, even the ship's compass. Goods containers are a favorite target. ``They know beforehand what's inside,'' said Helcio Muniz, president of the National Union of Merchant Marine Officers. ``They only go for the containers that have valuable cargo.'' Crews are virtually helpless, Muniz said. Ship rules do not allow crewmen to carry guns, and the deck watchman the unions require also is unarmed. Piracy became a serious problem in Brazil about two years ago, said Meton Soares Jr., president of the National Union of Shipping Companies. Brazilian ports are as dangerous as Singapore, Hong Kong and Bangkok were decades ago, before economic prosperity brought improved security, he said in an interview. About 40 percent of pirate attacks in Brazil occur in Santos, Latin America's largest port, about 280 miles southwest of Rio, Soares said. Last year, 55 ships reported losses from piracy in Santos, but many others were attacked and did not bother to file complaints, he said. ``The federal police began acting with rigor there,'' Soares said, ``but piracy continues and now it has spread to Rio.'' Rio is ideal for such marauders. Ships awaiting dock space ride at anchor for days in the middle of the Guanabara Bay, miles from land, and are easy prey. Pirates gravitated to Brazil centuries ago because of its 4,593-mile coastline and many natural ports. The word ``buccaneer'' is from a French term for early pirates who used the ``boucan,'' a Brazilian grill for roasting meat. English and French pirates raided Portuguese coastal settlements in Brazil as early as the 16th century, and later attacked ships carrying gold and gemstones to Europe. They were not driven off until the 19th century. Lloyd Brasileiro has strengthened its duty watches and improved on-board lighting to combat the latest outbreak of piracy. Anchor hatches are covered and the ship's ladder is raised at dusk. Goncalves said there even was a suggestion to put left and right shoes in separate containers of export footwear to discourage pirates. But he admitted the precautions were not enough. ``The problem is the bays are not policed,'' he said. ``We need armed, uniformed naval vigilance.'' Robbery on the sea is the responsibility of federal police, but they don't have boats and patrolling harbors is difficult. ``Police don't have the equipment to act on the water,'' Soares said. ``By the time a pirate attack is reported, that's often as far as it gets.'' Vice Adm. Sergio Doherty, director of coasts and ports for the Brazilian navy, said neither the navy nor police was equipped to fight piracy. ``What we need is a Coast Guard, like the United States or Argentina,'' Doherty said. The government shelved a proposal to create a coast guard in the early 1980s. Soares said the police ``have enough problems fighting crime on land,'' and he sees little chance of curbing piracy soon.

DOC.HEAD: Piracy Threatens Some Regions, but Generally in Decline
With BC-Pirate Coast
DOC.TEXT: Piracy is a terrifying threat to defenseless refugees fleeing Indochina, but the International Maritime Bureau says it is a declining nuisance to shippers in most parts of the world. Shipping companies face greater losses from damage to cargo or injuries to crews, said bureau director Eric Ellen, but piracy remains a risk. Pirates steal yachts in the Caribbean, perhaps intending to use them for drug smuggling. Vietnamese refugees are brutally attacked in waters off Thailand and crew members on giant tankers sometimes are victims of armed robbery. Ellen said whole ships are stolen in the Philippines. ``You can steal a ship to order, put the crew overboard or take them along if you want them,'' he said in an interview. Government functionaries can be bribed to provide the ship with a new name and call sign, and ``what you develop is a phantom ship,'' Ellen said. ``These ships with new identities can pick up cargoes, and then steal the cargo. It seems incredible, in this day and age, that a ship can just disappear.'' ``If it was an aircraft,'' he said, ``every airport in the world would be alerted. There is no such system in the maritime world.'' The bureau, a branch of the International Chamber of Commerce, is trying to update a world survey on piracy completed in 1988, but finds statistics hard to come by because ``very few incidents are officially reported,'' he said. According to Ellen, a truer picture emerges from reports of the ``protection and indemnity clubs'' shippers form to insure themselves against loss. He mentioned reports he had seen of hundreds of attacks on yachts in the Caribbean, compiled by a yachting magazine. Soviet and Israeli vessels generally are well armed, but Ellen said many ships have little defense other than the captain's pistol. ``Quite honestly, we don't have a good response to vessels that are under attack,'' he said. ``There is no maritime police service that can get to you in time.'' After the Palestinian hijacking of the Italian passenger liner Achille Lauro in 1985, during which an American passenger was killed, the bureau urged seaports to install airport-style security. Only the port of London did so, and there ``is a remarkable degree of complacency'' at many others, Ellen said. The most vulnerable people at sea are refugees fleeing Southeast Asia by boat. Pirates attacked 37 boats in the first half of 1990, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees headquarters in Geneva reported. It said at least nine refugees were killed and 266 were missing. Eighty-four boats were attacked last year, with 18 people confirmed dead and 734 missing, the refugee office said.

DOC.HEAD: Entomologist Says Americans Should Eat More Bugs
DOC.TEXT: What has a nutty flavor and looks like brown scrambled eggs? Bakuti. That's Nepalese for squished honeybees. What looks like ridged french fries, only with eyes and legs, and tastes great deep-fried? Bamboo worms. Yuk, you say? How about a nice helping of honey instead? Sorry to disappoint you, but it's really bee barf. OK, so maybe you can deal with the truth about honey. But that's not all. Most Americans don't realize they're already eating a pound or two of insects every year. You just can't see them because they're ground up into tiny little chunks in your strawberry jam, peanut butter, spaghetti sauce, applesauce and frozen chopped broccoli. The insect parts even add to the protein, making some products more nutritious, said Michael Burgett, an entomologist at Oregon State University. He estimates every acre of land in Oregon contains about 100 pounds of insect protein. In tropical areas, it's about 400 pounds. Burgett bemoans the fact that most of the protein is going to waste. Except for that extra touch of tartness in the jam on your English muffin, of course. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration says there is no way to eliminate all bugs from our food, so it sets what are called ``defect action levels'' to control the amount of insect parts, rodent hairs, molds and other tiny particles that pose no health hazard. ``Essentially, the FDA is saying you can only have enough bugs so you can't see them,'' Burgett said. ``We have an innate bias against insects I blame on our European heritage. For our culture, insects are outside the realm of food. The glaring exception is honey, which is bee vomit, essentially. It's a plant product mediated by an insect.'' Burgett is an internationally recognized expert on bees. He respects bees. He is fascinated with their behavior. And, he said, they make delicious cookies. ``A pound of bees is about 3,500 bees. You put them in the oven at low heat for eight hours, then grind or blend the dry husks into flour. Makes great cookies. About half my students ate the cookies the first year I made them. Most of them said they didn't taste any different. So I cheated the second year and put in `Grape-Nuts' to make them crunchy.'' But if you really want crunchy, the giant waterbug is the appetizer of choice. Roasted and eaten whole, it's a favorite in Asia, said Burgett, who's sampled a variety of insect fare. ``You'll find that Asian cultures have incorporated insects in their diets for a long time. One of the most popular insects in Asia is the giant waterbug, which is like a big cockroach. It's easily collected around lights at night, especially around ponds.'' In Thailand, you can judge a restaurant by the bugs on the menu. ``In Thailand, about 50 species of insects are commonly eaten. That's a lot. And they're eaten by a broad spectrum of society. I've gone to very nice Thai restaurants and they have excellent insect dishes on the menu,'' Burgett said. American consumers are so finicky about bugs they'll never eat them, Burgett said. At least they won't ``mass consume'' them in the numbers needed to make bug ranching a solid commercial success. ``They've talked about using termites in the Northwest. Highly nutritious with high protein content per body weight. But who's going to eat them? ``Bee keepers in western Canada kill their bees in the fall because it's too expensive to keep them through the winter. They restock from Southern California in the spring but all those bee pupae are going to waste. The major hurdle, again, is who wants to eat it? There is a gourmet market in Japan for the male pupae of the honeybee, but that market is small.'' If people won't eat cooked bugs, no matter how tasty and nutritious, at least they could tolerate more bugs in what they do eat, Burgett said. If the FDA would relax the limit for insect parts, say double it, U.S. farmers could significantly reduce the amount of pesticides sprayed every year. ``Snap beans are a perfect example. The 12-spotted cucumber beetle takes tiny little bites out of the beans. It doesn't harm the bean but consumers want perfection. So the growers spray the beans to rid them of beetles and bite marks. When growers drive up to the food processing plant, people sample the beans and bite marks, and if the ratio is too high, the company will tell the grower, `We'll have to process this batch differently,' so the growers makes less money.'' Farmers are spraying less because pesticides costs are rising and alternate pest management strategies are working, Burgett said. Much of the spraying that remains is for appearance, and that won't change until consumers stop being so squeamish about bugs, he said. ``If you say, `I don't want any bugs in my food, and I don't want any insecticide residue,' then we'll all starve,'' Burgett said. ``I'd rather eat more insects and less pesticide residue,'' he said. Will consumers agree? Burgett is a pessimist. ``Consumer acceptance is a big problem. Fifty years ago, it wouldn't matter if an apple had a moth larva inside, or if the bean had a beetle bite. Are these people shopping for flawless apples willing to pay the price for less insecticides? I think not.'' But he has advice for environmentalists and consumers who want to reduce the pesticides in our food: ``Bug the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Gallbladder Removal Avoids Incision, Speeds Recovery ^LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons have started using a new way to remove a gallbladder: They pull it out through a hole smaller than a dime. Patients can leave the hospital in a day or less, and return to work much faster than after standard surgery, surgeons say. The new technique also saves money and hurts less, they say. Surgeons are scrambling to learn the procedure, and they may use it for a quarter of gallbladder removals by 1992 and 75 percent by 1994, Kenneth Abramowitz, a health care market analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., predicted. ``Right now, patients are flocking to the physicians'' to get the new operation, said Nashville, Tenn., surgeon Douglas Olsen, a pioneer in the technique. Gallbladder removal, used to treat gallstones, is one of the nation's most common surgical procedures, done more than 500,000 times a year. The new procedure is called a laparoscopic or endoscopic cholecystectomy. As with a regular gallbladder removal, the patient is put under general anesthesia. Standard surgery has then called for an incision of 4 to 6 inches in the abdomen, although recently some surgeons have reduced that to 2 or 3 inches, Olsen said. The new procedure avoids any such incision. Instead, the surgeon makes two quarter-inch punctures and two half-inch punctures. One hole goes in or near the navel, one below the breastbone and two below the ribcage on the right side. The surgeon slips surgical instruments into the body through sleeve-like tubes in the holes. One instrument contains a tiny video camera so the surgeon can watch his progress on a screen. Using the instruments, the surgeon grasps the bag-like gallbladder, cuts it free with a laser or electric cauterizing device, and performs other follow-up procedures. Then he pulls the gallbladder out through the navel puncture. Olsen said he usually concludes by putting a single stitch in the navel and a few absorbable stitches in the other puncture sites. Once the holes heal they resemble minor skin blemishes rather than a surgical scar, so women ``can still wear their bikinis,'' Olsen said. The surgery avoids the injury to muscle and associated tissues that comes from a standard incision, so recovery hurts less and proceeds faster, surgeons say. Rather than spending five to eight days in the hospital, most patients go home in a day or less, said Olsen. He said he does it as an outpatient procedure; some surgeons hospitalize the patient overnight. And rather than waiting four to six weeks to return to work, the average patient needs only five days to a week, Olsen said. ``I've had people go back to work the following day after their operation, and that's not unusual,'' said Olsen. ``Patients almost immediately feel their energy return'' because the body needs not spend energy on healing tissues from the standard surgical incision, said Minneapolis surgeon Leonard Schultz. ``This is a patient-led revolution in health care,'' Schultz said. Insurance companies ``are now being deluged by patients saying, `I want this operation.''' For his patients, insurance companies that require pre-surgical authorization usually grant it for the new procedure, he said. About half the nation's 74 independent Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans cover the procedure, although the national association has made no recommendation on coverage, a spokeswoman for the national association said. Some other insurance companies cover the procedure, too, said spokesman Donald White of the Health Insurance Association of America. ``It is in fact a widely accepted technology.'' He recommended that people contemplating the surgery contact their insurance companies. Schultz said the cost of hospitalization plus the surgeon fees may come to about $7,000, or about $1,000 less than for standard gallbladder removal. The faster return to work also cuts disability payments, he said. While people talk about high technology boosting health care costs, ``here technology is helping to bring down costs,'' he said. Some surgeons express cautions. Dr. Paul Ebert, director of the American College of Surgeons, said about one in 20 patients who go under anesthesia for the new surgery wake up to find that a standard procedure was done instead. That occurs when the surgeon discovers severe scarring or some other problem that rules out the new procedure. The college recommends the new procedure be done by surgeons qualified to do a standard removal. The odds of an unexpected switch to standard surgery may decline as doctors learn to identify patients with such problems ahead of time, Ebert said. He also said complications and long-term outcome from the new procedure have not been documented, though initial indications suggest they will be about the same as with the standard procedure. ``The more of these I do, the more I realize there may be certain inherent problems of this operative procedure that still need some refinement,'' Schultz said. ``I think we've made it 99 percent safe. We've got 1 percent to go.'' Dr. Charles McSherry, director of surgery at New York's Beth Israel Medical Center, recommended selecting a surgeon carefully. He acknowleged it is very difficult for patients to get first-hand information on the skills of a particular surgeon. ``As best they can, they should certainly do whatever they can to check out the individual to see that he's experienced, and see what his reputation is in the community with his surgical talents,'' McSherry said. While gallbladder removals have gotten much attention from surgeons and patients, the technique has also been applied to other operations. Gynecologists use it routinely for a number of procedures. Surgeons have also used the technique to remove the appendix. And following hernia repairs with the new technique, Schultz said, patients take a couple pain pills and go back to work in two days. ``This blows my mind,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Physicians Remove Gall Bladders Through Navel
With BC-EXP--Gallbladder Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Two days after Cyndi Newman's gallbladder was removed, she was cheering at a Little League game and lifting her toddler out of his crib. ``It's hard to believe you can have an operation and not need pain medicine,'' said the 30-year-old mother of three. Sandra Ludwig, 39, gave an engagement party and went shopping the weekend after her surgery. The message on the answering machine at her northern Virginia home says: ``Hi, this is Sandra, a modern medical miracle. I'm out venturing around.'' And Ken Beswick, a United Nations official, went shopping the day after his operation and gave a presentation in Washington two days after that. Newman, Ludwig and Beswick are among several thousand people around the country whose doctors have removed their gallbladders using a new technique called laparoscopic cholecystectomy. About 500,000 people, two-thirds of them women, have their gallbladders removed every year. Most still are removed using traditional surgery, which requires four to six days in the hospital and three to six weeks of recuperation. Traditional surgery also leaves a 4- to 6-inch scar, similar to the prominent scar President Lyndon B. Johnson displayed to the press after having his gallbladder removed at the Bethesda Naval Center in 1965. Belly-button surgery was brought to this country from France a year and a half ago by Dr. Eddie Joe Reddick of West Side Hospital in Nashville, Tenn. Physicians use thin, elongated instruments and a tiny video camera on the end of a probe to remove gallbladders through a half-inch incision in the navel. ``Ninety-eight percent of our patients are in the hospital for less than 24 hours. They're able to return to normal within three to five days,'' said Dr. Karl A. Zucker at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore. Last fall, Zucker and his colleague, Dr. Robert W. Bailey, began using an electric cauterizer, instead of an expensive laser, to seal blood vessels and veins. The technique, using a common surgical tool, popularized the operation. They estimate about 5,000 surgeons nationally have learned the new procedure. Patients marvel at how well they feel almost as soon as they wake up from the anesthesia. Ludwig, a therapist at a community health center in Springfield, Va., said she was so anxious she had called Zucker frequently during the two months before her operation. ``I woke up, all I had was these little Band-Aids.'' Beswick, 59, had his gallbladder removed at University of Maryland Medical Center on his way back to Argentina from a conference in Canada. Three days after the surgery, he gave a presentation in Washington. Five days later, the chief technical adviser in Latin America for the International Atomic Energy Agency had flown for 18 hours back to Buenos Aires without discomfort. ``It's certainly the way to have one's gallbladder removed,'' Beswick said. ``You feel a little bit tender around the navel, that's all. Stiffness more than anything. The first couple days you have to be little bit careful when you stretch and straighten up.''

DOC.HEAD: New Magazine Offers Good Eating, Eating Well
DOC.NOTE: Eds: HealthFocus cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A promising new magazine aims to combine good eating and eating well. With just its premiere issue out, Eating Well seems to have found a niche with an attractive format, brightly written stories both serious and funny and recipes that should appeal to relatively well-off people who care about their health but cringe at tofu burgers and pickled seaweed. Eating Well created ``a lot of excitement'' at the recent National Nutritional Foods Association show in Boston, said Sara M. Starr, vice president of HealthFocus, a consulting firm for the healthy foods market. Too many health magazines, she said, are ``bland, brown and boring. They don't make food fun.'' ``I think it's a good idea, and I just hope they remember that one of the biggest parts of eating well is tasting good,'' New York restaurant consultant Clark Wolf said. ``We are just recovering from the nubby, dirty health food trends of the '70s.'' Well, there is a story about yogurt, and all the recipes include the nutritional content. But with stories about designer beef, the Napa Valley, Calif., estate of vintner Robert Mondavi, and even Southern cooking, the first issue could hardly be classified as for stereotypical ``health food nuts.'' ``I am looking forward to an article on butter,'' Wolf said. Not to be found in the first issue. There is, however, the very funny story of a woman who very wrong-headedly decides to go into the chocolate business, partly to rationalize her binges. And the distressing journey of a fish from its capture off Washington state as a rockfish to its sale a week later as fresh red snapper in an Iowa supermarket. Editor Barry Estabrook, 38, became interested in food journalism when his doctor told him his cholesterol was too high. He changed his diet, but ``at the same time, I don't want to give up interesting food,'' he said from the magazine's office in Charlotte, Vt. Eating Well is published by the Canadian company Telemedia and is a sister publication to Harrowsmith Country Life. It was the result of water-cooler conversation among the staff, many of them approaching age 40, Estabrook said. ``People started to talk about cholesterol levels, their parents having heart conditions and their own children's nutrition,'' he said. ``These are people who had been talking about Club Med vacations and real estate in the '80s.'' Eating Well, Estabrook said, fits between food magazines that ``blithely pour on Devon cream'' and the health magazines that ``shoehorn a food article in if they have the space.'' ``Once the land of meat and potatoes, North America is in the midst of one of the most significant shifts in eating habits in modern history,'' Publisher James M. Lawrence writes in his introduction to the first issue. With 144 pages, Eating Well has, predicatably, advertisements for spring water, Simple Pleasures, fancy kitchen cabinets, Lean Cuisine and Land's End. Its newsstand price is $2.95, and subscriptions for six yearly issues are $12. The difficult market for magazines _ while food magazines have prospered, Cook's magazine recently folded _ has not dissuaded Eating Well's publishers, who are guaranteeing paid circulation of 225,000 the first year, Estabrook said. This may be in part a result of the audience the magazine seeks: ``well-educated people who are not going to sit around and let the woes of middle age take over them,'' he said. ``There is a real genuine interest among people in their own health. It's one of things they have control over,'' Starr said. ``You may not be able to control the economy or the environment or the new taxes we're all going to get, but you can control what you put in your body and how it makes you feel.'' Eating well, Starr said, ``is not a special interest any more.'' Said Clark, ``Let's truly eat well. Eating well used to mean fois gras and caviar. Now it's a lot more complex. ... Let's make sure the `well' means more than just cholesterol levels.''

DOC.HEAD: New Danger Found in Destruction of Tropical Forests
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have identified a new threat to the atmosphere with the discovery that the burning of tropical forests is releasing large amounts of nitrogen into the atmosphere. Tropical forest destruction has been known to contribute to the warming of the Earth's atmosphere by the release of carbon dioxide. As carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increases, the atmosphere traps more of the sun's heat, giving rise to the so-called greenhouse effect. A study reported in the current issue of the journal Nature finds that the burning of tropical forests also is releasing significant amounts of nitrogen, some of it in the form of nitrous oxide _ a potent greenhouse gas. ``Nitrous oxide put into the atmosphere by biomass burning is a greenhouse gas 250 times more powerful (molecule for molecule) than carbon dioxide,'' said Joel S. Levine of NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., in a commentary on the new study. The burning of tropical forest ``biomass'' is also releasing nitric oxide, which contributes to pollution and is the fastest growing component of acid rain, Levine said. The study was directed by Paul J. Crutzen of the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry in Mainz, West Germany.
DOC.HEAD: Nursing Home Residents Less Depressed if Expected to Do Well,
DOC.TEXT: Study Says

Nursing home residents became less depressed when their caregivers were given rosy _ but bogus _ predictions about their progress, a study says. The residents also became more dependent on help for performing day-to-day tasks, researchers said. Both changes may have occurred because the caregivers spoke more warmly to them and physically helped them more, researchers suggested in the July issue of the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society. The study focused on 63 elderly people newly admitted to six nursing homes. They were randomly assigned to a high-expectancy group or a comparison group. Nurses and aides were told that members of the first group could be expected to do better than average compared with other residents with the same sorts of problems. No such prediction was given for members of the comparison group. On average, members of the experimental group showed a decline in depressive symptoms within three months, while those in the other group showed an increase. But the high-expectancy residents became more dependent on physical help, while the other group became less dependent. Previous research has linked increased helping by caregivers to a decrease in functional abilities, the researchers said. Study authors were from Harvard University, Beth Israel Hospital in Boston and the Brockton-West Roxbury Veterans Administration Medical Center in Boston.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Aug. 13

DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: A day after reaching their highest level in nearly five years, oil prices sank under the prospects that many oil-producing nations could pump plenty of crude to prevent shortages from further Iraqi aggression in the Persian Gulf. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the cost of crude for September delivery plummeted $2.35 to settle Wednesday at $25.96 a barrel, and prices for unleaded gasoline and home heating oil also plummeted.

President Bush's call for restraint during the Mideast crisis drew immediate response from Atlantic Richfield Co. The eighth-largest U.S. oil company froze wholesale fuel prices for one week. Arco was the first oil company to respond formally to the presidential request, but other oil giants said Wednesday they already were practicing restraint and denied charges they're using Persian Gulf tensions to gouge consumers.

Power companies and car clubs endorse President Bush's plea for the public to conserve energy because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Consumers are being asked to turn down air conditioners, burn fewer lights and use the gas guzzler less. A number of utilities called Wednesday for energy savings programs to help curb oil consumption. The American Automobile Association hopes to tell its 32 million members how to cut down on gas consumption because the average price nationally for self-serve unleaded has jumped 16.2 cents a gallon in a week.

The sudden jump in oil prices may not create any abrupt increase in demand for coal, but mines may receive a needed boost if oil remains high. Coal doesn't compete directly with oil and U.S. utilities cannot quickly switch from oil to coal in power plants, John Gresser of the National Coal Association said Wednesday. But the industry is positioned well to hike production if other countries switch fuels.

Even before the Iraqi invasion, the U.S. economy was falling off, according to a Federal Reserve survey of its 12 districts. Amid fears higher energy costs could shock the soft economy into a recession, the Fed survey released Wednesday showed the economy growing but at a slow or slack pace. And the U.S. Chamber of Commerce predicted that even without higher energy costs, the economy would grind to a standstill during the current quarter and fall into recession in the fourth quarter.

Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is confident Federal Reserve policymakers meeting in two weeks will lower interest rates to prompt growth. Brady said Wednesday the oil price shocks need not topple the economy into a recession. He also said the U.S. response to the Iraqi invasion made strong growth an even greater necessity.

Sources say the New York Stock Exchange will name William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran who founded a brokerage bearing his name, as its new chairman today. Individuals familiar with exchange operations said Wednesday that the exchange planned a special board meeting to approve the selection of Donaldson to replace John J. Phelan Jr. as leader of the nation's largest stock exchange.

Employees of United Airlines have an additional two months to find financing for their $4.38 billion buyout attempt, but any thought of coming in with a lower offer is probably out. Directors of the parent UAL Corp. met into the evening Wednesday before agreeing to extend today's deadline to Oct. 9. They said the company's financial advisors would continue negotiations with the employee group, but any restructured offer must retain the shareholder value contemplated in the $201-a-share bid made in April.

More than 1,000 pages of documents detailing Donald Trump's financial rescue package remain secret while his attorneys appeal a New Jersey decision that the papers must be made public. The Casino Control Commission ruled Wednesday the release would not constitute an unwarranted invasion of Trump's private business dealings. Public interest in casino operations takes precedence over Trump's desire to keep his business affairs private, the commission ruled.
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices gained ground around the world as traders searched for bargains and expressed relief that the Persian Gulf crisis may be stabilizing. The Dow Jones industrial average recovered from six days of losses and gained 24.26 points to close at 2,734.90. Bond prices were narrowly mixed Wednesday. The dollar was down against the Japanese yen but up against the German mark, the British pound and the Swiss franc. Gold prices were mostly lower, settling down $1.30 in New York at $383.20 a troy ounce, down $1.30 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Broker Suspended for 2 years in Thayer Inside Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: A former pro football player turned stockbroker has been barred from the financial industry for at least two years because of his involvement in the Paul Thayer insider trading scandal of the early 1980s. An administrative law judge ruled in favor of the Securities and Exchange Commission against William H. Mathis, barring the account executive with Bear Stearns & Co. in Atlanta, Ga., from any dealings with SEC-registered brokerages for at least two years. Mathis, a former National Football League running back who captained the New York Jets team that won the 1969 Super Bowl, can reapply for SEC approval to return to the business after two years, as long as it is in a non-supervisory position, Administrative Law Judge Brenda P. Murray said in a 27-page decision. In 1988 Mathis settled SEC civil charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. Murray's decision came in an SEC administrative action. Mathis was not at the Bear Stearns office in Atlanta when called for comment. His lawyers in Washington also were out of the office Wednesday. But one of them, Mahlon M. Frankhauser, issued a statement through his office which said in part: ``While Mr. Mathis believes two years' suspension from the business to be absolutely unjustified in light of the fact that he did not violate the securities laws.'' Frankhauser said Mathis probably won't appeal the decision. Mathis was among a wide circle of people who bought shares in potential takeover targets between 1981 and 1983 with inside information supplied by former Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Thayer and a close friend, Dallas stockbroker Billy Bob Harris. Both Thayer and Harris pleaded guilty in 1985 to obstructing justice. They were sentenced to prison and ordered to pay a total of $1 million in penalties and restitution. Thayer was deputy defense secretary in the Reagan administration for a year beginning in January 1983. Prosecutors said that Thayer, while chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the LTV Corp. and a board member of two other companies, gave confidential corporate takeover information to Harris, who in turn, bought stock for himself and friends and passed the information on to other associates, including _ allegedly _ Mathis. Mathis was accused of tipping others about LTV's tender offer for Grumman Corp.; Anheuser-Busch's tender offer for Campbell Taggert Inc. and Allied Corp.'s tender offer for Bendix Corp. The SEC claimed he knew, or should have known, the information was confidential. Mathis' lawyers had argued before Murray that the SEC shouldn't be able to suspend him for violating securities laws simply because he settled without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board Extends Deadline to Obtain Financing in Buyout Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Employees of United Airlines have an additional two months to find financing for their $4.38 billion buyout attempt, but any thought of coming in with a lower offer is probably out. Directors of the parent UAL Corp. met into the evening Wednesday before agreeing to extend today's deadline to Oct. 9. They said the company's financial advisors would continue negotiations with the employee group, but any restructured offer must retain the shareholder value contemplated in the $201-a-share bid made in April. ``Get the $200 any way you want, but get the $200,'' commented airlines analyst Samuel Buttrick of Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York. United Employee Acquisition Corp., the company formed to buy UAL, told the directors that the Middle East crisis ``had slowed the progress of its discussions with financing sources.'' But Buttrick noted that while the economic turmoil engendered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait no doubt exacerbated the search for financing, the buyout group was having problems long before the recent events in the Middle East. ``It's obviously been a long and difficult road for the acquisition group to find adequate equity financing,'' he said. The UAL board of directors told the employee group that if it fails to find backing by the Oct. 9 deadline, the deal is off. And, the board said, ``In light of the events in the Middle East, state of the financial markets and softening economy, there can be no assurance that a transaction can be completed.'' A man who answered the telephone at the buyout group's office Wednesday evening said there would be no immediate comment on the board's actions. Before the company revealed the extension, UAL stock recovered some ground it had lost in trading during the last couple of weeks. Analysts said the rally Wednesday in UAL's stock after a plunge of 38 percent in less than two weeks stemmed mainly from a sharp drop in oil prices. UAL's stock rose $13.50 to $114.50 a share Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. In the prior seven business days, the stock tumbled from $163 to $101 amid doubts that the buyout would ever be accomplished. Much of the skepticism was prompted by the withdrawal of three large New York banks _ Chase Manhattan Corp., Chemical Banking Corp. and Citicorp _ from a five-bank group that had begun loan talks with the buyout group. The two remaining banks, Bankers Trust New York Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp., have been joined by Security Pacific Corp. of Los Angeles, said Penny Maines, a spokeswoman for the California bank.

DOC.HEAD: Bovine Boot Salesman Says Now The Shoe's On The Other Hoof
Also in Thursday AMs report.
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: By now, Jim Wells is used to the laughs evoked by his product _ cow boots. But he says the number of dairy farmers who find it the perfect answer to serious hoof problems is increasing. ``That's everybody's first reaction. It's comical to see a cow wearing a boot,'' said Wells. ``They come over, make a joke about it, then ask what the boot is for. Then I've got them.'' Wells is attending New York's Empire Farm Days in Seneca Falls to find buyers and distributors in the United States for his ``Shoes for Moos.'' Since introducing the boot last August, Wells has sold more than 15,000 at $50 apiece in eight countries, including Canada, the Soviet Union and Japan. ``The response has been unbelievable,'' said Wells, a part-time marketing instructor at Conestoga College in Elmira, Ontario, and the owner of a clothing store. Paul Larkin, a dairy farmer from Hamilton, N.Y., grinned as he looked over Well's boot recently at the New York farm trade show. He walked away with one under his arm. ``It's bad news when you have a cow with hoof rot or some other kind of foot infection. I'm always looking for the better way and this looked like one,'' Larkin said. The boot _ which looks like a shorter version of a firefighter's boot _ is made of black, fabric-backed rubber with two bright yellow straps and buckles to hold it in place. It has a textured pebble bottom for traction on slippery surfaces. It's designed to protect the injured hoofs of cows while they heal. Normally, when a cow develops hoof rot, corns, ulcers or other foot infections, the cow is given antibiotics and the foot is bandaged and wrapped with plastic bags to keep the dressing dry. ``Plastic bags, as you can imagine, aren't the best fit. Cows will rub them, chew at them or whatever until they come off,'' said Wells. ``They can't do that with the boot.'' Another benefit is that boot-clad hooves don't need to be treated with antibiotics. That saves the farmer milk, which must be thrown away while a cow is on antibiotics, and the cost of prescriptions, which can cost as much as $170, Wells said. ``It's a smart idea,'' said Everette Bridgeman, a dairy farm worker from Bergen, N.Y. ``We've used old rubbers but they don't last long. I've heard of other farmers using disposable diapers. Something that's durable and works is what farmers are looking for,'' said Bridgeman. Customers with problems like Bridgeman's gave Wells the idea for his reusable cow boot. ``Three years ago, I didn't know a thing about cows. But a couple of Mennonite farmers came into my store and bought rubber boots for their cows. After talking to them, I realized there was untapped niche there,'' he said. There are 2{ million dairy cows in Canada and 11 million in the United States. Capturing just 1 percent of those markets would mean sales of $6.5 million. To discover what a cow looks for in comfortable footwear, Wells turned to his brother-in-law, Tom Byers, a classifier with the Holstein Association of Canada. Together, they designed and tested the prototype and convinced amused officials at Kaufman Footwear in Kitchener, Ontario, to manufacture it. ``We honestly thought this was just going to be a fad item,'' said Wells, who has been traveling full time in recent months to promote his product at dairy shows throughout North America.

DOC.HEAD: Deja Vu: Americans Asked to Save Energy and Drive Less
DOC.TEXT: Shades of the Seventies. Americans are being asked to cut down their power consumption and park their gas guzzlers because a Middle East conflict has crimped the flow of Arab oil. No, there aren't any long queues at gas stations or odd-even rationing based on license plate numbers. And no one's been ordered to adjust the thermostat to a set level. But car clubs and utilities have endorsed President Bush's appeal to conserve energy after cutting off Iraq imports since its takeover of Kuwait. ``Motorists understand action needs to be taken to guarantee access to gasoline supplies, not only for their cars but for theirs jobs and employment,'' said Geoff Sundstrom, spokesman for the American Automobile Association. In a leter to the White House sent Wednesday, the AAA supported the president's Persian Gulf actions. It also re-instituted its gas watchers program, a collection of tips on cutting gas consumption first issued in the 1970s during the Arab oil embargo. AAA, which has 32 million members, said the average price of self-serve unleaded gasoline was $1.24 cents on Wednesday, an increase of almost four cents from the day before and a jump of 16.2 cents a gallon in a week. Even car-crazed California, which has an abiding love affair with the automobile, is preaching savings. ``Try to make five gallons do the work of six,'' said Tom Rohrer of the California Automobile Association. None of the conservation would be needed if Americans weren't so hooked on foreign oil. Half the country's oil _ about 8.4 million barrels a day _ is imported. The dependence was first underscored with Arab oil embargoes in 1973 and 1979. It has now hit home again. ``Americans everywhere must do their part,'' Bush said in a nationally televised speech that appealed for conservation. There were more calls and visitors than normal Wednesday at the energy conservation center set up in 1979 by Consolidated Edison Co. of New York. The office helps consumers chose the most efficient appliances and touts energy-saving flourescent light bulbs. ``You don't have to change your lifestyle, but you do have to live smarter,'' said Harold McShane of Con Ed. ``Conservation is important. We shouldn't just wait for a crisis to do something about it.'' The utility's 2.8 million customers face higher bills because the company's oil costs have jumped $5 a barrel in a week. About 30 to 40 percent of its electricity comes from burning oil. ``We've been urging conservation all along,'' said utility spokeswoman Rosalie Zuckerman. ``People can help cut their costs if they use energy wisely and don't waste.'' One consumer who visited the center said she wouldn't mind cutting back because of Iraq. ``I'm willing to sacrifice. Why should we use their oil?'' said Madi Argueta, 30, of Guttenberg, N.J. Conservation was also the word in Sacramento, Calif., despite temperatures above 100 for the second straight day. ``There's not a shortage today, just a fear of a shortage,'' said David Freeman, general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District. ``This latest Middle East conflict is a wake up call to America. We dare not fall asleep again.'' Meanwhile, the U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, which promotes the use of nuclear power, said about 5 percent of the nation's energy comes from oil, down from about 17 percent in 1973. But dependence on oil has grown nearly 40 percent in the past three years to 730,000 barrels of oil per day for electricity. ``We are far too dependent on foreign oil. It's a message we've been carrying for a long time,'' said USCEA spokesman Scott Peters. ``We definitely need a strong energy strategy at the national level to prevent this kind of thing from happening.'' Nuclear power accounts for about 19 percent of the nation's electricity.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Gasoline Prices Near Presidential Home Fuel Customer Anger
LaserPhoto AD1 of Aug. 8
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wouldn't have to travel far from his Maine retreat this weekend to get an earful about soaring gasoline prices. Talk about price-gouging and big oil's greed surrounded the pumps at the Port Mobil filling station just down the road from the First Family's seaside hideaway. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait a week ago, prices have jumped 20 cents a gallon, angering summer vacationers and townspeople in this bustling tourist haunt midway between Portland and the New Hampshire line. Craig Fraser, an attendant at Port Mobil, said some motorists aren't swayed when he tells them the station is merely passing on increases imposed by suppliers and isn't making any more money. ``You try to explain it to them and they get really frustrated with you. They get real ugly,'' Fraser said. At Port Mobil and at the high-volume Gulf stations along the Maine Turnpike, where prices were a few pennies lower, motorists had no difficulty seizing on a villain. Some accused local dealers of price-gouging, but most pinned the blame on the big oil companies. ``The oil companies have taken advantage of a perceived panic to raise the price,'' said Gary Greene of Simsbury, Conn. ``The dealers are just passing it along.'' ``I don't fault the dealer,'' agreed Gordon Feldman of Baltimore. He accused the big oil companies of profiteering as they had during previous periods of international tension that raised prices. Others questioned why prices were going up so rapidly and maintained that there is no reason to charge more for gasoline already in stock or in the pipeline. ``I think the dealers are jumping the gun,'' said Jean Cornwell of Kennebunk Beach. ``I don't see any need for prices to go up now.'' William Franklin of Baltimore, driving his family of five home from picturesque Bar Harbor in a van with a camper that gets 11 miles per gallon, reserved his wrath for Iraq. ``It upsets me,'' he said. ``We helped Iraq once, and this is the thanks we get.'' Port Mobil, less than two miles from the president's home in Kennebunkport, is frequented by the Secret Service agents and other members of the White House staff. Owner E.R. Warren Co. Inc., an oil distributor as well as a retailer, has supplied te fuel that powers the president's limousine and his speedboat as well as the diesel-powered generators at the Bush compound. While tourism appears to be down from last year in much of Maine, Kennebunk's Lower Village and Kennebunkport's Dock Square have swarmed with vacationers this summer, sampling boutiques, restaurants and art galleries made famous by their proximity to the Bush family's summer home. Tourists account for roughly half the business at Port Mobil, a two-pump station overlooking the river that separates the two towns, but manager Michael Taylor said most complaints about gas prices come from Maine natives. Tourists seem less inclined to quibble, he said. ``They're here on vacation, and if it's $2 a gallon they're going to fill it up,'' Taylor said. ``I'm the same way when I'm on vacation.'' By Wednesday, Port Mobil was charging $1.359 for regular unleaded and $1.459 and $1.559 for the higher-octane blends, an eight cent increase that day alone.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Bush Should Tap Oil Reserves to Keep Prices Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Oil industry analysts blame President Bush's reluctance to tap the nation's emergency oil stockpile after the Iraq-Kuwait crisis for much of the 15 cents more a gallon many Americans are now paying for gasoline. ``There's a real question why we should put the economy and consumers through all this pain when we have the oil available,'' said Adam Sieminski, an oil economist for Washington Analysis Corp. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait last week and other nations agreed not to buy the 4.2 million barrels they had been exporting daily, oil prices have skyrocketing faster than any time since World War II, including the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. The United States built a 590-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve for just such a rainy day _ at a cost of $20 billion to taxpayers over the past decade. Japan and most European countries also have built similar stockpiles totaling 425 million barrels. Because there are countries that can still increase oil production _ chiefly Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela _ administration officials maintain there is no oil shortage and no need to tap the reserve to drive down prices. ``There's an overhead of oil in the marketplace, thank God,'' Bush told a news conference Wednesday. ``I hope that this rapid spike in oil prices will not be permanent. ... If the world begins to see assurances that there will not be a dramatic cutdown on oil, then things will return much more to normal in the market.'' At a conference in Washington on Wednesday, Mexican Foreign Secretary Fernando Solana, announced that his country would send an additional 100,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States to help fill the 700,000-barrel-a-day gap caused by the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The Mexican commitment is scheduled to last two months. One government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there is ``evidence on the ground'' that Saudi Arabia is moving to increase its oil production along with the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela. ``But there's been no official acknowledgement of it; they're keeping quiet,'' he said. ``We'll be pushing everybody who has any additional capacity to start using it.'' Amid those reports, prices of Brent Blent and West Texas intermediate crude fell between $1.50 and $1.90 a barrel on the London and New York markets Wednesday from $27.40-$28.30 a day earlier. The prices averaged $19.40 in July. Analysts said it would take up to a month to get all that incremental oil flowing, particularly from the Saudis. The Energy Department says it can have oil flowing from the U.S. strategic reserve 16 days after a presidential decision to use it. Sieminski and other analysts estimate that it would more likely take a month. Once oil is flowing, the Energy Department can pump up to 3.5 million barrels from the U.S. reserve, which is stored in salt caverns along the Texas and Louisiana coasts. It would only take a fraction of that _ 500,000 barrels a day _ coupled with similar coordinated releases from the other world stockpiles to douse fears of shortages and the resulting speculation and hoarding, analysts said. ``If you're going to let the market handle this, you're looking at a $15 increase and prices between $30 and $35 and spikes well above that in September and October,'' Sieminski said. At those prices, he said, the use of oil throughout the world would drop by a million barrels, but it would take six months to accomplish it, risking a worldwide recession in the process. ``If September is going to be a problem, and it looks like it is, the time to make a ... decision (to tap the reserve) is now,'' he said. U.S., Japanese and European officials in charge of the government stockpiles scheduled a meeting today at the International Energy Agency in Paris to coordinate possible use of their government reserves. ``We will draw down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve _ in cooperation with our allies _ if the severity of the situation warrants it,'' said John Easton, a member of the U.S. delegation. ```Presently _ I emphasize presently _ there is not a significant shortfall of crude oil in the market.'' Philip Verleger, an oil analyst for the Institute for International Economics, argued that immediately after the invasion of Kuwait last Thursday, Bush should have announced releases of oil from the reserve and closed trading in oil on the futures market for a day. ``Doing nothing fanned the flames and drove prices up ... a tragic mistake that has cost the consumers billions of dollars,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Announces Management Realignment in Merchandise Group
DOC.TEXT: Chairman Edward A. Brennan of Sears, Roebuck and Co. apparently figures if he wants it done right, he better do it himself. Operating on this theory, Brennan replaced the head of the company's retail division and took on the added responsibilities himself. He said the flagging retail operation has to ``move faster'' than it had under Michael Bozic. Bozic was moved Wednesday from chairman and chief executive officer to president and chief operation officer for the division. There will be no change in Sears' ``everyday low pricing'' merchandising strategy, Brennan said in a statement. The strategy began 17 months ago as the company struggled to reverse a decline in profits. ``While we have complete confidence in our strategy, we need to move faster and step up its implementation,'' Brennan said. The Merchandise Group's operating income in the last quarter plunged 32 percent, to $110 million from $161.6 million. Retail revenues rose 2.2 percent to $7.9 billion from $7.7 billion, but the group continued to underperform discount competitors such as K mart and Wal-Mart. Analysts said the realignment will give Brennan more control of the retailing division and more responsibility for its success or failure. ``It certainly signifies the importance of turning around the retail group,'' said Richard Nelson, a retailing analyst with Duff and Phelps Inc., in Chicago. Brennan started his Sears career in retailing and served as the division's top officer for four years before ascending to the corporate presidency in August 1984. Leo J. Shapiro, chief executive officer of Leo J. Shapiro and Associates Inc., a Chicago-based retail research firm, said Brennan faces an enormous task. ``I can see what Sears sees in him, but given his success I don't see why he wants the job,'' Shapiro said. ``He has to make Sears live up to its promise, to be a vital growing part of retail industry,'' he said. ``Right now, it's not.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up At Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were higher at midday Thursday, helped by a strong performance on Wall Street Wednesday and an advance in the stock index futures market. A Wall Street rally a day earlier, which drove the Dow Jones industrial average up 24.26 points to 2,734.90, buoyed sentiment in London during the morning, traders said. A rally in the September Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index futures contract also spurred buying in the stock market. Dealers said trading was light with the turbulence of the Middle East keeping both institutional and private investors away from the market. Oil stocks, the only sector to benefit from the potential shortage in world oil, were hampered by profit-taking and a drop in spot crude oil prices, dealers said. At 1 p.m. in London, the FT-SE 100-share index was up 11.5 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,249.0. Volume came to 203.6 million shares at midday, compared with 258.6 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Rise in Fourth-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Sara Lee Corp. said Thursday its profit rose 15.3 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter, despite a decline in revenue and lower results from its packaged meats and bakery products businesses. The packaged food and consumer products company said it earned $118.4 million, or 48 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $102.7 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter slipped 3.3 percent to $2.95 billion from $3.06 billion a year earlier. ``Higher margins in our coffee and grocery operations combined with a continued strong profit ... in our personal products businesses more than offset lower earnings in our packaged meats and bakery line of business,'' chairman John Bryan said in a news release. The company said total bakery volume fell 3 percent. Packaged meat volume increased 5 percent but profits were down because of higher hog costs, the company said. For the fiscal year, the company reported its profit rose 14.6 percent to $470.3 million, or $1.91 a share, from $410.5 million, or $1.75 per share, in fiscal 1989. Net sales for the fiscal year fell 1 percent to $11.61 billion from $11.72 billion in fiscal 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Reworks Lures on 1990 Models
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Thursday it will offer four-year loans at 4.8 percent on selected car lines and $1,000 cash rebates on others. The low-financing rate and rebate program runs through Sept. 26, the official introduction of Ford's 1991 models. The 1991 Escort and the Ford Explorer already are in showrooms and are exempt from the incentive program. Ford will offer the 48-month financing at 4.8 percent through Ford Motor Credit. Vehicles eligible for the rate are the Ford Taurus and Thunderbird and the Lincoln Mercury-built Sable and Cougar. Most other 48-month interest rates through Ford Credit are 7.9 percent. Cash rebates on Ford and Lincoln-Mercury vehicles range from $600 on the Aerostar minivan to $2,000 on the Lincoln Mark VII.

Stock prices were modestly higher in quiet early trading today as investors assumed a wait-and-see attitude while events in the Persian Gulf unfold further. The market has a more secure foundation following the solid gains posted Wednesday. As oil prices declined, Wall Street ended a string of losses in the previous session when bargain-hunters stepped in and picked up marked-down issues. In the first half hour of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 2.48 points at 2,737.38. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchangewith 504 issues up, 428 issues down and 531 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Boardtotaled 20.6 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.21 at 185.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index advanced 0.27 at 340.30. While traders believe the presence of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia will deter further aggressive moves by Iraq, the fact that Iraq is unwilling to leave Kuwait after last week's invasion continues to cloak the market in a veil of uncertainty. ``Everyone is sitting around watchfully waiting,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, second vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. She predicted little movement in either direction. ``With a weekend coming, I don't think anyone is going to step out and try to be a hero by buying the market,'' Zagorski said. Among actively traded issues, Wal Mart was up { at 30}; Pan Am was unchanged at 2[, and Philip Morris was up { at 46[. Among energy issues, which were hard hit Wednesday, Texaco was off [ at 62| and Exxon was down ] at 51]. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average snapped a string of six straight losing sessions and advanced 24.26 to 2,734.90. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by better than 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks, with 1,015 up, 601 down and 406 unchanged. Trading activity slowed from the brisk pace of recent days. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 190.40 million shares, down from 231.58 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 1.95 to 185.40. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 340.03, up 0.19.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Turmoil May Fuel Drive for Better Auto Efficiency
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait should build support in Congress for requiring major improvements in automobile fuel efficiency, environmentalists and consumer advocates say. ``Our troops in the Middle East may have to pay the ultimate sacrifice,'' Bill Magavern of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group said Wednesday. ``Encouraging conservation through greater fuel economy is relatively painless.'' Legislation is pending in Congress to require 40 miles-per-gallon fuel efficiency by the end of the decade, up from the current standard of 27.5 mpg. Automakers, who fiercely oppose the bill, acknowledge the Middle East crisis could make their lobbying more difficult. ``We're afraid it's going to be harder to fight,'' said Charles Lockwood, general counsel of the Association of International Automobile Manufacturers. ``We fear the Senate may take action without considering all the consequences.'' The bill, sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., cleared the Senate Commerce Committee on a 14-4 vote April 3. Floor debate is expected next month. ``We have been reminded that we squandered the breathing space of the 1980s _ not using that period of low prices constructively to lessen our dependence on foreign oil,'' Bryan said. More than 50 senators support the bill and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and its aftermath may provide the 60 votes needed to halt a filibuster, Magavern said. Under current law, new car fleets _ all the cars a company manufactures in a model year _ are required to average at least 27.5 miles per gallon. The Bryan bill would require each company to boost its average 20 percent by the 1995 model year and 40 percent by 2001. The typical fleet would average 34.4 mpg in 1995 and 40.2 mpg by 2001. Supporters say higher mileage standards are needed to force the auto industry to make more fuel-efficient cars. In addition to saving oil, improved efficiency would reduce air pollution, they say. Automakers say the bill's targets are technologically unrealistic and would require drastic reductions in automobile weight. All but the smallest cars would disappear from showrooms, they warn, and many consumers would hold onto their old gas guzzlers rather than crowd the family into a subcompact. ``It's an attempt to legislate the family car out of existence,'' General Motors Corp. spokesman Bill Noack said. When the first gasoline shortages hit in the 1970s, domestic auto companies had no fuel-efficient cars to sell, Ford Motor Co. Vice President Helen Petrauskas said. Now, however, ``we have numerous small and mid-size, highly fuel-efficient cars and trucks available,'' she said. ``We could adjust production volumes to accommodate greater consumer demand.'' Automakers will watch closely to see whether the latest oil scare rekindles interest in smaller cars, Chrysler Corp. spokesman Richard Muller said. If so, manufacturers will meet the demand _ but even then the Bryan standards would not be feasible, he said. Sales trends have been toward larger cars for the past eight years, Muller said. ``This is the age of cheap gasoline,'' he said. ``It's still priced very reasonably compared to other countries.'' Adjusted for inflation, he said, gasoline actually sells for less than during the early 1970s. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner notified Congress in March that the Bush administration opposed the bill. A spokesman said developments in the Middle East had not altered that position.

DOC.HEAD: GM Ready if Iraq-Kuwait Crisis Boosts Demand for Fuel Efficiency
With PM-Fuel Efficiency
DOC.TEXT: If the Mideast crisis moves consumers toward more fuel-efficient cars, General Motors Corp. says it quickly can increase production of four-cylinder engines. ``We've got plenty of (engine-making) capacity if there is a market shift. We would be able to handle it literally overnight,'' GM President Lloyd Reuss said Wednesday during a management conference organized by the University of Michigan. Questions about fuel-efficient cars are cropping up more and more as gasoline prices rise stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But one of the company's largest dealers says fuel efficiency isn't high on consumer's preference lists. Joseph Celozzi, new car sales manager at Celozzi-Ettleson Chevrolet-Geo in Chicago, said GM shouldn't worry about making lots of four-cylinder cars. ``You try to sell a four-cylinder car and you aren't going anywhere,'' he said. ``Very seldom will I sell a car with a four-cylinder. I don't even stock a four-cylinder for a midsize.'' The auto industry still is assessing potential effects from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent rise of gasoline prices. Typically, as gas prices increase, the balance between sales of large and small cars tips in favor of smaller vehicles with better fuel efficiency. Chrysler Corp., which has the best fuel-economy rating of the Big Three, gave up the subcompact market when it stopped making its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompacts in February. Ford Motor Co. is the only one of the Big Three that makes a subcompact in the United States. But sales of its Escort have slipped to the point that the company is offering incentives on its new 1991 models. Many of GM's most fuel-efficient cars are tied up in its four-vehicle Geo line. Two of the cars are imported directly from Japan and two others are made at joint ventures in California and Canada. As an alternative to making subcompacts, Reuss said GM is ready to increase production of its four-cylinder engines for larger cars. There's a risk for automakers in increasing the percentage of small cars they sell at the expense of large-car sales _ they aren't nearly as profitable as larger cars. The Big Three were burned during the oil and gasoline supply crisis in the early 1970s, and Japanese companies got their feet in the door of the U.S. market with small, fuel-efficient cars. The U.S. auto industry has changed since then. Engine technology during the 1980s improved horsepower and fuel efficiency at the same time. Also, efficiency of exhaust emission systems has improved, resulting in better overall fuel economy. The Big Three carefully are monitoring consumer attitudes, mainly through their dealers. Business at River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth in Houston has been slow during the last few days, General Manager Alan Helfman said, possibly because of the Mideast events. ``Sales of big cars are going down,'' Helfman said. ``I had a sales increase just before this happened, and in the last few days, it's gotten quiet.''

Stock prices were marginally higher in quiet early trading today as investors focused on narrow segments of the market and assumed a wait-and-see attitude while events in the Persian Gulf unfold further. Dealers said much of the trading activity was occurring in retail and energy issues.
