DOC.HEAD: Flint Strike Could Hamper Other Plants
DOC.TEXT: Six to eight General Motors Corp. assembly plants may have to close or cut production because of a strike by 2,800 workers at a parts plant, the automaker says. The walkout Wednesday at GM's AC Rochester Division Flint West plant came after negotiations with the United Auto Workers union on employee grievances about health and safety issues broke off Wednesday morning. ``We're obviously disappointed,'' said GM President Lloyd Reuss, reached at a meeting at Traverse City. He estimated the walkout could force production cuts or shutdowns at six to eight assembly plants. ``I would expect the assembly plants to be impacted in the next two to three days,'' Reuss said, declining to identify the plants. With a typical assembly plant employing 5,000 people or more, the numbers of employees affected could be in the tens of thousands, GM spokesman John Maciarz said. The strike will affect assembly operations more quickly because of the automaker's adoption of the just-in-time parts inventory system. The just-in-time system involves manufacturing gas tanks, van doors and grilles, pickup truck grilles and other parts, and shipping them as they are needed, rather than keeping costly inventories in storage. ``There are no big warehouses out in back any more,'' Maciarz said. ``Certainly a large number of our assembly operations would be impacted, and other supplier divisions would be impacted because of not being able to send parts to assembly plants,'' he said. ``By Monday, anyway, we would begin to see an impact.'' Maciarz said GM negotiators were ready to continue talks with the union, but he didn't know when they might resume. ``Hopefully, it won't be a long strike,'' said Duane Zuckschwerdt, a UAW bargainer. Because the impact would spread rapidly to other plants and other employees, the local is under pressure not only from GM but from other UAW locals, said David Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. If a strike is a local matter and not part of a national UAW plan, he said, ``Both GM and the UAW are going to find a way to eliminate them from the game.''
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 410.08 up 2.35 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed In Cautious, Pre-Report Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade in quiet, cautious trading in advance of this afternoon's Agriculture Department crop report. Wheat futures were moderately higher, extending Wednesday's gains. Corn was fractionally lower and soybeans were up slightly. The USDA report was due out after the close and was to contain the first government estimates of 1990 U.S. corn and soybean production based on field surveys. A survey of grain analysts yielded corn production estimates ranging from 7.7 billion to 8.2 billion bushels compared with last year's 7.5 billion. Analysts estimate 1990 U.S. soybean production at 1.8 billion to 1.9 billion bushels versus last year's 1.9 billion. The USDA also is expected to revise upward its projection for the U.S. corn stockpile as of Aug. 31, 1991, due to an expected decline in Soviet grain imports during the crop year that begins Sept. 1. In early trading, wheat futures were 2\ cents to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.87} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with September at $2.51\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with September at $1.17{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3\ cents higher with August at $5.94{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after Wednesday's advance; pork futures were lower, extending Wedneday's steep losses. Live cattle were .12 cent lower to .25 cent higher with August at 78.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .30 cent higher with August at 89.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent to .52 cent lower with August at 56.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.15 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with August at 48.50 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Artist's Estate Reaches Settlement With Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Playboy can only sell two of four posters based on drawings Keith Haring had done for the magazine, and it must tell buyers they were not authorized by the late pop artist, according to an out-of-court settlement. The settlement was announced Wednesday. Haring's estate filed suit in June in U.S. District Court in Manhattan against Playboy Enterprises Inc., claiming copyright infringement and deceptive trade practices. The posters were being sold along with ``certificates of authenticity'' for up to $600, said Peter Stern, attorney for the Keith Haring Foundation. The posters are worth only about $5, he said. The estate also claimed that three of the four drawings had been ``colorized,'' at least one was altered and Haring's signature was added to two of them. Under the settlement, Chicago-based Playboy agreed to recall and cease marketing two of the posters, Stern said. The other two must bear a disclaimer stating: ``This (work) was made without the participation of Keith Haring or his Estate.'' Playboy also agreed not to issue ``certificates of authenticity'' or to use the Haring trademark or logo. The settlement did not involve any payment of money by either party, Playboy said in a news release. The Haring estate, Playboy said, agreed to stop selling and turn over to Special Editions Ltd., its inventory of Haring-designed T-shirts that was published in ``Playboy'' magazine in 1986. Special Editions is a subsidiary of Playboy Enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Posted Average 5.7 Percent July Sales Gain
DOC.TEXT: The nation's big retailers today reported mixed July results as seasonal weather and promotions to clear out summer merchandise buoyed business at several major store chains. Last month marked a continuation of a gradual slowdown in consumer spending, analysts said. With unemployment on the rise and inflation expected to flare up due to the recent oil price surge, retailers coulrlier's $2.02 billion. But on a comparable store basis, sales grew a more modest 2.2 percent. One of the standouts, as usual, was Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which posted a 21 percent increase in total July revenue to $2.4 billion from $1.98 billion. Its same-store sales grew 8 percent in July. The rapidly growing discounter is expected to challenge Sears and K mart for the No.1 ranking in terms of nationwide revenue this year. Several specialty apparel retailers also outperformed the industry. The Gap Inc., for instance, said its July sales jumped 36 percent to $114 million from $84 million last year. Sales at stores open a year or longer rose 28 percent. Among other retailers reporting today were: _Department store operator J.C. Penney Co. said its July sales rose 3.2 percent to $1.01 billion from $974 million a year earlier. Same-store sales grew 2 percent. _Dayton Hudson Corp., which owns department stores and the big Target discount chain, said its sales grew 16.4 percent to $984 million in July from $845 million a year earlier. Same-store sales were up 4.4 percent. _May Department Stores Co. said its sales grew 9.8 percent to $606.8 million from $552.7 million last year. Comparable store sales rose 4.4 percent. _Woolworth Corp., owner of numerous specialty store chains, said its domestic sales increased 8.7 percent to $389 million in July from $358 million last year. Domestic same-store sales rose 4.9 percent. _Melville Corp., which operates off-price, drug and other specialty stores, said its July sales rose 9.7 percent to $554.1 million from $505.2 million a year earlier. It didn't release results on a same-store basis. _Specialty apparel retailer Limited Inc. said its sales grew 19 percent to $348.9 million in July from $292.5 million in 1989. Same-store sales rose 6 percent.

Stock prices were drifting in subdued trading today as investors focused on narrow segments of the market and assumed a wait-and-see attitude while events continued to unfold in the Persian Gulf. Traders said much of the day's activity centered on retail and energy issues. The nation's major stores are reporting mixed July sales today, and oil stocks continue to attract attention as U.S. forces take up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia to protect the world's largest oil exporter. In addition, nervousness surrounds the Treasury's planned sale this afternoon of $10.25 billion in 30-year bonds. The auction comes on the heels of a disappointing response to Wednesday's sale of 10-year notes. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was off 2.72 points at 2,732.18 at midday. Gainers were nearly matching losers on the New York Stock Exchangewith 627 issues up, 663 issues down and 545 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Boardtotaled 71.94 million shares at noon, compared with 93.78 million shares at the same time Wednesday. While traders believe the presence of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia will deter further aggressive moves by Iraq, the fact that Iraq is unwilling to leave Kuwait after last week's invasion continues to cloak the market in a veil of uncertainty. ``Everyone is sitting around watchfully waiting,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, second vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``With a weekend coming, I don't think anyone is going to step out and try to be a hero by buying the market,'' Zagorski said. Crude oil prices were little changed. Among energy stocks, which were hard hit on Wednesday, Texaco was up | at 63]; Exxon was down \ at 51{, and Mobil was unchanged at 66]. In the retail sector, where mixed sales results were coming in for July, Wal-Mart was down \ at 30; Woolworth was up [ at 29; Limited was up 1 at 19], and J.C. Penney was down } at 52]. Among other actively traded issues, Continental Airlines, which confirmed Chairman Frank Lorenzo is resigning, jumped 2\ to 6} on the Amex. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.09 at 185.31. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index advanced 0.37 at 340.40.

DOC.HEAD: Salomon To Downsize Philipp Brothers Unit
DOC.TEXT: Salomon Inc., parent of the Wall Street house Salomon Brothers, said Thursday it will scale down the commodities trading operation of its Philipp Brothers unit. In a statement, Salomon attributed the move to ``prolonged difficult market conditions and trading losses.'' The operation that will be scaled back and repositioned within the parent company trades nonferrous and precious metals, agricultural products and other non-energy-related commodities, said Salomon spokeswoman Macy Egerton. She said she could not provide information on whether the downsizing would involve job losses or provide any other details. Salomon said in its statement that it was too early to say how much the downsizing program would cost the company, but that it was not expected to exceed $200 million before taxes. The downsizing does not involve the energy-related activities of Salomon's Philbro Energy unit or the securities traded by Salomon Brothers, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart's Quarterly Net Up 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. on Thursday reported 25 percent growth in its second-quarter profit on a 25 percent sales gain. The fast-growing discounter, based in Bentonville, Ark., earned $272.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the three months ended July 31, up from $219 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales grew to $7.54 billion in the retailer's fiscal 1990 second quarter from $6.05 billion a year before. David Glass, president and chief executive officer, credited the company's merchandising strategy for producing the profit improvement. ``Our customers continue to support our efforts to serve them with quality merchandise and service,'' he said in a news release. But he said that forecasts for the second half of the year ``are characterized by anticipated economic uncertainty.'' Wal-Mart has bucked the slowing trend in the retail industry this year and has consistently outperformed its competitors. The discounter might pass Sears, Roebuck and Co. and K mart Corp. this year in annual sales volume, industry analysts say. Sears and K mart are the nation's first- and second-ranked retailers, respectively. Also on Thursday, Wal-Mart reported its sales for July, which exceeded the gains posted by most other major general merchandise chains. Last month sales rose 21 percent to $2.4 billion from $1.98 billion a year earlier. Sales at Wal-Mart-owned stores open a year or longer rose 8 percent. For the first half of its year, Wal-Mart earned $526 million, or 46 cents a share, up 26 percent from $417 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the first half amounted to $14.31 billion, up 25 percent from $11.42 billion in 1989's first half. Wal-Mart opened two new distribution centers and completed a third during the second quarter, resulting in an addition of 3,110,620 square feet of distribution space. In the quarter, 18 new Wal-Mart stores and four Sam's Wholesale Clubs were opened. For the year, the company has opened 36 Wal-Mart stores, nine Sam's and one Hypermart USA. Wal-Mart operates in 30 states.

DOC.HEAD: VW Offers 30-Day Money Back Guarantee On Passat
DOC.TEXT: Struggling with weak sales, Volkswagen United States Inc. is offering a 30-day money back guarantee on its mid-size Passat automobiles. Anyone unsatisfied with a Passat car or station wagon in the first 30 days or 3,000 miles of ownership may return it and get their money back, Bill Young, vice president in charge of Volkswagen United States, said Wednesday. Other automakers have offered or are offering similar guarantees, although none allow a buyer to walk away with their money. Oldsmobile, for example, is offering to let buyers of its 1990 models who are not satisfied after the first 30 days or 1,500 miles of ownership return a car for credit toward the purchase of another Oldsmobile. At VW, Gelgota said, ``You get the full refund, sales tax, title and license fees and everything. It's your cash back.'' VW doesn't think it is risking its money, Gelgota said. ``It's based on our research. Ninety-seven percent of our customers are so satisfied they would recommend the Passat to a friend or relative.'' VW will purchase any returned cars from dealers, Gelgota said.

The German automaker, which holds less than 2 percent of the U.S. auto market, has been plagued with sluggish sales. The company sold an average of 1,426 Passats a month through July, compared with Volkswagen's ultimate goal of 3,000 a month.

DOC.NOTE: $adv13
For release Monday Aug. 13
DOC.HEAD: Milkman's Back, But This Time With Much More
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's just after dawn as David Whitehead maneuvers his boxy milk truck up the first driveway of the day. At the house, he grabs two half-gallons as he jumps out, drops them into the insulated box, then is off to his next stop. The thud of cartons has replaced the clatter of bottles. But otherwise, this could be a scene from the 1940s, when nearly every gallon of milk Americans drank at home was delivered to their doorsteps. His reassuring presence may not be as pervasive as it was 50 years ago, but the milkman is definitely back, in Connecticut and other parts of the country. And he's updated for the '90s with a product list that rivals any small grocery store. ``With more women working, the convenience of having the product delivered to the home is more appealing because they have better things to do with their discretionary time,'' says Michael Marcus, president of Marcus Dairy in Danbury, Conn. ``There are enough people out there who want the service,'' he said. ``It's just a matter of getting the word out.'' Nostalgia is part of the appeal. Marcus said his customers are clamoring to have their milk delivered in glass bottles, partly for ecological reasons _ they're recyclable _ but also for the memories they conjure up. His milk now comes in plastic-coated paper cartons, but he plans to bring back bottles as soon as he can find a manufacturer. For the same reason, drivers for the Palm Beach Milk Co. in Palm Beach, Fla., wear the traditional white uniform, black bow tie and white hat. Marcus drivers wear gray uniforms, sans hat. ``The old axiom of the milkman being part of the family, we're fostering that image,'' said Jacques von Spiro, who started Palm Beach Milk three months ago to cater to a growing market. In Connecticut, 25 Marcus trucks fan out across the state six days a week. The 110 stops on Whitehead's route include fancy beachfront estates, modest homes in middle-class neighborhoods and small homes in public housing projects. Orders run the gamut. One family gets a half-pint of cream delivered twice a week. Another gets practically everything Marcus Dairy offers: eight varieties of milk, orange and grapefruit juice, cottage cheese, sour cream, eggs, ice cream, yogurt, butter, bacon and plastic trash bags. Fat-free beef will soon be offered on some routes, and the dairy is negotiating with an independent grocer to deliver all groceries, Marcus said. ``If I could have all my groceries delivered, I would,'' said Patricia Carrubba, a customer on Whitehead's route who has been getting her milk and orange juice delivered for two years. Marcus charges $1.92 for a half-gallon of home-delivered milk, compared to a dollar and change in some stores. That's enough of a difference to make the milkman the ``first to go'' when a family suffers a financial crunch, said Whitehead, a beefy, bearded 42-year-old who has been with Marcus Dairy for 21 years. Business also slows down during the summer, he said. Michael Marcus, whose grandfather started the dairy in 1924, says home milk delivery started to decline during the 1950s and 1960s with the rise of the two-car family. His deliveries dropped to their lowest point around 1978, but started to rebound slowly about five years ago. Today, they account for about 9 percent of his business, or about 7,500 accounts. Marcus, whose other customers include schools, hospital and other institutions, projects growth of 1 percent a month and hopes home deliveries will account for half his business within a couple of years. Von Spiro said he researched the home delivery business for two years before starting Palm Beach Milk in May with 208 customers. He now has more than 1,000 customers, and hopes to expand in Florida and across the country. His company offers 98 products, including baked goods and smoked salmon, delivered in pre-packaged, cooler-like boxes. The milk, which comes in glass bottles, is $1.99 a half-gallon. Just 1 percent of the 3 billion gallons of milk produced nationwide is delivered to the home, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. But dairymen like Marcus and von Spiro see a growing if modest niche for the home-delivery business. ``With both husbands and wives working, there's not a lot of time,'' von Spiro said. ``They appreciate this.'' Von Spiro said his typical Palm Beach customers aren't spectacularly wealthy, but working couples between the ages of 25 and 50, most without children. In addition to yuppies, Marcus's Connecticut drivers also serve some lower-income families and elderly shut-ins who can't get to the market. For some customers, like Vera Cole with a mansion on Long Island Sound, delivery simply makes life easier. ``I find I spend less money on groceries because if I get milk and orange juice from the milkman, I don't make as many trips to the grocery store,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday, Aug. 13

DOC.HEAD: Reports 66 Percent Rise in Fourth Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit climbed 66 percent from results a year ago that were depressed by a big onetime charge. The consumer products giant said it earned $284 million, or 78 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $171 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier. P&G said its quarterly earnings would have increased 14 percent, excluding the effect of the $78 million, after-tax reserve established in June 1989 to consolidate production facilities. Worldwide net sales for the fourth quarter rose 14.4 percent to $6.22 billion from $5.43 billion a year earlier. For the year, the company said its earnings rose 32.8 percent to $1.6 billion, or $4.49 a share, from $1.2 billion, or $3.56 a share, the previous year. Worldwide net sales rose 13 percent to $24.08 billion for the year from $21.4 billion the previous year. Procter & Gamble said the earnings increase for the year was due primarily to what Chairman Edwin L. Artzt called the biggest worldwide unit volume increase the company has achieved in 32 years. P&G also said a lower corporate income tax rate and the manufacturing consolidation reserve fund contributed to the earnings increase. The growth in earnings was greater than the increase in earnings per share because of the November 1989 acquisition of Noxell Corp., a Maryland-based maker of skin care products, in exchange for P&G common stock.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Airlines Boosts Fares by 5.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines joined the list of airlines boosting their fares because of recent increases in jet fuel, announcing Thursday a 5.3 percent increase on all international and domestic fares effective Aug. 15. The announcement follows by one day the announcement of a 10 percent hike by American Airlines. Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines also have said they will raise fares to offset higher fuel prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis. Whit Hawkins, Delta's senior vice president for marketing, said that jet fuel costs have risen 10 cents a gallon since July 31. He said that the fare hike reflects only the fuel price increase. Delta says the 10-cent a gallon increase in fuel represents $200 million a year in operating expenses. Michael W. Gunn, American Airline's senior vice president for marketing, said the increase at American will go into effect Friday for flights in the continental United States, Hawaii and the Caribbean and on Aug. 15 for international flights.

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson Named Chairman Of New York Stock Exchange
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 new grafs after 6th graf pvs, Grasso's additional... to UPDATE with Donaldson comments, quote. Picks up 7th graf, Phelan, chairman...
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange today elected Wall Street veteran William H. Donaldson as chairman and chief executive officer, replacing retiring head John J. Phelan Jr. The NYSE's board also expanded President Richard A. Grasso's duties to executive vice chairman. Both appointments take effect Jan. 1. ``I don't think we could get a finer selection than Bill Donaldson,'' Phelan told a news conference. Donaldson, who first came to Wall Street 35 years ago, called the appointment ``a tremendous homecoming.'' The announcements came after a special board meeting to select a new leader for the nation's largest and the world's second largest stock exchange. Donaldson, 59, founded Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. in 1959 with two college friends one year out of Harvard Business School. He was tabbed by a nine-member search panel appointed after Phelan in February announced plans to retire at the end of the year. Grasso's additional responsibilities were described by people familiar with the selections as an inducement to keep him at the exchange. It was widely known that he had wanted the chairman's job. Donaldson praised Phelan's administration for being ``responsive to the unexpected,'' during such events as the market gyrations that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. ``As we've seen from the last few days, new challenges come from unexpected places,'' Donaldson said. He said some of the challenges facing the exchange in the 1990s will be keeping up with technological changes affecting global securities trading. ``New generations of technology will have to be deployed in support of the soundest trading concepts,'' Donaldson said. ``Innovative financial products will have to be tested for their acceptability in the marketplace as well as their technical excellence.'' Phelan, chairman since 1984, will remain a consultant for NYSE relations with foreign stock exchanges. He currently is chairman of the Association of International Stock Exchanges and has traveled extensively during his tenure cultivating ties with markets abroad. Donaldson left DLJ in the early 1970s to serve as an undersecretary of state to Henry Kissinger. He later founded Yale University's School of Organization and Management before returning to Wall Street in the early 1980s. He founded and still operates a money management and merchant banking firm, Donaldson Enterprises Inc. in 1980. Donaldson is best known on Wall Street for leading and winning a fight to overturn an NYSE ban on publicly owned securities firms. After the exchange agreed to let DLJ sell stock to the public in 1969, many securities firms followed. Donaldson takes over one of the most high-profile jobs in the securities industry at a time of increased competition from overseas markets, rapidly developing technology and controversial volatility that allegedly has undermined individual investors' confidence in the stock market. Wall Street executives said Donaldson's strong ties in Washington would help Wall Street in such fights as a Bush administration plan to tax stock transactions.

DOC.HEAD: Government Moves to Get $40.9 Million from Keating, Other
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs `Timothy Ryan ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE that restitution order is largest sought by regulators. ADDS 2 grafs with background of pvs highest order. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators moved today to get $40.9 million in restitution from Charles H. Keating Jr. and five other officers of a Phoenix holding company that owned the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The Office of Thrift Supervision also said it also wanted to remove Keating and five other officers from American Continental Corp., which owned the Irvine, Calif., thrift before its $2 billion failure last year. Timothy Ryan, director of the federal agency, called the move ``the most significant enforcement action OTS has ever undertaken.'' The restitution order is largest sought by federal regulators. The administrative action against Keating and the other American Continental officers seeks to recover $40.9 million in losses from three business deals that one official said showed ``evidence of blatant disregard for the safety and soundness of Lincoln.'' If recovered, the money would be returned to Lincoln, which was seized by federal regulators April 14, 1989. The restitution order applies to Keating and the five executives and Ryan said the agency is seeking the money from all six, either individually or as a group. Keating is already named in a $1.1 billion racketeering suit filed by the Resolution Trust Corp. charging him with fraudulently diverting depositors' money. A federal grand jury in Los Angeles is conducting a criminal investigation of Keating's financial dealings and sources say the Justice Department is investigating whether he improperly donated $1.3 million to five senators who intervened with regulators on his behalf three years ago. OTS also issued an order demanding that Keating produce in five days a detailed accounting of his own assets. Ryan said regulators don't believe Keating's repeated claims since his company filed for bankruptcy protection last year that he is broke. ``There was just too much money available to him and too short a time for it to disappear,'' Ryan told reporters at a news conference. ``We believe Mr. Keating and his associates profited from the improper use of depositors' funds and we want that money returned to Lincoln.'' The order requires Keating to identify all foreign bank accounts and assets and bars him from transferring any money overseas. It also requires Keating to give OTS two days notice before he transfers any money or assets worth more than $5,000, OTS said. The administrative action seeks to remove Keating and the top executives of American Continental from office and to bar them ``from ever serving in position in any federally insured institution,'' Ryan said. OTS also sought to remove Judy J. Wischer, president and chief executive officer of American Continental; Robert J. Kielty, a director, senior vice president and general counsel of the company; Keating's son, Charles H. Keating III, an executive vice president and director; and two of Keating's sons-in-law who are vice presidents _ Robert J. Hubbard and Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. The amount sought represents losses that regulators say Lincoln suffered as a result of three business deals involving subsidiaries of American Continental. The transactions detailed by regulators include the purchase by an American Continental subsidiary of the Hotel Ponchartrain in Detroit and its subsequent resale at an inflated price to a limited partnership that included Keating and his associates. Regulators contend that Lincoln financed the hotel purchase without sufficient underwriting and continued to pour money into the losing Detroit hotel with a line of credit that exceeded its market value. The OTS restitution order includes $4.4 million in losses from purchase of 1,000 acres of desert land 20 miles from Phoenix and its resale at inflated prices to Westcontinental Mortgage Corp. Regulators contend the sales were intended to improperly boost Lincoln's profits and allow American Continental to take tax deductions. The order also seeks recovery of $12.3 million in losses that regulators say Lincoln suffered from the misuse of an employee stock ownership plan. The plan borrowed money by Lincoln to finance the purchase of American Continental stock from Keating and others, including the five other executives named in the order. Until today, the largest restitution action was a $24 million suit filed earlier this year against Thomas Spiegel, former owner of the failed Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif. Spiegel is accused by regulators of squandering depositors' money on vacations, wine, guns and business deals with junk bond king Michael Milken.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Freezes Wholesale Fuel Prices After Bush Request
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS New grafs 4-6, The price cuts ... and Chevron, with Dole telegrams. Picks up 4th graf pvs, BP ...
DOC.TEXT: BP America Inc., Phillips Petroleum Co. and Conoco Inc. said today they were cutting their gasoline prices, while Atlantic Richfield Co. announced a one-week price freeze. Other big oil companies promised to practice price restraint amid public outcry over alleged price gouging and after President Bush asked the industry to show restraint in the face of escalating tensions in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. The companies have denied allegations that they have been using instability in the Gulf as an excuse to drive up prices at the gas pumps. Unleaded gas has risen more than 16 cents a gallon since Iraq invaded Kuwait last Thursday. The price cuts came as Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., sent telegrams to top executives of 11 oil companies on Wednesday warning of possible legislation in response to recent gasoline price increases. He urged the companies to delay any additional price increases ``until clear and convincing justifications can be presented.'' ``I can assure you that it will be very difficult to stop legislation controlling the prices of petroleum products or taxing profits resulting from these increases should no action be taken by the oil industry,'' Dole said. The telegrams were sent to chief executive officers of Amoco, Mobil, Conoco, Exxon, Shell, Texaco, BP America, Unocal, Pennzoil, Atlantic Richfield and Chevron. BP, the Cleveland-based subsidiary of British Petroleum and the 9th-largest oil company in the United States, said it was rolling back prices at the gas pumps by 3 cents per gallon. The company cited recent easing in prices in the pretroleum markets and Bush's request for restraint. No. 11 Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., said it was cutting prices at some of its gasoline terminals by as much as 4.5 cents due to market changes. Conoco, a wholly owned subsidiary of Wilmington, Del.-based Du Pont Co., said it lowered by 3 to 4 cents its wholesale prices for gasoline and by a penny its price for diesel fuel. Kevin Lindemer, an energy analyst at Cambridge Research Associaties in Cambridge, Mass., said the companies' actions were ``primarily to help consumers and wholesalers take the edge off, maybe help head off some hoarding.'' ``It takes some of the panic and fear out of the market,'' he said. ``It helps prices take a bit of a breather.'' Arco said Wednesday its freeze affects prices of gasoline, diesel and jet fuel. Arco said it was encouraging its dealers, who by federal law set their own pump prices, to avoid increases. The company said if crude oil prices continued to rise at the end of the week it would be forced to raise prices. ``Otherwise, if we remain below the market we risk a run on our stations which could drain our supply and create a panic buying situation in the marketplace,'' Arco said. Several oil companies said they backed Bush's call for restraint, but defended price hikes on the grounds that crude oil prices had increased much faster than gasoline prices in the last month. ``Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, crude prices have increased approximately 35 percent,'' Houston-based Shell Oil Co. said in a statement today. The company promised to exercise restraint but it did not lower prices, saying its increases had been about half of the national average. The industry has come under assault in recent days from politicians and consumer groups alleging price gouging. Some took to the offensive against their critics. ``Unfortunately we are in an election year and there is a temptation on the part of many of those in the political arena who, in the desire for public exposure, thrash out one more time at the oil industry,'' said Robert McClements, chairman and chief executive of Philadelphia-based Sun Co. Exxon Corp. said it would continue pricing its products ``in a responsible manner that reflects overall market supply conditions.'' The world's largest oil company said it buys 2.7 million barrels of oil daily and ``must compete on world markets and pay world market prices.'' Oil companies have been criticized frequently since gas prices soared from about 39 cents a gallon in 1973 to 53 cents a year later following the Arab oil embargo. Prices climbed to 69 cents by 1978, before surging above $1 when Iranian supplies were cut off by its 1979 revolution deposing the regime of U.S. ally the Shah. More recently, prices jumped after the Exxon Valdez spill off the Alaska coast last year and heating oil skyrocketed during a December freeze. Despite allegations, no profiteering or collusion by companies was proven. Herbert Schmertz, a senior public relations official at Mobil Corp. during the 1970s oil crises, said the companies should criticize the government for increasing reliance on foreign oil by balking at developing domestic sources. ``The finger should be pointed right back at the people who are doing the screaming,'' he said. ``They caused this problem.'' He said that in 1973, ``we treated those attacks as if they were rational attacks and we responded in a rational way. You can't deal with irrational attacks in a rational wars' funds. Concert audiences, theatergoers and visitors to museums and art galleries are being recruited as foot soldiers in the arts advocates' battle to protect the NEA from serious damage this fall when Congress debates extending the life of the $171 million federal arts agency. Congress, prompted by protests of NEA-financed projects, amended this year's agency budget to ban federal support of ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts.'' Supporters of restrictions say the issue is not censorship, as many artists contend, but taxpayers' right to decide where their money is spent. In a recent full-page ad in major newspapers, the Rev. Pat Robertson asked members of Congress, ``Do you want to face the voters in your district with the charge that you are wasting their hard-earned money to promote sodomy, child pornography and attacks on Jesus Christ?'' On the other side, pamphlets labeled ``Be Quiet and the Arts Will Just Go Away'' are being handed to theater patrons in Chicago, courtesy of the Illinois Arts Alliance. Inside are cutout post cards urging senators and House members to support the NEA, and this warning: ``A small faction of politicians and extreme right-wingers want to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts, which provides government support for artists and arts institutions in the United States. This minority is well organized and vocal. Their side is winning.'' In Baltimore, patrons of Baltimore Symphony Orchestra concerts, Center Stage plays and Maryland Art Place exhibition openings are asked to write members of Congress, sign petitions and dial a special 900 telephone number appealing for a five-year extension of the NEA, without any anti-obscenity restrictions on the grants it awards. ``It's now time for us to stand up,'' said Philip Arnoult, director of the Theater Project in Baltimore. The League of American Theaters and Producers in New York published a pro-NEA editorial in Playbills that have reached an estimated 1 million theatergoers. The Metropolitan Arts Commission in Portland, Ore., working with Mayor Bud Clark, won the endorsement of the U.S. Conference of Mayors for a letter to Congress urging no-strings support for the endowment. Besides the ``art ambulance'' and a multimedia ``Caravan for Freedom of Expression'' van that has toured Boston neighborhoods, arts supporters there have circulated a ``Declaration of Cultural Rights'' that opposes what they view as threatened government censorship of the arts. A full-page advertisement in the Boston Globe last month, featuring a once-controversial John Singer Sargent portrait of a woman with a plunging neckline, resulted in 1,000 calls urging members of Congress to support the NEA, the ad's sponsors said. An estimated 5,000 patrons of San Francisco Bay Area bookstores signed letters petitioning Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., to vote against anti-obscenity curbs on the endowment. Rodin's ``The Thinker'' was shrouded for an hour every day during a 12-day ``Festival for Freedom of Expression'' in San Francisco that was backed by more than 200 arts organizations. Bob Lynch, director of the non-profit National Association of Local Arts Agencies, said his organization's 900-number campaign has yielded an estimated 100,000 mailgrams and perhaps a half-million personal calls and letters to Capitol Hill in support of the endowment. Although the NEA's conservative critics are heavily financed, Lynch said, ``we will ultimately win because it is becoming clear that Americans recognize the value of the arts and the endowment, and are not people who respond blindly to the other side's appeals to `stop sin'.'' The House has agreed to begin debate on the arts endowment's fate in September, when it will consider Republican-led proposals to restrict the agency's grant-making authority, shift the bulk of its grant money to state control or abolish the NEA altogether. ``Time is of the essence,'' said Anne Murphy, executive director of the non-profit American Arts Alliance, a national arts advocacy coalition. ``Every individual who calls, writes or meets personally with a member of Congress really does help.''

DOC.HEAD: British Government Clears Cadbury's Acquisition of Perrier Operations
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Trade and Industry on Thursday cleared Cabdury Schweppes PLC's 125 million-pound ($34 million) acquisition of Source Perrier's non-cola soft drinks business. The department also cleared the planned merger of the home improvement operations of the retailers Boots Co. PLC and W.H. Smith Group PLC. The Perrier purchase, announced in May, includes two plants in the Paris area and another in Marseilles for various brands of Perrier subsidiary Compagnie d'Exploitation de Boissons Refraichissantes, including Oasis, Atoll, and Gini. Under a deal announced in June, Boots and W.H. Smith will each hold 50 percent of a home improvements joint venture, which is expected to operate under the trade name of W.H. Smith's ``Do It All'' chain. The combination of ``Do It All'' and Boots' ``Payless'' chain will create an operation with 230 outlets in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar edged lower today against major foreign currencies in quiet trading in Europe. Gold prices were higher. Herwig Priellip, chief trader at Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank in Frankfurt, said trading reflected ``a total lack of interest'' in currency dealings for the moment. Dealers said the dollar has some underlying support as tensions remain high about developments in the Persian Gulf where Iraq invaded Kuwait last week. But other traders expect the dollar to weaken, as the Middle East situation settles down and attention refocuses on the weakening U.S. economy and the possibility of lower U.S. interest rates. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 149.68 Japanese yen from 150.00 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 149.80 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 149.735 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8720 from $1.8660 late Wednesday. At midday in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8685. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.5915 German marks, down from 1.5940; 1.3385 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435; 5.3340 French francs, down from 5.3445; 1.7930 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7955; 1,164.75 Italian lire, down from 1,166.37, and 1.1467 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1485. Selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.5960 German marks, 1.3440 Swiss francs, 1,166.45 Italian lire and 1.14685 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to $385.25 a troy ounce, up from $382.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $385.00 an ounce, up from $384.35 late Wednesday. DOC.HEAD: President of Thrifty Corp. Resigns; 100 Stores to Shut Down
DOC.TEXT: The president of Thrifty Corp. announced his resignation and said 50 to 100 of its stores would be closed in two years. Richard G. Eils, who began his career with Thrifty 25 years ago as an industrial engineer, announced his departure after serving as chief executive since February and president for 10 years. Eils, 52, said he is leaving to pursue other interests. His replacement as president, Daniel Seigel, practiced law and had never worked in the retail industry before joining Thrifty in March as executive vice president and chief financial officer. Seigel, who began his tenure with Thrifty's parent, Pacific Enterprises, in 1974, was promoted to president of the company's alternative energy and leasing businesses before working for Thrifty. He will be in charge of Thrifty's day-to-day operations, while Leonard H. Straus remains company chairman. Thrifty's chief executive position, meanwhile, was left vacant. Company officials said they will begin interviewing candidates with executive retailing experience, but said no decision had been made on whether the job would be filled. No decision was announced on which stores will be closed. As many as 2,000 employees could be affected by the shutdowns, but officials said dismissals would be kept to a minimum by transferring workers to healthy stores. Thrifty's seven chains include Thrifty, Thrifty, Jr. and Big 5 Sporting Goods. It operates 1,070 drugstores and sporting goods shops, accounting for 29,000 of Pacific Enterprises' 40,000 employees and close to half of its revenue. Price-slashing by such competitors as the Sav-On drugstore chain have hurt the stores' business. Last year, Thrifty brought in only one-fifth of its after-tax operating income. Meanwhile Wednesday, Pacific Enterprises said it lost $229 million in the second quarter, stemming from a one-time accounting charge of $275 million. Analysts predict the loss will result in higher earnings for the energy and retailing company in future quarters.

Stock prices advanced in subdued trading today as investors focused on narrow segments of the market and assumed a wait-and-see attitude while events continued to unfold in the Persian Gulf. Traders said much of the day's activity centered on retail and energy issues. The bond sale came on the heels of a disappointing response to Wednesday's 10-year note auction. DOC.HEAD: Yield Rise on 30-Year Bonds at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose in Thursday's auction to the highest level in more than a year as the government concluded its quarterly refunding. The average yield was 8.87 percent, up from 8.84 percent at the last auction on May 10. It was the highest rate since 30-year bonds averaged 9.11 percent on May 11, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8} percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,874.70. A total of $10.3 billion in bonds were sold out of bids totaling $26 billion. The Treasury on Thursday also sold $10.1 billion in 36-day cash management bills with an average discount rate of 7.79 percent. The discount rate understates the actual return to investors: 7.96 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,922.10. The refunding included the sale of $11.5 billion in three-year notes on Tuesday and $10.5 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday. The notes and bonds are regularly sold at auctions held four times a year to replenish the government's coffers. Undersecretary Robert Glauber said the proceeds this week would refund $20 billion of privately-held notes maturing on Aug. 15 and raise approximately $12.25 billion in cash.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Soybean Futures Rally Ahead of Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and soybean futures prices rallied strongly Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a final round of jockeying for position ahead of an eagerly awaited Agriculture Department crop report. Corn futures fell slightly. John Frazier, director of agricultural trading with Gerald Inc., said the market moves reflected expectations that the government would project a larger 1990 U.S. corn crop and a smaller soybean crop than last year. A pre-report survey of grain analysts yielded corn production estimates averaging 7.92 billion bushels compared with last year's 7.53 billion. Analyst estimates for 1990 U.S. soybean production averaged 1.86 billion bushels versus last year's 1.93 billion. In the report, which was released after the close, the USDA projected corn production at 7.85 billion bushels and soybean production at 1.84 billion bushels. Both numbers were below market expectations and were expected to prompt higher openings in those markets on Friday. At the close, wheat futures were 3 cents to 6 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.90{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1} cents lower with September at $2.50{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 3 cents higher with September at $1.19{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 6\ cents higher with August at $5.98 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Shell, BP Post Sharp Profit Declines
DOC.TEXT: Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Cos. said Thursday its profit fell 44 percent in the second quarter and British Petroleum Co. PLC posted an 89 percent drop. They each cited weaker crude oil prices in the period that ended more than a month before prices rocketed higher after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Royal Dutch-Shell said its results also reflected lower margins in its chemical division and the weakness of the dollar. Royal Dutch-Shell, which is based in The Hague, the Netherlands, and in London, said its net income for the three months ended June 30 fell to 563 million pounds, or $940 million, from 1.01 billion pounds a year earlier. Revenue rose 4 percent to 16.7 billion pounds, or $27.9 billion, from 16.1 billion pounds a year earlier. ``The outlook for the rest of the year is obviously extremely uncertain and almost entirely dependent on how events in the Middle East unfold,'' Royal-Dutch Shell said. The company said its net income for the first half fell 40 percent to 1.38 billion pounds, or $2.3 billion, from 2.29 billion pounds a year ago. Revenue rose 12.8 percent to 34.2 billion pounds, or $57 billion, from 30.36 billion pounds a year earlier. London-based BP, which owns Cleveland-based Standard Oil Co., said its second-quarter net income fell to 53 million pounds, or $92 million, from 477 million pounds a year earlier. Its revenue fell 1 percent to 7.26 billion pounds, or $12.2 billion, in the quarter from 7.34 billion pounds a year earlier. For the half year, net profit plummeted to 397 million pounds, or $663 million, from 1.09 billion pounds a year earlier. Six-month revenue rose 10 percent to 15.3 billion pounds, or $25.5 billion, from 13.9 billion pounds a year earlier. The results for both companies are not directly comparable with those for American companies, since they use an accounting method that values inventories at their acquisition costs rather than at current costs. American companies generally use a method that values inventories at current costs.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Delaying Development of Luxury Car
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is delaying the introduction of a new luxury car in favor of a vehicle to succeed its compact Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim, a company executive said Thursday. ``We're going to adjust the timing of the LX,'' said Glenn Gardner, Chrysler's general manager of new platform engineering, referring to the code name for the new luxury car. The LX originally was to be introduced shortly after the so-called LH went into production. But because a successor to the Spirit-Acclaim has a potential to sell better than a luxury car and, consequently, return more profit for the investment, it was decided to push back the LX, Gardner said. He said the most pressing priority for the company is the LH, a midsize car due out in the fall of 1992 as a 1993 model, and there is some pressure in the corporation to bring the car out earlier. ``Mr. Iacocca said he wants six months (cut from the introduction schedule). I told him he can't have it,'' Gardner said, referring to company Chairman Lee Iacocca. ``He's a very persistent individual.'' The realignment comes about a year after Iacocca said a billion-dollar cost-cutting program would not alter the development plans for new vehicles. ``Our $15 billion, five-year program remains intact and we don't comment on sepecific future products that are contained in that program,'' Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said. Gardner's comments came during the fourth day of a week-long management conference sponsored by the University of Michigan. Wall Street analysts have criticized Chrysler for opting to build the Viper low-volume, high-performance sports car when the company should accelerate development of the LH midsize car. Between the introduction of the LH and the Spirit-Acclaim successor, Chrysler is expected to bring out a new subcompact car. Chrysler left the subcompact segment when it shut down the Detroit assembly plant that built the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizion last February. The Spirit-Acclaim successor will be introduced sometime around 1995, Gardner said. Those cars were introduced in the spring of 1989 and are assembled in Newark, Del. Also at the conference, Ford Motor Co. officially unveiled its 4.6-liter, V-8 engine for the 1991 Lincoln Town Car which goes into production later this year. The engine to be built at Ford's $780 million revamped engine plant in Romeo, Mich., is the first of the company's ``modular'' family of engines. Modular engines give manufacturers flexibility and cost reductions by creating common basic engine structure with interchangeable components giving each kind of engine its own characteristics. ``Overall, we estimate the new family of engines will share about 350 parts, or about 75 percent of the engine,'' said David F. Hagen, general manager of Ford's engine division. ``New V-8 variations will cost about $60 million to develop compared to about $500 million for a typical new engine program.'' He said the modular engine concept will be expanded to Ford's huge Cleveland engine plant, which will build a new series of V-6 engines to enter production in the mid-1990s. Meantime, Richard Donnelly, head of General Motors Corp.'s newly created Engine Division, said the company is moving to consolidate its engine research, development and manufacturing, which could close an engine plant sometime in the future. He did not say which factory may be affected.
The stock market moved solidly higher today in a late rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 21.29 at 2,756.19 with five minutes left to go in the session.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Delegates Assess Impact of Middle East Oil Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Emergency oil stockpiles do not yet need to be tapped to make up for an embargo against Iraq and Kuwait, delegates from industrialized nations decided Thursday. But the 21-nation International Energy Agency will take steps to ``sharpen preparedness if the situation deteriorates,'' said Chairman Ulrich Engelmann. ``We must be prepared for that.'' Concluding a daylong meeting to assess the impact of the boycott, the IEA decided enough oil exists on world markets to forestall dipping into emergency reserves. Engelmann blamed speculation for dramatic increases in oil prices, but said the higher prices should dampen demand. He predicted some OPEC members will boost production, but did not say which ones or by how much. Conservation and switches from oil-based fuels to natural gas would also help to keep stocks high, he said. The IEA is empowered to help its members survive the potentially damaging loss of loss of 4.2 million barrels of oil per day produced by Iraq and Kuwait. The members are ready to use their emergency stockpiles and to share them with each other if necessary, said a Canadian delegate on condition of anonymity. IEA members include the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and most Western European countries except France, Finland and Iceland. Oil supplies have not been affected by the boycott yet, Engelmann said, because shipments from Iraq or Kuwait to IEA countries normally take 10 days. The United Nations imposed the embargo Monday to punish Iraq's invasion of its smaller neighbor a week ago. Delegates will meet again in two weeks, when the market could begin to feel the shortfall. The IEA's two main weapons are to inject emergency stockpiles into the market, or share oil with members suffering the worst shortages. The emergency stock-sharing program is the group's ultimate weapon. It is supposed to take effect when 7 percent of projected supplies to the entire IEA or any of its members is obstructed. Once triggered, the system allots oil reserves to member countries according to a preset formula. U.S. Assistant Energy Secretary John Easton said neither measure is immediately necessary. But the United States favors putting oil from its 590 million-barrel stockpile on the market as simpler. ``We will draw down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve _ in cooperation with our allies _ if the severity of the situation warrants it,'' he said. The IEA issued a communique urging countries to refrain from ``abnormal purchases'' of petroleum. ``Companies should show restraint by avoiding abnormal spot market purchases or other undesirable purchases of oil during the period of this supply disruption,'' the statement said. Engelmann, of West Germany, said the group found no evidence oil companies had taken advantage of the invasion to boost prices. IEA Executive Director Helga Steeg said the group does not plan to deal with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on supply questions. Iran has shown interest in such talks. OPEC President Sadek Boussena said in Algeria on Wednesday that individual OPEC members should avoid breaking ranks to increase production unilaterally.

DOC.HEAD: Air Rifles Being Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Crosman Products is recalling nearly 53,000 air rifles that may have a defective trigger mechanism, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. The company is recalling its Model 3100 air rifle, which has been sold nationally since July 1986 and may contain an improperly hardened sear in its trigger. If the sear is not properly hardened, it may wear prematurely and the consumer may not be able to cock the airgun, the commission said. If the consumer does manage to cock a gun with a defective sear, it said, the rifle could discharge unexpectedly without the trigger being pulled _ even if the safety mechanism is engaged. The commission said no reports of injury or accidental discharge have been received. Crosman discovered the problem after inspecting a returned airgun that would not cock. Consumers who own Crosman Model 3100 air rifles should discontinue use and call the company toll free at 1-800-836-3100 for instructions. The line is open from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. EDT, Monday through Friday. The East Bloomfield, N.Y., company will inspect all returned rifles, replace defective sears and return the airguns at no charge.

Goldman, a vice president at St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. The market was particularly nervous about the auction, which made up the final leg of a three-part record refunding, because Wednesday's sale of 10-year notes went off poorly. Traders believe the presence of U.S. forces there will deter further aggressive moves by Iraq. But they assumed a wait-and-see attitude as Arab leaders gathered in Cairo for a high-stakes summit on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Bondholders Fail to Agree on Brewery Sale
DOC.TEXT: Bondholders in Australian businessman Alan Bond's financially troubled Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. failed to agree to the sale of the company's brewing assets, a company director said Thursday. Alan Bond said last month he would resign as chairman of Australia-based Bond Corp. if shareholders and bondholders approved the 1.85 billion Australian dollar ($1.5 billion) sale, and two other proposals. Most of the bondholders who attended a meeting in London Thursday voted in favor of the resolutions but the vote fell short of the required 75 percent, director Peter Lucas said. Holders of sterling bonds agreed to the sale of the brewing assets to Bell Resources Ltd., which is 58 percent controlled by Bond Corp., but U.S. bondholders did not, he said. U.S. bondholders are to be asked to meet Nov. 10 to vote again, he said. Both types of bondholders also failed to agree to a 12-month moratorium on bondholders' interest payments and the formation of a committee to discuss the restructuring of Bond Corp.'s debt. They will meet again on Nov. 30, Lucas said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Alleges Fraud and Manipulation in New Jersey Firm's Offering
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint Thursday alleging fraud and stock manipulation during the public offering and subsequent trading of over-the-counter securities of a New Jersey manufacturing company. The firm, Beres Industries Inc. of Lakewood, N.J., two of its officers and the president, and three traders of the now-defunct brokerage that executed the offering were named in the lawsuit filed in Newark, N.J.'s federal court. The complaint seeks more than $1 million in alleged illegal profits from Beres chairman, Charles Beres, and his son and company president, Charles Beres Jr. It also seeks unspecified profits from the brokerage employees. SEC attorney David Miller said the firm, Monmouth Investments Inc., made about $3 million through the alleged illegal practices. The SEC said Beres Sr. and Monmouth president Arden R. Brown failed to disclose to regulators an agreement in which Beres would sell 1.2 million shares of his privately held securities to Monmouth at below-market prices. The complaint further alleged that after the July 1986 public offering, Monmouth dominated the market of Beres securities through ``boiler room'' selling tactics and artificially manipulated the stock price through various schemes. Monmouth, a former member of the National Association of Securities Dealers, was based in Englishtown, N.J., and had 14 branch offices with about 10,000 customer accounts. It went out of business in March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Steady in U.S. After Tumble in Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to UPDATE with closing Dow. Picks up 3rd graf pvs ``Everyone is sitting ...'' SUBS 6th graf pvs with three new grafs to UPDATE with closing oil prices and currency figures. Picks up 9th graf pvs ``Worries that ...'' SUBS final two grafs to UPDATE dollar and long bond.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. financial markets steadied today as traders assessed the military developments in the Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks rose 24.01 to 2,758.91, buoyed mostly by a positive response to a Treasury auction. ``Everyone is sitting around watchfully waiting,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, an executive at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. She predicted little movement in either direction. ``With a weekend coming, I don't think anyone is going to step out and try to be a hero by buying the market,'' Zagorski said. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones average rebounded from six straight losing sessions to gain 24.26 points. In the oil market today, the September contract for the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil lost 29 cents to settle at $25.67 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract plummeted by $2.35 per barrel Wednesday following reports that other oil-producing countries would step up production to cover any disruption in shipments from Iraq. A barrel of North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was up 7 cents in London trading at $25.05 per barrel. Elsewhere, stock prices tumbled in Tokyo and the dollar firmed in cautious foreign exchange trading. Worries that Japan will be jolted by a disruption in oil imports discouraged Japanese investors, despite the rebound on Wall Street. Japan relies on imports for virtually all of its oil needs. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 893.41 points, or 3.13 percent, ending the day at 27,615.73, its lowest level since Oct. 25, 1987, when the key index closed at 27,421.49. Meanwhile, stock prices rolled forward in London in a recovery triggered in part by Wall Street's strength a day earlier. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 7.4 points at 2,244.9 at the close. Currency dealers in Europe said the dollar was firming in the absence of major news on the Persian Gulf. In late London dealings, the dollar was quoted at 149.80 Japanese yen, down from its earlier Tokyo close of 149.68 yen. The dollar also lost ground against the German mark in Europe, slipping to 1.5915 marks, from 1.5940 marks late Wednesday. In New York dealings, the dollar was quoted at 149.85 yen and 1.5985 marks. In the American credit markets, long-term Treasury bonds rallied on the strength of a refunding auction that attracted greater demand than expected. In late trading, 30-year issues were up about $8 per $1,000, yielding 8.75 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $6.03 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds rose by a sharp $6.03 billion in the latest week, as Middle East tensions prompted an exodus of investors from stocks and bonds, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to a new high of $401.94 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a revised $1.30 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The previous week's total also was revised, to $395.91 billion. The influx of cash came as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and subsequent tensions caused gyrations in the stock and bond markets due to speculation about the possible economic impact of events in the key oil-producing region. ``Investors moved out of stocks and bonds in light of unsettled markets and placed their money in money market funds,'' said Jacob Dreyer, vice president and chief economist at the institute. The biggest weekly rise in the funds' assets _ $9.64 billion in the week ended Oct. 21, 1987 _ came during the stock market collapse as investors sought safe havens for their money. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 249 general purpose funds rose $3.7 billion to $139.42 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds rose $946.9 million to $162.24 billion, and assets of 169 institutional funds rose $1.39 billion to $100.29 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.50 percent from 7.56 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.58 percent from 7.62 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, up from 44 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.10 percent as of Wednesday from 6.11 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.04 percent from 5.02 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.75 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.81 the previous week. Yields were 7.90 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.97 percent; 7.96 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.02 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.11 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson Named Chairman of New York Stock Exchange
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran and friend of President Bush, was named Thursday as chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange. Donaldson, 59, will succeed John J. Phelan Jr., who won wide praise for safely steering the nation's largest exchange through the 1987 stock market crash and helping to avert a protracted world financial crisis. The NYSE's board also named president Richard A. Grasso, who had wanted the top post, as executive vice chairman with expanded responsibilities. Both appointments take effect Jan. 1. Donaldson, a co-founder of the investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., brings broad experience on Wall Street, in government and academia to one of the most high-profile jobs in American business. He arrives at a time of rapid technological change, global market interdependence and increased competition overseas that threaten to redefine the basic structure of the 198-year-old exchange, a worldwide symbol of capitalism. ``This is one of the most challenging jobs in the country today,'' Donaldson told a news conference at the exchange in lower Manhattan. ``The opportunity to be here at a time of great change appeals to my spirit.'' Donaldson's first job on Wall Street was at the old brokerage G.H. Walker & Co., run by Bush's uncle Herbert Walker. Donaldson was a classmate of the president's brother, Jonathan, at Yale University and is friends with the Bush family. In 1959, just one year out of Harvard Business School, Donaldson and two friends founded Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He left in 1973 after the company grew from its initial $100,000 investment to the nation's 10th largest brokerage. Donaldson served in the Nixon and Ford administrations, first as an undersecretary of state to Henry Kissinger in 1973-74 before becoming special White House counsel to vice president Nelson Rockefeller. A Yale trustee, Donaldson in 1975 helped create a graduate business school and served as dean of Yale's School of Organization and Management until 1980, when he returned to Wall Street to open a private investment firm, Donaldson Enterprises Inc. ``He's coming from a major background,'' said Muriel Siebert, a Wall Street veteran who heads her own brokerage. ``He knows (the NYSE) from a business basis because he has headed a firm. He knows his way around Washington and politics.'' ``The combination is important,'' said Primerica Inc. President Jeffrey Lane, a board member of the competing American Stock Exchange. ``The industry needs a strong leader who can pick up the baton that John Phelan is passing. He has all the right credentials.'' Donaldson becomes the fourth full-time, paid chairman of the Big Board since the job was created in 1972. He was tabbed by a nine-member search panel appointed after Phelan in February announced plans to retire at the end of the year. Donaldson is known on Wall Street for leading and winning a fight against the NYSE to lift a ban on publicly owned securities firms. After the exchange agreed to let DLJ sell stock to the public in 1969, many securities firms followed. Donaldson said among his main concerns will be the NYSE's role in global securities trading and the ``maintenance, restoration and enhancement of public confidence in the operation of the market'' that eroded after the 1987 crash. Among other challenges, he cited new forms of electronic trading, the prospect of round-the-clock securities trading, monitoring new regulation and wild fluctuations that have shaken public confidence in the stock market. Donaldson praised Phelan's administration for being ``responsive to the unexpected,'' during such events as the market gyrations that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week. Phelan, chairman since May 1984, will remain an advisor for NYSE relations with foreign stock exchanges. He currently is chairman of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges and has traveled extensively during his tenure cultivating ties with markets abroad. Phelan, 59, said he will serve as chairman of the Aspen Institute, a policy think tank that arranges speakers on various issues, continue his work on foreign markets at the exchange and serve on corporate boards. Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the SEC looked forward to working with Donaldson. He said Phelan ``consistently demonstrated strength, wisdom and vision'' and ``helped to maintain both the integrity and the competitiveness of the U.S. securities markets.'' Grasso, 44, is a 22-year NYSE veteran. His additional responsibilities were described by people familiar with the selections as an inducement to keep him at the exchange. It was widely known he had wanted the chairman's job.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance in U.S. trading Thursday after moving mostly lower in earlier dealings abroad. Gold prices gained. Interest in the dollar as a safe investment haven waned in the absence of fresh Middle East hostility, currency dealers said. Earlier this week as outcry over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait intensified, investors scrambled to buy dollars. Investors typically turn to dollars in times of political and economic uncertainty. A retreat in oil prices from the lofty levels reached in recent days also paved the way for an end to the dollar-buying binge. World oil transactions are conducted in dollars and a rapid runup in petroleum prices had boosted demand for dollars. But on Thursday oil prices fell in the United States for a second straight session. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, edged 29 cents a barrel lower to $25.67 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The dollar also was weighed down by concerns about the U.S. economy's health. There has been widespread speculation that the Federal Reserve soon will try to revive the faltering economy by pushing down interest rates. Lower rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to curb demand for dollars. The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo where the currency fell to 149.68 Japanese yen at the close from 150.00 yen Wednesday. Later in London, it rose to 149.80 yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 149.805 yen, down from 149.90 yen late Wednesday. The dollar strengthened against the British pound in New York trading after weakening in London. A pound fetched $1.8680 late in New York, compared to $1.86885 late Wednesday. In London, sterling rose to $1.8720 from $1.8660 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.5965 German marks, up from 1.5920; 1.3435 Swiss francs, down from 1.3380; 5.3510 French francs, down from 5.3365; 1,168.50 Italian lire, up from 1,165.00; and 1.14695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14785. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, were: 1.5915 German marks, down from 1.5940; 1.3385 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435; 5.3340 French francs, down from 5.3445; 1.7930 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7955; 1,164.75 Italian lire, down from 1,166.37, and 1.1467 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1485. Precious metals prices posted scattered gains. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $385.80 a troy ounce, up $2.60 from Wednesday's settlement. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted an ounce of gold at $385.60, $2.90 higher than Wednesday's late bid. Gold rose in London to $385.25 an ounce from $382.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to $385.00 an ounce, up from $384.35 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.52 an ounce to $384.17. Silver bullion prices were flat to modestly higher. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.857 a troy ounce, up from $4.843 Wednesday. An ounce of silver was unchanged in London at $4.87.
