DOC.HEAD: Stocks Post Further Gains
DOC.TEXT: The stock market advanced Thursday as investors were encouraged by a successful Treasury auction and the absence of further negative news out of the Middle East. Stock prices seesawed in a narrow range before moving decisively upward at midday. The gains, however, were not entirely broad based. Much activity centered on retail issues, since the nation's major chain stores reported July sales, and on energy stocks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 24.01 points to close at 2,758.91. The advance builds upon Wednesday's 24-point rise, which snapped a six-session losing streak. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 837 up, 695 down and 474 unchanged. Trading was subdued. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.81 million shares, down from 190.40 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 188.04 million shares. Activity was lackluster early in the session, but nervousness mounted ahead of the Treasury's sale of $10.25 billion in 30-year bonds. Traders continued to reflect on Wednesday's auction of 10-year notes, which went very poorly. But the government received a healthy $25.96 billion in bids in the final leg of a three-part record refunding, and the yields on the bonds were lower than expected. On that, ``the the bond futures rallied and took the stock market along,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. With stock prices already depressed, Goldman said the ``conditions were there, and the bond market provided the excuse'' to buy. Looking to the Middle East, traders were relieved that hostilities did not escalate. Still, they were monitoring events as Arab leaders gathered in Cairo for a high-stakes summit on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``Everyone is still very concerned ... but the fact that there is still no blow-up over there ... gives (the Arabs) time to mend some fences,'' said William Lord, first vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers. He predicted traders will lighten up their stock holdings on Friday so they are not exposed over the weekend. In the retail sector, Wal-Mart led the Big Board actives list, rising ] to 30|. Elsewhere, K mart was down ] at 30]; Sears Roebuck was up | at 30\; J.C. Penney was down ~ at 52\, and Limited was up 1\ at 19|. Oil stocks were mixed. Texaco was up [ at 62~; Mobil was down { at 65~; Exxon was up [ at 51~ and Amoco was up { at 56}. Many major oil companies rolled back or froze their gasoline prices. Among other actively traded issues, Unitel was up 1 at 25]; General Motors slipped [ to 40~; Philip Morris gained ~ to 46{ and Boeing jumped 1{ to 54{. Leading the actives list on the Amex was Continental Airlines, which gained 1} to 6\. The carrier confirmed Chairman Frank Lorenzo was stepping down. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $18.43 billion, or 0.57 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.84 to 186.24. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.24 to 401.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.59 at 339.94. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 5.25 to 412.98. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 341.49, up 1.46.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Steadying From Iraq Shock
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices sank and stocks advanced Thursday for the second straight day in the absence of fresh shocks from the Persian Gulf. ``We're in the eye of a hurricane right now,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil trader for Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``Most people believe something else is going to happen, but we don't know what.'' Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait a week ago caused severe reactions across all financial markets as traders fretted about possible disruptions of oil shipments from the Middle East. Although those concerns persist, the movement of U.S. troops into the region to defend Saudi Arabia against a strike from Iraq have reassured many traders the past two days. In addition, other oil-producing nations have indicated they would increase production to counter a cutoff of oil from Iraq. In the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks gained 24.01 to finish at 2,758.91, extending a rebound that began with a 24.26-point jump Wednesday. In the oil market, the September contract for U.S. crude oil lost 29 cents to settle at $25.67 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract had plummeted $2.35 per barrel Wednesday. Crude oil contracts traded between $25.35 and $26.60 per barrel Thursday, which some traders described as the narrowest range in the last several trading sessions. ``There was no fresh news that would make us react,'' Beutel said. ``Everybody's playing defense right now.'' Reports during the day about the movement of Iraqi and U.S. troops caused some blips in the market, but in general, those reports were not a major concern. ``The build-up of troops is not a plus or a minus at this point,'' said Bob Baker of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``It's what takes place with oil supplies now.'' Statements aired at an emergency meeting of the 21-nation International Energy Agency in Paris further bolstered confidence about supplies. ``Presently there is not a significant shortfall of crude oil in the market,'' U.S. Assistant Energy Secretary John Easton told delegates from industrialized nations. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, the near-term contract for home heating oil dropped .36 cent to 69.77 cents per gallon. The September contract for unleaded gasoline gained .21 cent to 76.42 cents per gallon, partly on technical trading factors. Elsewhere, stock prices tumbled in Tokyo after making strong gains the previous day. Oil worries have been harder to shake in Japan, which relies on imports for virtually all of its energy needs. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 893.41 points, or 3.13 percent, ending the day at 27,615.73, its lowest level since Oct. 25, 1987, when the key index closed at 27,421.49. Stock prices made slight gains in London in a recovery triggered in part by Wall Street's rebound on Wednesday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 7.4 points at 2,244.9. In the currency markets, the dollar was mixed in New York after drifting lower in overseas trading. With the price of oil dropping, so was the demand for dollars, which are used to conduct the world's oil transactions. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 149.805 yen, down from 149.90 yen late Wednesday. The dollar fetched 1.5965 German marks, up from 1.5920. In the American credit markets, long-term Treasury bonds rallied on the strength of a surprisingly strong auction of new issues. The rally lowered spot interest rates, which helped propel the stock market's rise.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher In Latest Week
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended July 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,270.4 billion from a revised $3.270.1 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,056.8 billion from $4,056.6 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $809.8 billion from $807.8 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.1 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.0 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,269.4 billion, a 0.7 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,056.1 billion, down 0.6 percent, while M1 rose 1.8 percent to an average of $808.2 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $1.178 billion, compared with a rise of $383 million a week earlier. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $455 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $522 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $220 million in the two weeks ended Aug. 8, down from a revised $351 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $309.8 billion in the two-week period ended Aug. 8, down from $309.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Tough Guy in the Airline Business Says He's Out of There, For Now
DOC.TEXT: Airline boss Frank Lorenzo said Thursday he's quitting the flying empire he built in the 1980s, hurt by a barrage of bad publicity and labor bitterness about his tough-guy management style. The 50-year-old entrepreneur, who came to symbolize a tumultuous decade of airline deregulation, is selling most of his stake in Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. to Scandinavian Airlines System. The leading foreign carrier has held a small stake in Houston-based Continental for two years. Lorenzo also is resigning as chairman and chief executive, to be replaced by Delta Air Lines Inc. President Hollis L. Harris. Harris, a highly respected manager, was lured to Continental after a discreet search that started four months ago. Lorenzo will receive nearly $30 million in severance, retain a small interest in Continental's stock options and keep a seat on the company's board of directors. But Lorenzo's influence in running the company virtually will disappear and his compensation reflects a fraction of the value the airline operation used to have in better times. Houston-based Continental Holdings, formerly known as Texas Air Corp., once commanded 20 percent of the domestic airline market through its ownership of Continental and Eastern airlines. But its business has been severely crimped by heavy debts and a debilitating strike at Eastern that's now 17 months old. Last year the parent company lost $885.6 million, an industry record. ``It's been perfectly obvious to me that I personally have become a lightning rod for many of the attacks that the company has taken in the process of making the changes that have been required,'' Lorenzo said. ``This transaction allows me to step aside and allows the company to have a new management,'' he said. Asked what he would do now, Lorenzo said, ``Take a little time to catch my breath. I haven't had much time to do that.'' He spoke to reporters at a New York news briefing, flanked by Hollis and SAS Chairman Jan Carlzon. All three called the arrangement a strategic move that would strengthen Continental into a global airline for the 1990s. SAS, which is spending a total of $50 million in the deal, will roughly double its stake to 18.4 percent of the company's voting stock. Carlzon said SAS had no interest in gaining control of the airline. Federal law already limits foreign ownership is limited to 25 percent. ``We think Continental has an interesting future,'' Carlzon said. ``It's better to have 18.4 percent than 9.9 percent.'' Wall Street reacted positively to the announcement, reflecting investor optimism that the change would help Continental's business improve. Its stock, which traded as high as $23.75 a share over the past year but recently traded in the $4-5 range, rose $1.75 on the American Stock Exchange in active trading to $6.75. Lorenzo's exit from the airline world marks the end of an era that in many ways was shaped by him. From his initial plunge into the flying business in the 1960s as an analyst for Trans World Airlines and later as an executive of a small Texas airline company, Lorenzo helped pioneer innovations ranging from cut-rate fares to the industry's first hostile takeover. But Lorenzo aroused labor hatred because of what unions called his brutal tactics to cut employee costs, one of the biggest expenses in the industry besides fuel. Lorenzo called his strategies necessary to stay profitable in deregulated skies that allowed airlines to set their own fares and fly wherever they wished _ enormous changes in an industry unused to competition. His war with labor began after he won Continental Airlines in a takeover bid in 1981. Two years later he plunged the airline into bankruptcy court, scrapped union contracts and hired low-cost replacements for striking workers. Lorenzo's reputation among unionists worsened after he bought unprofitable Eastern Airlines in 1986. Three years later angry unions struck, accusing Lorenzo of gutting the airline. He responded by placing Eastern in bankruptcy court, but its enormous debts and enduring strike crippled the carrier and made creditors increasingly edgy. Last April an irritated federal bankruptcy judge gave control of Eastern to a trustee, which many strikers regarded as vindication. Unionists reacted to Lorenzo's announcement Thursday with a mix of satisfaction and resentment. The International Association of Machinists, which has led the Eastern strike from the start, said he was largely responsible for the problems in his company. ``Frank Lorenzo demolished Eastern Airlines, wreaked havoc on thousands of workers' lives and severely devalued Continental Airlines,'' said John Peterpaul, IAM general vice president. ``Those facts dampen our elation at seeing Lorenzo finally leaving the industry. He is the epitome of what is wrong with corporate America today. ``Our condolences to whatever industry he stalks next.''

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Prices Expected to Rise After Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain analysts predicted a rally in corn and soybean futures prices after the Agriculture Department on Thursday released harvest projections that fell short of market expectations. Soybean futures rose Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade in anticipation of the report. Wheat futures also advanced while corn retreated. On other commodity markets, gold and silver futures advanced; oil futures fell; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower. Wheat futures settled 3{ cents to 6 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.90\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 2 cents lower with September at $2.50\ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3 cents higher with September at $1.19{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 6\ cents higher with August at $5.98\ a bushel. In a report released after the close, the USDA estimated the 1990 corn harvest at 7.85 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's crop. The government projected a soybean crop of 1.84 billion bushels, down 5 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels. Both numbers were below market expectations, which averaged 7.92 billion bushels for corn and 1.86 billion bushels for soybeans. Analysts predicted corn futures would open 2 cents to 4 cents higher Friday in reaction to the report while soybeans would open 5 cents to 10 cents higher. Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc., a Chicago-based analytical firm, said soybeans would draw further support from the USDA's projected drop in U.S. soybean stockpile. The government said soybean stocks are likely to fall from an estimated 275 million bushels at the end of this month to 225 million bushels by Aug. 31, 1991, the end of the 1990-91 crop year. The latter estimate was 40 million bushels below the USDA's July projection. The government raised its projection for Aug. 31, 1991, corn stocks to 1.21 billion bushels from last month's 1.13 billion. The increase reflects expectations for a 19 million metric ton increase in Soviet Union grain production over last year and a corresponding 8 million ton drop in Soviet grain imports. ``The corn market will have to grapple with what the wheat market has been grappling with: less export demand,'' Karlin said. He said that in light of the projected decline in Soviet grain purchases and the market's recent weakness, ``I'm not so sure whether the positive implication will be able to hold over long term.'' Gold and silver futures ended higher on New York's Commodity Exchange while oil futures retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange in see-saw trading that closely followed developments in the standoff between Iraqi and U.S. troops in the Middle East. Analyst Peter Cardillo, who follows the oil and precious metal markets for Jesup, Josephthal & Co., said he believes there is a 50 percent to 60 percent chance of an Arab solution to the problem, possibly as early as Friday. But unless the Arab nations agree on a formula to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and bring down oil prices, he said the economies of the Western world will fall into a recession and severely reduce demand for Arab oil. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 29 cents to 61 cents lower with September at $25.67 a barrel; heating oil was .36 cent to 1.2 cents lower with September at 69.77 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.25 cents lower to .21 cent higher with September at 76.42 cents a gallon. Gold settled $2.40 to $2.60 higher with August at $385.80 a troy ounce; silver was 1.3 cents to 1.4 cents higher with August at $4.857 a troy ounce. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle settled .28 cent lower to .77 cent higher with August at 78.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 89.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .48 cent lower to .10 cent higher with August at 56.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.98 cents lower with August at 48.52 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Earnings Fall Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Earnings at N.V. Philips, the major Dutch electronics company, fell sharply in the second quarter, the company said Thursday. Philips said it earned the equivalent $20.6 million in the quarter ended June 30, based on Thursday's value of the Dutch guilder. That compares with a profit of $131.1 million in 1989's second quarter. Revenue for the second quarter totaled $7.55 billion, down marginally from $7.56 billion a year earlier. The results were an improvement from the first quarter, when Philips reported a profit of about $3.2 million, down from $117 million a year earlier. The drastically lower results shocked investors, leading to the resignation of Philips Chairman Cor van der Klugt and lawsuits by U.S. sharholders. In June, Philips said in a statement that its 1990 profit would be ``very low.'' At an shareholders meeting last month, Philips said it would undertake a major restructuring primarily involving its computer division, which has performed poorly.

DOC.HEAD: Schering Plough Withdraws Anti-Hypertensive Drug
DOC.TEXT: Schering-Plough Corp. announced Thursday that it was withdrawing from the market a blood pressure-reducing drug that has been linked to isolated cases of liver damage. Though the number of toxicity cases ``was quite small in relation to the number of patients using dilevalol, our decision was taken in the best interest of the potential patient population for the drug,'' Alexander Z. Lane, president of Schering-Plough Research, said in a statement. The company said it was halting the sale of dilevalol in Japan and Portugal _ the only two countries where it is sold over the counter. A pending marketing application before the federal Food and Drug Administration will be withdrawn, the company said. Company spokesman Linn Weiss said liver toxicity developed in 17 of 176,000 patients who had been taking the drug as part of worldwide clinical trials or under the care of a physician. In all but one of the 17 cases, flu-like symptoms and fatigue disappeared after the medication was discontinued, Weiss said. A Japanese man taking the drug died, but Weiss said medical experts could not link his death definitively to the anti-hypertensive drug. Sales of dilevalol in the first eight months since it was introduced overseas totalled about $20 million, the company said. Withdrawing the drug from the market will not affect Schering-Plough's financial performance or its projected earnings per share this year, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Workers, Investors Encouraged by Buyout Extension
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines workers and stock market investors indicated Thursday they were encouraged by a decision extending the life of an employee buyout bid. But the two-month reprieve granted late Wednesday by UAL Corp., United's parent company, offered no guarantee that the $4.38 billion, $201-per-share deal will get done. Indeed, there is some concern that a provision allowing UAL's board to call off the deal at any time could hamper the buyout group's ability to obtain financing commitments by the new Oct. 9 deadline. Steven Matthews, a spokesman for the union-led buyout group, declined comment Thursday on that possibility. He said the group was ``going forward'' and hoped to arrange financing commitments as quickly as possible. Matthews also declined comment on a Wall Street Journal report that the buyout group had requested a three-month extension. UAL stock initially rose on the New York Stock Exchange, trading as high as $123, but it closed at $113.75, down 75 cents. Without the deadline extension, the bid to make United the world's largest employee-owned company would have expired Thursday. The buyout group blamed its failure to line up loan commitments on the Middle East crisis, which it said had ``slowed the progress of its discussions with financing sources,'' according to a statement issued Wednesday by UAL. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last week has caused airline fuel prices to soar and airline stock prices to drop, presumably making United a greater credit risk. Airline analyst Robert Decker of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago, said the Middle East situation ``provides a convenient alibi.'' ``It certainly is a factor,'' he said. ``But the way events were unfolding, it didn't seem the group would have financing arranged by the deadline anyway.'' Decker said the extension gives the buyout group more time to either find financing or restructure its proposal, perhaps to reduce the $155-per-share cash component of the offer. UAL indicated, though, that it would not accept a lower total bid. Skepticism about the buyout mounted in recent weeks after three large New York banks _ Chase Manhattan Corp., Chemical Banking Corp. and Citicorp _ withdrew from a group of banks that had begun loan talks with the buyout group. The banks indicated they might be willing to make the loans if the buyout group obtains other financing from non-bank sources. The group reportedly is negotiating with a number of aircraft manufacturers and parts suppliers for such financing. At least three other banks _ Bankers Trust New York Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp. and Security Pacific Corp. _ are continuing to discuss loan possibilities with the buyout group.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union, Employees No Closer On Contract Agreement; Reports Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Officials representing 2,500 union workers at Western Union Corp. on Thursday said they have rejected the company's proposal to extend an expired contract by 90 days. Union employees have been working under the terms of the two-year contract since it expired Aug. 6. Union members have authorized their leadership to call a strike, but a settlement deadline has not been set, Dan J. Beckstead, president of the Communications Workers of America-United Telegraph Workers Bargaining Council, said. Warren Bechtel, a spokesman for Upper Saddle River-based Western Union, said more than 1,000 workers have been trained to replace striking union workers. Bechtel has been close-mouthed on the substance of the talks, but Beckstead said Western Union has given ground on two crucial issues, while maintaining a firm stand on its attempt to cut medical costs by putting union workers' medical benefits on par with those offered to non-union employees. The two sides have been negotiating this week at a hotel in Virginia Beach, Va. The CWA represents operators, customer relations clerks, other clerical workers and field technicians that work for Western Union nationwide, Beckstead said. Meanwhile Thursday, the company said it lost $27.6 million, or 44 cents a share, on revenues of $146 million in the second quarter. The company lost $4.9 million, or 40 cents a share, on revenue of $158 million in the second quarter of 1989. Western Union said the loss in the April-June period of this year was due at least partly to costs incurred with the firm's proposed recapitalization plan. Total revenues for the first six months of 1990 were $291 million, down 8 percent from revenues of $316 million for the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Accused of Selling Inside Information About Corporate Clients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, They are ..., to show Jeffer Management also named; SUBS 14th graf pvs, Smith, Jeffers ..., to CORRECT second reference to Jeffer.
DOC.TEXT: An attorney formerly with a prestigious corporate law firm was accused Thursday of selling inside information about planned takeovers in a multimillion-dollar trading scheme. The lawyer, Steven L. Glauberman, was charged with four counts of conspiracy, securities fraud and wire fraud in a criminal information brought by the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan. Glauberman, 39, of Manhattan, was an associate at the firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he specialized in mergers and acquisitions. The government alleged he leaked inside information about clients involved in some of the best-known takeovers of the 1980s to a stock broker, who passed it along to others. Glauberman simultaneously settled a civil complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission, agreeing to pay back $221,000 in his alleged illegal profits. The SEC said he tipped off Eban Smith, a former broker-dealer at the Stamford, Conn., office of Smith Barney & Co., to 29 planned or pending corporate transactions between 1984 and 1989. These included Bristol Meyers' 1985 bid for Genetic Systems, a management leveraged buyout of National Gypsum, also in 1985, Black and Decker's 1988 unsolicited bid for American Standard, Walt Disney Co.'s offer for Gibson Greetings, and K mart's bid for Payless Drugstore Stores Northwest Inc. The SEC said Smith paid Glauberman $50,000 for the information and also traded in a special account for Glauberman's benefit. Glauberman's attorney, Martin Perschetz, said he had no comment on behalf of his client. Smith, 41, of Greenwich, Conn., was charged in a separate criminal indictment with using the information he obtained from Glauberman to buy and sell securities for his own account and to solicit more business for his firm. In addition, two other investors who allegedly were tipped off by Smith were charged criminally with making trades based on the information from Glauberman. They are Peter H. Jeffer, 44, a Manhattan money manager, and Stanley P. Patrick, 43, of Old Lyme, Conn., a former stock trader. Jeffer Management Corp., a New York corporation created by Jeffer that stopped doing business in 1988, was also named in the indictment. Court papers said Smith, Jeffer and Patrick earned a total $3.75 million in illegal profits through the trades. The SEC said Smith's portion of profits was more than $1.1 million. Smith, Jeffer and Patrick also were named in the SEC civil complaint. Jeffer settled, but Smith and Patrick did not, meaning the commission is still trying to recover their alleged profits in the scheme. In addition, Glauberman's sister Lori, an associate director in the preferred stock department of Bear Stearns & Co., was accused by the SEC of trading in the securities of at least 11 of the deals. According to the SEC, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Glauberman agreed to disgorge $221,098; his sister, Lori, 36, agreed to disgorge $19,135.
